HEADLINE: On Camera Again, After 7 Years;
Documentary's Subjects Now Speak Out as Teen-Agers

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Lucy, voluble as always, is at boarding school these days; the pressure to become a Princetonian seems irresistible. Alexis is pretty serious about becoming a marine biologist. And Luis, no longer homeless but charismatic as ever, has left the Latin Kings gang in Milwaukee but will soon star as a gang member onstage in a Victory Memorial Church production.
They are seven years older now, and they're back. That demographically correct band who became America's darlings in 1991 has returned in a second installment of the documentary series that is following the lives of 16 children from age 7 through adulthood. It will be broadcast for 90 minutes as "14 Up in America" on Sunday night on Showtime. 
"This series has no beginning, middle or end," said Phil Joanou, the director. "I like that the project lacks inherent dramatic structure. It's just life. The drama is in how all these lives will turn out."
The American series is based, of course, on the groundbreaking British documentary that has tracked 14 English children for the last 35 years as they have segued through school, college, jobs, marriage, children, success, failure, euphoria and agita.
It is "a unique longitudinal, psychological and social history that defies broad definition," said the executive producer of the series, Michael Apted, the English filmmaker who, in 1964, produced the first of the highly praised "7 Up" documentaries.
The documentaries have proliferated across the globe: after the American version was filmed in 1990, Mr. Apted set loose a Russian documentary crew that filmed 7-year-olds in Russia. That team has just completed its own version of "14 Up." Subsequently, versions of "7 Up" were started in South Africa, Japan and Germany.
Mr. Apted, gray-haired, tweedy and avuncular at 57, first filmed his group of English youngsters when they were 7 and he was 22, then visited them again when they were 14, 21, 28 and 35. The newest installment, "42 Up," will be broadcast on the BBC next month.
The series is "a mix of instant history, sociology and soap opera," Mr. Apted said. "It's either a great Victorian novel, or a fascinating invasion of people's privacy. It depends on how you look at it." The American version is following the master script. Mr. Joanou interviewed more than 20 7-year-old boys and girls from disparate ethnic, racial, economic and social backgrounds in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Lincoln, Neb., and Dublin, Ga.
Six of the children had well-off parents; six were poor, including one, Luis, from a homeless family; the rest had middle-class backgrounds. The group includes children who are Asian, black, Hispanic and white.
In "7 Up," three Manhattan second graders, Lucy, Alexis and Kate, were filmed in the elite precincts of the Nightingale-Bamford School in Manhattan. They wore pressed uniforms and crisp white blouses.
Now, Lucy and Alexis -- who, like the other subjects of "14 Up," are identified only by first names in the documentary and who spoke on the condition that their last names not be published -- were being casual at Sofia, a Madison Avenue pizza hangout in the independent-school zone on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
They have become minor celebrities not only in their schools but also as far away as Paris, "where someone came up to me and said, 'I've seen you on TV,' " Lucy said.
Kate, who couldn't get to Sofia but was interviewed later, said, "A baby sitter I hadn't seen in years called me when she saw it."
Alexis said, "When the film comes out, it's sort of a home video, but it's played for the whole world."
Lucy shook her head and said: "I see what a spoiled brat I was at age 7. I kept babbling on, and wouldn't let anyone speak."
 
Changing Schools, Changing Lives
The girls lost touch with one another as they changed schools through the years. "When I entered the interview room, it was weird to see Lucy and Alexis again," said Kate, 15. "At first I was expecting them to be 7."
In the fourth grade Alexis transferred to the Chapin School in Manhattan, which she termed "intensely competitive." Lucy and her parents moved to Long Island, and in the 10th grade she began attending Lawrenceville, the New Jersey boarding school, where she skipped a grade. "Lawrenceville is totally pro-Princeton, so of course I want to go there," she said.
Kate's parents divorced a year ago, and she, her mother and two sisters have moved to Westchester County. Currently Kate, who volunteered in a Manhattan women's shelter when she was 7, is interested in being a social worker.
For Luis, "right now the church is my life," he said. He was originally filmed in Manhattan in Public School 97 on East Houston Street, when he was attending school there while his family lived in a shelter on the Lower East Side. At 7 he had huge, canny eyes and streetwise indomitability; these days he is a rangy ninth grader, a running back on his Milwaukee high school football team, the South Division Cardinals.
His current ambition "is to be the pastor of a church," said Luis, who prefers being called Tony these days. He said of the documentary series: "It's nice to feel like a movie star for a while. When you're in the ghetto, you're not paid too much attention, and when they did this video, it said they actually cared."
Mr. Apted said the original, British "7 Up" in 1964 "was an accident, a one-shot." Its immense popularity gave him "the idea to go back at seven-year intervals," said Mr. Apted, who has directed feature films ranging from "Coal Miner's Daughter" (1980), with Sissy Spacek, and "Gorillas in the Mist" (1988), with Sigourney Weaver, to "Nell" (1994), with Jodie Foster, and "Extreme Measures" (1996), with Gene Hackman.
The film that recommended Mr. Joanou to Mr. Apted was the documentary "U2: Rattle and Hum" (1988). Mr. Joanou (whose name is pronounced joe-ON-oh) was the director of "State of Grace" (1990), with Sean Penn; "Final Analysis" (1992), with Richard Gere, and "Heaven's Prisoners" (1996), with Alec Baldwin.
The American series is ultimately intended for theatrical release in 2012, when its subjects are 28, following the pattern of the English series. Until then, , an installment is to appear every seven years as a television special.
"I am struck with how savvy and worldly-wise the American 14-year-olds are," Mr. Apted said. "My English children were a bit more innocent."
The original English series has focused on the disparities of the English class system, as played out in the children's lives. Mr. Joanou said his subjects "are not as class-bound as the English, or at least not as aware of class boundaries."
He added: "They see themselves as equal. In our country there are strong economic boundaries to opportunity, but the kids don't see them. That's positive for them, but it's also disturbing for the culture."
To a reporter who interviewed the "Up" youngsters when they were 7, it is clear that their lives have been transformed by fate and the meander of time. But their personalities seem fixed -- blurred pictures that are slowly developing before the camera.
"Their lives are unpredictable, but I'm inclined to think that their core personality doesn't change," Mr. Apted said.
To Mr. Joanou, "it is the most important project in my life," he said. "There is nothing else like it for a documentarian."
"It's impossible not to reflect on where you were seven years ago,"he said. "Then, the kids were waist high, and now they're taller than me. I'm 36. Now I have gray hairs, and a little less on top."
 
Seeing Growth As a Painful Process
For Mr. Apted, the project is equally consuming. "Without being nauseating about it, they are very much like a family," he said, "and our lives are interwoven whether we like it or not."
The "14 Up" bunch has found growth to be a painful process. "At 7 I thought I knew everything, I was so confident of what I had to say," Lucy said. "Now I'm not so sure if I'm right. I guess now we're facing the world."
Alexis said she was "more aware of being better off and the advantages it gives you," adding: "But you can have a whole lot of money and just slack off. It may sound retarded to say this, but I believe we all have the same chance of succeeding."
They are quite aware of the documentary process, and at times are annoyed by it. "I feel I was stereotyped as some kind of Upper East Side rich snob," Kate said.
She added: "I don't think that the five minutes they give you tells anything. It's not a portrayal of the real me. And I don't know what you can learn about a whole generation from 17 kids. I had mixed feelings about being in the film again. But they said that everyone else is doing it, so I felt pressured to do it."
The group "is supposed to represent our generation," Lucy agreed, "but we're so much more than what you see on screen. And of course they have to ask us questions like 'Are you having sex?' I mean, puh-lease! The interview went on so long I began giggling and couldn't stop."
Luis said he "took the questions like a test" in the film interview, and "I answered them with truth; I don't know if I passed."
 
Looking Ahead To the 21 Mark
The American teen-agers say they intend to participate in the next round, at age 21. "It's risky," Lucy said.
Alexis interrupted: "But it's a cool risk. At least people will know that you were alive. We'll leave something behind."
Lucy smiled. "I feel we're part of an experiment," she said, "but I think we're taking over the experiment. I'm already making plans to be hyper and outgoing at 21, versus depressed and solemn at 14."
Deadpan, Alexis said: "Absolutely. I'm working on my wardrobe for age 21."
It is hard not to come to the aid of some of the children who are struggling, Mr. Joanou said. "We feel protective of them, but we can't help them," he said. "We have to remain objective, and show the truth that we see. We have to let their lives unfold."
As the years go by, Mr. Joanou said, "sadly, it's not impossible that there will be tragedy." He added, "Life throws a lot of curveballs, and no one gets out alive."
What is the destiny of his subjects? "It's a cliffhanger," he said. "Stay tuned for 2005."

HEADLINE: Chinese Spurn Appeal To Allow Opera Tour

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, June 23

 BODY:
After a day of last-minute efforts to negotiate a compromise that would permit a local opera company to travel to New York City to perform a classic Chinese opera, "The Peony Pavilion," as a centerpiece of the Lincoln Center Festival next month, cultural officials here continued to block the project. The director of the Shanghai Bureau of Culture insisted that the modern staging of the work was inappropriate for foreign viewers and would not be permitted to travel.
Coming days before the arrival of President Clinton, who is scheduled to land in China on Thursday evening, the artistic controversy threatens to sour an otherwise optimistic atmosphere that has been carefully planned by Chinese and American officials for the visit, which includes three days in Shanghai beginning on Monday. 
 Nigel Redden, director of the Lincoln Center Festival, flew to Shanghai on Monday to try to reach a compromise with Shanghai officials so the opera would not have to be abandoned. Although the contract between Lincoln Center and the Kunqu Opera Company does not technically involve the Bureau of Culture, its officials have exercised unwritten authority to step in and make decisions.
After an inconclusive meeting today, the director of the Bureau of Culture, Ma Bomin, reissued a statement made last week declaring that extensive revisions of the opera's script were still necessary before it could be approved. It also accused the director hired by Lincoln Center, Chen Shi-Zheng, of introducing "feudal," "ignorant" and "pornographic" elements into the opera.
Mr. Redden was more conciliatory, apparently hoping for a last-minute breakthrough even as that possibility seemed increasingly unlikely.
"I still hope that we can somehow break the logjam, but I do not have anything positive to report," Mr. Redden said.
The six-part production is scheduled to begin on July 7, with nightly performances through July 12. The six parts are then to be compressed into a weekend marathon, scheduled to begin on July 17.
The opera company's containers packed with six tons of elaborate sets, props and costumes are still stranded at Shanghai International Airport, where a cargo flight scheduled for last week was unexpectedly blocked.
 At Lincoln Center, Janice Price, the vice president for marketing and communications, said that "Thursday is our drop-dead date" for departure of the cargo if the production was to open as planned on July 7. The opening night is already sold out, she added.
 But she said it was possible that the production could begin later and be extended past the scheduled close of the festival, on July 26. A complicating factor, she said, is that the six-day presentation must precede the three-day marathon and adequate rehearsal time is needed between the two.
One of the most stunning aspects of the fracas is that plans to perform a 400-year-old Chinese opera in the United States reflect the innocuous, nonpolitical sort of cultural exchange that China's Government is trying hard to promote. Showcasing elements of China's endlessly complex culture is something its leaders generally prefer to talk of human rights or nuclear proliferation.
Yet the standoff over "The Peony Pavilion" is a reminder of the considerable political power still wielded by a small band of ultraconservative officials in this nation despite all the liberating social and economic changes under way here. Many of these officials control cultural and media affairs in the ministries.
Rather than promoters of artistic performances, cultural officials often view themselves as the last guardians of Communist Party ideology, outdated and unpopular as it is with most Chinese.
Last week Ms. Ma objected to elements of the unorthodox staging of the opera introduced by Mr. Chen. It was not political content that offended Ms. Ma but rather the innovative way that he approached the opera, a 55-scene extravagaza that he wanted to stage in its 20-hour entirety.
Mr. Chen insists that his interpretation of the opera , recreates the original spirit of the work written by Tang Xianzu in 1598 and lost over the years as the genre deteriorated, becoming so stilted and lifeless that relatively few Chinese viewers could enjoy it.
His staging appeared to be a singular success, with the audience at a dress rehearsal in Shanghai this month responding with laughter and raucous applause.
Even The People's Daily, the principal Communist Party newspaper, published an enthusiastic review on June 11.
"In such an open theatrical environment, the audience is struck by a richly interesting picture of life of ordinary people in the Ming Dynasty," the reviewer wrote. "This opera is intoxicating from the opening moments."
Other official comment also reflected broad approval from the authorities, before Ms. Ma stepped in.
Just a few days ago, China's Minister of Culture, Sun Jiazheng, went out of his way to cite the coming performance of "The Peony Pavilion" in New York as a prime example of cultural cooperation to be celebrated during President Clinton's visit.
But on Saturday, the day the New China News Agency reported Mr. Sun's comments in Beijing, cultural officials in Shanghai opened a personal attack on Mr. Chen, who grew up in China and moved to the United States in 1987.
In commentaries published in Shanghai's three major state-run newspapers, the cultural officials sharply criticized Mr. Chen, often in stilted and sometimes xenophobic language common to Chinese Communist Party oratory, accusing him of pandering to foreigners, aggrandizing his artistic vision and ignoring sacred traditions.
While the original opera is wildly suggestive, a scene of lovemaking between a man and a ghost occurs behind a screen, without any nudity onstage. As Mr. Chen likes to point out, the eroticism of the opera is refined by modern standards, just as it was in the works of Shakespeare, Tang's contemporary.
The differences between cultural bureaucrats like Ms. Ma and an innovative director like Mr. Chen represent a distinct clash between old and new in China.
The Bureau of Culture relies on faithful copying of well-known performance methods, and insists on a respect for or at least a passive acceptance of authority.
In contrast, young artists like Mr. Chen stress creativity, individual thinking and experimentation. It is no surprise that his interpretation of "The Peony Pavilion" appears to enjoy virtually unanimous support from actors young and old in the opera company, including its head, who has a leading role in the opera.
Ms. Ma, an experienced singer of Peking Opera before she became an official in 1986, now heads one of the most conservative branches of the Shanghai government.
Ms. Ma stresses the need for better control over cultural affairs, even though the government continues to cut financing for the arts and is even starting to ask for corporate sponsors for cultural affairs it can no longer afford to finance itself.
"People should not be surprised if artistic troupes appear, named after specific companies," Ms. Ma told Liberation Daily last month.
Even Ms. Ma's way of making her views public over the last week relied on old-fashioned party indirectness and obscurity, not that it fooled anyone. When she released a statement on Saturday criticizing Mr. Chen, she did so without signing any official's name, instead using the "Kunqu Opera Company Performance Group," as though the actors from "The Peony Pavilion" were voicing the objections.
But no actors stepped forward to claim any such view, and the fax number printed on the statement was from the Bureau of Culture.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Billion here, billion there, and soon your estimate on 1998 U.S. ad spending reaches $200.3 billion.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the disk jockeys on the old Top 40 radio stations who shouted, "And the hits just keep on coming!"? Well, the rosy predictions for domestic advertising spending just keep on coming from a leading industry forecaster.
Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at the McCann-Erickson USA unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, said yesterday that he would again raise his estimate of spending for 1998. The reason: myriad signs of economic growth that have been more robust than anticipated. 
 "We're in a good, strong upward movement," Mr. Coen said at a presentation of his predictions at the University Club in midtown Manhattan. "The economic climate looks even more favorable."
So "barring any unforeseen developments," he added, "things look better for 1998 than they did in December," when he issued his previous forecast.
Ad spending is closely watched because it is deemed a reliable indicator of the health of the economy. For instance, advertising as a percentage of gross domestic product peaked in 1987 and 1988 at 2.35 percent as the economy boomed, and then it fell as a recession took hold, bottoming out at 2.12 percent in 1992.
Mr. Coen predicted that marketers would spend a record $200.3 billion in the United States in 1998, up 6.8 percent from a revised figure of $187.5 billion for 1997. The 1997 figure marks a gain of 7 percent from the $175.2 billion that was spent in 1996.
If Mr. Coen's prediction holds, advertising as a percentage of G.D.P. will "match or pass" the previous peak of 2.35 percent, he said.
While stronger than expected, the growth expected for 1998 would be the smallest in percentage terms since a 5.2 percent increase in 1993. Yet, if the figure of $200.3 billion is indeed reached, it will be the first time that domestic ad spending tops the $200 billion level. Overseas ad spending first passed that figure in 1995.
Conditions for ad spending overseas will not be as favorable this year as they will be in the United States, Mr. Coen said, primarily because of the economic downturn in Asia. As a result, he has trimmed his estimate for overseas ad spending in 1998 for a second time.
Mr. Coen "has highlighted the concerns in Asia, which are warranted but manageable," said Karen Ficker, an analyst at Furman Selz in New York who follows the media and advertising industries. Ms. Ficker, who attended Mr. Coen's presentation, said: "We're encouraged by his upward revisions in the United States. Everything we see seems to support that."
Mr. Coen, who has been tracking advertising and media trends since 1948, issues his predictions twice a year, in June and December, revising them based on updated data.
Though he was once known for overly optimistic forecasts, he most recently has underestimated spending as the American economic expansion chugs along.
The estimate of $200.3 billion is the third made by Mr. Coen for American ad spending in 1998. In June 1997, he forecast a 1998 figure of $196.5 billion, which he raised six months later to $198.4 billion. Yet "the demand for media time and space" continues mostly unabated, Mr. Coen said, so he has increased his prediction once more.
Economists are projecting that unemployment and inflation in 1998 will fall from 1997 while housing starts and vehicle sales will rise, he added, and there are factors, like the Olympics and elections, that stimulate demand for ads in even-numbered years.
In raising his forecast for 1998, Mr. Coen cited the first-quarter results in several large national ad categories such as automobiles, up 17 percent from the corresponding period of 1997; toiletries and cosmetics, up 14 percent; food, up 11 percent; movies, up 9 percent, and beverages and snacks, up 8 percent.
In some secondary national ad categories, he said, the gains were even larger: insurance, up 33 percent; airlines, up 28 percent; computers, up 26 percent, and beer and wine, up 22 percent.
As a result, several national media enjoyed double-digit percentage gains in ad revenue during the first quarter of 1998, Mr. Coen said, including cable television networks, up 15.8 percent; the four biggest broadcast TV networks, up 14.9 percent, and spot radio, up 11 percent.
Of Mr. Coen's forecast of $200.3 billion, $118 billion is in national ad spending, up 7 percent from 1997, and $82.3 billion is in local ad spending, up 6.5 percent from 1997.
Among the local media registering gains in ad revenue in the first quarter of 1998, Mr. Coen mentioned spot television, up 13 percent; newspaper classifieds, up 9.8 percent; spot radio, up 9 percent; Yellow Pages, up 4.6 percent, and retail newspaper ads, up 4.4 percent.
"It looks like another pretty good year for local newspaper advertising," Mr. Coen said, because "everything we look at suggests consumers are spending a little more freely" on the types of merchandise sold through newspapers.
Turning to ad spending abroad, Mr. Coen's revised figure for 1998 is $218.4 billion, compared with a forecast he made in December of $236 billion and a forecast he made in June 1997 of $240.5 billion. Overseas ad spending last year totaled $210 billion, down 1 percent from $212.1 billion in 1996; it was the first decline internationally since 1993.
The Asian crisis "affects the overseas consolidated numbers," Mr. Coen said, offsetting strong increases in ad spending expected in such countries as Brazil, Britain and Mexico. Among the largest declines Mr. Coen predicted were those for Indonesia, down 30 percent from 1997; Malaysia, down 20 percent, and South Korea, down 10 percent.
Mr. Coen's worldwide total estimate for 1998, then, is $418.7 billion. If it pans out, it will be the first time the total exceeds $400 billion. It would mark an increase of 5.3 percent from a final figure of $397.5 billion for 1997. That spending last year represented a gain of 2.6 percent from $387.3 billion spent in 1996, the smallest annual increase since 1993.
Mr. Coen's initial worldwide forecast for 1998, made in June 1997, was $437 billion, which he lowered to $434.4 billion in December.
And making his first prognostications about 1999, Mr. Coen estimated spending in the United States at $212.3 billion, which would be up 6 percent from 1998, and spending overseas at $228.2 billion, up 4.5 percent from this year.
His worldwide total for next year, then, is $440.5 billion, an increase of 5.2 percent from 1998.
And beyond 1999?
"As we approach the year 2000," Mr. Coen said, "we think the momentum will build" and may produce something like the "upsurge we saw in 1976," when ad spending in America rose smartly because of the Bicentennial celebration.
So, ad spending at the millennium could be "hitting half a trillion dollars," Mr. Coen said.
About 50 people attended Mr. Coen's presentation, which was his 25th annual midyear update. The turnout was lower than usual because some agency executives and journalists had left to attend the 45th International Advertising Festival, which continues through Saturday in Cannes, France.
McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Tries to Halt Selloff in Bank's Shares

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 23

 BODY:
Japan's Finance Minister tried to calm the financial markets today and avert a further selloff in the shares of a large weak bank, as the Government moved a step closer toward establishing a system to help restructure failed banks.
The nation's leaders are working out the details of what they're calling the Total Plan to tackle $600 billion in bad and doubtful loans infecting the banking system. 
 The plan has taken on a special urgency because of news reports that Long-Term Credit Bank, one of Japan's biggest financial institutions, is in trouble. The market has driven down its stock by more than 60 percent in the last couple of weeks.
Long-Term Credit is reportedly seeking a rescue merger to help stabilize its business. The bank has denied the reports, as well as accounts of merger discussions, but said today that it was working on a restructuring plan.
Japan's anemic banking system is considered an underlying cause of the malaise that has afflicted the world's second-largest economy, severely weakened the yen and stock market and played a role in the broader economic problems confronting much of Asia.
A United States delegation visited Tokyo last week to discuss Japan's predicament after both countries took the unusual step of buying yen and selling dollars to strengthen the Japanese currency. But the yen has started to weaken again, and today the stock market fell 1.7 percent.
Government leaders, one after another, expressed assurances today that Long-Term's depositors, lenders and counterparties in financial transactions would not suffer losses.
"I hope depositors and investors feel assured about their assets," Hikaru Matsunaga, the Finance Minister, said.
Long-Term Credit's stock price fell to a record low of 62 yen on Monday, from more than 200 just a couple of weeks ago. Today, it was the most heavily traded stock, closing at 71 yen, up 9 yen.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto also tried to reassure depositors and investors today that the Government would maintain financial stability. He said the Government would take "drastic measures to resolve the bad loan problem and will completely protect sound borrowers."
A high-level group of ministers and members of the dominant Liberal Democratic Party today approved an overall proposal for the Total Plan, which will be submitted to a special parliamentary session shortly after Upper House elections July 12.
The group today also endorsed the idea of establishing a "bridge bank," and will work out the details by July 2.
This bank would take over the assets and liabilities of banks facing bankruptcy and have the ability to lend money, so that the borrowers of failed banks would not be hurt.
Critics say unless the plan is properly structured, the bank could just keep expanding if the number of bankrupt banks increased.

HEADLINE: Lab Reports Of Iraq Poison Bolster Case For Sanctions

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 23

 BODY:
The first physical evidence that Iraq loaded deadly VX nerve gas into missile warheads before the 1991 war in the Persian Gulf has strengthened the resolve of the United States and its allies to maintain the embargo on Iraqi oil sales, diplomats said today.
United Nations weapons inspectors excavated warhead fragments in March from a weapons dump at Nibai, Iraq, and shipped them to a United States Army laboratory at Aberdeen, Md. The laboratory found significant traces of VX, an agent so toxic that a few drops can kill. 
 "It's a nail in the coffin for Iraq's efforts to lift sanctions and to show substantial progess on disarmament," the chief United States delegate, Bill Richardson, said today in an interview.
Britain's chief delegate, Sir John Weston, said there is no room to give Iraq the benefit of the doubt about the existence of "extremely potent chemical weapons" like VX. "I think it ill serves the United Nations not to look the facts in the face and to deal with them squarely in a case of this kind," he said.
The United States and Britain have fought against relaxing the sanctions, which were imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, until weapons inspectors verify that Iraq is free of weapons of mass destruction and the means to make them. The condition was spelled out in Security Council Resolution 687, enacted in 1991.
The three other permanent members of the Security Council, China, France and Russia, have supported a more accommodating approach that takes into account the limited cooperation Iraq has offered so far. The oil sanctions have already been relaxed to allow Iraq to earn money for food and medicine imports.
But the discovery of VX on missile warhead fragments, first reported today by The Washington Post, has sounded alarms because it offers proof that the Iraqis lied when they called their VX program purely experimental. Experts say that if the Iraqis could stabilize VX sufficiently to pour into warheads, they could also keep it stable enough to hide for years from inspectors.
President Clinton left little doubt that the United States will use the discovery to keep the sanctions on Iraqi oil. "Let the inspections go forward and don't lift the sanctions until the resolutions are complied with," he said today.
Iraq, in a statement today by its United Nations mission, said the Aberdeen analysis of warheads could not be correct because "continuous production failure" had prevented the use of VX in any munitions.
The Iraqi statement also sought to find fault with the handling of the VX samples, saying Baghdad was told that only one of the seven samples analyzed had shown variable traces of VX. It also said that the samples were taken without giving Iraq equivalent samples, as had been agreed upon, and that no soil samples were taken for comparison.
The statement also noted that Iraq had insisted that any analysis of importance be done in a neutral country or be divided among laboratories of other countries.
The Security Council is to be briefed on the issue on Wednesday by Richard Butler, the Australian diplomat who heads the arms inspection team. In a report he sent to the Security Council last Thursday, Mr. Butler said that when he met with Iraqi officials in Baghdad on June 13 and 14, they refused to address questions about production of VX, some biological agents and missile fuel.
Mr. Butler, who arrived in New York today from Australia, refused to talk about the Aberdeen results.
Ewan Buchanan, a spokesman for the team, said, "No doubt it will be discussed in depth in the council tomorrow, which is the proper place for such discussion."
A Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Butler was advised that the warhead shards had tested positive for VX before he arrived in Baghdad on June 11, and raised the matter informally with his Iraqi counterpart, Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz. Mr. Aziz, according to the diplomat, dismissed the finding as a lie.
Mr. Butler's report sent to the Security Council on Thursday alluded to their confrontation. "During the discussions, the commission presented the preliminary results of the chemical analysis of certain excavated remnants of special mission warheads," it said. "The Iraqi side rejected these results."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Environmental Entrepreneur Closes a Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
FORTUNATELY for Tom Fox, the story of his little yellow water taxis no longer works as a perfect metaphor for his life.
By now, the boats were supposed to have been buzzing around the waterfront several times a day, moving people to various stops from the Brooklyn Bridge to the Intrepid museum, but Mr. Fox had to shut down the whole enterprise in August after only three months because the boats didn't have enough power to navigate the harbor. New York's currents proved too much for them. 
 Imagine what a halfway imaginative biographer could make of this detail if Mr. Fox were still the blue-jeaned environmentalist of his youth, hopelessly proselytizing for more green space in the city of mortar, writing position papers on the importance of community gardens. But Mr. Fox makes money these days as an environmental and development consultant, wears a tie to work (some days), and last week watched a longtime dream come true when the state and city finally agreed on how to build and operate a pulsating strip of park along the Hudson River on Manhattan's West Side.
Mr. Fox has been crusading for that park for years, including three as founding president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, which drew up the plans for the five-mile park and worked out its fundamental compromises with the surrounding communities, deciding when the green of chlorophyll should give way to the green of economic development. The Pataki administration replaced him in 1995, preferring someone with more direct loyalty to the Governor's staff, but the plan that will now proceed is virtually unchanged from the one developed by him and his staff, and so the moment is finally sweet.
"For me, it feels like closure," he said this week in his consulting-firm offices at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue. "We're actually going to have the largest riverfront park in the United States right here in river city, and we the people made it happen."
Not all the people, of course. There are still those who oppose the park as a development grab, environmentalists once on the same side as Mr. Fox in fighting Westway and other large projects around the city, who now spit out his name in derision as a sellout. In the never-ending wars that rage between real estate interests and Manhattan's community boards, he is the necessary go-between, someone who can talk to both sides but is not trusted fully by either one.
Marcy Benstock, the implacable (but increasingly marginalized) foe of Westway and the proposed park, says Mr. Fox was never an environmentalist and calls the park twice as bad as Westway. Gene Russianoff, senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group, says he knows of no other advocate in the city as focused and ferocious as Mr. Fox, but fears that the "develo-park" will be slowly whittled by economic interests.
ALL of this is frustrating for Mr. Fox, who used to lob seeds into vacant lots as a leader of the Green Guerrillas and remembers with pride working to stop Mortimer Zuckerman's proposed tower at the southwest corner of Central Park. He says his colleagues have become so used to stopping things that they can no longer create and the Hudson park would never happen without developments like the Chelsea Piers to pay for its operation.
"They're naive," he said, windmilling his arms around as if to shed some of his excess energy. "In the 21st century, without all the government funding we used to have, you have to find other ways to finance and build parks. And if there's any contribution I've made, it's the idea that parks can be self-financing, so that the money generated in the park can only go to its design, construction, management and operation."
Mr. Fox, 51, grew up on Ocean Avenue in Flatbush -- only a few blocks from the rambling Victorian where he and his wife and son live now -- and he played in Prospect Park as a boy, but he never cared much about the spaciousness of nature until he volunteered for the Navy in Vietnam, serving in combat from 1966 to 1968. Seeing jungles and marine life up close transformed him, and he came home to study biology at Brooklyn College and to develop environmental programs as a ranger in the Federal Gateway National Recreation Area.
If the war didn't quite radicalize him, it made him realize the value of fighting for a cause, and he spent years fighting for community gardens and open space on various boards and commissions around the city. But he says there was always a pragmatic aspect as well. He enlisted the support of construction unions by convincing them that open space in a city generates development and economic activity, citing Frederick Law Olmsted's arguments for Central Park more than a century earlier.
Though some advocates criticize him for trying to cash in on the planned park with his water taxi plan after being removed from the conservancy, he says it was a natural way to "do well by doing good" with a service that will benefit the public and, perhaps someday, his own bottom line.
"I'm trying to be an environmental entrepreneur here," he said. "Some environmentalists just call attention to problems. I come from the group that tries to figure a way to solve those problems, and as near as I can tell, that almost always involves money."
Of which he needs $2 million for boats with a bit more power.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A 20-Year G.M. Parts Migration To Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MATAMOROS, Mexico, June 20

 BODY:
In one of General Motors' sprawling auto parts plants in a Matamoros industrial park just south of the Rio Grande, thousands of Mexican workers earn $1 to $2 an hour producing instrument panels and steering wheels for G.M. cars and trucks.
Until just a few years ago, United States workers earning close to $22 an hour at G.M.'s Delphi East factory in Flint, Mich., made the instrument panels. And those at a plant to the north in Saginaw produced the steering wheels. 
 G.M.'s shift of production from Flint and Saginaw to this border city facing Brownsville, Tex., was part of a sweeping 20-year transfer of its United States auto parts industry across the border. Since 1978, General Motors has built more than 50 parts factories in Mexico, which today employ 72,000 workers, making its parts subsidiary, Delphi Automotive Services, Mexico's largest private employer.
Other companies from the United States have, of course, also moved plants to Mexico. The Ford Motor Company has 11 parts factories in Mexico; Chrysler has none.
The transfer of production to Mexico and other countries has become a focus of the United Automobile Workers' strike against G.M., which began at a stamping plant in Flint and at the Delphi East factory. U.A.W. officials in the United States have accused General Motors of "putting America last."
In Mexico, where the strike has idled 23,000 workers at two dozen Delphi plants, managers have told workers that the union is demanding that G.M. close its Mexican plants and return its parts production to the United States, said Juan Villafuerte Morales, a union officer representing workers at Delphi's Matamoros factories. The plants have been partly idled by the strike in Flint.
"Most of our workers understand that they're doing work that used to be done in United States factories because managers explain that to them on the plant floor," Mr. Villafuerte said. "And let me tell you, the jobs are very welcome here."
General Motors says that transferring production south has enabled it to cut costs in labor-intensive assembly production, compete more effectively against Ford, Chrysler and Japanese auto makers, and keep engineering and other operations in the United States.
The financial advantages of producing parts in Mexico are substantial, and some economists say that the North American Free Trade Agreement, which went into effect in January 1994, has only increased them. Many plants have no union, and those that do are represented by the Confederation of Mexican Workers, which is controlled by Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and works with the Government to avoid strikes. The union has kept the U.A.W. at arm's length.
Thousands of Mexican workers at G.M. and other United States-owned factories live in dirt-floor shacks in slums ringing the industrial parks where they work. Yet many say that they are delighted to have their jobs, which often start at Mexico's minimum wage of $3.40 a day but can pay experienced workers several times that. A Delphi spokesman said the company would in the next 18 months help 7,000 employees buy their own homes.
"It's a good job," said a 23-year-old woman who earns $1.36 an hour painting buttons on car radios at Deltronicos de Matamoros, a Delphi plant. The woman, who asked that her name not be used during an interview at her one-room wood-frame shed in a gritty, wind-blown Matamoros squatters' settlement, said the choking smell of solvents at her work station gave her headaches. "It's difficult work," she said. "But I'm glad to have it."
G.M. opened its first factory in Mexico in 1935, assembling trucks in the capital from parts imported from the United States. After a 1962 Mexican law required foreign auto makers to increase the local content of their vehicles, G.M. built three engine and vehicle plants in the 1960's and 70's. The new plants, like similar factories built by Ford and Chrysler, assembled vehicles for the Mexican market. In the decades since, G.M. has continued to assemble vehicles in Mexico.
But in the late 70's, in response to a 1965 law encouraging foreign manufacturers to produce goods here for export tax-free, General Motors changed strategy. "G.M. began to see Mexico as a supplier for its U.S. vehicle assembly plants, and in the 1980's built an entire parts industry here," said Arnulfo Arteaga, a Mexico City professor who studies the auto industry. "Now, Delphi's Mexican plants basically turn out parts once produced in the United States."
G.M. erected its first Mexican parts plant, to assemble wiring systems, in the large border city of Juarez in 1978.
"What is now Delphi Automotive had run into unprecedented competition," said Michael J. Hissam, a spokesman at Delphi's Mexican headquarters in Juarez. "We embarked on a plan to reduce costs by focusing final assembly in Mexico while keeping our more capital-intensive engineering, tooling and prototyping activities in the U.S. Did we come to Mexico for lower labor costs? Yes. But we also found something else -- excellent Mexican management and a dedicated Mexican work force."
Nicholas Lobaccaro, an auto industry analyst with Merrill Lynch, said General Motors had no choice but to seek lower-cost labor for parts production. G.M. is not doing anything that their competitors and that independent auto suppliers aren't doing," Mr. Lobaccaro said, adding:
"There's been tremendous pressure on parts pricing. To compete in the global economy, you need labor to be paid commensurate with value added. And you can't pay $46 an hour to do wire harnesses."
Dozens of other G.M. parts plants would be built across northern Mexico in the years that followed. In Matamoros, four Delphi plants were built in an industrial park near the intersection of Ohio Street and Michigan Avenue.
One Delphi plant, Componentes Mecanicos, opened in 1980. About 10 years later, Delphi began shifting production of instrument panels to the factory from Delphi East in Flint, said Larry Mathews, a spokesman for Flint's U.A.W. Local 651, which is currently on strike.
"They just crated the equipment, hoisted it onto a tractor-trailer, and sent it away to Mexico," Mr. Mathews said. "There's hardly anybody at this plant who hasn't seen machinery moving out in a crate with an address on it that says 'Mexico.' "
In the 1970's, Mr. Mathews added, the Delphi East plant had 13,000 workers; today, it has fewer than 6,000.
A 37-year-old worker at Componentes Mecanicos who asked that his name be withheld, said in an interview outside his two-room Matamoros home that if he qualified for a weekly attendance bonus, he earned about $1.90 an hour. Newly hired workers receive $1.05 an hour, he said. His wife also works at a G.M. assembly plant in Matamoros, and by pooling salaries, the couple has managed to rise slightly above subsistence. They own a battered Ford pickup truck, and although their home has no indoor plumbing, they have equipped it with a television set and an electric fan. He coaches his three sons in a soccer league.
Next door to Componentes Mecanicos is the Deltronicos plant, built in 1979. In the mid-1980's, G.M. shifted much of its car radio production from its Delco plant in Kokomo, Ind., to Deltronicos, U.A.W. officials said. The work force at Kokomo has dropped to 4,800 from 11,000 in 1977, the union said. The Deltronicos plant employs 5,400 workers.
Across the street from Deltronicos is a Matamoros plant owned by the Trico Products Corporation of Buffalo, a unit of Tomkins P.L.C., which supplies windshield wipers to G.M. as well as Ford and Chrysler. The transfer of much of Trico's production to Mexico since 1987, which came despite entreaties from Buffalo city officials, has reduced Trico's Buffalo work force to 200 from 2,400, U.A.W. officials said.
Misaela Castro Margaro, who is 21, earned $1.05 an hour fitting vinyl blades onto wiper assemblies at the Matamoros plant until her three-month contract expired earlier this month. She said the work was hard but she missed her job.
"I loved that plant," she said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: MONEY;
Clinton's Challenge: Time to Deal With Asian Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
For a year the Clinton Administration has tried to minimize its direct involvement in Asia's economic crisis, pulling strings at the International Monetary Fund, sending out envoys to cajole foreign leaders and avoiding the lead role Washington took when it saved Mexico from economic implosion in 1995.
But as President Clinton prepares to leave for China, the Asian crisis, in the words of one of his top aides, is becoming "worse and worse every day," and it is becoming far more difficult for the leader of the world's largest economy to deal with it at a distance. 
 For the first time there is talk inside the Administration and at the World Bank of the possibility of an Asian depression. And Mr. Clinton will end his trip in Hong Kong, once Asia's booming example of free enterprise, whose chief executive declared on Monday that a recession was "more far-reaching than we anticipated."
Market instability, which a few months ago seemed contained, now amplifies as it circles the globe. Trouble in Southeast Asia unnerves investors in Japan, the meltdown of the yen sets off a crisis of confidence in Russia and China, and those jitters rattle Central Europe and Latin America.
Plan A, a yearlong effort to devise solutions through the I.M.F. and the World Bank, where the United States is the largest and most influential member, is clearly not working. But Mr. Clinton's economic team says direct American aid to the countries in deepest trouble -- even Russia, in which the United States has the most at stake -- is out of the question. In short, there is no Plan B.
In the weeks leading up to his trip, Mr. Clinton has delved into some risky market diplomacy, offering symbolic indications of support for Russia and Japan, in the hope that investors will be calmed by Washington's commitment.
Three weeks ago, faced with an imminent devaluation of the ruble that would undercut the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton backed additional international financial aid for Russia. Last Tuesday, concerned about an attack on the yen, he approved intervening in the currency markets to prop up Japan. On Friday he urged China not to worsen a risky situation by devaluing its own currency, an argument that his aides say he will repeat in Beijing.
All those are stopgaps. Their success depends on decisions in Moscow and Tokyo and Beijing that the United States has relatively little power to influence. That is worrisome for three reasons.
First there is a fear in the White House that America's yearlong insulation from the Asian crisis may be peeling away.
Mr. Clinton's aides are circumspect about raising those worries in public, for fear of inciting added troubles in the markets. But Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's public comments make it clear that he is far more worried about the domestic effects of the Asian crisis now than he was two months ago.
"If a major crisis were to develop," he said last week at the White House, "the effects in our nation could be great."
He cited the dramatic fall in American exports, the most measurable example. Others worry that as money pours out of Asia, it is seeking safe haven in the United States, creating a market "bubble" that could collapse when global economic fortunes change and investors sell dollars and re-invest in Asia.
The second concern is more stark. If the I.M.F. is unable to contain the instability, what does Washington do next? The $12 billion United States contribution to the bailout of Mexico was an economic success. But it cannot be repeated. Congress refused to back financial aid for America's closest neighbor, and it screamed when Mr. Clinton dipped into a fund under the control of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve.
An amendment to a major budget bill in the House this week would forbid the Administration from using that fund again, a step that Mr. Rubin warned today would "constitute an unacceptable limitation on the executive branch's ability to protect critical U.S. economic interests."
The fund, he noted, was used last year to provide backup to the I.M.F. in preventing an imminent national default in South Korea.
But Mr. Rubin's aides concede that using the fund again, even if Congress enacts no limitation, would raise an uproar, just when the Administration is trying to persuade the House to approve an additional $18 billion for the I.M.F. Even if Russia needs aid, one senior official asked recently, "where would we get the money?"
That leads to the President's third challenge, convincing China this week that it has to resist temptations to devalue its currency and convincing Americans, via television, that the global economy can do them more good than harm.
China has said it will keep its currency pegged to the dollar, even though Asian devaluations have made its products less and less competitive.
"China's got to hold the fort," C. Fred Bergsten, president of the Institute for International Economics, said. "If not, if the strong center buckles, all hell breaks lose."
Mr. Clinton will have to make the case that economic engagement benefits American workers. There is already considerable suspicion that the North America Free Trade Agreement cost American jobs, even if the evidence is mixed.
In China, Mr. Clinton has to argue that Asia is America's best long-term bet, despite the latest crisis and Congressional suspicions that China is bent on stealing technology. It was a more convincing argument in better economic times.

HEADLINE: Growth of Factory-Like Hog Farms Divides Rural Areas of the Midwest

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: LENNOX, S.D.

 BODY:
Clouds the color of gunmetal billowed across the South Dakota sky as Merlyn Steever slouched in a metal chair in a now-empty barn, his arms folded in weary resignation.
"I give up," Mr. Steever, a 50-year-old farmer, said as he waited for the trucks to load the last of his pigs and take them to slaughter, ending his career as a hog producer. "I just can't compete with the big corporates. I don't see how any farmer can." 
 The rapid growth of big hog factories, which are more akin to the corporate efficiency of General Motors than the bibbed-overall ethos of American Gothic, has emerged as perhaps the most contentious issue in the nation's farm country.
While some big-scale corporate hog farming has existed for years, it is now starting to dominate this sector of agriculture, with companies increasingly owning the hog plants, the slaughterhouses and the distribution centers.
The desperation of smaller farmers, along with anger among townspeople in rural areas offended by the foul smell of the huge hog barns, has stirred debate in a dozen states that are now considering plans to curb such plants, which can threaten underground water supplies. A ballot initiative in South Dakota, to be voted on in November, would effectively outlaw corporate livestock production. And Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma recently signed a bill restricting big hog operations.
On the Federal level, the Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to work with the states to impose strict pollution-discharge permits on all large farms by 2005. The agency said in March that it would propose regulations that could range from the installation of equipment to capture methane fumes to changing the composition of animal feed to control certain nutrients in the waste.
"It's nasty," said Barbara Dunham, 37, whose house, about a half mile from a big hog plant in central Illinois, saw its assessed property value drop 30 percent recently because of the smell. "It gets so bad you can't go outside. And you have to scrub down your inside walls."
Defenders of the big hog plants, where thousands of hogs are confined in small pens, say the producers can scarcely be blamed for delivering the kind of lean, low-cost pork that American consumers demand. The hog companies say they take every precaution to insure health and safety. And they say they contribute mightily to state tax coffers and rural regions that are starving for jobs.
"This issue has divided communities and turned neighbor against neighbor," said John Bixler, a spokesman for Dakota Rural Action, an advocacy group for small farmers in South Dakota.
Premium Standard Farms, which is owned by the Continental Grain Company and is the nation's third largest pork producer, pays about $200 million in income to about 3,000 workers in Missouri, according to a study by the University of Missouri.
Randy Mahoney, a 31-year-old supervisor for the hog company, said that when he was a teen-ager in the early 1980's, he watched the pain on his father's face when the family farm was foreclosed.
"It's a story you could hear from a lot of people around here," said Mr. Mahoney, who makes nearly $40,000 a year and never has to worry about prices on the hog markets. "I never dreamed I could stay close to home, continue doing the kind of work I'm doing and make a good living."
Before leaving work, Mr. Mahoney must shower and change clothes. Pig manure, he concedes, stinks.
That is the smell of money, say the hog plants' defenders, echoing a refrain that has been used for generations to defend steel mills, oil refineries and rubber incinerators.
To people whose image of raising pigs evokes Old McDonald's farm, the sight of big confinement operations would conjure something more from George Orwell. For example, every steel building at a Premium Standard plant near Harris, Mo., houses 1,150 hogs -- 48 pens 20 feet long and 9 feet wide, each holding about 25 pigs. The pigs are genetically designed to produce an identical cut of meat. They are inseminated artificially, and their hooves never leave concrete.
Many of the independent farmers also use this confinement method, reducing labor and saving space. The bottoms of the pens are slatted, so that waste drops and collects in a lagoon. The water, which is full of hog waste, is then spread over cropland as fertilizer.
Craig Hoogestraat, who farms his family's century-old hog operation near Lennox, a city of about 1,700 people in southeastern South Dakota, moves through the hog pens to check on the newborn piglets suckling sows in the small pens.
Mr. Hoogestraat, a former teacher who said he returned to farming after realizing that pigs were better behaved than junior high school students, leaves an oldies rock music station playing on a radio in the hog pen. Asked why he selected a music station for the pigs, he deadpanned: "Because they get upset if they hear the broadcasts of the hog reports."
Despite his upbeat ways, Mr. Hoogestraat worried aloud that if hog prices reached much lower than $35 per hundredweight -- the cost per 100 pounds of a live hog -- he did not know how he could stay in business.
His father, Donald, a former president of the South Dakota Pork Producers Council, stood by and shook his head with worry. The elder Mr. Hoogestraat, who has been a prime mover behind the anti-corporate measure, said the growth of big agricultural operations simply mirrored the trend of behemoths in every sector of the economy.
"You look at the Chrysler merger," he said. "You see Citibank and Travelers getting together. What's going to happen when all this money is concentrated in so few hands? "
Smaller farmers say they cannot produce goods at the same prices as the bigger outfits, which have deep pockets and the efficiency of scale.
But in the hog business, the competitive differences between independent farmers and big companies run even deeper. Many of the bigger hog companies now breed the animals, own the slaughterhouses and market the meat.
This control of the process allows the big companies to withstand lower hog prices, because they can make it up on the retail end. For the independent farmers, a drop in producer prices can spell doom. And lately, that is what has been happening.
Prices per hundredweight of live hogs have been in the $33-to-$45 range this year, the lowest prices in the last quarter-century, and a disaster for many pig farmers.
Economists have a mixed view about the power of laws intended to stop corporate farming. Nebraska has perhaps the nation's toughest law of that kind, forbidding any corporation to engage in farming. The measure has endured Federal court challenges. And it has, indeed, kept out corporate farmers. The South Dakota measure was drawn up along similar lines, exempting family-owned corporations. But huge family-owned operations can cause as many environmental problems as the corporate concerns.
As in the rest of agriculture, the trend toward bigger operations is unmistakable. The average swine farm today produces 432 hogs. Twenty years ago, the average farm produced 87.5 hogs.
Perhaps most significant, meatpackers get about 30 percent of their hogs from their own hog-breeding operations or from large-scale contracts with farms. That compares with 2 percent in 1970. When slaughterhouses and breeders have such close arrangements -- or, in fact, are the same company -- the market shrinks for independent farmers.
Bernie Hunhoff, a Democratic State Senator in South Dakota who is running for governor against the Republican incumbent, William J. Janklow, contends that this trend is reducing competition and creating monopolies for big companies.
"When you cut off access to markets, that's not free enterprise," said Mr. Hunhoff, who grew up on a hog farm near Yankton and supports the anti-corporate farming measure. "We're at a crossroads here. Are we going to defend and protect family farms? Or are we going to let everything to the control of the corporates?"
Mr. Janklow has opposed the ballot initiative and defends the big hog farms as good corporate citizens.
The measure has also divided farm groups. Organizations that represent the bigger, more conservative farmers and ranchers, like the Pork Producers Council, have expressed opposition to the measure, while the more liberal National Farmers Union has supported it.
Farmers like the Hoogestraats look down the flat gravel roads near their farm and recite the names of 10 farmers who have stopped raising hogs in the last few years.
"We might not win this thing," said Craig Hoogestraat, referring to the anti-corporate measure on the ballot. "But we're not going down without a fight."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Craig Hoogestraat, left, and his father, Donald, laughed as they held piglets at their family-owned hog farm near Lennox, S.D., last week, but were not laughing about plunging hog prices that could close their business. (Ken Klotzbach for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:

Parakeet on Park
This may rank right up there with the notion of alligators in the sewer: a bright blue parakeet on a Park Avenue doormat. Now he is living in -- what else? -- a gilded cage. And the bird is a he. The salesclerks at Bernardaud, a store better known for Limoges porcelain than for avian biology, checked.
But first they had to coax him off the doormat and into the store, at Park Avenue between 60th and 61st Streets. "We tried to encourage him to do something -- get on a pencil -- but no, he was uncomfortable with that idea," said MARY KAY DENNING, a spokeswoman for the store. "We were able, with the help of a chauffeur who pulled a beach towel out of the car and someone passing by who told us that if we covered him, we could handle him." 
 MARK SCHWARZ, a lawyer who passed by while prospective brides at Bernardaud were watching the salesclerks chase the parakeet, said that the bird was "swooping around the moldings and too close to the $200 wine glasses."
Ms. Denning said that the bird, whom the salesclerks have named Barbu (it means bearded, in French), ended up in a high-ceilinged stockroom. He eventually did a, uh, swan dive for a snack, landing on someone's muffin, and was moved to a restroom ("so no one could go to the bathroom for the next six hours"), then to the cage.
Ms. Denning said she had hoped to hear from Barbu's previous owner, but so far, not a peep.
 
Madeline Moves To the Big Screen
All together now: "In an old house in Paris that was covered with vines lived 12 little girls in two straight lines." That sentence was uttered more than once at a party at Tavern on the Green after the New York premiere of "Madeline," a film based on the Ludwig Bemelmans series of books, the first of which begins with that much-memorized line.
The reviews from the crayons-and-ice-cream set were generally positive. "I liked when she sank into the water," said ADRIENNE FISHMAN, who will be 6 next month, after reciting the opening line with her sister, JULIA, 9.
CHRISTOPHER LAWFORD was doing no such recitations. "Not on your life," he said. He had a question about pronunciation: "Is it Mad-uh-linn or Mad-uh-line?" A chorus that included his daughter, SAVANNAH ROSE, 8, favored the second. "I'd never read it until I had my daughter," Mr. Lawford said.
 
Table Hopping
Table 45 has become the hangout for literary types at Della Femina, a restaurant in East Hampton, N.Y. One night, SALMAN RUSHDIE, who went underground after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini pronounced a death sentence against him in 1989 after the publication of his novel "The Satanic Verses," had dinner at Table 45. The next night, LEONARD RIGGIO, the chief executive of Barnes and Noble, was seated at the same table. . . . "Inflation has taken place, to the tune of 6 cents," said DANNY MEYER, an owner of Gramercy Tavern and the Union Square Cafe. He was talking about the fixed-price lunches being offered by more than 100 restaurants this week, a custom begun in 1992, when the price was $19.92. "Our two restaurants were completely booked even before it was announced," he said. . . . TIM and NINA ZAGAT, compilers of restaurant guides, issued their predictions for food in the 21st century at the restaurant 21: they foresee computerized cookbooks and kitchens with "essentially one computerized food storage unit" that can freeze or cook.
 
Give Them Land, Lots of Land . . .
DAVID LETTERMAN may accumulate more than just speeding tickets in Montana. He reportedly has his eye on a ranch in bear country.
JACK SALMOND, a fourth-generation rancher, says that Mr. Letterman is considering buying a chunk of the Salmond Ranch in northwestern Montana. "We're in the talking stage now," said Mr. Salmond, who would not say how much land or how much money was being talked about. He said that he had listed 10,000 acres for sale last fall for $7 million but had taken the land off the market.
Mr. Letterman, who has made his speeding on parkways in Connecticut a running gag on his late-night talk show, visited Montana last month and was stopped in Darby for, yes, speeding. He also passed through Choteau, 250 miles northeast of Darby, where he told the Choteau Acantha newspaper, "I've never seen anything so beautiful in my life."
As for Mr. Salmond, he is not a big "Late Show" watcher. "Don't know very much about it," he said.
With his wife expecting, the radio personality DON IMUS wants a house with a nursery and a nanny's room.
Mr. Imus has filed plans to build a seven-bedroom, seven-bath house on 3.8 acres he owns in Westport, Conn. A public planning and zoning hearing is scheduled July 23. Mr. Imus needs a construction permit, as well as a demolition permit to tear down the existing two-story house on the property, which he bought last year for $4.6 million. JAMES BARRON

HEADLINE: SUNY Budget Lets College Keep Revenue

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The trustees of the State University of New York adopted a budget yesterday that allows campuses to keep the tuition and fees they bring in, a step aimed at making the colleges more responsive to market forces.
The move is widely viewed as a harbinger of the broader transformation of the university that its board has sought for several years, but that some legislators and campus representatives have fought. 
 The colleges have been turning over their tuition revenue to a central university pot. The money has then been reallocated under a complex formula that has allowed the university to keep open smaller campuses that some see as less economically viable.
In the short term, the budget for next year gives more money to all campuses. The actual increases for the fiscal year that begins July 1 range from less than 1 percent for the five Colleges of Technology to more than 7 percent for the Binghamton, Geneseo and New Paltz campuses. No increase in tuition is envisioned.
But critics fear that in the long term, the new formula establishes a Darwinian system that will leave smaller campuses vulnerable.
"We feel that this model will lead to many campus closings," said Kenneth P. LaValle, chairman of the State Senate's Committee on Higher Education, "and that it will factionalize the state university system, pitting campuses against each other."
State legislators have long been wary of changes that could threaten campuses in their home districts. When SUNY tried to pare campuses several years ago, for example, it was stymied by legislators who fought the loss of institutions that were important to their communities economically and culturally.
But advocates of the new system said it would strengthen the colleges by encouraging them to improve their programs and attract more students.
"The colleges will have to go out and hustle," said Thomas W. Carroll, president of the Empire Foundation for Policy Research, a conservative interest group that has been pressing for a more market-oriented approach. "This is a fantastic change from the socialist cross-subsidy method that has kept people afloat by administrative fiat.
"Before," he said, "it didn't matter whether you were run well or poorly. The only thing that mattered was that you didn't close your doors, or the state legislators would get upset."
Within SUNY, the new budget is seen as a first step toward a broader system of performance-based financing. Under such a system, SUNY would allocate tax money to the campuses based on factors like the types of courses they offered and how their students scored on standardized tests. SUNY's provost, Peter Salins, has developed a preliminary list of such performance indicators that he will discuss with the colleges in the fall.
Senator LaValle and other state legislators tried unsuccessfully last week to pass legislation that would prevent SUNY from adopting a new financial system. "My fear was that if we left Albany without passing anything, the trustees would take action," Mr. LaValle said. "By adopting the budget, they have done it."
But rather than voting on a new system, the trustees, meeting at the SUNY College at Plattsburgh, adopted a budget that reflected some of the basic principles of that system.
"We never have voted on an approach," said Scott W. Steffey, SUNY's vice chancellor for university relations. "But we have changed the way we have constructed it so there are incentives, and so that it is easier to see how the money is being apportioned."
Tuition represents only about 40 percent, or $600 million, of the SUNY budget, which will total $1.6 billion next year, up 4.4 percent from this year. Most of the rest comes from state subsidies.
Although all of the state-operated campuses will see budget increases, some will be bigger than others. The university centers at Albany and Binghamton are among the winners, with increases of about 7 percent. In contrast, SUNY Buffalo and the state units at Cornell University will see increases of only about 3 percent. SUNY Stony Brook will see a 5.5 percent increase.
In New York City, the College of Optometry in Manhattan and the Health Science Center at Brooklyn will both receive increases of less than 3 percent, while the Maritime College in the Bronx will get a 4 percent increase.
SUNY officials said that for the first time, Cornell and the College of Ceramics at Alfred University have been included in the budget allocation process, rather than being handled separately, and will be treated under the same principles as the other campuses.
The new budget is based on enrollment forecasts the colleges have made for the coming year; they will be penalized if their projections are significantly different from the actual enrollment.
The changes do not apply to SUNY's 30 community colleges, which draw some of their financing from their communities.
Small colleges, which are seen as most vulnerable unless they can raise their enrollments, are being at least partly protected under the new formula. SUNY officials said that they will provide a certain level of financial support for basic operations at colleges with enrollments of 5,000 students or fewer.
The new budget also raises the amount given to colleges to match the money they bring in for sponsored research to 20 percent, from 9 percent.
