HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
China's stable currency is protecting it, for now.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
BRIEFING reporters before President Clinton's touchdown in China, the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, explained that the Chinese economy was "an island of stability" -- the only Asian power that was still growing, the only one whose currency had not taken a dive since the troubles swept the region last summer.
What he didn't explain is that China's economy is fundamentally in no better shape than, say, Indonesia's. Or that the primary reason the Chinese yuan hasn't budged is that currency markets lack the mechanism to topple it: unlike most Asian economies, China does not allow anyone to exchange its currency for dollars or yen without Government permission. 
 Does that mean the hordes of economists who counseled developing economies to adopt convertible currencies as quickly as possible were wrong? "Frankly," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, "the answer is 'yes.' "
With hindsight, it is easy enough to do a Dorian Gray-style analysis of the Asian economic miracle. Vast domestic savings and sheer hard work effectively masked the fragility and lack of sophistication of institutions that support modernization in a capitalist economy. As a result, Asia was able to grow rapidly through the 1980's and 1990's, even though far too much money went into grandiose, ill-advised investments and far too many banks and businesses took open-ended risks by borrowing heavily in foreign currency.
But the often-corrupt, top-down capitalism that weakened the economies of Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea and Indonesia describes China equally well. Indeed, Indonesia had a more solid institutional base on which to grow.
Indonesia's private banks, largely left alone by President Suharto's family and friends, flourished. Moreover, unlike China, Indonesia carried far less baggage in the form of inefficient state-owned industries with debts that could not possibly be repaid.
However, when currency panic spread from Thailand and Malaysia last fall, Indonesia proved extremely vulnerable. For one thing, it was easy to bet against the Indonesian rupiah because it had long been legal to exchange rupiah for other currencies. For another, Indonesian banks and industries owed billions of dollars to banks and bondholders that were callable on a few months' notice.
In China, by contrast, there was no easy way to make a currency bet in which you won if the yuan were devalued. To buy dollars with local currency requires permission from the Chinese central bank, which is not forthcoming unless it serves Government policy. Moreover, Chinese banks and corporations have very little short-term dollar debt because Beijing won't cooperate. Lenders won't lend dollars because they can't be repaid unless the Government agrees. Most foreign investments in China are thus in the form of equity in Chinese subsidiaries of foreign corporations or in long-term loans to Chinese corporations that are tied to machinery imports such as aircraft.
While hindsight has not been kind, there was method to the seeming madness of all those economists who pressed developing countries to allow free convertibility of currencies. Among other things, convertibility attracted foreign capital by reassuring investors that they could always repatriate their profits. It gave local importers and exporters a means of hedging their currency commitments. It reduced incentives for Government corruption.
But George Perry, an economist at the Brookings Institution, notes that the exceptionally high domestic savings rates in Asia (in contrast to Latin America) minimized the advantages of free convertibility. "What Asia needs is foreign technology and business organization, which comes with direct foreign investment, not dollar loans," he said.
While an inconvertible currency creates inefficiency since Government bureaucrats ultimately decide who has access to foreign cash, the cowboy capitalist ethic of financial markets in developing countries creates equally important inefficiencies. After all, private lenders in most of Asia were plainly out for the quick profits that came with borrowing in foreign currency -- and thus apt to ignore their exposure to currency fluctuations. With a convertible currency, "you're betting the farm on the vagaries of the international markets," said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University.
China is not entirely immune to the Asian currency flu. As Beijing has publicly acknowledged in recent weeks, China will eventually feel compelled to devalue the yuan to insure that its exports remain competitive. But devaluation is probably months or years off, both because Hong Kong would be adversely affected and because China is enjoying the prestige derived from currency stability.
But the Chinese focus on stability is the exception in a global economy full of opportunistic borrowers and pathologically optimistic lenders. The best hope now, Mr. Perry suggests, is that "we will finally respond to the alarm bell that rang three years ago in the Mexican peso crisis." The movers and shakers of international finance, he argues, have to make clear that freely convertible currencies are accidents waiting to happen.

HEADLINE: Malongo Journal;
Why This Pampered Paradise? It's Oil, Stupid!

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: MALONGO, Angola

 BODY:
In this remote northern region of war-ravaged Angola, many of the accents are from the South -- Texas, Mississippi, Louisiana.
Here there are paved roads smooth enough to Rollerblade on. Folger's coffee seems to be percolating in every office. You can have hot dogs and chocolate chip cookies for lunch. Or play golf on the 18-hole par-3 course. 
 In the 20 years that civil war has raged across this once lush and prosperous former Portuguese colony -- leaving virtually every road cratered, every power plant destroyed, every manufacturing plant silent -- the oil rigs at Chevron's installation have just kept on pumping. The offshore horizon is a collection of spindly towers, some spouting bright orange gas flames.
The uninterrupted flow was made possible by one of the more bizarre twists of money and politics. At the height of the war, Chevron's installation was protected by Cuban troops who were supporting the Marxist Angolan Government in its struggle against a rebel onslaught.
At that time the United States was a staunch supporter of the rebels, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita, the acronym for its name in Portuguese. But the Reagan Administration continued to allow Chevron to produce oil, about 50 percent of which went to Angola to pay for its war against Unita. Most of the oil was sold to America.
The Cubans are now gone. With the country in an uneasy bridge between war and peace, Angolan troops protect the area, which as part of Cabinda Province is cut off from the rest of Angola, and business is booming. The compound is a work in progress: expanded living quarters, a new dining hall, new office space and a new clinic are all under construction.
Angola is Africa's hottest oil territory right now. Recent offshore discoveries by Chevron and other international oil companies hold out the promise that Angola, which pumps about 740,000 barrels a day, may someday rival Nigeria's two million a day. Experts say this new-found wealth has the potential to speed Angola's recovery from its war.
Yet what troubles many diplomats and business executives is the habit the wealth has of disappearing. Angola's books have remained so opaque that the International Monetary Fund refuses to do business here. World Bank officials say that more than half of the Government's spending is on items not in the official budget. And while Luanda, the capital, has become a city with fancy sports cars and Paris couture imports, such luxuries remain the province of a tiny minority.
In Cabinda City, the nearest town to the Chevron compound, there are no signs of Paris, and few of public works. The roads quickly turn to dirt, and much of the housing is shacks. A public pool under construction when civil war broke out in 1966 remains unfinished and overgrown, only the diving board rising above tree line as a reminder of what might have been.
Here, as across the country, many civil servants are paid irregularly. And banditry by unfed soldiers is considered at least a part of the growing violence in rural areas.
Inside the compound, Chevron has built a bubble world. Its American employees work 12-hour days for 28 days straight, then jet back home for 28 days' rest. They are not allowed outside the fence, which is widely believed to be surrounded by land mines, although Chevron officials decline to talk about most security measures. Worried about their employees' safety, Chevron does not even let them drive the 12 miles between Malongo and the airport. They are taken by helicopter.
"Nobody just walks out the gate," said Larry Jostes, who is general manager here for 28 days, then goes home to San Francisco for 28 days of rest. "We know where everybody is all the time."
Many of the oil workers say their families know little about the country. Chuck Blevins, who runs a platform 30 miles out at sea, says he doubts that his wife or children back in Mississippi could find Angola on a map. Here the focus is on the huge machinery and engineering feats that keep the oil production up.
"It is a very exciting time to be here," said Don Nicholson, an electronic instrumentation specialist from Utah who has been working on one of the platforms for nine months. "We're at the cutting edge of the business."
Mr. Nicholson says he is curious nonetheless about what goes on in Angola and has attempted some Portuguese lessons, though without much success. "That Portuguese is just tearing me up," he said.
The oil companies have survived by remaining politically neutral and are not inclined to change that. Once the oil heads for the markets, they don't really worry about what happens to Angola's share of the profits.
But it is increasingly an issue for Angola, which has seen little social rehabilitation despite annual budgets of about $3.5 billion and 40 months of relative peace.
"Where has all the money gone?" has become a growing refrain here, even with members of Parliament. One recently lashed out at the Government, describing decrepit hospitals where 12 children a week die of malaria. Another said prisoners die of starvation in the country's jails.
Government officials have defended their reluctance to let anyone see the books by pointing out that they are still at war and do not want information about their financial strength to leak out. International creditors say some of the oil profits go straight into arms purchases, but corruption is widely assumed to siphon off much of the rest.
Meanwhile, the Government is driving harder and harder bargains for its oil. In the past, bidders merely submitted breakdowns of how eventual profits would be split. Now they must cough up "signing fees" that in the last 18 months amount to more than $200 million.
According to the London-based newsletter Africa Confidential, much of this new income remains inside the state oil company, Sonangol, and never makes it to the ministries of health and education that desperately need it.
Even if the money reached the treasury, Angola is probably unable to spend it wisely, experts say. For instance, since it is unable to get cheaper I.M.F. loans, Angola is paying huge foreign debts built up during the war at exorbitant interest rates.
Decades of war have left Angola with little expertise at investment management. But so much money is on the way that it will be impossible, some experts hope, for corrupt bureaucrats to steal it all.
"The magnitude of the resources," a diplomat said, "make it impossible for you to just quietly take the money away."

HEADLINE: Peruvian Premier Offers to Quit in Dispute Over Jailed American

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, June 24

 BODY:
Peru's Prime Minister of three weeks said today that he had offered to resign after President Alberto K. Fujimori rejected his idea to pardon a New Yorker imprisoned for life on terrorism charges. Mr. Fujimori declined the resignation offer.
The Prime Minister, Javier Valle Riestra, a 67-year-old lawyer and political independent, sparked a storm of Congressional protests when he suggested on Sunday that the 1996 military trial of Lori Helene Berenson, the New Yorker, was legally flawed and should be annulled. 
 On Tuesday, President Fujimori emphatically and swiftly rejected the suggestion that the 28-year-old former Manhattan resident be expelled to the United States.
"I find myself in a difficult emotional situation," Mr. Valle Riestra said in a radio interview today. "I live in a difficult situation because I can't be in continual and constant disagreement with majority opinion."
Since his surprise appointment to be coordinator of Mr. Fujimori's Cabinet only three weeks ago, Mr. Valle Riestra has made a series of statements opposing Government policy that have puzzled foreign diplomats and local journalists alike.
On his first day as Prime Minister, he said he opposed President Fujimori's expected bid for a third term in 2000. Soon after, Mr. Valle Riestra said he disagreed with the Government's plan to use military courts to try common criminals. And he has suggested that several Cabinet members be dismissed and replaced by human rights lawyers who have been critical of the President.
But it was his televised statement on Sunday that Ms. Berenson should be pardoned because of a lack of due process and "for reasons of state and for the sake of Peru's prestige" that isolated Mr. Valle Riestra from the entire Fujimori Administration and much of the political establishment. Newspaper editorials harshly criticized him, as did several prominent legislators.
Ms. Berenson has been held in a tiny cell high in the Andes since her conviction in January 1996 by a tribunal that did not allow her lawyers to question evidence or to cross-examine witnesses. She was accused of aiding the Marxist guerrilla group Tupac Amaru in a plan to take the Peruvian Congress hostage. Ms. Berenson said she was innocent but expressed sympathy for the rebels.
President Fujimori's choice of Mr. Valle Riestra came as a complete surprise. The constitutional lawyer and former Congressman had long been a member of the leftist APRA party and an advocate of human rights. But with Mr. Fujimori's standing in the polls falling, the economy jeopardized by the Asian economic crisis, and sensitive negotiations with Ecuador over a border dispute entering a crucial stage, several experts said the President was looking to broaden his base and improve his image by naming a liberal to be Prime Minister.
This morning, Mr. Valle Riestra sounded tired and frustrated, as if acknowledging that his efforts to push reforms in the Fujimori Administration had failed. But by an afternoon news conference, he sounded defiant again, as if President Fujimori's refusal to accept his resignation signified a victory.
"I will continue in this struggle, even when I oppose the chief of state," he told reporters, shaking his fist. "All the repressive acts of this Government must be opposed, and that is what I will continue to do."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Release Patent Data On a World Wide Web Site

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
In a new plan for making Government information freely available over the Internet, the Clinton Administration will announce today that it will make the full data base of the nation's patents since 1976 and trademark text and images starting from the late 1800's available on the World Wide Web beginning in August.
The project, which will create the largest Government data base on the Internet, is to be announced by Bruce A. Lehman, Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, in a speech to the American Bar Association's section on intellectual property law in Williamsburg, Va. 
 The decision to make the data base freely available is a result of a fierce debate that has gone on for years between public interest advocates who argue that Government information should routinely be made available on the Internet and companies that purchase the data from Government agencies to resell.
Indeed, the Clinton Administration's action came less than a week before a deadline imposed by Carl Malamud, an independent Internet pioneer, who in May said he planned to purchase the data from the Patent and Trademark Office and make it publicly available if the Government failed to act.
After imposing the deadline in a letter to Vice President Al Gore Jr. and the Commerce Secretary, William M. Daley, Mr. Malamud said that he had received an anonymous donation to support his project and that he was developing his own system of patent and trademark records.
Mr. Lehman, however, said that his agency had already made a commitment to Mr. Gore to make the data base available as part of the Vice President's "reinventing government" program.
Mr. Malamud said today that he had decided to shelve his plans.
"Our site was a backup in case the Administration refused to budge," he said. "We very pleased with the outcome of this five-year struggle. The American public gets the data they deserve, and the Clinton Administration has shown real responsiveness by reversing its earlier policy."
In January 1994, Mr. Malamud's group, the nonprofit Internet Multicasting Service, posted the full text of filings made by corporations to the Securities and Exchange Commission and several years of the patent data base over the objections of the S.E.C. and the Patent and Trademark Office. His organization later added data bases from the General Services Administration, the Federal Election Commission, the Federal Reserve Board and the Government Printing Office.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Lehman said that it had long been his intention to make both data bases available on the Internet but that he needed first to meet a range of technical and policy criteria.
"Creating a 1.3-terabyte searchable data base is a big technical feat," he said. A terabyte is one trillion characters of information, equivalent to about a million copies of "Moby Dick."
First, he said, such a system requires tight security provisions to isolate it from the Patent and Trademark Office's internal computer network. In addition, he said, his agency had to perform an economic analysis on how the decision would affect both the Patent and Trademark Office and the information industry.
"We have no interest in competing with the private sector," he said, adding that his agency's analysis had shown that the private-sector offers added value beyond the patent and trademark documents.
The new data bases will be available at the Patent and Trademark Office's Web site beginning in August, when trademark text will go on line. Trademark images and patent text will follow in November. Patent images linked to the text of the patents will be made available by March 1999, he said.
The data base of more than two million patents will be searchable by key word, as will more than 800,000 registered trademarks and 300,000 pending trademarks. The entire data base will be made up of 21 million documents.
Currently the Patent and Trademark Office makes abstracts of patents available, a system that is already providing users with more than three million pages of patent material a month.
The Patent and Trademark Office received 237,045 patent applications in the most recent fiscal year -- a 14.9 percent annual increase -- and approved about 114,000 patents. Trademark applications grew by 11.8 percent, to 224,355.
The new data base on the World Wide Web is a significant step forward, Mr. Lehman said, adding that his plan calls for completely automating the nation's patent system by 2003.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's 'Mr. Yen' Will Keep His Post

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 24

 BODY:
Japan's top financial diplomat, Eisuke Sakakibara -- known in some circles as "Mr. Yen" for his ability to sway the currency markets -- has retained his post as Vice Finance Minister for international affairs for another year, the ministry said today.
Speculation had increased lately that Mr. Sakakibara would be replaced in this month's annual Finance Ministry personnel shuffle, but that was before the joint Japanese-American currency intervention last week, in which he played a key role. The intervention at one point strengthened the battered yen by nearly 10 to the dollar. It has since resumed its decline, settling in New York today at 141.25 to the dollar. 
 Mr. Sakakibara had come under criticism from ruling-party and opposition politicians, and even from his boss, Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga, for outspokenness. He was assailed by some in the ruling party for orchestrating a $20 billion Japanese effort in April to prop up the yen, which proved largely ineffective.
Traders said today that Japan needed Mr. Sakakibara to stay in his post at a time of such volatility in the currency.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Lose Early Gains As Note Auction Falls Short

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities lost early gains and ended mixed yesterday, reflecting some disappointment over the results of a Government debt auction and uncertainty about Japanese financial plans.
Traders said market participants were concerned about any further rise in the dollar because that might provoke more central bank intervention to support the yen, as when the United States and Japan bought yen last week and sent the dollar down sharply. The dollar has since retraced much of the loss. 
 The 30-year bond slipped 8/32, to a price of 106 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.66 percent, from 5.64 percent on Tuesday.
In early dealings, Treasuries followed the dollar fairly closely, as the United States currency initially gained strength against the yen, retreated on rumors of Japanese central bank intervention and rebounded on skepticism about Japan's ability to solve its financial problems.
Bonds also derived some early strength from the Government's monthly report yesterday on production of long-lasting goods, which showed a sharp decline in May. The report suggested that the crisis in Asia was slowing economic growth, which tends to help the bond market because it diminishes the possibility of higher inflation.
But bonds began to weaken after the Treasury's $11 billion five-year note auction was seen as a little below average, with the notes awarded at a price to yield 5.454 percent, less than the 5.47 percent dealers had anticipated. The results suggested softer demand than expected for new Treasury debt.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Telecommuncations Issues Send the Dow Up by 95.41

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The stock market rose sharply yesterday on the strength of demand for shares in telecommunications equipment makers and cable companies after the AT&T Corporation agreed to buy Tele-Communications Inc.
The transaction raised expectations that the demand for such equipment will surge in the consolidation of the telecommunications industry. 
 "Telephone, Internet and broadband services will be through bigger 'pipes' that TCI is rolling out," said John Golden, an analyst for telecommunications and computer-related stocks at John Hancock Funds, which oversees about $35 billion. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 95.41 points, or 1.1 percent, to 8,923.87, bringing its gain since Monday to 212 points.
The increase came even as AT&T, one of the 30 Dow stocks, dropped 5 3/8, to 60, its biggest loss since Oct. 27, after warning that the TCI acquisition will hurt its earnings for three years.
The Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 13.39, or 1.2 percent, to a record 1,132.88. The Nasdaq composite index, loaded with telecommunications equipment stocks, rose 33.19, or 1.8 percent, to 1,877.76.
Volume on the Big Board totaled 715 million shares, above the three-month daily average of 607 million.
TCI rose 1 1/16, to 39 3/4, in trading of almost 45 million shares, making it the most active issue on United States exchanges.
Other cable stocks also rallied. The Cablevision Systems Corporation jumped 14, to 76; Time Warner Inc. rose 5 1/8, to 88, and Adelphia Communications Corporation gained 4, to 33 3/4.
Among telecommunications equipment makers, ADC Telecommunications rose 3, to 35 5/8; Scientific-Atlanta Inc. rose 2 1/8, to 24 1/16; Tellabs Inc. gained 4, to 73 3/8, and the General Instrument Corporation, a maker of digital cable boxes, jumped 2 15/16, to 26 1/8. Northern Telecom rose 2 5/16, to 56 1/16. Lucent rose 1 5/8, to 80 1/8.
"You're seeing a convergence among a number of industries as everybody competes to be the full-service providers to the consumer -- long distance, local, cellular and data," said Rick White, who manages $2.5 billion for Salomon Brothers Asset Management Inc. in New York.
As companies broaden their offerings, he added, "they're engaging in an arms war, where the telecom equipment makers are the guys that are peddling the arms."
All the regional Bells fell on the prospect of AT&T's assault on their local telephone market via TCI's cable lines. Bell Atlantic Corporation dropped 5 7/8, to 92 1/2; SBC Communications Inc. fell 1 1/2, to 39 3/4; the Ameritech Corporation lost 2 3/8, to 42 1/2; the BellSouth Corporation fell 2 1/2, to 67, and U S West Inc. dropped 1 5/8, to 48 11/16.
The Microsoft Corporation rallied for a ninth day, bringing its gain for that period to 23 percent. The No. 1 maker of personal computer software, which won an important appeals court ruling Tuesday in the Government's antitrust case, brings out its Windows 98 operating system today. Shares rose 4 3/16, to a record 104 15/16.

HEADLINE: G.M. Calls Strikes Illegal and Threatens Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 24

 BODY:
General Motors said today that two strikes in Michigan that have crippled its car and truck production were illegal, taking an unusually hard stance against its national union over local walkouts.
The company said in a statement that it would seek to take the United Automobile Workers to expedited arbitration and wanted a response from the union within 48 hours. The company also plans to block payments of unemployment benefits to idled workers. G.M. tried a similar tactic in a 1996 strike in Dayton, Ohio, but almost all states granted unemployment benefits. 
 "We should not have to support a strike against ourselves," said Gerald A. Knechtel, vice president of G.M. in charge of personnel for the company's North American operations. "We will vigorously pursue this action in all of the states in which we have affected operations."
The company's latest stance was communicated in a letter to Richard Shoemaker, the union's point man in negotiations with G.M., and was disclosed as U.A.W. leaders at a convention here continued to forecast a long summer of heated labor battles with the company.
Mr. Shoemaker said today that the letter accused union negotiators of thwarting management efforts to settle the local issues that set off strikes by 9,200 workers at two factories in Flint, Mich., and also accused them of essentially waging a national strike. The strikes have idled more than 140,000 workers.
Mr. Shoemaker dismissed the letter's accusations as "theatrics."
"Steve and I met with Jack Smith and other G.M. executives," he said in an interview. "If their charges were valid, that would have been the time to bring them up, not while we're trying to have serious negotiations. Someday they're going to have to start taking this strike seriously and begin to work toward a solution instead of wasting time twisting perception."
The U.A.W. has maintained that its members are on a strike because of hundreds of health and safety grievances, including hazardous leaking fluids and dangerous noise levels, issues that U.A.W. locals are allowed to strike over. But many striking workers have openly focused their anger at a series of broken commitments concerning investment at the plants. The two sides will have to meet with an arbitrator before going before a judge.
Mr. Shoemaker said he saw little chance that the letter would end the work stoppage or deter future strikes by union locals in Dayton, Indianapolis and at a Flint car factory scheduled to be closed next year. A strike at the brake factories in Dayton alone would cripple G.M., just as one did for 17 days in 1996. And all the local skirmishes could ignite an even larger showdown during next year's national contract talks with G.M.
In his statement, Mr. Knechtel of G.M. said, "Our contention is that the strikeable issues identified by the union are contrived and that the real issues that led to these costly disputes are ones that the unions have agreed to be nonstrikeable issues."
Frank W. Buck, a Cleveland lawyer who represents the management of many auto parts companies during labor disputes, said that G.M. could seek a court injunction demanding that the union return to work or even ask that the U.A.W. cover G.M.'s losses during the strike, which analysts estimate at close to $1 billion. "It's pressure General Motors can bring to bear," he said. But Federal laws limit when courts can intervene in labor disputes, making it likely that G.M.'s latest action is aimed mainly at forcing a settlement with the union.
Dale Brickner, professor emeritus of labor and industrial relations at Michigan State University, views the legal fight as a risky strategy for both sides. He said G.M. would have to explain why it was challenging the Flint strikes as a national dispute while it did not do so in more than a dozen similar local strikes over the last three years. The union, meanwhile, would have to prove that its fight was truly based on health and safety issues at the striking plants.
G.M.'s latest action was largely overshadowed here today by the re- election of Stephen P. Yokich to his second and final term as president of the 61-year-old union. Mr. Yokich did not even comment on the letter, though people close to him say it has intensified the union's resolve not to capitulate to G.M., which employs 220,000 of its 750,000 members.
Clearly, the 62-year-old Mr. Yokich has more important issues to deal with regarding the union's future. He wants to be known as the president who expanded the union's power base outside the nation's Big Three auto makers. The U.A.W. has been under pressure for decades to stem a precipitous decline in membership, which has dropped from a peak of 1.5 million in 1979, and to bring small parts shops and foreign auto giants such as Honda, Toyota and Nissan into the U.A.W. fold.
As for G.M., Mr. Yokich has largely left the tedious negotiations to Mr. Shoemaker, a savvy negotiator who has drafted some of the union's most complex agreements. He said further labor strife with G.M. was almost assured because the auto maker was in such a race to expand its global presence that it was disregarding input from workers and overlooking the long-term effects of breaking investment commitments in the United States.
"Globalization is a fact of life, and we recognize that General Motors just like every other auto maker has to be a player in that worldwide market," Mr. Shoemaker said. "But that doesn't mean G.M. can forget the agreements it's made here in America with local unions. If we can't convince them to address these issues in a rational and honest manner, then these kinds of confrontations will continue."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE AGENDAS -- U.S. Needs Something to Show for Its Policy, While China Wants Some Respect;
For Beijing, the Primary Need Is Recognition as a Major Player

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 24

 BODY:
China would love President Clinton to announce here this week that Taiwan, which China considers a renegade province, will get no more American weapons, that China's application to join the World Trade Organization is near approval and that the economic and military sanctions the United States imposed after the 1989 crackdown on student-led demonstration in Tiananmen Square will be lifted.
In truth, as the leaders here already know, China will get few if any of the policy changes it wants during the state visit that begins on Thursday. 
 And yet, China's leaders and people are ecstatic about the visit, the first by an American President in nine years and one that is already being hailed here as a great step forward in diplomatic relations.
This summit meeting is important to China for both symbolic and practical reasons. Symbolic, because the Chinese clearly feel that, by his very presence, Mr. Clinton, leader of the world's No. 1 economic and military power, will confer new status on China as a major international player.
Practical, because China's leaders are convinced that friendly ties with the United States are crucial to their ambitious goal of creating a more market-oriented and prosperous economy.
What China seeks most right now, one senses here, is not so much the things that get discussed at meetings, like trade or security or even a cave-in on Taiwan. It is, in a word, respect.
The Chinese wear their country's painful history on their sleeves and invariably bring it up in discussions of foreign policy. After the humiliating foreign incursions of the 19th and early 20th century, decades of terrible civil war and then the destructive chaos of Mao's political campaigns, culminating in the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution, China feels it is finally on its feet. Its economy has surged, its leadership is stable and China is more than ready to take what it believes to be its rightful place.
"This visit means that China finally has been noticed by the world," said Xiong Zhiyong, dean of the Foreign Affairs College in Beijing. "The American Administration is recognizing the importance of China."
This is also the first visit by an American President since 1989, and the leaders here hope that it will mark, if not an end to world disapproval of that year's massacre of hundreds of civilians around Tiananmen Square, at least tacit agreement to push the lingering ghosts to the side.
For President Jiang Zemin personally, to again stand beside the American President, following his touted tour of America last year, may cement his stature as a statesman able to take up where the late Deng Xiaoping left off.
At a more practical level, friendly ties with the United States are seen as vital to Beijing's domestic aims.
"The paramount goal of China is to modernize, and to do that we need a durable, peaceful environment," said Yan Xuetong, a foreign policy expert at the Chinese Institute of Contemporary International Relations. "If we get on bad terms with the United States, we'll never get the right environment."
China has embarked on two major, precarious transitions, said Jia Qingguo, a professor of international studies at Beijing University: a shift in politics from personal, charismatic leadership toward more bureaucratic and technocratic rule and a shift in the economy from rigid socialism toward a market economy.
"We need stability to carry out these reforms," Mr. Jia said. "And we need all the support we can get to help China through this difficult period."
Many Chinese scholars said that while the outside pressures and criticisms that come with deeper contacts will be controversial here, China badly needs more foreign trade, more foreign investment, more advanced technologies as well as more cooperation in developing energy sources, fighting air and water pollution and other technical areas. For all these things, leaders here believe, the United States is the primary source.
China, though its military power is growing, wants to avoid costly confrontations in Asia. It has an almost willful naivete about the fear its rising military capability inspires among its neighbors. China, despite its past support for Pakistan, is working with the United States to contain a nuclear arms race in South Asia and peacefully resolve tensions on the Korean peninsula. It is also wary of the recently affirmed Japanese-United States security alliance and suggestions that even Japan could support the defense of Taiwan in a crisis.
Taiwan, as officials here never tire of saying, remains the "core issue" in Chinese-American relations. There seems little doubt here that in the event of a serious step toward independence by Taiwan, China would risk all its gains by resorting to military force if necessary, possibly forcing America's hand in turn.
But many Chinese foreign policy experts also recognize that Mr. Clinton has little political space to maneuver on Taiwan. So long as he strongly reiterates American support for "one China," the Chinese leaders seem ready to let the matter ride for now, though they maintain the right to use force and harshly criticize American sales of advanced weapons to Taiwan. They also know that closer Chinese-American ties implicitly pressure Taiwan to tread carefully in any moves toward formal independence.
The post-1989 sanctions barring American government export loans and restricting exports of arms and certain high-technology items, such as satellites and advanced computers, definitely rankle Chinese pride and they also impede the high-priority quest for superior technology.
Still, recent comments by Chinese officials on the sanctions have sounded more resigned than angry.
On Monday, the Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, Shi Guangsheng, was asked whether a case-by-case rather than general easing of sanctions would do. "China welcomes any action that will result in the relaxation of export restrictions," he said.
Acceptance into the World Trade Organization, in which all the Western countries and Japan as well as many developing countries set trade rules, has been a prime political and economic goal. .
For now, the Chinese leaders have swallowed their pride as American negotiators declared that the country is far from satisfying requirements for access to China's markets. On Monday, Mr. Shi, instead of lashing out, noted that "we don't have any timetable," and expressed the hope of further progress this week.
Because the Clinton visit, and more generally ties with the United States, have been invested with so much meaning here, some Chinese who know both countries well fear that dangerously unrealistic expectations are being created, with the potential to create a backlash.
A leading Chinese specialist in American affairs, who spoke on condition of anonymity, worried that China underestimates the force and staying power of issues like human rights or the concerns in Washington about transfer of sensitive technologies and possible illegal political donations.
"The most disastrous misperception of the United States is that Americans are purely pragmatic, practical people who only care for money, and don't have strong inner political and spiritual values," the scholar said.
If the two countries can weave mutually advantageous strategic and economic ties, the scholar said many Chinese mistakenly think, then irritating American concerns like human rights or the status of Tibet will recede.
Suisheng Zhao, a Chinese-born political expert at Colby College in Maine, who recently visited Beijing, expressed concern that the Chinese are reading too much into the American relationship -- some businessmen even predict it will boost China's stock market -- and will be in for a rude surprise once things turn sour.
"The weight of this summit is very different on the two sides of the Pacific," Mr. Zhao said.
But Mr. Xiong, the dean of the Foreign Affairs College, felt a more realistic view was spreading -- that more Chinese realize that relations between major powers will have ups and downs, that countries are not all friend or enemy. "We know it won't always go smoothly," he said.

HEADLINE: COMMUNICATIONS GIANT: THE SHAREHOLDERS -- A Hitch in the AT&T-TCI Hitch;
For Shareholders, a New Type of Stock to Behold

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Widows and orphans, hold onto your hats.
As part of the merger between AT&T and Tele-Communications Inc., millions of AT&T shareholders, many of them individual investors who own the stock for its relative safety and high dividend yield, are about to become holders of one of Wall Street's sexiest and most complex inventions, so-called tracking stock. 
 True, AT&T's stock -- which was divided into long-distance and local operating companies in the 1984 breakup and then split three ways more than two years ago to create separate equipment, phone and computer companies -- is no longer held mostly by the proverbial widows and orphans of old. But its shareholders, even the most sophisticated among them, will be puzzling over this latest deal for a while.
What is a tracking stock? It is a security typically issued by a large conglomerate with interests in a wide variety of businesses. Because the security is designed to track a narrow segment of the company's far-flung operations, issuing it is a good way for a company to put a discrete market value on those operations alone. The stocks are likewise bought by investors interested in whatever aspect of the business the stock tracks.
There is a big difference between common stocks and tracking stocks, however. In most cases, ownership of tracking shares does not represent direct ownership of the business's underlying assets, as common stock ownership does. The underlying assets are still owned by the issuing company, but in a tracking stock the issuing company agrees to parcel out the economics of the business, as it were, giving its shareholders a stake in the entire operation while its tracking stockholders can concentrate their bet.
Although tracking stocks have been around for about 15 years, only about 15 companies in the United States have issued them. These companies range from household names such as General Motors, USX and Georgia-Pacific to smaller companies like Seagull Energy, the electronics retailer Circuit City and the Genzyme Corporation, a biotechnology concern.
Why is staid AT&T going the tracking stock route? The heads of both companies are big believers in the concept. John C. Malone, chairman of TCI, has a tracking stock, called Liberty Media Group, that represents the performance of the company's cable programming. And C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chief executive, came from G.M.'s Hughes Electronics division and is comfortable with the idea.
By issuing a tracking stock, AT&T can accomplish objectives generally achieved in a corporate spinoff without incurring any of the negatives, such as having to meet some fairly stringent tax law requirements. To make a spinoff tax-free to shareholders, for instance, the parent company would be prohibited by the Internal Revenue Service from having dealings with the new company once a spinoff had taken place. But the company also gives up some of the advantages of a clean spinoff, which means investors are not likely to place as much value on the tracking stock as they would on a new spinoff owning the same assets.
"People recognize that a tracking stock is not the same as outright ownership, so they do trade at some discount" to what they would have fetched in a spinoff, said Robert Willens, a tax and accounting analyst at Lehman Brothers in New York.
Still, the company gains a lot from issuing a tracking stock. Once a company has issued one, it can count on being able to raise capital at the higher valuations that it expects investors to assign to that particular aspect of the company's business. It can use that money for either acquisitions or capital investments in the operation.
General Motors, for example, was the first company to float a tracking stock. It issued two, one to cover its now-divested Electronic Data Systems subsidiary (so-called "E" shares) and another ("H" shares) to track its Hughes Electronics division. Both were higher-growth businesses than G.M.'s more predominant automotive operations, and so investors were more eager to own them. G.M.'s "H" stock, for example, now trades at around 36 times what Hughes Electronics earned over the last 12 months, while G.M. trades at a price/earnings multiple of 8.
Under the terms of the AT&T merger, the company will offer 0.7757 share of its common stock for each share of TCI Group series A and 0.8533 share of AT&T for each share of TCI's series B stock. AT&T expects to issue 440 million shares in the transaction. The existing TCI tracking stock, in a modified form, will be reissued by AT&T and therefore will remain as a separate, publicly traded security after the merger. Mr. Malone holds a controlling interest in Liberty Media Group.
Although AT&T will acquire title to Liberty Media Group in the deal, it has agreed to pass along all the benefits of ownership to the holders of the tracking stock. If Liberty Media Group were to be sold, for example, all the proceeds would go to its tracking shareholders, none to AT&T. Shareholders of AT&T will not receive shares of Liberty Media Group as part of the merger.
But AT&T didn't stop there. The company will also issue a new tracking stock of its own in the merger. This stock will represent the activities of AT&T Consumer Services, a new subsidiary that will result from the merger. The subsidiary will include AT&T's interests in residential long-distance, wireless and Internet services and TCI's cable and telecommunications businesses. The company expects AT&T Consumer Services to have revenue in 1999 of $33 billion and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of around $7 billion.
Not included in the new AT&T tracking stock will be the products and services AT&T offers to business customers, including Internet access, long-distance and wireless services and high-speed data offerings. These operations are expected to generate revenue in 1999 of at least $29 billion and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $12 billion.
Those who own AT&T common stock will have a claim on both AT&T's business and consumer operations, while the tracking stockholders will trade exclusively in a piece of paper focused on the consumer side of the business. Also excluded from the tracking stock will be the assets of the AT&T network and AT&T's wholesale business, in which the company generates revenue of about $2 billion selling long-distance time on its lines in bulk.
All this makes for one complicated deal. Indeed, confusion surrounding the merger may have contributed to the 8 percent decline in AT&T stock yesterday. Tepid action in TCI Group's shares, up $1.0625, to $39.75, also seemed to indicate investor confusion and doubt about whether or not the deal will go through.
The merger poses two major risks that may contribute to the doubt. One is that Federal regulators will not approve it. Another is that TCI's chairman, Mr. Malone, will change his mind and walk away from the proposed merger as he did five years ago when Bell Atlantic offered almost $17 billion for TCI.
Are tracking stocks riskier than investing in the parent company? Only in the sense that their lack of diversification makes a bet that much more narrowly placed. For example, CMS Energy Group, a gas and electric utility and energy concern in Dearborn, Mich., has a tracking stock, CPG, that reflects the performance of its gas distribution subsidiary. If gas prices plunged, the tracking shares would probably be hurt more than the shares of the more diversified parent.
What about the fact that tracking stocks have no assets underlying them? This has not presented a problem to shareholders because none of the companies that have issued these shares have experienced financial problems.
When can AT&T shareholders expect to get their new tracking shares? That is unclear. According to Mr. Willens, the tax and accounting analyst, tracking stocks are typically issued to shareholders either in the form of a stock dividend alone or combined with an initial public offering of the subsidiary's shares.
Eileen Connolly, an AT&T spokeswoman, said the company had not decided how it would get the Consumer Services tracking stock into investors' hands. "We have said that a portion will be held by the public," she said, "but we have not said how that will be achieved."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE AGENDAS -- U.S. Needs Something to Show for Its Policy, While China Wants Some Respect;
Clinton Needs Ways to Allay Unease in U.S. About Beijing

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: XIAN, China, Thursday, June 25

 BODY:
President Clinton's aerial caravan arrives here today for a visit eagerly sought by his Chinese hosts as long-overdue recognition of China's status as a major global power. But Mr. Clinton leaves behind an America deeply uneasy about the conduct and intentions of a rising China.
In the days leading up to the summit talks, the friction in the relationship has been evident in the two countries' failure to reach agreement on a number of agenda items the United States considers important, including human rights, trade, military cooperation, and a largely symbolic gesture to announce that neither country would aim its nuclear missiles at the other. 
 Aware of these problems, the White House has been trying to make the case that the success of the visit ought to be measured not in the number of agreements reached or documents signed -- they will be relatively few and modest -- but in whether Mr. Clinton and President Jiang Zemin can subtly redefine the relationship between the two nations.
Mr. Clinton's nine-day voyage to China is the longest Presidential visit to a single country since Harry S. Truman attended the Potsdam peace conference in Germany after the end of World War II in Europe. It is the first to China since President Bush was here in 1989.
The President intends to devote the majority of his schedule and his public appearances to addressing China's people, not its leaders. He will visit a small village that has conducted its first open election, attend services at an officially registered Protestant church in Beijing, speak to students at Beijing University, and engage in a round-table discussion with young entrepreneurs in Shanghai. The official part of his schedule is essentially limited to a half day of meetings with Mr. Jiang and two elaborate dinners.
The hope, the President and his advisers say, is to show the American people a dynamic and diverse China that could become the American economy's biggest customer and an important ally in the 21st century.
The message is simple: China is too big to be ignored and the United States-China relationship too important to fail.
"That relationship," Mr. Clinton said in an address 10 days ago outlining the goals for his trip, "will in large measure help to determine whether the new century is one of security, peace and prosperity for the American people."
The President's schedule is also an answer to critics in Congress and elsewhere, who object to the warming of relations with a Government that still jails dissidents, threatens Taiwan, oppresses Tibet, forces abortions and imposes stiff tariffs on American goods and services.
The political goal of the President's journey, as formed by White House strategists, can best be understood as a long defense of his policy of engaging China, which is the focus of investigations on Capitol Hill into political contributions and the possible transfer of American technology to the development of Chinese nuclear missiles.
Thus the visit will be heavily symbolic, beginning with his arrival in Xian, the ancient Chinese capital.
The official welcoming ceremony will be held Saturday morning in Tiananmen Square, a place where the Chinese have celebrated triumph and witnessed tragedy repeatedly over the decades since the Communist revolution of 1949. Mr. Clinton has already come under criticism in the United States for agreeing to appear at the square, the symbol of the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in 1989.
The trip ends in Hong Kong, which Mr. Clinton will portray as the hoped-for future of all China.
The images Mr. Clinton wants his domestic American audience to remember are his contacts with ordinary Chinese -- villagers, students, business people, first-time homeowners, churchgoers.
As Mr. Clinton makes his progress from historic Xian to imperial Beijing to bustling Shanghai to picturesqe Guilin, he will be following the standard tourist itinerary. Each stop has a policy component, but it the risk for the White House is that Americans will see only the pictures and find few concrete benefits to the United States.
"This is a highly risky summit for the President," said David Shambaugh, director of the Sigur Center at George Washington University and a former China policy adviser at the National Security Council and the State Department. "It's the longest trip of his Presidency and he is spending most of it sightseeing."
The White House has tried to win Chinese concessions in some important areas as part of the President's visit. But senior officials said Mr. Clinton left for China with little prospect of agreement on major parts of that agenda.
The White House had hoped that China would sign the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, as Beijing promised to do this spring, when Mr. Clinton chose not to sponsor a resolution condemning China's human rights practices. But President Jiang announced that China would only sign the convention this autumn.
China also has thus far rejected American efforts on Tibet, by refusing the idea of a visit, by an internationally known person or organization, to the young Panchen Lama designated by the Dalai Lama. China has appointed its own Panchen Lama, the second-ranking spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhists. According to Beijing, the 9-year-old boy who was named by the Dalai Lama and his parents are under the state's protection in an unnamed location.
China has also resisted American requests to stop the re-education of monks and nuns in Tibetan monasteries, and has thus far not released any well-known Tibetan prisoners of conscience. Nor has China yet released any of the dissidents on list given to Beijing by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
China has also rejected the idea of any sweeping review of the cases of nearly 2,500 prisoners convicted under a counter-revolutionary offense now scrapped from Chinese law, including some dating from the Tiananmen demonstrations.
And officials in Washington were pessimistic about the possibility of an agreement under which China would stop aiming its nuclear missiles at the United States.
Officially, the White House said there was still hope for the gesture and sent the deputy national security adviser, James B. Steinberg, to China ahead of Mr. Clinton for a last round of talks.
But State Department and Pentagon officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it was unlikely a deal could be reached. China has insisted it would not "detarget" its missiles until the United States pledged not to use nuclear weapons first in a crisis. "We're absolutely deadlocked," one official said.
Against this political backdrop, Mr. Clinton hopes to assuage domestic critics of engagement with the Chinese with frank talk on China's continuing human rights abuses. He will remind China's leaders that attempts to meddle in American politics by secret campaign contributions are illegal and unacceptable. He will praise China for its role in trying to restrain an arms race between India and Pakistan, and press it not to sell missiles to Pakistan. He will urge it to open its markets.
Also on the agenda is the Asian financial crisis, and Mr. Clinton will thank China for not devaluing its currency, a step which might lead to other devaluations and worse financial problems in Asia.
On many of these points the President has come under attack from critics across the political spectrum in the United States, who complain that he is turning a blind eye to Chinese misbehavior in the interest of advancing commercial ties to the world's most populous nation.
"What is his real policy? Engaging them by money?" asked Harry Wu, a Chinese dissident now living in the United States. "Only in giving them money, it means an appeasement policy. If your policy, foreign policy, doesn't contain a moral basis, this is a typical, hypocritical appeasement policy."

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Retreated by 2.6% in May

BYLINE: Bridge News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Orders to United States factories for big-ticket durable goods fell sharply in May as Asia's economic crisis helped to depress orders for transportation- and electronics-related goods.
The Commerce Department reported today that total orders for durable goods fell by 2.6 percent, to $184.305 billion in May, the largest decline in five months. The May decline followed a revised 1.6 percent rise in April, originally reported as a 2.2 percent gain. 
 Economists said that the drop in May durable orders, which was far worse than the seven-tenths of a percent decline expected by economists, confirms that the nation's economy will slow substantially in the second quarter after the very rapid 4.8 percent growth rate in the first quarter.
Weaker exports to Asia combined with an effort by United States businesses to work off excess inventories mean that American manufacturers are seeing fewer orders, economists said.
Kevin Logan, senior economist at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson in New York, said the decline in durable orders in May is "one more piece of evidence that fits with the picture of weakening demand in the manufacturing sector."
The Commerce Department said that the fall in durable orders in May was led by a 3.5 percent plunge in transportation orders. New orders for civilian aircraft, a significant swing factor for durables orders each month, fell 13.3 percent in May, the department said.
In other key categories, new orders for electronic and other electrical equipment fell 6.8 percent in May, the largest decline since September 1997.
Even stripping out the volatile transportation sector, durable goods orders still fell by a sharp 2.3 percent in May, the department said.
"The decline was across the board," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at the Canadian investment firm Nesbitt Burns, a unit of Bank of Montreal. "It certainly was the weakest report so far this year."
Ms. Cooper said the durable goods report suggested that overall growth in the nation's economy could slow to around 2 percent in the second quarter, less than half the first-quarter pace.

HEADLINE: Saks 5th Ave. Is Said to Be Up for Sale

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Saks Fifth Avenue, one of New York's oldest and most esteemed names in retailing, is on the selling block, executives who have been briefed on the effort said yesterday.
The majority owner of the 97-store Saks, Investcorp International, a Bahrain-based investment bank, has richly profited from investing in other luxury retailers like Tiffany and Gucci and selling them. The company has been seeking a similar way to profit from Saks. 
 Retailers tend to fetch one to one and a half times revenue, which would mean Saks could be priced at between $2 billion and $2.5 billion.
Saks was bought by Investcorp in 1990 for $1.6 billion, and the company sold 20 percent of Saks to the public in 1995 for $25 a share, or $425 million. Although the stock soared in its early days of trading, it has since failed to post the kinds of returns that Investcorp enjoyed with Tiffany & Company and the Gucci Group rewarded Investcorp with. Yesterday, shares of Saks closed at $24.8125, down 43.75 cents.
Investcorp has a longstanding practice of acquiring companies, providing capital and other resources for growth and then selling them in the public marketplace or to private investors. But the decision to sell Saks was initiated by the retailer's board, the executives who have been briefed on the matter said. The board has retained outside investment bankers to do the deal.
Saks and Investcorp declined to comment last night.
By many measures, Saks has performed well. The company's earnings rose 95 percent in its last fiscal year, to $55.8 million on sales of $2.2 billion. Sales have been growing at a compound rate of 15.6 percent since 1994. And sales at stores open at least one year, the best measure of a retailer's health, rose 3.8 percent last year. The company has significantly reduced its debt load, which was a terrible drag on it in the early part of the decade. Its most recent quarter was especially stellar.
But it has been stymied by inconsistent sales, especially in its Off Fifth division, its outlet shops, where same-store sales fell 6.5 percent last year. Those weak sales, and a weakness in the market for lower-priced apparel, known as bridge wear, pushed the cost of goods sold up 13.8 percent last year.
What is more, the company is perceived to have a merchandising management weakness, analysts said. Last fall, Rose Marie Bravo, the company's president, resigned to become chief executive officer of Burberrys Worldwide. The company was unable to find an adequate replacement, and instead appointed an executive vice president of merchandising, Jeanne B. Daniel, from Tiffany.
Still, Saks has one of the most famous names in the universe of retailing, and a strong crop of managers, most notably Brian E. Kendrick, the company's chief operating officer, who has earned much respect on Wall Street.
The question, however, is: Is there a retailer left to make the purchase? The industry has consolidated greatly over the last decade, leaving few independent luxury chains looking to grow. Among its competitors, Neiman Marcus, a unit of Harcourt General, is an obvious candidate, as are LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the luxury holding company based in Paris that owns a number of the high-end brands found on the store's floors, and Dickson Poon, which is looking to have a presence in New York.
Both of those companies, however, have been badly hurt by Asia's economic crisis. The closest thing Federated Department Stores has to a Saks is Bloomingdale's, which is still considerably less fancy than Saks, which has courted an even wealthier customer base in the last few years.
Still, retailers are always looking for new ways to gain economies of scale; indeed last year Saks made a bid for Barneys New York, which is operating under Chapter 11 bankrutpcy protection, for $290 million for the company. The offer was rebuffed by Barney's creditors, and Saks later said it would offer no more. LVMH and Dickson Poon also looked at Barneys last year.
Saks was founded in 1867, and as a privately held company operated as a division of Gimbel Brothers Inc., the department store that is now defunct. In September 1924, Horace Saks and Bernard Gimbel opened the landmark Fifth Avenue store, which today accounts for roughly 20 percent of the entire company's sales.
In 1973, Saks & Company was acquired by B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. through its acquisition of Gimbel Brothers. Investcorp bought the company in 1990 from B.A.T.
Today, Saks Holdings, the holding company for the retailer, operates 41 full-line stores, 5 scaled-down stores in smaller cities as well as 8 small stores catering to resort regions. Its off-price store, Off Fifth, is in 43 locations.
In its 131 years, Saks has seen its competitors fade away. In New York City, the retail capital of the world, there is no B. Altman anymore. There is no Bonwit Teller. And Henri Bendel is a shadow of its former self. Saks is in many ways in a rarified class by itself.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
As Yen Slides, U.S. Renews Pressure on Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
A week after the Clinton Administration signed off on a multibillion-dollar intervention in the currency markets to support the Japanese yen, American authorities stepped up pressure on the Japanese Government today to make good on its promises of economic reform and avoid another decline in the yen's value.
"The steps we can take -- currency intervention -- can have an effect, but they can have an effect primarily through what they signal," Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, hours after returning from a trip to Japan and Indonesia. "What is crucial is the pace of action," he said. 
 So far, investors seem to have been unimpressed with the speed of Japan's efforts to clean up $600 billion in bad bank debts, spur the economy and accelerate the deregulation of its financial markets. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told President Clinton last week that he would accelerate those efforts, a promise that led to the joint intervention in the currency markets last Wednesday. That sent the yen's value up sharply, though briefly -- it lingered at a rate around 136 to the dollar for a day or so.
But the yen has slipped ever since, as Japanese leaders reverted to talking about the difficulties inherent in moving quickly. Late today, the yen settled in New York trading at 141.25 to the dollar, compared with 139.15 on Tuesday, and not far below the level when the United States agreed to step in.
Investors appeared to interpret Mr. Summers's comments as suggesting that Washington would not intervene again any time soon. But they have been burned once before: When Mr. Summers's boss, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin, told Congress earlier this month that interventions only worked temporarily, traders saw that as a green light to bet against the Japanese currency. Their rush to sell yen at that time gave Mr. Rubin an opportunity to take the markets by surprise.
Today, Mr. Summers also told the Senate committee he had received additional assurances from Chinese officials that they were "committed to maintain exchange-rate stability," despite growing pressure to devalue their currency, the yuan.
United States officials fear that a devaluation, while intended to keep Chinese exports competitively priced with the goods of other Asian nations, would greatly worsen the Asian financial crisis -- setting off another round of currency devaluations.
President Clinton is expected to raise these matters directly when he meets with Chinese leaders in Beijing this weekend. But already the Administration is praising China for its restraint, and the Chinese are hoping to parlay their resolve not to devalue into some kind of diplomatic advantage.
Mr. Summers said further today that the International Monetary Fund was on the verge of another economic agreement with Indonesia -- its fourth, but the first since President Suharto's resignation. While details of the accord are skimpy, it will enable the I.M.F. to resume aid to Jakarta at a time when economic projections for the country are growing considerably more dire.
The country is suffering what United States officials call a food crisis, with increasing reports of malnutrition in outlying islands, after years in which Indonesia boasted of self-sufficiency in food production. The number of Indonesians living below the poverty line may increase by almost 80 million this year, or nearly 40 percent of the population, the World Bank warned several days ago.
American officials fear that such distress would worsen attacks on ethnic Chinese in Indonesia.
Mr. Summers made an oblique reference to such attacks today. He said that when he met with Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, in Jakarta on Monday, he told him "it is essential that all of Indonesia's people, rich and poor alike, enjoy a sense of security that their homes, their businesses and their futures in the country are secure."
The focus of Mr. Summers's testimony today, though, was on Japan, and he repeated the theme that the Japanese had only a brief "window of opportunity" to act.
But in private, many at the Treasury and the White House are skeptical about how much Japanese leaders will be able to deliver before Prime Minister Hashimoto visits Washington on July 22 -- a visit that is intended in part to keep pressure on Japan and in part to appease it after Mr. Clinton's extended visit to China, which begins in Xian on Thursday.
"The situation in Japan is a source of very considerable concern," Mr. Summers said today. "Growth has turned negative; the banking system is increasingly stressed. While the passage last week of a significant stimulus package is a welcome step, we remain very concerned about Japan's economic and financial situation."
"This is a pivotal moment for Asia and the global economy," he added. The weakness in Japan is now having a clear impact on the other troubled economies in Asia."
