HEADLINE: Paul O'Dwyer, New York's Liberal Battler For Underdogs and Outsiders, Dies at 90

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

 BODY:
Paul O'Dwyer, a spirited liberal voice in New York politics from his immigrant days in the Democratic clubhouse to his glory years as a fiery anti-Vietnam War insurgent, died Tuesday night at his home in Goshen, N.Y. He was 90.
Mr. O'Dwyer had been in failing health from the effects of a stroke and died quietly in his sleep, according to his nephew and law partner, Frank Durkan. 
 To his deathbed, Paul O'Dwyer, a white-maned, fiercely browed advocate, embraced a raft of minority causes, identifying with indigents and immigrants, progressives and underdogs well beyond America -- from the guerrilla fighters for a Jewish home state to the diehard rebels of his beloved Ireland.
Mr. O'Dwyer was an enduring if rarely elected politician who impressed successive generations as an eloquent battler in the name of conscience. Arriving in America at age 18, he labored up from dock work and garment packing to become one of New York's leading defenders of the underclass.
"The ideals should always come first," Mr. O'Dwyer counseled in a long public life steeped in voluntary civil-rights battles and vociferous challenges of the political establishment.
Elected twice to the New York City Council, he seemed more at home in the politics of the outsider. As an Irishman who had lived under British occupation, he heartily joined the ongoing American struggle against prejudice suffered variously by Jews, blacks, women and the very latest immigrant wave.
"Politics is the only machinery around on which you can really straighten things out," he said in his softly unyielding brogue.
A fleet, unapologetic gadfly, Paul was the antithesis of his older brother William, who rose from the police force to become an urbane master of machine politics as Mayor of New York from 1946 until 1950, when scandals shook his administration. The O'Dwyers moved separately on the crest of Irish-American political power before it faded in the city.
Paul O'Dwyer far outlasted his brother "Bill-O" in public life, fighting for the labor movement and embattled immigrants in the 1940's, against McCarthyism and racial segregation in the 50's, and against the Vietnam War in the 60's. In the antiwar movement, he stood as a patriarchal exception in the eyes of young pacifists intent on trusting no one over 30.
 
'We Were Changing This Nation'
An ally of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in the successful antiwar challenge to President Lyndon B. Johnson's renomination in 1968, Mr. O'Dwyer scored an upset victory himself in the New York Democratic Senate primary that year, but lost in the November election to Senator Jacob K. Javits.
"We were taking a country engrossed in an immoral war," he declared afterward, pounding the arm of his chair in celebration of that struggle. "We were changing this nation. By God, we did it. We did do it."
He could make a rampart of a legal brief, too, successfully litigating a landmark 1951 fight against the powerful Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. That suit opened the way for blacks to live in Stuyvesant Town, a huge Manhattan housing complex, and presaged an era of desegregation across the nation.
Mr. O'Dwyer honed his courtroom skills suing insurance companies in negligence cases. But his outside interests were his larger life: He successfully defended Kentucky miners accused of blowing up a bridge in a union dispute, just as he won acquittal of a black teen-ager accused of homicide in a New York City riot in the mid-60's. He sued City Hall to force more budget money into public transit for the working class, just as he defended an unpopular union chief during a city garbage collection strike. In 1958, he joined with Eleanor Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman, the former Governor, to found the Committee for Democratic Voters, the state party reform movement.
But his outspokenness for minority causes helped deny him a mainstream role in politics. As president of the New York chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, Mr. O'Dwyer was denounced as a radical for angrily challenging Red-baiting assaults on civil liberties by politicians who were intent on searching for Communist leanings among teachers and other government workers.
"When you come from the period of, first, the Depression and then the McCarthy era," he explained, "if you survive that, then you're less likely to be cautious expressing yourself."
Paul O'Dwyer was among the first volunteers litigating in Deep South integration struggles. "It was like a present on Christmas morning," he enthused about his participation. He was also gladly troublesome as a delegate to the 1964 Democratic National Convention, leading the fight to see the black Freedom Democratic party of Mississippi represented. Personally close to a generation of black politicians, Mr. O'Dwyer managed the campaigns of several. He was credited by Mayor David N. Dinkins with salvaging his career by coaxing him back into public life after Mr. Dinkins had earlier been forced to resign a city job because of his failure to file income tax returns from 1969 to 1972.
"As a young person, impressionable, I almost forgot who I was, as the Irish often do here," Mr. O'Dwyer once commented on the roots of his desegregation fervor. "Because you are white you think you will be treated equally. I was corrected by my brothers, who were here ahead of me."
He rued the fading of an era when "Irish Catholic" was synonymous with "liberal Democrat," and told the joke about a tenement clubhouse boss scandalized at the news that O'Brien had turned Republican. "That's a damned lie," the boss thundered. "I saw O'Brien at Mass last Sunday."
As a civil libertarian, Mr. O'Dwyer tapped into vivid memories from his Irish childhood of insurrection against British occupation forces. "The Black and Tans used to drive through the town, shooting it up," he said, recalling the rampages of the British auxiliary police. "It wasn't too different from Mississippi."
 
Defended Berrigan And Bricklayers
A florid-faced, articulate bantam, Mr. O'Dwyer successfully argued before the Supreme Court for the right of mainland Puerto Ricans to take their voter literacy test in Spanish. In 1972, he stood in defense of a pacifist group called the Harrisburg Eight, led by the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, and won them a mistrial on charges of an anti-Government plot against the Nixon Administration during the Vietnam War.
No less fervidly did he represent uncelebrated sandhogs, hod carriers and warehouse clerks in formative trade union years when, he recalled, "strikebreaking and union-busting remained widespread and brutal." He carried a union card in Local 975 of the International Longshoremen's Association. In 1968, he declined to cross a wildcat picket line outside a television studio when he was a Senate candidate, telephoning the apoplectic interviewer to explain, "These are my people."
Mr. O'Dwyer accepted the role of the city's Commissioner for the United Nations during the Dinkins administration. But soon he was boycotting the U.N. cafeteria for its anti-unionism, and finally resigned so he could speak out against human rights abuses by some of the nations he was supposed to be welcoming.
Born June 29, 1907, in the village of Bohola, County Mayo, in western Ireland, Peter Paul O'Dwyer was the 11th and last surviving child of Patrick and Bridget McNicholas O'Dwyer. They were schoolteachers who raised their family in Ireland's grim potato economy, packed into a rude house without plumbing. He later endowed a home for the handicapped on his family home site.
"I sprang from the 'shabby genteel,' " he once said with a smile, using Eugene O'Neill's qualification for the striving Irish poor. Paul O'Dwyer counted himself fortunate for the high school education he received before having to follow four older brothers to New York in the age-old immigration of young Irish to opportunity.
He soon picked up on the politics of Jefferson and Paine after finding clannish lodgings in Mrs. Maguire's Irish boarding house at West 103d Street and Columbus Avenue in Manhattan. Landing a paying job within two days -- a touch of clubhouse patronage via brother "Bill-O" -- he moved fast on the classic immigrant's route to betterment through night school, first at Fordham University, then at St. John's Law School in Brooklyn.
So fast did he move that he had to obtain special permission from Chief Judge Benjamin Nathan Cardozo of the New York Court of Appeals to take his bar exam in 1929, four years after arriving from Ireland and two years before he could receive citizenship. In 1931, Paul O'Dwyer became America's newest citizen-lawyer, ringing with the impulses of Thomas Paine. "He sounded simple and logical to my young mind," Mr. O'Dwyer explained.
Anti-Semitism in college fraternities had bonded him to Jewish friends, he recalled in his 1979 autobiography, "Counsel for the Defense." "And the Kings County Young Democratic Club thenceforward was made up of 35 Jewish classmates and me," he noted proudly.
It followed naturally that he was involved in the cause of a Jewish homeland in 1946 by arranging for the illegal entry of Holocaust survivors to Palestine and by aiding the gun-running operations of the Irgun militants fighting the British in the Holy Land. The next year, as chairman of the Lawyers' Committee for Justice in Palestine, he pleaded at the United Nations for Israeli sovereignty.
Successfully defending an admitted Jewish gun-runner in New York in 1948, Mr. O'Dwyer told the court, "He was only doing what every other freedom-loving person would be doing."
As a lawyer, Mr. O'Dwyer became a principal in one of the city's flagship immigrant law firms, O'Dwyer & Bernstien. He began as a clerk to Oscar Bernstien and worked his way to senior partner. From the firm's offices in the financial district, Mr. O'Dwyer helped build the business but found time for assorted challenges to social injustice, typically without fee. He soon was respected as one of the city's sharper-tongued liberals.
"If I thought at the end of the year that all I did was make a living, I'd regard it as a pretty incomplete year," he said of his rich life as an agitator within the system.
"If I've had any success at all, it's been in large measure from listening to young people," said Mr. O'Dwyer, whose eagle-like visage -- a dark-eyed glare and shock of prematurely white hair -- stood out in the thick of any battle.
 
Leading a Welcome For Gerry Adams
Even in decline he stayed keen for political justice. In 1994, he beamed from a wheelchair and led the welcoming cheers when Gerry Adams, the Northern Irish republican political leader, was finally allowed into the United States to plead his grievance against Britain. Mr. O'Dwyer was the national coordinator for the American League for an Undivided Ireland.
He ran 12 times for elective office in campaigns noteworthy for threadbare war chests and left-liberal agendas, daring to call for decriminalizing drug addiction in one. His two successes were in 1963, as Councilman at Large in Manhattan, and 1973, as City Council President, a post in which he made sure to alter the city's official founding date from 1664, when the British landed, to 1625, when Dutch settlers arrived. In six total years in office, he instigated numerous causes, including an uphill battle in 1965 to raise the city's minimum wage to $1.50 an hour.
Mr. O'Dwyer's abiding comfort was in the good fight. Losing to Carol Bellamy in a 1977 bid to remain Council President, he said, "I fought for a lot of civil rights 25, 35 years ago, including women's rights, and I'm in poor shape to complain if I find myself in the way of the machinery that I myself helped set in motion."
He offered a decidedly Irish smile of bemusement when critics focused on his antiwar activity and tried to dismiss him as a single-issue politician.
"The one issue is fair play over the period of a lifetime," Mr. O'Dwyer amended.
His wife of 45 years, the former Kathleen Rohan, died in 1980. In 1984 he married Patricia Hanrahan, then the upstate chief of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's women's division. She survives him, along with four children from his first marriage: William, of Albany; Rory, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Brian, of Manhattan, and Eileen O'Dwyer Hughes of New York. He had eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
Mr. O'Dwyer long tried to persuade his wife, Patricia, to restake the family flag in elective politics. She finally agreed this year, and he lived to see her running for the 95th State Assembly District in Orange County, true to his favorite line of Yeats:
That I may seem, though I die old,
A foolish, passionate man.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Paul O'Dwyer, top, was known for his leonine face and equally ferocious advocacy for the underprivileged and hated. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times, 1976); His brother William, above right with Paul in 1957, was Mayor of New York from 1946 to 1950.

HEADLINE: Democrats in China

 BODY:
We would feel more confident about the lasting value of President Clinton's trip to China, which begins today, if we knew that someone had included among his briefing papers a summary of Ronald Reagan's extraordinary visit to the Soviet Union in 1988. Mr. Reagan used that trip to meet with prominent dissidents and speak directly to Soviet audiences about fundamental freedoms and the advantages of democracy, and there was little that his host, Mikhail Gorbachev, could do about it but grumble. Mr. Reagan knew that one of the important powers of a traveling President is the right to speak plainly in lands unaccustomed to open debate. Bill Clinton has the same luxury. The cause of human rights will be poorer if he squanders it.
Mr. Clinton's aides have said he will address the issue in some way, and there is no shortage of promising venues. His itinerary includes a small village that has just conducted its first open election, an ecumenical church and a classroom at Beijing University. But there is one obvious setting in which Mr. Clinton can seize the moment, politely but firmly, to assert American values. That is Tiananmen Square, which he will visit on Saturday, and where hundreds of peaceful pro-democracy demonstrators were slaughtered on June 4, 1989. 
 The Chinese, of course, prefer to see Mr. Clinton's visit to Tiananmen Square not as a reminder of that tragedy but as a form of closure, a way of saying farewell to a relationship strained by that memory and moving quickly to the "constructive strategic partnership" celebrated in last fall's meeting in Washington between Mr. Clinton and China's President, Jiang Zemin. But why accept Beijing's definition of what the Tiananmen visit means? More than 700 people were arrested there nine years ago, and many are still in prison. Mr. Clinton can honor their memory by describing their sacrifice as a reminder of how much further China and its leaders must travel.
This is one of the points the President's Republican critics have been trying to make on Capitol Hill. On Tuesday they tried unsuccessfully to ram through a series of amendments that, among other things, would have denied visas to Chinese officials involved in religious persecution or forced abortions, and put new restrictions on some forms of economic aid to Beijing. Senate Democrats said the entire exercise was an attempt to embarrass the President. "I'm not going to allow one single vote on China this week," said Senator Thomas Daschle, the Democratic leader. But there are also plenty of liberal Democrats who believe that in pursuing his policy of engagement Mr. Clinton has looked squishy on human rights.
Of course China cannot be viewed through a single lens, and of course there will be other important issues on the President's agenda in the next nine days. But the Chinese leadership has already profited greatly from his visit. His very presence is an affirmation of Beijing's growing power. The Chinese are certainly strong enough to hear straight talk on American values and a Presidential statement of solidarity with the democrats in Chinese society. A show of Presidential will would not disrupt the trip. It might even make it memorable.

HEADLINE: Voracious Computers Are Siphoning Talent From Academia

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
The high-tech field, the fastest growing of the nation's economy, has become so voracious in its hiring that computer science departments across the country are losing graduate students and, in growing numbers, undergraduates to an industry fueled by vast sums of money.
While the evidence is still anecdotal, universities report that faculty positions in computer science are going unfilled and doctoral programs have seen a big drop-off in applications. Moreover, students working toward master and bachelor degrees are increasingly abandoning their studies for well-paying jobs in a field whose wealthy stars, like Bill Gates, famously dropped out of college. 
 As a result, many experts fear that fundamental research will decline and that the next generation of American computer scientists will be stunted.
"I'm afraid we're eating our seed corn," said Peter J. Denning, vice provost of George Mason University in Virginia.
For many young people, a job paying $30,000 to $60,000 a year seems far more appealing than pursuing a degree whose value is unclear.
"A degree is just a piece of paper with a gold stamp on it," said Jonah Blossom, 20, who left Santa Barbara City College after one year to take a full-time $30,000-a-year job as an on-line computer specialist at a nearby concern where some of his bosses and colleagues did not finish their studies. "That paper isn't going to help you find bugs in a system or create compelling Web sites. That depends on your ability. My employers are not interested in certificates or where I've been to school."
While other academic fields over the years have witnessed shifts in talent away from universities -- it happened in biotechnology in the 1980's -- there is no precedent to what is happening today in computers both in the scale and in the challenge it poses to the discipline. It is as if every college student with any athletic ability suddenly faced the realistic prospect of a career with a professional sports team.
"Without wanting to sound hysterical, this is really changing the shape of education in a fundamental way," said Guy Smith, who runs the multimedia laboratory at Santa Barbara City College. "You hear of kids leaving high school and making almost six figures. Recently we brought in 30 computer information officers and asked them about entry-level skills. I didn't hear the word 'degree' come up very often."
Joseph A. Liemandt dropped out of Stanford University after his junior year and founded the Trilogy Development Group, a hugely successful software marketing company in Austin, Tex., in 1989. Mr. Liemandt says his company, like many others, simply does not care about an applicant's university credentials.
"If we interview two people and one has a 4.0 from M.I.T. in computer science and doesn't impress us in the interview," Mr. Liemandt said, "and the other dropped out of some small college and impressed us, we'd always hire the second guy.
"I personally didn't learn anything in college classes. And when I hear people talking about taking two years to earn an M.B.A., I remind them that there are companies that went from zero to $70 million in two years. Take your pick. A lot of people come to work for us because they want to start their own companies and figure two years with us are better than an M.B.A."
Computer science professors, in something of a state of shock, are sharply divided over what is happening and over how to respond.
Most are warning that when the overheated market for programmers and Web-site designers cools or shifts in emphasis, those who have left their studies will be, in essence, laid-off blue-collar workers without credentials, like telephone operators after digital switching or auto workers after robotics.
"Our message is, 'Make sure you aim to get yourself a career and not just a first job,' " said Ellen F. Hartigan, vice president of student affairs at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, who says her students are being recruited to leave for full-time jobs before getting their degrees.
"Many of our students are the first generation in their family to go to college and they don't have the parental support that encourages them to stay on and finish and go to graduate school," Ms. Hartigan said. "These offers are very tempting. So we are now much more pro-active, teaching freshmen about career preparation."
At Florida Institute of Technology in Melbourne, Richard Newman, associate dean of engineering, says his institution is trying to compromise with corporate raiders by urging cooperative ventures whereby the companies pay for students to complete their studies while they work.
"We even had two or three freshmen go off to take jobs setting up Web pages," Mr. Newman said. "We're trying to find a solution to end the competition between us and industry."
But some computer experts say universities have failed to keep computer science curriculums up to date.
"Universities have done such a bad job of providing what you need to know that a B.A. in computer science is almost considered worthless," said Allen Holub, an author and computer design consultant in San Francisco. "Many tenured professors came out of math departments. Mathematicians make lousy programmers. They focus on algorithms, which are the underlying rules of some programs. But the vast majority of programs today are not algorithm based but data based."
Kenneth E. Martin, a professor of computer and information sciences at the University of North Florida in Jacksonville, and a member of the Computing Sciences Accreditation Board, acknowledges that the gap between theory and practice has grown dangerously large.
This is partly because of the growth of sophisticated new computer languages, like Java, with which programmers can draw on a pre-packaged set of formulas and tools and simply plug them in, without a need for understanding the underlying theory of computer language.
"Curriculums are going to have to change." Professor Martin said. "There is no question about it. Right now, we can't compete. You can legitimately ask whether what we teach is as important as it used to be.
"Today, it is more of a hacker's world, and it is less obvious that students need to know the fundamentals to function at a high level. With the arrival of Java, they don't program in the same way as in older languages.
"After a semester learning Java, a student can already do an incredible amount. My colleagues see their former students with a B.S. and stock options. Maybe that's better than an M.S."
The existence of well-paid, creative work without full academic credentials in an exciting field is the result of both economic and cultural factors. The American computer industry is exploding. The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that the need for systems analysts, engineers and computer scientists will more than double from now until 2006.
Today there are an estimated 933,000 jobs in these fields; by 2006, the bureau estimates that number will rise to 1.9 million. Yet the nation's computer science programs are only graduating 25,000 students with bachelors' degrees yearly.
This projected gap is borne out by the experience of those in career services.
"If every one of the 1,600 students graduating this year from Northeastern were computer majors, they would all have jobs," said Carol S. Lyons, dean of career services at Northeastern University in Boston. "We're seeing signing bonuses of $7,000 to $9,000, relocation offers, stock options and starting salaries in the high 30's to low 50's."
Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh reports that applications to its graduate program in computer science dropped to about 500 this year, from a high of about 900 just a few years ago. And the size of the graduate program at California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo has declined to about 40 from 60 in the last few years.
Avram Cheaney, 22, who grew up in West Virginia, quit Carnegie-Mellon and moved to Silicon Valley in California several months ago. He posted his resume on the Internet through a temporary computer employment agency and received 25 calls. Today he earns $40 an hour.
"I feel like I can work anywhere," Mr. Cheaney said. "Any company that has computers needs people, and with my experience, I am light-years ahead of many people still in school. Two years' experience is all that is needed. You can't say, 'I've been a Web-page designer for 10 years' because the field hasn't been around that long. The younger generation can get a jump on things."
Another attraction is the anti-conventional nature of an industry, many of whose giants -- Steven P. Jobs and Stephen Wozniak, the founders of Apple computers, in addition to Mr. Gates, -- are college dropouts. Job opportunities at computer companies often emphasize loose dress codes and strange hours as well as the financial possibilities.
Here, for example, is how Trilogy, the Austin software company, describes its "company culture" on its Web site:
"What matters at Trilogy? Results, results, results. The focus is not on how many meetings you attend or that you show up for work at 7 in the morning every day. What's more important is the value you add to Trilogy and the experience you bring. As for work hours, Trilogy believes in flexibility. It makes the most sense that people work when they are most productive, and only you know when that is."
It says that some employees dress fancy for work because they want to while others "wear a clean T-shirt and shoes when they want to dress up," adding: "Some work from 5 A.M. to 5 P.M., others don't believe in the cruel and unusual abuse of alarm clocks and never show their faces before lunch time." There is further talk of huge bonuses and "company boats, spontaneous trips to Las Vegas, nights out on the town, trips to Hawaii, fully stocked kitchens."
Employers say there are distinct advantages to younger people. They have enormous energy, are willing to work long hours and still consider working all night an adventure. But others say they prefer to hire people who have finished college, both because their minds are more trained and disciplined and because it is better for them to get their degrees.
"We want to use their talents and be respectful of their education," said Dawn Legg, director of operations at Dega Technologies in San Luis Obispo, Calif., a start-up company whose Web master is 18 years old. "At the same time, we have a business to run."
Many of those who left college to take jobs say they want to go back to school, either part time soon or full time later, both for the sake of long-term job security and for the satisfaction of having completed their degrees. But their elders worry that by the time those former students feel the need to return, it will be too late.
James L. Beug, chairman of computer sciences at California Polytechnic, put it this way: "I have students from 10 years ago saying, 'Oh, Jim, my company just folded and I don't have my degree to make a new job search.' Meanwhile, our curriculum has changed vastly from 10 years ago.
"My fear is that these kids who haven't finished will last about seven years on the job market. If they haven't learned to learn and can't go sideways into management, what happens to them?"

HEADLINE: White House Revises Policy On Contracts for Minorities

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The White House today announced a new affirmative-action policy under which minority-owned businesses will be given an advantage when they compete for Government contracts in industries where surveys show they are underrepresented but not in industries where they seem to have a fair share of the market.
What this means, for example, is that companies controlled by blacks will get a leg up in trucking contracts with the Government but not in food manufacturing. 
 In the case of construction, a preference will be given to minority contractors in some regions of the country, where surveys show that their share of the Government's business is smaller than could be expected, but not in other parts of the country.
All told, affirmative action will be employed in industries representing about three-quarters of the money the Government spends on procurement contracts with small businesses, the White House said.
The policy was devised to meet the terms of a Supreme Court decision in 1995 that strictly limited the justification and scope of Government programs that grant preferences based on race or sex.
In a statement issued by the White House shortly after he left for China, President Clinton said that the new rules "continue my promise to mend, not end affirmative action."
The approach, he added, "satisfies constitutional requirements while targeting our efforts in areas where disparities still exist."
Opponents of affirmative action challenged the new policy. Abigail Thernstrom, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute and one of the most outspoken academic critics of racial preferences, called the policy "old wine in new bottles."
"Counting heads is a bad way of measuring discrimination," Ms. Thernstrom said.
Representative Charles T. Canady, a Florida Republican who is the sponsor of legislation to end racial preferences in Government programs, said that under the new policy "decisions will still be made on the basis of ethnic background" and that "classifications based on race are inherently harmful."
Many supporters of affirmative action were pleased. Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat who heads the Congressional Black Caucus, said the new policy will "provide opportunities for qualified minority businesses to compete openly and fairly for Federal Government contracting opportunities."
But Wade Henderson, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, which lobbies for the interests of members of minorities, called the policy "at best a mixed bag."
Mr. Henderson said he was afraid it will "mean a loss of business for some women and minority-owned firms."
The Administration has defended the principle of affirmative action in Congress and the courts. But since the 1995 Supreme Court ruling, it has curtailed or cut back many of the dozens of programs throughout the Government involving racial preferences.
For example, all programs were ended in which a specific sum of money or percentage of contracts was set aside for minority-owned companies. In addition, programs designed to help members of minorities and women win contracts from the Federal Highway Administration, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency have been reduced in scale. So have programs to increase the number of minority teachers, scientists and Foreign Service officers.
But until now, there has not been a Government-wide policy on how to handle procurement contracts.
In the Supreme Court's decision, in which it voted 5 to 4 in a case called Adarand Constructors v. Pena, it held that Government programs that extended advantages to members of minorities had to serve a "compelling national interest" and be "narrowly tailored" to address the effects of discrimination.
The policy announced today applies to what the Government calls "small disadvantaged businesses" and affects every Government procurement contract for which there is open bidding. It does not need to be approved by Congress. It will go into effect in stages between now and Jan. 1.
Businesses owned by American Indians and Americans who are black, Hispanic or Asian are presumed to be disadvantaged. Those owned by whites, including women, fit the standard only if they can show through a "preponderance of the evidence" that they are socially and economically disadvantaged.
Businesses that are considered disadvantaged and bid for contracts in particular industries will be entitled to a 10 percent price break. That means that they will be the low bidder if their price is within 10 percent of the low bid filed by a business that is not disadvantaged.
To determine where discrimination exists, the Government evaluated more than 70 industries. The survey compared in the fiscal year 1996 the value of contracts in each industry that went to disadvantaged businesses, called utilization, with what it called the capacity of such companies to perform the contracts.
Capacity was based on such factors as the age and size of the companies and was meant to show the value of contracts that would go to disadvantaged businesses if everything else was equal.
The method was called benchmarking.
Under the policy, the 10 percent price break will be allowed only in industries where the value of contracts let in the year studied was well below the capacity of disadvantaged businesses.
For instance, affirmative action will be allowed in textile mill products, where 2.2 percent of the money went to disadvantaged businesses but the capacity was said to be 8.3 percent. It will also be allowed in oil and gas extraction, where utilization was 9.7 percent and capacity 13.8 percent, and in trucking, where utilization was 21.4 percent and capacity was 35.4 percent.
But affirmative action will not be allowed in food manufacturing, where 10.4 percent of the value of contracts went to disadvantaged businesses and the capacity was said to be 8.3 percent. Other examples of industries where the price break will not be permitted are forestry and fishing, with 25.2 percent utilization and 18.6 percent capacity, and agriculture, 41.5 percent utilization and 29.9 percent capacity.
The White House said that in most industries a nationwide survey was sufficient. But in the case of construction contracts, the country was broken down into nine regions because of the disparity in hiring in different areas.
Affirmative action will be practiced for general contractors in the Middle Atlantic States, where the survey found that only 13.6 percent of Government contract money went to disadvantaged contractors, while the capacity was 18 percent. But it will not apply in construction contracts with general contractors in the Pacific States, where utilization was 29.4 percent and capacity was 27.1 percent.
The White House promised to keep updating the survey.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
OPEC Reaches New Deal to Cut Oil Production

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: VIENNA, June 24

 BODY:
Overcoming a serious political dispute that split the Iranian delegation and threatened the final agreement, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced late today that it planned to reduce its oil production by more than 1.3 million barrels a day, or nearly 5 percent, in the latest attempt to push up prices.
The 11 members of OPEC and other producers have been facing a severe crisis since oil prices began a sharp decline in November, falling below $12 a barrel last week to the lowest level in more than a decade. Two earlier moves to reduce production, including sharp cutbacks pledged in March, have largely failed to keep prices from dropping. 
 The much-anticipated agreement was announced here at the meeting of OPEC oil ministers near the close of the commodity markets in New York today. The dispute among the Iranians had sent oil prices dropping during the day, wiping out an early rally in European markets after reports that a deal was imminent. But prices ended little changed, with crude oil for August delivery settling up 8 cents, at $14.60 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The Iranian split, as well as OPEC's reputation for being unable to maintain production cutbacks, left some experts questioning how long the agreement would hold. "It is a fragile agreement by its very nature, as it depends on the pledge of each country to cut its production," said Fadhil al-Chalabi, a former OPEC under secretary. He added that some countries might again be tempted to increase production if prices rise.
The deal was nearly scuttled early this evening, shortly before it was first to have been announced, when the Iranian oil minister, Bijan Namdar-Zanganeh, who represents the moderate views of President Mohammed Khatami, engaged in a public dispute with Kazempour Ardebili, a senior figure in the Iranian leadership who tends to reflect the views of the Revolutionary Guards and other hard-liners.
The two officials argued loudly over who had the authority to speak for Iran during the final negotiations over the production accord. Several OPEC oil ministers who attended that meeting said privately afterward that they feared the dispute would deflate any rally in oil prices the agreement might otherwise have brought.
At one point during the session, according to several officials who were present, Nigeria's oil minister, Dan Etete, raised his walking stick in anger at the two Iranians, proclaiming, "This is no way to do business."
In the end, the Iranians and several oil ministers stormed out of the closed-door meeting, and OPEC was forced to delay the announcement of the agreement.
"When a senior member of the Iranian delegation disagrees with his minister publicly, it poses a big question mark about what is happening there," a senior Arab delegate said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "Can you imagine what it would be like if in our delegation the minister and the deputy minister argued over who speaks for the country?"
But other officials said there were some benefits from bringing the Iranian dispute out into the open. "It is good that a misunderstanding has been aired here because last time when we here in March, we left with two different Iranian interpretations of a deal," said Nordine Ait Laoussine, Algeria's former oil minister, who is a senior adviser to his country's OPEC delegation. "This time, we are all clear as to where Iran stands."
By agreeing this time to cut their daily output by 1.3 million barrels, the 11 members of OPEC have pledged since March to remove a daily total of about 2.6 million barrels from the market.
If OPEC, which controls about 40 percent of the world's oil production, can live up to those commitments, it could significantly reduce the excess supplies of crude oil that have sent prices plunging. But too often, oil producers both in and outside OPEC have failed to meet all their pledges.
Late in March, for instance, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, with Mexico helping as intermediary, led a coalition of oil exporters that agreed to cut oil output by 1.7 million barrels a day. But fewer than one million barrels are estimated to have actually been taken out of production, and oil prices, which initially rallied, resumed their decline.
Earlier this month, a number of these countries agreed to cut a further total of 740,000 barrels, starting on July 1.
The production cutbacks announced by OPEC today will expand on the reductions planned for July 1 by more than 600,000 barrels a day.
The biggest sacrifice in production is to come from Saudi Arabia, which plans to reduce its output by 425,000 barrels daily. Venezuela promised to cut its oil output by 325,000 barrels, and the United Arab Emirates by 100,000 barrels a day.
After much negotiation, Iran agreed to lower its production by 65,000 barrels a day instead of OPEC's request for a 95,000-barrel cutback. Mr. Ardebili, who is an adviser to Iran's Foreign Minister and the oil minister as well as Iran's governor on the OPEC board, insisted on the smaller cut, saying this quantity was what the Government had authorized. But Mr. Namdar-Zanganeh, the Iranian oil minister, said he would agree to a larger cut.
A senior Arab official said the differences in these Iranian positions reflected concerns over the rising production of oil by Iraq, Iran's rival and its wartime enemy in the 1980's. Over the last year, the Iraqi Government of President Saddam Hussein has raised its production of oil with United Nations permission to 2.2 million barrels a day, of which it exports 1.7 million barrels, crowding Iranian and Saudi sales.
It does so under an oil-for-food agreement worked out with the United Nations, and if its production should continue to expand, the Iraqis might reclaim their old position as OPEC's second-largest oil producer after Saudi Arabia, passing the Iranians.
For that reason, the hard-liners in Teheran have insisted on giving as little as possible. But President Khatami's Government, which is eager to improve ties with the rest of the world, has insisted on more cooperation. Both tendencies are represented in Iran's OPEC delegation.
A number of non-OPEC countries that attended the meeting as observers, including representatives of Mexico, Russia, Norway and Oman, have made some production cuts themselves.
Mexico, which reduced its output by 100,000 barrels a day at the beginning of April, plans to cut another 100,000 in July.
But Norway, which has cut 100,000 barrels a day, has no plans for further reductions. Russia pledged reductions this year of 80,000 barrels daily, and Oman offered a 50,000- barrel-a-day cut.
OPEC officials acknowledged that it would take a while for the market to verify that these pledges had been carried out.
And, there is concern here that the Asian economic crisis, which has removed about one million barrels a day in demand, could grow worse, making further production cuts necessary.

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts Won't End Japan's Woes

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your June 20 editorial "Time for Action in Japan" spoke to the need for aggressive tax cuts, ostensibly to stimulate domestic spending. This would militate against the tendency for Japan to export its way out of recession, at the expense of its beleaguered Asian neighbors. 
 Unfortunately, cultural inclinations, an aging population and availability of foreign investment would probably push most of any reasonable increase in family income into savings, not spending. Furthermore, most middle-class Japanese are saturated with consumer goods. An important reason is that they simply don't have the space to house more.
The land on which to build larger, affordable housing around Japan's cities exists. However, its cost has been out of sight because the Government pays part-time farmers to grow rice or fruit or raise a few head of cattle on tiny plots. We need to press Japan to do whatever is necessary to create affordable housing for its citizens.
 
RONALD D. OLSEN
Sanibel, Fla., June 20, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 163 words

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts Won't End Japan's Woes

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Time for Action in Japan" (editorial, June 20): Some Administration officials' reading of Japan's economic policy -- that the country's hidden strategy is to let the yen fall, making Japanese goods less expensive in the United States -- ignores a fundamental problem facing Japan. The country depends on imports for nearly all natural resources. 
 Oil, essential for Japan's survival, will cost more if the yen is weak. The same is true of food, for which Japan depends on imports.
If a weaker yen continues, it will hit ordinary Japanese as inflation. Japanese leaders know inflation is more fearful than recession, for it is the one thing that could destabilize the country. What politicians and economists alike need to worry about is what is to be done when the world's second-largest economy is destabilized.
 
MICHIKO Y. AOKI
Worcester, Mass., June 20, 1998
 
The writer is an associate professor of Japanese at Clark University.

HEADLINE: House Votes to Block F.D.A. On Approval of Abortion Pill

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
In an affirmation of its anti-abortion stance, the House voted today to block the Food and Drug Administration from approving an abortion-inducing pill.
The agency in 1996 had deemed the pill, RU-486, safe and effective and allowed its use in limited, tightly controlled studies. But it has not given final approval for general use. 
 Abortion opponents described the measure as a way to prevent the use of taxpayer dollars to further the killing of unborn children; abortion-rights advocates said the measure, which was attached to an agriculture appropriations bill, was a circuitous way to try to prevent women from having any kind of abortion, even one that they say is the earliest, safest and least invasive.
The effect of today's House action -- on a relatively close vote of 223 to 202 -- is unclear. The measure came to public attention with so little advance notice that its sponsor, Representative Tom Coburn, a Republican from Oklahoma and an obstetrician, said he was still looking for someone to introduce it in the Senate.
The Senate, even under Republican control, has been more supportive of abortion rights than the House. But if a similar measure did pass the Senate, it would present President Clinton with a political dilemma, and neither side would predict today what he might do.
Mr. Clinton, who supports abortion rights, has supported the advancement of RU-486 in the past. But opposing this measure would also mean vetoing the broader, politically appealing $56 billion agriculture bill. The bill provides $23 billion in food stamps, $609 million for food-safety inspection and $2 billion for rural economic projects. It also helps wheat farmers by exempting them from sanctions on India and Pakistan for exploding nuclear devices and protects subsidies for sugar processors and peanut farmers.
Joe Lockhart, a spokesman for Mr. Clinton, said the Administration opposed the bill. He said it would allow Congress to intervene in the drug-safety standards of the Food and Drug Administration. But Mr. Lockhart stopped short of saying the President would veto the measure.
"We're early in the process," he said, suggesting the Senate would scrap the measure.
Still, supporters of abortion rights were concerned that Mr. Clinton could waver on this matter because he is under political pressure on so many other fronts.
"This White House needs to issue a strong veto message immediately," said Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester County and a leading defender in the House of abortion rights.
While Mr. Clinton has stood firm in allowing a procedure that abortion opponents call partial-birth abortion, the Administration has sent signals that Mr. Clinton could side with the Republicans on another anti-abortion measure moving through the House. That bill would make it a crime for anyone to transport a minor across state lines for an abortion. Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, recently wrote a letter to Congress saying that the President would support the measure if it were properly drafted.
And the difficulty of opposing the entire agriculture bill because it contains anti-abortion language was demonstrated by the House. The bill passed 373 to 48. It was opposed by 23 Republicans and 25 Democrats.
Many of the Republicans voting against the larger bill were conservatives who objected to other parts of it like the farm subsidies, which they perceive as corporate welfare.
Douglas Johnson, a lobbyist for the National Right to Life Committee, said today's passage was important because it mattered so much to "the abortion industry."
Mr. Coburn's measure would prohibit the Food and Drug Administration from using taxpayer money to test, develop or approve any drug for the chemical inducement of abortion.
"The business of the F.D.A. is to protect lives, not to facilitate death," Mr. Coburn said in the floor debate.
The agency has approved RU-486, generically called mifepristone, for research purposes. But no manufacturer has said it wants to make the drug on a large scale for general use. That has held up final F.D.A. approval, which requires inspections of laboratories and other actions that cannot take place until someone starts making it.
The Population Council, a nonprofit group in New York, has been working to bring mifepristone to the American market through private investors called the Danco Group.
Heather O'Neill, a spokeswoman for Danco, said today that Danco had identified a manufacturer "willing and able" to make the drug but she would not name it. Nor would she say whether the company was actually producing the drug yet but she said the drug would be available next year. She said the group was "horrified" by today's House action but was moving ahead to bring the drug to the general market anyway.
Gloria Feldt, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said that the House blockage of the food and drug agency process "came from left field" and that her organization had not had a chance to discuss it yet with the Clinton Administration. But she was by no means certain the President would veto it.
Later today the House approved a $250.5 billion military spending plan providing personnel with a 3.1 percent pay increase and new weaponry but not the $1.9 billion Mr. Clinton wanted for American forces in Bosnia, Reuters reported.
 The House passed the package by a 358-to-61 vote, providing $3 billion more than is being spent on the military but $271 million less than the Clinton budget request. A Senate military spending bill readied for floor consideration also does not provide money for Bosnia.
 Bill Young, Republican of Florida, a leading lawmaker on military matters said the money was omitted because the Administration had never explained the American policy for Bosnia.

HEADLINE: Birds in the Bush and the Database

BYLINE: By LES LINE 

 BODY:
HEY, I just entered my sightings from my last trip, and Avisys says I hit 100 birds for the year from the train," Mike Savage recently announced to members of his on-line bird-watching community.
"We were stopped at a red signal along the Great Salt Lake," continued Mr. Savage, a train engineer in the West for Union Pacific who spots birds from the cabs of the 400,000-pound, yellow-and-gray locomotives he drives. "I raised my binos to scan the shore, where I had willet, lesser yellowlegs and greater yellowlegs (No. 99) together in one view. The greater was a new train bird for me and was quickly followed by No. 100, a black-bellied plover, also a new train bird." 
 Train birds? For the uninitiated, bird-watchers (or "birders" as the serious ones call themselves) tend to be compulsive list-keepers. They keep lists of bird species seen in places like their yards, counties, states. They keep trip lists, seasonal lists, annual lists and life lists, which are all the birds seen in one's lifetime. And Mr. Savage keeps what has to be the most unusual list of all.
As a bird-watcher in the 1990's, he also keeps his birding lists on a Hewlett-Packard palmtop computer loaded with Avisys software, which was written for birders by a birder. Other bird-watchers frequently use other aids, like a global positioning system device to help them know where they are -- not to mention such sophisticated devices as a high-end Sony cassette tape deck with a parabolic microphone for recording and playing back songs to lure recalcitrant birds out of vegetation and into the open.
Time was when a life list was kept with penciled check marks next to columns of bird names arranged in taxonomic order -- loons first, sparrows last -- in the front of a field guide by Roger Tory Peterson.
There were pocket checklists on folded cardboard, not pocket computers, for recording the species seen on special trips to national parks or wildlife refuges. And notes about observations in the field were kept in a notebook of the paper-carrying variety, not one with an Intel chip aboard.
Time was when binoculars were the only hardware a birder carried. They were bulky, heavy and costly field glasses, often military surplus. If you were in a group birding from the edge of a marsh, someone probably had a spotting scope that provided a fuzzy view of ducks in the distance.
Times certainly have changed in the world of bird-watching, a pursuit that red-blooded outdoorsmen once derided as a hobby for little old ladies in tennis shoes. One company alone, Bushnell, markets more than 80 models of binoculars in a wide price range, while Carl Zeiss offers a technological breakthrough: a 20-power spotting scope that weighs only 42 ounces and can be held and focused with one hand.
The scope's optical components are mounted on a mechanical suspension system that eliminates a shaky image from hand movement (although the suggested price tag, $2,995, might cause a quiver or two). There is also a large choice of night vision binoculars and scopes for watching the nocturnal activities of whippoorwills and owls.
And that's just a start. "There's a real need for birding Sherpas," Dr. Arie Gilbert said as he hefted an enormous duffle bag into the back of a friend's mini-van one day not long ago for a morning of birding along the Housatonic River near Kent, Conn.
Dr. Gilbert, a Queens chiropractor and hard-core birder since his high school days, totes a load of equipment: Leica 10x42 rubber-armored binoculars, among the ne plus ultra of birding optics; a Minolta 35-millimeter autofocus camera with a 500-millimeter telephoto lens for documenting unusual sightings; a Kowa zoom spotting scope and a heavy Bogen tripod to support it; a Sony tape deck with parabolic microphone, and often a laptop computer with a Global Positioning System receiver and DeLorme's Street Atlas program for navigating to and around unfamiliar areas. Oh, and yes, somewhere in the bag there's a Peterson field guide.
Another high-tech birder is Mr. Savage, a 42-year-old Union Pacific engineer from West Jordan, Utah, who hauls a hundred or more freight cars on a 264-mile run between Salt Lake City and Elko, Nev. The tracks cross the Great Salt Lake Desert, climb the Pequop Mountains and descend into the Humboldt River Valley -- a spectacular range of wildlife habitats where the train passes through just two towns and there are very few cars for the driver to worry about. So Mr. Savage never leaves for work without binoculars and his computer. "It's a good thing I don't have to steer," he quipped.
Other birders carry handheld G.P.S receivers like Garmin's G.P.S. III. They track unmarked trails and update printouts from Toposcout CD-ROM's that contain all of the United States Geological Survey topographic maps for their state.
The laptop computers plugged into their car-lighter sockets are likely to be loaded with an audio CD with the vocalizations of nearly every North American bird species, along with a program called Avisys Song that enables a fast comparison of similar songs by very different birds, like the worm-eating warbler and the chipping sparrow.
What Dr. Gilbert didn't bring along was a cellular phone, which Ann Johnson, vice president of the Iowa Ornithologists' Union and Web master of the Iowa Birding site on the Internet, considers essential for live updates to and from friends as she runs around the countryside near Des Moines on Saturdays.
Cellular phones also let birders quickly report sightings to any of the dozens of Rare Bird Alert telephone hot lines around the country. These bird-alert reports are also available on the Internet, but they are usually updated weekly. For the truly fanatical, the Houston Audubon Society offers a subscription reporting service on rare birds in the United States and Canada. In addition to Internet access to sightings and directions, it offers a "We Call You" service; birders who need certain species for their North American lists get a call if one of them -- or a bird new to the continent -- is reported.
There are quite a few takers. A study on the economic impact of wildlife watching, released this month by the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, said 17.7 million Americans took bird-watching trips in 1996.
A subset of those millions are the men and women who aspire to the exclusive 700 Club and 800 Club, limited to birders who have seen more than 700 or 800 of the 914 bird species north of the Mexican border.
In Britain, birders in dire need of "twitches," sightings of rare species, may rely on pagers for breaking news. "A typical twitcher will be searching around when a message like 'great auk on Outer Hebrides' comes on," said John Farrar, a British trade union official in South Yorkshire. "The twitcher will drop everything, apart from his or her scope and credit card, and charge off north." Of course, the great auk, a giant penguinlike ocean bird, was last seen in 1844. But that's the general idea.
Like his American counterparts, Mr. Farrar carries a handheld computer to record sightings on Avisys, a Windows database system devised by Jerry Blinn, who was a programmer turned manager before he retired from International Business Machines and wrote Avisys. Mr. Blinn, definitely a serious birder, markets the software and its companion, Avisys Song, through his company, Perceptive Systems in Silverdale, Wash.
"Birders have an insatiable appetite for data on what they've seen, where they saw it and why," Mr. Blinn said. "They want a program where they record the habitat, the weather, the bird's behavior, even unbelievable stuff like cloacal swelling."
Many birders' databases can be viewed on personal pages on the Web. That's a new way to brag about one's life list -- but the sites are also a useful place to find information if you need to know the arrival dates of spring migrants, for instance, in a particular area. Across the Internet, there is enough information about birds to keep a watcher indoors for a month, including the huge Breeding Bird Survey database at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center in Maryland. Other pages offer mnemonics to help birders remember songs and calls, like "look-up, over-here, see-me, up-here" for the red-eyed vireo; sound files for 51 Brazilian birds, and the insane song of the laughing kookaburra, an Australian kingfisher.
Elsewhere on the Web, through satellite tracking, it is possible to follow a Laysan albatross's 90-day, 25,000-mile round trip over the North Pacific to find food for its chick. Web cameras focus on nesting peregrine falcons in Seattle, white storks in Germany and tree swallows at the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology in Ithaca, N.Y. In partnership with the National Audubon Society, the Lab (as birders know it) offers nonscientists the opportunity to "bird with a purpose" by participating in on-line projects like Warbler Watch. The Web page of the Gay Birders Club in England "enables contact between gay and lesbian bird-watchers worldwide." And if your E-mail box isn't full, you can subscribe to any of some 60 specialized mailing lists on subjects like seabirds, cavity-nesting birds, hummingbirds or Turkey's birds. The Web supersite that has Internet links galore is (what else?) called Birding (birding.miningco.com).
Or you can grab a beat-up Peterson guide and binoculars worn to the bare metal by years of heavy use, leave all the high-tech gizmos at home and go on what Dr. Gilbert calls "a treasure hunt," watching the activities of the most common birds, like the American robin, for half an hour without worrying about peer pressure to run up the day's score. Dr. Gilbert said, "That's the fun part of birding."

Optical Power
A Handful of Viewing Power
FOR bird-watchers, power means power. Higher-powered optics make birds appear closer so they can be identified through the field marks that, for example, distinguish a lesser yellowlegs from a greater yellowlegs. Those differences are often subtle: The greater yellowlegs has a long, slightly upturned bill and thicker leg joints, while the lesser yellowlegs has a straight bill. If you see the two shorebirds side by side, the lesser is noticeably smaller, but otherwise it's a tough call.
Ten-power binoculars deliver the highest magnification that is practical for handheld viewing -- if you have steady hands -- but many bird-watchers, especially women, prefer 7X or 8X models. If you want to view an oriole in the top of a shade tree in your yard, binoculars are all you will need for a good look and a confident check mark on your list.
But wetlands birds, like loons, ducks, gulls, sandpipers and herons, as well as birds of prey, are typically seen at a distance. That is when a spotting scope is useful. Models that zoom from 15X to 45X or from 20X to 60X are popular among birders, but a sturdy tripod is needed to keep the image from jiggling. Even then, if there is a stiff wind, you can get queasy from a tremor in the image that increases along with the magnification.
Trying to hold a spotting scope in your hand, even at the lowest magnification, is futile. Or at least it was until Carl Zeiss, the famous German optical company, adapted 16th-century technology and introduced a 20-power stabilized monocular/scope that can be comfortably held and focused in one hand. With the press of a button, the image becomes sharp and rock-steady.
The military has used high-power gyro-stabilized binoculars for decades, notably on ships at sea, but they are heavy and require a power source. Further, the gyro takes time to spool up to speed, and a power source, like a battery pack, is required. And the gyro's whine, while inaudible to humans, spooks wildlife.
The stability of the Zeiss 20x60S depends on mechanical ingenuity, not electronics. There isn't one circuit inside the light, ergonomically contoured and water-resistant housing of the scope, which weighs just 42 ounces. Rather, the scope's prism, which is required for image reversal, is mounted in a suspension system that moves left, right or down with the user's hand so the incoming light rays always fall on the same image plane. Any vibrations caused by hand tremors are mechanically suppressed.
For some bird-watchers, a drawback of the Zeiss stabilized monocular is its suggested retail price: $2,999.95. If your pockets are deep and you prefer a 20-power stabilized binocular, which is heavier and not so slick to use in the field, Zeiss has that, too -- for $4,999.95.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE APPEAL;
EX-CHINESE LEADER CONFRONTS BEIJING ON 1989 MASSACRE

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 25

 BODY:
Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as Communist Party chief at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989, has challenged the nation's leaders to admit that the incident was not only reprehensible but also an immense political blunder.
Mr. Zhao, who has been under house arrest for nine years, made his case in a letter to the party's Central Committee by arguing that President Clinton's visit to China, which begins today, offered a chance to reverse the official verdict on the massacre that bloodied the streets of Beijing and deeply scarred the nation's conscience. The Communist Party has insisted that the Government had to call in the military to quell a "counter-revolutionary rebellion." 
 For a former Communist Party leader to so openly confront the leadership, and on such a sensitive political issue, is extraordinary in China. Yet it may reflect Mr. Zhao's confidence that the party's position is squarely on the wrong side of history, and that the vast majority of Chinese people agree with him.
By trying to provoke debate in the party on the events of June 4, 1989, when the military killed hundreds of demonstrators after seven weeks of protests in Tiananmen Square, Mr. Zhao has also risked further punishment. Two former officials who know Mr. Zhao, and who attested to the letter's authenticity, said he intended that it be both read by party leaders and circulated in Beijing.
"Now we are facing the arrival of a new open, democratic and information-age era," Mr. Zhao wrote in the letter, which was published today by the Reuters news agency. "What reason do we have to reject the will of the people, cling to the June 4 problem and block our road to democratic politics? The trend of democracy cannot be blocked."
In contrast with previous fallen leaders in China, Mr. Zhao has steadfastly refused to admit wrongdoing, apparently calculating that creating some distance between himself and his successors can leave the door open to a possible return to power, should the current leadership falter.
No liberal when in power, Mr. Zhao was fast losing influence when students erupted in protest in the spring of 1989, and he painted himself as sympathetic to their cause as a way to try to save his own career.
Whether a pragmatic politician or a cynical one, he now uses his opposition to the crackdown as his greatest weapon. His supporters make the case with eloquent simplicity.
"Resolving the June 4 question is a common desire of all Chinese people," said Bao Tong, Mr. Zhao's chief aide for many years, who spent seven years in prison after 1989. "Political reform is the biggest issue in China today. It begins with June 4."
When Mr. Clinton arrives in China, landing in Xian tonight and then proceeding to Beijing on Friday, he will follow an itinerary designed to accentuate the nonpolitical side of life in China. Meeting teachers, lawyers and entrepreneurs, he is expecting to celebrate the ever-greater degree of personal freedom in the private affairs of ordinary Chinese.
Yet Mr. Zhao's letter, and even the mere mention of his name, is a pointed reminder of the authoritarian and secretive system that still reigns, sharply restricting political freedom.
Mr. Zhao's case is not a typical one. Held under tight security for nine years, he has never been charged with a crime. His real offense was to lose in the high-stakes poker of Communist Party politics at a time of crisis in 1989, and to refuse to go quietly.
By contrast, Mr. Zhao's rival and predecessor as Communist Party chief, Hu Yaobang, took a much more conciliatory stance after he was dumped in January 1987. By accepting criticism and promising obedience to his successor, Mr. Hu retained a seat on the Politburo until he died in April 1989, the spark for demonstrations by students who used his death as an excuse to protest Government shortcomings.
Yet Mr. Zhao has also retained his membership in the Communist Party, and under the sometimes arcane rules that guide China's ruling elite, that allows him certain privileges, like access to internal documents, even as he is deprived of other more basic rights, like freedom of speech and movement.
Mr. Zhao lives with his wife in a spacious home on a small alley near the Forbidden City in Beijing, and not far from Zhongnanhai, the compound where China's leaders live and work. He can receive select, pre-approved visitors, and often sees his daughter and two sons.
Said to suffer from mild heart trouble, he has occasionally been allowed to play golf, a sport he became passionate about during his rise to power on the coattails of Deng Xiaoping in the 1980's. Every time Mr. Zhao wants to leave Beijing, he must apply directly to President Jiang Zemin, who personally decides.
In recent years, Mr. Zhao has spent many winter months in the resort city of Hangzhou, where he is believed to have been in February 1997, when Deng died. Mr. Zhao applied to Mr. Jiang for permission to return immediately to Beijing and attend Deng's memorial service, but Mr. Jiang turned down the request, eager to establish himself as the sole heir to Deng and evidently still threatened by Mr. Zhao's reputation as a capable economic reformer.
Although Chinese leaders generally try to avoid public discussion of the Tiananmen incident, the issue weighs heavily on top-level party politics and has been repeatedly debated at internal meetings, as Prime Minister Zhu Rongji recently confirmed.
At a news conference in March, Mr. Zhu was asked about the Tiananmen incident. He appeared to offer the party line in response.
"In recent years, every major meeting of our party and Government has drawn a correct conclusion regarding that matter, and that conclusion can not be changed," the Prime Minister said.
Yet careful listeners noticed that, inadvertently or not, Mr. Zhu's comment revealed that at "every major meeting," the Tiananmen incident had to reaffirmed.
"In my experience, only if an issue is raised will it be reaffirmed," Mr. Bao, Mr. Zhao's former aide, said. "That means there are different views. Otherwise there would be no need to discuss it."
In his letter, Mr. Zhao uses the issue of China-United States relations to call for a reappraisal of the June 4 incident, which he calls "one of the biggest human rights issues in this century."
"President Clinton's visit to China marks a turn for the better in Sino-U.S. relations," Mr. Zhao wrote. "But the United States and the whole of the West have again and again raised the issue of June 4 and the issue of human rights in China.
"Rather than let it become an obstacle to international relations, it would be better to resolve the issue of June 4 ourselves, voluntarily."

Chart: "China and the U.S.: A Tumultuous Half Century"
President Clinton arrives in China today in the first state visit by an American President since the military suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989. Although specific issues at the summit meeting in Beijing on Saturday will range from trade and the Asian financial crisis to human rights and Taiwan, a high priority of Mr. Clinton's trip, which follows the state visit by President Jiang Zemin of China to the United States last fall, is to bring greater stability to what has been a turbulent relationship between the two countries.
 
* 1951-1953 -- North Korean troops invade South Korea, igniting a war that pits China and the United States against one another.
* 1954 -- The United States and Taiwan sign a mutual defense treaty.
* 1955-70 -- Ambassadors from Washington and Beijing meet in Geneva, followed by occasional ambassadorial-level meetings in Warsaw.
* 1976 -- Mao dies.
* 1979 -- China and the U.S. establish diplomatic relations. In a joint commun-ique Washington says it will maintain unofficial relations with Taiwan. China's new leader, Deng Xiaoping, visits the United States. Congress passes the Taiwan Relations Act reaffirming an American commitment to Taiwan and pledging to maintain arms sales.
* 1982 -- In a third joint communique, the United States pledges not to increase arms sales to Taiwan.
* 1992 -- President Bush approves the sale of F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan. Bill Clinton, running for President, accuses Mr. Bush of coddling China's leaders.
* 1993 -- President Clinton insists on linking most-favored-nation trading status for China to its human rights record.
* 1994 -- Mr. Clinton drops the policy of linking M.F.N. renewal to human rights.
* 1997 -- President Jiang Zemin makes a state visit to the United States. China releases a prominent dissident, Wei Jingsheng, into exile.
* 1998 -- China releases another dissident, Wang Dan. Senate Republicans open an investigation into charges that China gained sensitive missile technology by launching an American satellite, and that the Chinese military illegally contributed to the Democrats' 1996 election campaign.

HEADLINE: Growth Rate Of Economy Is Revised Up, To Brisk 5.4%

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The economy grew much more quickly than originally believed during the first three months of this year, with businesses and consumers increasing spending at a rapid rate, the Government said today.
The nation's gross domestic product -- the sum of all goods and services produced within United States borders -- increased at a seasonally adjusted 5.4 percent annual rate during the period from January to March, the Commerce Department said in a revision of its 4.8 percent estimate a month ago. 
 But much of the latest growth spurt also came from a buildup in business inventories, which is already slowing growth in the current quarter because manufacturers are cutting back production while they sell the stockpiled goods. The inventory buildup rose by a record $105.7 billion in the first quarter.
A further possible sign of economic weakness emerged today in a separate report from the Labor Department that showed a surge in unemployment that reflected the General Motors strike that started three weeks ago.
First-time applications for unemployment benefits jumped by 34,000 last week to 364,000, the highest level in nearly a year. Many of the new claims came in Michigan, Wisconsin, Indiana, New York and Ohio, states where G.M. manufactures.
In a sign of the economy's strength, however, the National Association of Realtors said today that sales of existing single-family homes rose 1 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.82 million. That is just short of March's record pace of 4.89 million homes and leaves sales on a pace to set a record for the full year.

HEADLINE: Not So Easy to Sell Saks Fifth Avenue

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
To the average New York shopper, Saks Fifth Avenue might seem like the ultimate acquisition.
There is the landmark name. The chic frocks. Tourists from around the world flock to buy anything bearing the store's logo. A first trip to Saks in search of a bridal gown or lipstick is a rite of passage for New Yorkers who regard shopping as a serious sport. 
 But for the average investment bank actually trying to sell the retail legend, name and cachet do not so easily equal a deal.
Saks Holdings Inc., the holding company for the retailer, said yesterday that its board, as expected, had approved a sale or merger of the company, and retained Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company to assist. An acquisition or merger of the 97-store chain would end the ownership of Investcorp International, the Bahrain-based investment bank, which holds the majority stake in the retailer. Saks was bought by Investcorp in 1990 for $1.6 billion, and the company sold 20 percent of Saks to the public in 1995 for $25 a share, or $425 million.
Most retail analysts and investment bankers will not discuss potential buyers, largely because they are hoping to get some banking business of their own from one. But all the potential acquirers are known to them because the department store universe has gotten increasingly small as stores like B. Altman have closed and others like Macy's have fallen under the umbrella of giant chains like Federated Department Stores Inc.
Federated, which owns Bloomingdale's, Macy's, Sterns and several other chains, would seem like the biggest player in the game. But the fit does not seem perfect. Federated has been focusing on every place except New York in recent years, rolling out Bloomingdale's in California and eyeing potential acquisitions in the Midwest, where it has no presence.
Further, the chairman of Saks, Philip B. Miller, has taken the store on an interesting strategic journey. Mr. Miller tossed out the clothing lines that are the bread and butter of Federated stores, like Liz Claiborne, in favor of pricier lines like Dolce & Gabbana. The move increased sales for Saks, but it also means that the store has little in common with Federated or the giant May Department Stores Company, which owns Lord & Taylor, another store less snazzy than Saks.
Then, there is Nordstrom Inc. "It would be a real step up for them," said Walter Loeb, the retail consultant. "It would give them greater access to name brands." But shares of Nordstrom are held largely by the retailer's founding family, and it seems unlikely that they would be willing to do a stock transaction to acquire Saks.
No one knows, of course, how much Saks could fetch, but luxury retailers tend to be valued at roughly eight-tenths to one and a half times revenues, which would put the price for Saks roughly between $1.8 billion and $2.5 billion. Few retail companies have that kind of cash. Further, supplier synergies would be limited, especially since Nordstrom has a totally decentralized regional buying structure.
Neiman Marcus, a unit of Harcourt General, is another potential buyer. The two companies sell similar high-end merchandise and have similar customers. They have been stomping around each other's territory for a few years -- Saks has gone into Houston and Dallas, Neiman has opened stores recently on the East Coast -- and have privately expressed interest in each other in the past.
But if the two were to get together, could an antitrust argument result? Outside of Barneys New York, which is tiny compared with those two, and dozens of small specialty stores around the country, Saks and Neiman are truly the only national outlets for the Giorgio Armani and Jil Sander's lines. Mr. Miller has also put an emphasis on scaled-down Saks in small cities, like Greenwich, Conn., further tightening the retailer's grip on the luxury market.
"If manufacturers feel they benefit from bargaining one of these stores against the other," said Richard M. Steuer, an antitrust lawyer at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, "they would have the kind of argument the Government would listen to."
Mr. Steuer pointed to the scuttled merger between Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc. last year, a union the Government found a threat to free trade. "Even though this takes the issue from the mundane to the sublime, the question of their ability to have a lock on a certain universe of sellers remains," he said.
International retailers are another option. LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton is said to have already looked and moved on. Dickson Concepts Inc. has been badly hammered because of the Asian recession. Harrods Department Store in London is a good possibility.
And there is always the possibility that Saks executives could try to raise enough cash to buy the retailer outright.
