HEADLINE: U.A.W. Strike Is Being Felt Far From Flint

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., June 25

 BODY:
Strikes at two General Motors' parts factories here, which started as local disputes over work hours and equipment investments, are producing economic effects now slowly rippling out across North America.
The strike was felt immediately in this town because the General Motors Corporation accounts for more than half the employment and taxes. When 3,400 workers went on strike at a metal parts stamping factory here on June 5, nearby restaurants lost half their business, while the pool table and bar stools at the pub across the street have been deserted. 
 G.M. soon closed 26 of its 29 assembly plants in North America and curtailed production at nearly 100 parts factories. These factories have temporarily laid off 147,900 production workers, including 10,400 in Canada and 32,400 in Mexico, nearly half of G.M.'s North American work force. The Labor Department announced today that first-time claims for unemployment jumped 10.3 percent last week in the United States, the first of many economic indicators likely to reflect the strike's effects.
Now the impact of the strike is reaching into communities and states where the auto industry has been less visible than in the industrial Midwest. ITT Industries has laid off 1,200 workers at a windshield wiper factory in Rochester. The Lear Corporation has laid off 2,800 employees at car seat factories from Delaware to Texas. And Harvard Industries has laid off 900 of the 1,250 workers at its factories in Churchill, Tenn.; Wytheville, Va., and Newfields, N.H.
The latest strike has surpassed in lost production a strike two years ago at two G.M. brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, and amounts to the costliest labor dispute in the auto industry since a two-month national strike against G.M. in 1970. Private economists are beginning to shave their estimates of the annualized growth rate of the nation's economic output during the second quarter. Prior to the strike, the consensus was for the economy to expand at about a 3 percent annual rate; now experts expect that to be more like 2.5 percent because of the strike.
The economy rebounded sharply after previous G.M. strikes, as auto workers put in overtime to make up for lost production, and the same is expected this time, Government and private economists said. Economic indicators "do bounce back the following quarter" after G.M. strikes, said Lee Price, the Commerce Department's chief economist.
But the strikes are already beginning to cause hardship for some, although many companies are trying to soften the blow in order to hold on to skilled workers at a time of low unemployment.
Autoliv ASP Inc. furloughed nearly 450 employees at air bag factories around Salt Lake City this week. Many of Autoliv's workers reluctantly volunteered for their furloughs as an unpaid summer vacation. One of them, Nikki Vaughn, a 20-year-old assembly line worker who is expecting a baby in September, volunteered for the furlough rather than accept a job on another, unfamiliar Autoliv assembly line making parts for another auto maker. "We didn't think it would affect us, but now it has," Ms. Vaughn said, adding that she would save money by shortening a planned vacation this summer.
The Capitol Coney Island Family Restaurant, a 24-hour establishment near one of the Flint factories, has allowed workers to leave early but has not laid off anyone even though business is off by a quarter in the restaurant and three-quarters at the takeout window. "It's hard to find people," said Philip Kosman, the restaurant's owner.
Gerry G. Tighe, the general counsel of Harvard Industries, said that he wished the White House would take a bigger role in seeking to end the strike. President Clinton has expressed concern about the strike, but has said that the company and the union should settle their disagreements through collective bargaining.
 The 9,200 striking workers here are collecting $150 a week in benefits from the United Automobile Workers union. Laid-off workers are generally eligible for state unemployment benefits of $200 or $300 a week, depending on the state. G.M. said on Wednesday that it would try to block benefits for laid-off U.A.W. workers but an attempt in 1996 by G.M. to do so met with little success.
With growing signs that the strike will not be settled during G.M.'s annual summer shutdown during the first two weeks of July -- and with the likelihood that it will take two or three weeks for new parts to be made and for factories to reopen after a settlement -- economists are also reconsidering their growth forecasts for the third quarter. Paul Ballew, the Federal Reserve's expert on the auto industry for many years and now the chief economist at J. D. Power & Associates, the consulting firm, said that the strike could reduce economic growth in the third quarter by as much as seven-tenths of a percentage point if the strike lasts into August, as leaders of the United Automobile Workers union threatened this week. The lost production might not be recouped until the end of the first quarter of next year, because it is difficult to make up for lost production during the autumn, when new models are being introduced, he added.
William A. Strauss, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said that while the strike's effects might be temporary, it could have a slight but longer-lasting effect, increasing inflation. The auto industry has been in a price war, spurred by a glut of late-model used cars and the dollar's rise in value in currency markets, which makes imported cars and car parts cheaper. New-vehicle prices have dropped by nine-tenths of 1 percent in the last 12 months. This has helped to restrain inflation because new car prices make up 5.1 percent of the Consumer Price Index.
G.M. is likely to offer fewer discounts as it runs low on cars. And, because G.M. still holds nearly a third of the United States auto market, other auto makers may follow its example, Mr. Strauss said.
"It's a likely scenario that we're going to have less competition, which means higher prices," he said.
G.M. laid off 1,500 more employees today, mostly auto parts workers in the United States and Mexico. G.M. executives asked assembly plant managers on Wednesday morning to send home any "nonessential" maintenance workers at shuttered factories and turn off the power to the machinery to save money on utility bills. But G.M. officials said today that this would result in very few layoffs.
According to the Commerce Department, the Dayton strike trimmed three-tenths of a percentage point from the annualized rate of economic growth in the first quarter of 1996. Growth in that quarter was 1.8 percent, but the economy recovered with 6 percent growth during the second quarter of that year.
The 1970 strike had a greater effect. The annualized change in economic activity actually dropped 3.9 percent in the fourth quarter, when the strike occurred, but then bounced back with an 11.3 percent gain in the first quarter of 1971.
The current strikes could have a longer-term economic effect if they result in G.M.'s closing some of its chronically unprofitable small-car factories in the United States and investing overseas instead. Donald Hackworth, G.M.'s group vice president for North American cars, said last week that G.M. would reconsider its investment plans in the United States if the U.A.W. did not agree to improve productivity.
G.M. is the nation's largest company and its North American operations account for about 1.5 percent of the nation's economic output. In 1970, G.M. still accounted for 2.3 percent, according to the Commerce Department.
G.M.'s after-tax losses from the current strikes are approaching $1 billion, for which the company is not insured. Through Friday, G.M. will have lost the production of roughly 230,000 vehicles, compared with 180,000 vehicles lost during the Dayton strikes.
The effects of the current G.M. strikes would be even worse were it not for the nation's strong economy, which is making it easier for laid-off workers to find new jobs. Trucking companies are having a very hard time finding drivers, for example, and have been taking out newspaper advertisements and sending recruiters here.
"Some of the drivers in this area don't have as much to do because of the strike," said Bill Davis, a recruiter for Certified Transport L.L.C., who drove five hours here from Indianapolis on Wednesday morning to hire two drivers who responded to the trucking company's ads.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA;
In Xian, 'A New Chapter in China's Story'

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Clinton's arrival remarks yesterday in China, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
Thank you for the key to your city and for this magnificent welcome. Here in this ancient capital, China seems very young to me tonight, blessed with both a proud history and the promise of tomorrow. I am delighted to begin my journey in Xian, once the capital of China, still the heartland of the Chinese people. 
 I was raised in the heartland of my country. I know that the character of a nation is determined by the hard-working people who live here.
Over 1,000 years ago, during the Tang dynasty, which I have seen recreated tonight, Xian was, perhaps, the most open and culturally advanced city in the entire world. From this place trade routes extended through Asia to Europe and Africa and to this place great thinkers came, spreading philosophy and new ideas that have contributed to the greatness of China.
Tomorrow I look forward to seeing the terra-cotta warriors, the old city walls, the Muslim quarter. I look forward to learning more about China's great contributions to the store of human knowledge, from medicine and printing to mathematics and astronomy, discoveries on which so much of the whole world's progress is based. But I want to see more of the new nation you are building on a scale even the emperors could not have foreseen. The China that gave us printing now boasts fax machines, computers and cell phones. Xian is home to film makers, Internet explorers, business people of every description.
Here in this city famous for calligraphy, a new chapter in China's story is being written. We Americans admire your accomplishments, your economy, your hard work, creativity and vision, your efforts against hunger and poverty, your work with us on peace and stability in Korea and South Asia. A new day is dawning for the Chinese people, for China's greatness lies, as always, with its people.
Our own history has convinced Americans that the greatness of any country is measured in its people, in their shared reverence for family and community, for work and learning and in their individual thoughts, beliefs and creativity. Respect for the worth, the dignity, the potential and the freedom of every citizen is a vital source of America's strength and success.
In this global information age, where both economic growth and individual opportunity are based on ideas, a commitment to providing all human beings the opportunity to develop their full potential is vital to the strength and success of the new China, as well.
As I travel across China I hope to learn as much as I can about the Chinese people, your history and your dreams for the future. And I hope to help the Chinese people understand more of America's history, the lessons the American people have drawn from it and the dreams we hold for the 21st century.
I believe both Chinese and Americans aspire to many of the same things, to provide for our families, to teach our children, to build our communities, to protect our Earth, to shape our own futures and pass brighter possibilities on to our children. There may be those, here and back in America, who wonder whether closer ties and deeper friendship between America and China are good. Clearly, the answer is yes.
We have a powerful ability to help each other grow. We can learn much from each other. And as two great nations we have a special responsibility to the future of the world. The steps we take over the next week can lead to far greater strides for our people in the years ahead.
Here in this city of your magnificent history, we must always remember that we too are ancestors. Some day our children and their children will ask if we did all we could to build just societies and a more peaceful world.
Let our monuments be their judgment that we did that. Let our progress include all people with all their differences, moving toward a common destiny.
Let us give new meaning to the words written in the ancient Book of Rites, what you call the Li Jing, "When the great way is followed, all under heaven will be equal."

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: THE OPINION -- JUSTICES, 6-3, BAR VETO OF LINE ITEMS IN BILLS; SEE H.I.V. AS DISABILITY;
RULING ON BIAS LAW

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
People with H.I.V. infection can be covered by the Federal law that bars discrimination on the basis of disability even if they have no symptoms, the Supreme Court ruled today in a major victory for people with the virus that causes AIDS.
Voting 5 to 4, the Justices agreed with a Federal appeals court's ruling that a woman with asymptomatic H.I.V. infection, who was refused care in a dentist's office, met the definition of disability under the Americans With Disabilities Act. 
 The Court stopped short of ruling flatly that H.I.V. infection is automatically covered by the disability law, a question that Justice Anthony M. Kennedy's majority opinion said was not necessary to the decision. There is no dispute that people with full-blown AIDS are disabled within the meaning of the 1990 law.
The majority held that the woman's decision not to have children because of her H.I.V.-positive status brought her within the law's definition of disability: an impairment that "substantially limits" one or more "major life activities." Reproduction is such an activity, Justice Kennedy said. Excerpts, page A19.
Although the opinion's scope was limited, its tone suggested that in subsequent cases, all or almost all H.I.V.-positive people would be able to claim the law's protection. "Major life activities" is a broad phrase that should be broadly interpreted in light of the prospect of inevitable progression to a "dread and fatal disease," Justice Kennedy said.
Beyond its application to the nearly one million people in the United States who are H.I.V.-positive, the decision was important as the Court's first substantive review of the eight-year-old disability law. The Court's analysis suggested that the law would also cover other conditions that some lower courts have regarded as beyond its scope, including infertility, well-controlled diabetes and cancer that is in remission after treatment. Justice Kennedy said it was not necessary for a life activity that is compromised by an impairment to have a "public, economic or daily character."
The majority opinion was joined by Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist dissented, as did Justices Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas and Sandra Day O'Connor. The dissenters said that reproduction was not a major life activity and that in any event the ability to have a child was not "substantially limited" by H.I.V. infection in the way the law used that phrase.
The decision, Bragdon v. Abbott, No. 97-156, was short of a complete victory for the patient, Sidney Abbott, who brought the lawsuit in 1994. After finding that she was covered by the law, the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit went on to rule that despite his fear of infection, the dentist, Randon Bragdon, had illegally discriminated against her by refusing to treat her in his office, in Bangor, Me.
The Justices vacated that final part of the ruling today, however, ordering the appeals court, which sits in Boston, to take further evidence on the question of risk. The disability act provides an exception under which a person with an infectious condition need not be treated if the condition "poses a direct threat to the health or safety of others," defined as a "significant risk" that cannot be eliminated by appropriate procedures.
Justice Kennedy said that within the scope of this appeal, the Supreme Court had not been able to review evidence on this question. He said such evidence should be limited to "objective, scientific information," in particular the views of public health authorities.
This in itself was an important part of the ruling, because the Court rejected Dr. Bragdon's argument that the judgment of risk could be made by the individual practitioner. Dr. Bragdon's own view should receive "no special deference simply because he is a health care professional," Justice Kennedy said, adding that "his belief that a significant risk existed, even if maintained in good faith, would not relieve him" of liability if broadly accepted medical evidence was to the contrary.
Lawyers for Ms. Abbott said they were confident they would prevail in the renewed lower court proceedings, in light of the views of leading public health authorities on the safety of treating H.I.V.-positive patients and the absence of evidence that any patient had ever transmitted H.I.V. infection to a dentist. The Clinton Administration, which entered the case in support of Ms. Abbott, told the Court that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had "found the risk of H.I.V. transmission in the dental context so low as to be unquantifiable."
In his dissenting opinion, however, Chief Justice Rehnquist said that given evidence that patients had transmitted the virus to health care workers on 42 documented occasions, it was likely that Dr. Bragdon could establish that it was "objectively reasonable" for him to refuse to treat an infected patient in his office.
The dentist, alerted by Ms. Abbott's disclosure on a new-patient information form that she had H.I.V., had offered to fill her cavity in a hospital, where in fact he did not have privileges to practice. It was at that point that she filed suit.
Her lawyer, Bennett H. Klein of Gay and Lesbian Advocates and Defenders, a Boston public interest law firm, said he was "elated" by the decision today, which he said would send a strong signal to lower courts that all H.I.V.-positive people are protected under the law.
The 1990 law offers broad protection against discrimination on the basis of disability in employment and places of public accommodation, which are defined as including medical offices. A related law, the National Fair Housing Act Amendments of 1988, uses the same definition of disability to bar housing discrimination.
Matthew Coles, director of the AIDS Project of the American Civil Liberties Union, said the decision was important in demonstrating that the Court was willing to look at "the basic purpose of the Americans With Disabilities Act." Contrary to many narrow lower court interpretations, he said, the law was intended to be read "not like an antitrust regulation but like a civil rights law."
Ann Elizabeth Reesman, a lawyer here who filed a brief on behalf of an employer group urging the Court to reject reproduction as a "major life activity," said the ruling had significantly broadened the scope of the law. Employers will most likely find the decision troublesome, she said, because "reproduction is such a broad term that it will be more difficult to tell who is covered and what employers' obligations are."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The case that led to the Supreme Court's decision on H.I.V. dated from 1994, when a dentist, Randon Bragdon, above, refused to treat Sidney Abbott, left, at his office in Bangor, Me., because she was infected with the virus. (Photographs by Associated Press)(pg. A19)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Local Bells See Bright Side In AT&T-TCI Merger Deal
Shares of the five local Bell telephone companies dropped by almost 4 percent on average, shaving about $11 billion from their combined market value one day after AT&T agreed to acquire Tele-Communications Inc. for $31.8 billion. 
 The decline was attributed to AT&T's lessened need for the Bells' networks to reach local customers once it gains access to TCI's extensive cable system, which reaches 10.5 million homes. The local Bells, however, think the merger will help them enter the $80 billion long-distance market, something they have sought to do. News Analysis. Page D3.

Sunbeam Facing a Bleak Outlook
Shares of Sunbeam have plummeted 42 percent since the board of the appliance maker dismissed its chief executive, Albert J. Dunlap, two weeks ago. Now the company has confirmed that the S.E.C. is investigating its accounting practices and Sunbeam is delaying registering a planned bond offering. D7.
 
Power Cutbacks in Midwest
Utilities throughout the Midwest asked customers to cut the use of appliances because of a heat wave that has resulted in a surge in demand for electricity. Many industries in the region also reduced their power consumption, canceling shifts and sending workers home early. A14.
 
House Approves Overhaul of I.R.S.
The House approved legislation worked out by House-Senate negotiators that would lead to an internal reorganization of the Internal Revenue Service, create an independent board to oversee its operations and give taxpayers more rights and powers in disputes with the tax collection agency. A15.
 
Strong Growth in First Quarter
The economy grew at a 5.4 percent annual rate during the first three months of this year, stronger than originally estimated. D2.
 
Computer Issues Lead Stocks Down
Concern about profits for the computer industry's bellwethers sent the Nasdaq and Standard & Poor's 500-stock indexes down. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.71, to 8,935.58. D7.
 
Yields on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.65 percent, from 5.66 percent Wednesday. D7.
 
Saks Hires Advisers for Its Sale
As expected, the holding company for Saks Fifth Avenue has approved a sale or merger of the 97-store chain. It retained Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company to assist with a deal that would end the ownership of Investcorp International. D2.
 
Repeal of Stock Regulation Urged
Announcing arrests in an international stock swindle, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, called on Federal authorities to repeal a regulation that he said leaves investors vulnerable to fraud. B4.
 
G.O.P.'s Low-Budget Tobacco Bill
Republican leaders in the House of Representatives offered a one-page outline of the kind of tobacco legislation they prefer as an alternative to the ambitious anti-smoking bill shelved by the Senate last week. The Republicans favor an advertising campaign to discourage teen-age smoking, no increase in tobacco prices and diminished authority of the Food and Drug Administration to regulate tobacco products. A13.
 
Oil Falls on Doubts About Cutbacks
Oil futures snapped a four-day rally and fell almost 4 percent, to $14.03 a barrel, on skepticism that oil producers would keep promises to cut production. D7.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Little Changed In Light Trading as Dollar Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices pared early losses and ended little changed yesterday, as the dollar gained in currency trading against the yen. Prices were also weakened by dealers' hedging Freddie Mac's $4 billion global bond offering yesterday.
But trading volume in the Treasury market was nearly half of the average for a Thursday in the second quarter, so price movements are exaggerated somewhat. 
 The price of the 30-year bond edged up 2/32 , to 106 24/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 5.65 percent, from 5.66 percent on Wednesday.
Treasury prices came under pressure as underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company, J. P. Morgan and Salomon Smith Barney sold the five-year Freddie Mac note issue at a price to yield 5.77 percent, or about 26 basis points over the new five-year Treasury note sold Wednesday. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
Also weighing on the market was slightly stronger than expected housing data, early weakness in the dollar against the Japanese yen, a strong stock market that gave back a good chunk of its gains during the day, supply and technical factors.
Traders said shorter-maturity bills were in strong demand for the most part as the three-month bill rate dropped below 5 percent on a variety of factors, including end-of-the-quarter demand.
Treasury prices fell early in the session after the Commerce Department said gross domestic product increased at a seasonally adjusted 5.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, much higher than its estimate of 4.8 percent a month ago.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said "despite still-booming home sales, the somewhat surprising, upward revised 5.4 percent G.D.P, statistic, while subject to further change with next month's annual revisions, certainly demonstrated the economy's torrid expansion during the first quarter was likely to slow substantially, due mainly to an inventory overhang."
"Furthermore," he said, "economic activity seems to be encountering some head winds at the onset of the third quarter in the forms of sagging durable goods orders, the G.M. strike, and an ever-widening trade deficit."
Mr. Fine said he expected that Federal Reserve policy makers would keep monetary policy unchanged at its two-day meeting next week because of benign inflation, a growing budget surplus, strong dollar and continued turmoil in Asia.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Computer Profits Outlook Cuts 2-Week Rally's Gains

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, led by Intel and Microsoft, on renewed concern about profits for the computer industry's bellwethers.
An afternoon slump in the two stocks pulled the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down from a record, and took the steam out of a two-week rally in computer shares. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.71, to 8,935.58, losing most of a 101.14-point gain that took the average above 9,000 for the first time since June 10. The Dow would have fallen if not for a gain in Union Carbide. The S.& P. index fell 3.60, to 1,129.28. The Nasdaq composite index fell 14.51 points, to 1,863.25.
Investors are "waiting for corporate profits to get over this hump," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist at C. H. Dean & Associates in Dayton, Ohio, which oversees $5 billion.
Operating earnings in the second quarter for the companies in the S.& P. 500 are expected to rise about 3.5 percent, compared with 8.9 percent a year earlier, according to I.B.E.S. International Inc. That's better than the first quarter's 1.5 percent rise, which was the worst in seven years, but far from the gains of 10 percent or more in 21 of the previous 25 quarters.
Investors put money into some stocks that lagged in recent weeks, including Union Carbide, up 4 1/4, to 52 1/4. James Hickman, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, said that after meeting with Union Carbide he expects management to cut costs in coming months.
Some investors expect the market to revive as second-quarter earnings reports begin in the middle of next month. "This earnings season is going to be strong, so I think we're really in for a summer rally in the stock market," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Zurich Kemper Investments Inc.
Intel, the world's biggest computer-chip maker, and Microsoft, the No. 1 independent maker of personal computer software, led stocks' gains this week as investors concluded that demand for their products would revive in the second half of the year. The companies had slumped with other computer stocks as Asia's slowdown hurt business. In the previous nine days, though, Microsoft soared 23 percent.
"There reaches a point where people say this is too much too soon," said Larry Wachtel, a stock market analyst for Prudential Securities Inc. "We've had an enormous move in the big-cap stocks."
Microsoft fell 3 3/8, to 101 9/16 . Intel dropped 1 3/4, to 75 5/8. While Intel did not warn of a profit shortfall for the current quarter, as some feared, investors said they were reluctant to bid the shares higher without assurance that the glut of personal computers will ease in the second half.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Oil Prices Break 4-Day Rally On Skepticism Over OPEC Cuts

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil snapped a four-day rally yesterday and fell almost 4 percent on skepticism that oil producers would follow through on promises to cut production by 3.2 million barrels a day and reduce a global supply glut.
Traders said they thought that steeper cuts yet were needed because of the history of some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' ignoring quotas to which they had agreed. 
 "The market really hasn't given these cuts much credibility because they're discounting them by 50 percent," said Alan Struth, chief economist at Phillips Petroleum in Bartlesville, Okla. He said OPEC had only been able to cut about 50 to 60 percent "of what they say they will."
In trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for August delivery fell 57 cents a barrel, to $14.03, partly erasing the $1.47 in gains made over the previous four trading days on optimistic expectations about OPEC's intentions to curtail production.
On Wednesday night, the producers' organization, meeting in Vienna, increased the size of cutbacks promised for this year to 2.6 million barrels a day. Non-OPEC producers, led by Mexico and Norway, have also pledged some reductions, which would bring the intended output reductions to 3.2 million barrels.
But global inventories remain ample, partly reflecting a slowdown in demand from economically troubled Asian countries.
In addition, Iraq, which exports crude oil under a United Nations-negotiated oil-for-food program, has negated much of the others' cuts with increased exports.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE VILLAGE;
In a Schoolyard Near Xian, a Grass-Roots Moment

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: XIAN, China, Friday, June 26

 BODY:
The President led a schoolyard discussion today in Xiahe, about 30 miles east of Xian and adjacent to the famed archeological site of the terra-cotta warriors buried in the tomb of Emperor Qin Shihuang.
The President heard from a carefully selected group of citizens of Xiahe and nearby towns: a schoolteacher, a clinic worker, a restaurant owner and the manager of a factory that produces souvenir replicas of the terra cotta warriors. 
 The President listened intently, asking whether Government policies had led to growing prosperity in the village, educational levels and the challenges of running a small business in the booming economy.
Xiahe is a village of 400 people. One man told the President that his family's annual income had exploded to 30,000 yuan from 1,000 yuan before 1982.
Mr. Clinton also took questions. A restaurant owner asked him why he was holding such a discussion.
"For two reasons," the President answered. "First of all, I think it's important for people in positions like mine, in the United States and China, understand how people live at what we call the grass-roots level and understand how the policies we make affect the way people live and the lives of ordinary citizens."
He continued, "And secondly, because the American people are very interested in learning more about the Chinese people as a result of my trip. So when we do this there will be pictures and reports of this meeting in America so people just like you in America will have a feeling for what it's like to be a teacher or run a restaurant or work with old people."
Asked about Taiwan, Mr. Clinton said, "It's obvious there will be no change in our position one way or the other on this trip."
 Next on the itinerary for the Clintons is a tour of Emperor Qin's tomb.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE SCENE;
Xian Turns Out, and It Wasn't Even Compulsory

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: XIAN, China, June 25

 BODY:
On this steamy summer night, the people of Xian took to the streets to welcome President Clinton on the first stop of his state visit, in what many here said was one of the largest spontaneous gatherings they could remember.
"There's never been another event like this here -- I don't think I've ever seen this many people come out for anything," said Sun Qinqi, an engineer, who said he had decided to pass up the World Cup soccer game to cram onto the sidewalk just inside the Old City's South Gate to catch a glimpse of the Presidential motorcade's arrival. 
 He scanned the high-spirited crowd wondering aloud: Did more people turn out to celebrate the arrest of the infamous Gang of Four in 1976, which brought the decade-long Cultural Revolution to an end? Were there more in the spring of 1989, when people gathered to express sympathy for demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in Beijing?
"No," he concluded, "there just weren't so many then."
As early as 9 this morning, factory workers, students, bankers and public officials started vying for position on the sidewalks around the square before the South Gate, where the President was to give a short speech. And by this evening, a crowd five deep extended out of the square for two miles down South Avenue, along the route Mr. Clinton was rumored to be taking back to his hotel.
Despite a huge police presence, the green-uniformed officers stoically tolerated a large, ebullient crowd of spectators, including some perching in trees and atop newspaper kiosks. They watched as men in Adidas shirts and women carrying beepers jumped blithely over the barricades in front of Kentucky Fried Chicken to applaud when the President's black limousine, bearing American and Chinese flags, finally passed.
It was a heady evening for Xian, the once-proud capital of ancient China but in recent years plagued by a stagnant economy and hundreds of thousands of layoffs. Indeed, many enthusiasts expressed hope that Mr. Clinton's visit would help restore Xian's name -- or at least bring new business to town.
On the street tonight, few seemed to mind that they could neither see the elaborate welcoming ceremony nor hear the President speak.
Gu Fuyin, a factory director, and his wife, Cao Mingli, had dressed up, brought stools and waited four hours to catch a glimpse of the motorcade. Some work places had urged their employees to be welcoming toward Mr. Clinton. Nonetheless, the middle-aged couple marveled at a celebration that was "spontaneous" and "not required by politics."
"The two country's relations are developing quickly, and now we are feeling much more friendly," Mr. Gu explained.
Ren Liansheng, 25, a Xian native who works on a construction project in Gansu, took off three days to attend the event, because "this is great for Xian, to promote economic development."
And Li Yuhua, 45, a factory worker in a flower-print dress who was crammed onto the sidewalk just across from the South Gate, only slightly overstepped the mood of the crowd when she exclaimed: "He's young and he's achieved so much. And we hope he'll achieve more. He's an epic-making man."
Even before the Clinton's plane touched down, shopkeepers could feel the benefits of his visit.
On Wenyibei Street, a bustling commercial street outside the city wall, Jia Jiwan, 34, had decorated the window of his fashionable clothing store with pictures of the President.
"We always say we should grasp the opportunity to reinvigorate the economy, and this is like a windfall," he said. "So this visit could be a turning point. Afterward, Xian -- and its products -- will be better known in the world."
At a small outdoor market near Xian's beautifully ornate 18th-century Bell Tower, Lu Xiurong, 47, said the impending arrival of Mr. Clinton had done wonders for her business, which sells children's clothes, skimpy underwear and bras.
"We were just saying how happy we were he is coming," said Ms. Lu. "When the people are in a good mood, as they are now, they wander through the market and buy." She said sales had increased 60 percent in the last two weeks, with American-flag pajamas a best seller.
At the state-owned Foreign Language Bookstore, 200 copies of a Chinese book about President Jiang Zemin's visit to the United States last fall sold out in two days last week.
But other businesses did not fare so well.
Two months ago, a 45-year-old widow named Liu Guiqing who had been laid off from a candy factory paid $100 for a pedicab that she drove to support her two children.
But on June 1, the Xian police informed Ms. Liu and other pedicab drivers that their cabs were old-fashioned and could no longer operate in the city center. The move supposedly was intended to relieve Xian's traffic congestion, but she and many others say the impending Clinton visit was to blame.
With no other way to make money, Ms. Liu has decided to take a chance, to earn a few dollars a night. In a city center now devoid of pedicabs, she goes out after nightfall and turns down rides that involve traveling on main thoroughfares.
"I have seen a few police trucks, but they have so far left me alone," she said. "I think it's because I am a woman."
Also on Wednesday, as Mr. Clinton was traveling to Xian, Fu Sheng was aboard a train out of the city, to the seaport of Qingdao. Mr. Fu, 38, who in 1989 had led Xian workers in a demonstration to support the protests in Beijing, was ordered to leave town before the President's arrival.
Three times in recent weeks, the party secretary at Mr. Fu's work place, the Xian Institute of Navigation, gave him the choice of being laid off or going to Qingdao.
When he finally left, he was accompanied by a co-worker assigned to make sure that he arrived at his destination. But he was upset that he had to leave Xian while his wife had to work and his 9-year-old was preparing for examinations.
"The meeting between the Americans and the Chinese is a good thing, another handshake," he said before his departure. "But why have authorities violated my rights?"

Mr. Clinton began his nine-day visit to China in the ancient city. Chinese jammed the sidewalks in Xian yesterday to watch the welcoming ceremony for President Clinton. HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Starts Visit to China By Answering Critics in U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: XIAN, China, June 25

 BODY:
With the pageantry of thundering drums and clanging gongs, President Clinton was welcomed to China tonight, the first American President to visit this country in nearly a decade, and he mildly rebuked critics in Washington who have attacked his policy of engagement with Beijing.
"There may be those here and back in America who wonder whether closer ties and deeper friendship between America and China are good," the President said, speaking as much to his audience at home as to the throngs of Chinese who poured into the streets of Xian today to give Mr. Clinton a tumultuous welcome. 
 "Clearly, the answer is yes," the President said. "We can learn much from each other. And as two great nations, we have a special responsibility to the future of the world. The steps we take over the next week can lead to far greater strides for our people in the years ahead." Excerpt, page A8.
 On Friday morning, the President met with some of the residents of a nearby village to "understand how people live at what we call the grass-roots level."
The 30-minute arrival ceremony was a made-for-TV spectacle, for both the Chinese and American audiences, replete with warriors in Tang dynasty costumes, a score of maidens in flowing white gowns bearing baskets of flowers, and yellow-robed riders astride strutting horses. Red paper lanterns hung from the lampposts and bright silk banners bearing images of mythical birds of good fortune flapped in the breeze on a mild smoggy night.
The crowds of factory workers, students, bankers and public officials began vying for position at 9 A.M. on the sidewalks around the square in front of the Old City's South Gate, where the President gave a short speech nearly 12 hours later. By evening, the crowd extended for two miles down South Avenue out of the square.
Still two days away from the formal part of his trip, a one-day summit conference with President Jiang Zemin in Beijing, Mr. Clinton did not dwell here on any of the major, substantive differences between China and the United States. Instead, he offered brief remarks that stressed the positive aspects of the way the Chinese-American relationship has developed since 1989, the year in which President Bush visited China and the Chinese Government used military force to crush pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square.
In addition to his diplomatically indirect reference to the political climate in the United States about China, recently inflamed on Capitol Hill over questions about illegal campaign contributions and the spread of nuclear weapons, Mr. Clinton offered a gentle reminder of the gulf between the two countries on matters of human rights.
"Respect for the worth, the dignity, the potential and the freedom of every citizen is a vital source of America's strength and success," the President said as army searchlights played in the sky above him. "In this global information age, where both economic growth and individual opportunity are based on ideas, a commitment to providing all human beings the opportunity to develop their full potential is vital to the strength and success of the new China, as well."
In Beijing, United States officials complained to the Chinese Government today over reports that several dissidents had been detained and others harassed in relation to President Clinton's state visit. President Clinton repeated this complaint in his remarks Friday morning.
But in Xian, which the White House chose for the first stop because it is a city without a strong political symbolism in modern times, the focus was on ceremony and on the enthusiastic welcome.
The President and Hillary Rodham Clinton, showing the effects of their 18-hour, 10,000-mile journey from Washington, made their way down 150 yards of red carpet to the base of Xian's flood-lit South Gate, part of the fortifications that once guarded the city, China's imperial capital for more than 1,000 years.
Xian's Mayor, Fang Xichu, officially welcomed "your excellency Mr. President and Mrs. President," and presented Mr. Clinton with a key to the city.
"Isn't it a delight when friends visit from afar?" Mr. Fang said, quoting Confucius.
The South Gate, also known as the Gate of Eternal Tranquillity, was built in 1317, 400 years after the end of the Tang dynasty, 618-907 A.D., a period many Chinese regard as a high point in their civilization.
The crowd in the large square facing the gate numbered only a few hundred, limited by security concerns. But thick throngs lined the route of Mr. Clinton's 50-car motorcade into the city from the airport.
Still, it was a moment to be savored for many in the crowd, a break from the routine and a sign of China's growing acceptance as a weighty world player.
"I've lived here more than 20 years and I've never seen as many people gathered for anything before," said Chang Yingxiao, a division chief in the Xian health bureau.
Chen Tong, a 13-year-old boy, came to the parade route to see Mr. Clinton's car and perhaps catch a glimpse of the President himself. "I very much like President Clinton, I even worship him," he said. Asked if he held any other Americans in such reverence, the boy answered, "George Washington and Michael Jordan."
In his remarks, the President made reference to the controversy raging in the United States over his nine-day, five-city trip to China. Nearly a third of the members of Congress had urged Mr. Clinton to delay the trip until charges of illegal Chinese contributions to the 1996 Democratic campaign and the transfer of missile technology to China had been resolved. Many human rights advocates object to his rewarding the Chinese Government with a state visit while thousands of political dissidents remain jailed.
Mr. Clinton -- whose aides have hoped to use the trip to project an image back to the United States of a prospering, striving China that poses new challenges for economic competition, not nuclear or ideological confrontation -- struck that tone from the first moments of his visit.
"Here, in this city famous for calligraphy, a new chapter in China's story is being written," he said. "We Americans admire your accomplishments, your economy, your hard work, creativity and vision, your efforts against hunger and poverty, your work with us on peace and stability in Korea and South Asia."
He added: "I believe both Chinese and Americans aspire to many of the same things: to provide for our families, to teach our children, to build our communities, to protect our Earth, to shape our own futures and pass brighter possibilities on to our children."

ABOUT XIAN
The focus of government, religion and art for 1,000 years, Xian was China's capital until the end of the flourishing Tang dynasty
in 907 A.D. Monuments and relics of the imperial city's former splendor are still intact, along with what is now a modern industrial center.

HEADLINE: Alarmists Overstate China Army Buildup

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Stop Playing by China's Rules" (Op-Ed, June 22), Robert Kagan and William Kristol cite the "alarming rate" at which China is increasing its defense spending and call for "reversing the decline" in American spending. But China's spending is difficult to tally accurately. 
 The International Institute for Strategic Studies puts 1991 Chinese spending at $19 billion. But with high inflation, the "threat" disappears. The nominal increase of 159 percent between 1986 and 1994 is a rise of only 4 percent in real terms.
With China's economy slowing because of the Asian financial crisis, the United States can safely continue to engage China without increasing its own military spending. Fears that an increase in Chinese spending is being used to implement long-dormant expansionist tendencies should not be ignored, but neither should they be overdramatized. What we see does not portend a gigantic buildup by a hostile country so much as an affordable, long-overdue upgrading of the military of the world's most-populous country.
 
DAN SMITH
Washington, June 22, 1998
 
The writer is associate director for operations, Center for Defense Information.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
One Week After a Slump, S.& P. 500 Closes at a Record

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market finished a strong week yesterday, as blue-chip issues rode into record territory despite longstanding fears about the economic crisis in Asia.
Wall Street analysts continue to warn about a slowdown in corporate profits this year, partly because of Asia, but investors are sending most of the major stock indexes significantly higher. 
 After falling sharply just over a week ago, dropping nearly 5 percent below its record high, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index soared this week to a record 1,133.20 yesterday, pushing the index up nearly 16.8 percent for the year.
The Dow Jones industrial average also gained, rising 231.67 points, or 2.7 percent this week, to close at 8,944.54, about 3 percent below its record of 9,211.84, set on May 13.
Technology stocks were even stronger, led by Microsoft, which soared about 10 percent this week after a Federal appeals court made a ruling in Microsoft's favor in the company's dispute with the Government over competition issues. The composite index of the Nasdaq stock market, where Microsoft trades, gained 88.24 points, or 4.9 percent, on the week to close at 1,869.53.
"We're in the midst of a summer rally," said Harvey B. Hirschhorn, the chief investment strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham in Chicago. "The market had been oversold for a while, but we're seeing a lot of support from the bond market, where yields are at a decades-long low."
Indeed, bond prices soared again yesterday, dropping the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond to 5.63 percent, close to its lowest level in nearly 30 years. Inflation fears continue to diminish, and a flood of cheap imports from Asia promises to keep prices low, traders believe.
As for share prices, yesterday's gains were meager, just 8.96 points on the Dow and 3.92 points in the S.& P. 500. But the weekly gains were an impressive show of confidence after months of seesaw trading over concerns that a slowdown in Asia would curb corporate profits.
Even with the Asian worries, a steady flow of Government reports depicting a vibrant American economy, with lower interest rates and soaring consumer confidence, has put investors in a jubilant mood.
Yesterday, for instance, the Government said consumer spending accelerated in May. That followed a Thursday report that the economy in the first quarter grew at an annual rate of 5.4 percent, the second-fastest pace in a decade.
Those kinds of numbers seem to have served as a counterweight to concerns about slowing profit growth at home, and the prospect of an even sharper pinch from falling demand for American-made goods in Asia.
Wall Street analysts say they believe that investors are overlooking the profit slowdown and banking on a powerful economy that will eventually create another wave of hefty profits in the near future.
But in recent weeks, Wall Street has been subjected to a steady stream of profit warnings. "We think the economy is in a profits recession," said Richard Bernstein, the chief quantitative analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Joseph Abbott, a research manager at I.B.E.S. Inc., which tracks earnings, said that profits for the companies in the S.& P. 500 are projected to rise just 2.6 percent in the current second quarter, down from double-digit gains a year earlier.
And the strike at General Motors plants could cut that figure even more. Yesterday, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company lowered his second-quarter earnings estimate for G.M. If profits at G.M. are sharply reduced, in line with the Goldman forecast, I.B.E.S. says growth in S.& P. profits would shrink to just 1.6 percent in the quarter.
Charles Hill, who compiles forecasts for First Call Inc., said earnings expectations were falling at a faster-than-normal rate this quarter.
"We're seeing more negative pre-announcements," he said. "And there could be significant disappointments in the third and fourth quarters. Asia is certainly not going to get better that quickly."
Mr. Hirschhorn at Stein Roe projects that profit growth will decline in the third and fourth quarters largely because of rising wage and price pressures.
"We're not overly excited about the next 12 to 16 months," he said. "We've had nirvana, and now we're moving into post-nirvana."

HEADLINE: CBS to Sell Westinghouse Nuclear Units for $238 Million and Debts

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The CBS Corporation will sell its Westinghouse nuclear and government services operation to a joint venture formed by the Morrison Knudsen Corporation and a British nuclear-fuel processor, the companies said yesterday.
For CBS, which changed its name from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in December, the sale rids the company of the last vestige of its industrial past. 
 For Morrison Knudsen, a $1.7 billion construction and engineering company based in Boise, Idaho, that came near to bankruptcy because of severe debt earlier this decade, the deal is a way to increase its nuclear business quickly.
For Westinghouse, it means a final end to speculation about its future. "We've worked under a lot of uncertainty in the last few months, and we are really glad it's over," said Charles W. Pryor Jr., who will remain Westinghouse president.
So is CBS management. Until last fall, CBS had said that it would spin its industrial businesses off to shareholders. Analysts had projected that even in a booming market, the entire group, which included conventional power systems and process controls, would garner no more than $3 a share; at an anticipated 700 million shares, that would have brought no more than $2.1 billion.
Under the agreement announced yesterday, Morrison Knudsen and British Nuclear Fuels Ltd. will pay $238 million in cash and assume $950 million in liabilities and other obligations of the nuclear operations.
Jack Bergen, a spokesman, said CBS would probably use the money to buy back stock and acquire more radio and outdoor media companies like Transportation Displays Inc., CBS's bus-stop advertising company.
The joint venture will retain the Westinghouse Electric name and will remain in Monroeville, Pa. Morrison Knudsen is providing $168 million of the $238 million in cash, but will assume only $30 million of the $950 million in liabilities. Still, it will get 60 percent of the equity in the company.
That structure may go a long way toward getting the deal approved by the United States Government.
"People are concerned about foreign countries having influence on the nuclear industry, and Morrison Knudsen probably had to be in control for this deal to fly here," said George Davies, an analyst with ADDco Investment Research who also owns Morrison Knudsen stock.
Indeed, that was the trump card that some American bidders for the company hoped they held. "This is an important strategic business, and it would be better if it had remained under 100 percent U.S. ownership," said Linden S. Blue, vice chairman of General Atomics, a San Diego company that had bid for Westinghouse.
William Wicker, a spokesman for the Energy Department, said, "We provided CBS with our assessment on the impact a sale might have on security, and they indicated willingness to address our concerns."
British Nuclear Fuels, a $2.5 billion company whose stock is owned by the British Government, is no stranger to American projects. Its American subsidiary, BNFL Inc., operates cleanup and decommissioning contracts at five Energy Department sites. "We have unique security relationships with the United States Government," said Thomas M. Crimmins Jr., BNFL president.
Nor are the companies strangers to each other. "Our ability to work together is proven," said Dennis R. Washington, Morrison Knudsen's chairman and largest shareholder, adding that his company and BNFL were already teamed up on a project to clean up the Energy Department's Rocky Flats plant near Denver and that Morrison Knudsen and Westinghouse had worked together on projects at the department's Savannah River plant.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Waits As 2 Banks Weigh Merger

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 26

 BODY:
Long-Term Credit Bank, one of Japan's biggest and weakest financial institutions, is in negotiations to merge with a smaller, stronger rival, a move that could turn the combined bank into a showcase for the Government's first blueprint to clean up the nation's bad debt.
If Long-Term's talks with the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company succeed, it would create a bank with $316 billion in assets, slightly behind the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the biggest bank in the United States with $364.7 billion in assets. It could also end weeks of worries that financial troubles at Long-Term could spread and endanger financial stability in Japan, which is already suffering from its worst postwar economic performance, a weakening currency and a jittery stock market. 
 "We have a bit of a crisis of confidence in the financial system, and confidence needs to be restored," said James P. Fiorillo, a financial analyst at ING Barings. "Investors have demanded action and they're getting it."
Japanese news media reported today that a deal was possible, and both banks confirmed later in separate news conferences that they were in talks.
The deal would effectively mean that Sumitomo Trust, with $118 billion in assets, would absorb Long-Term, the nation's 10th-largest financial institution, with $198 billion in assets. Though trading was halted in the stocks of the two companies after word of the talks appeared, Long-Term shares rose nearly 26 percent. Sumitomo shares fell 3 percent.
Koichi Kato, secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, welcomed the talks, though he denied reports that party leaders had helped broker the negotiations. Nonetheless, a deal would offer a timely opportunity for the Government to put into practice a blueprint it calls the Total Plan, aimed at tackling the nation's $600 billion in bad debt held by banks. The debt is considered an underlying cause of Japan's economic malaise.
As part of that plan, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto today ordered details to be drawn up for the establishment of a "bridge bank" to assume the loans and clients of a failed institution. It would operate like the Resolution Trust Corporation, set up by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation aimed at resolving the 1980's savings and loan crisis in the United States.
A deal between Sumitomo Trust and Long-Term is by no means certain. The talks have already raised questions about the role of the Swiss Bank Corporation, which just began joint ventures with Long-Term in asset management and securities.
Sumitomo Trust officials, who said they had been approached by Long-Term about a merger, suggested tonight that Sumitomo itself was interested in becoming a "global player."
Sumitomo is one of Japan's largest trust banks, which manage funds for large institutional investors.
Long-Term is one of three Japanese credit banks established at the end of World War II to provide long-term business loans in an effort to rebuild Japan's economy.
Bankers and analysts say Long-Term had been facing difficulty securing funds in the interbank loan market, a critical source of fund-raising for banks. Today the bank said it had met routine repayments on five-year and one-year debt securities, worth roughly $2.8 billion. Long-Term's president, Katsunobu Ohnogi, insisted today that the bank was "not insolvent."
But analysts say that some foreign financial institutions, concerned about Long-Term's health, were not eager to continue purchasing the bank's debt securities. Moreover, such concerns make the bank highly vulnerable to any sudden shocks, so that it needs to conclude a rescue deal quickly.
The success of the deal would depend partly on the degree of public funds Sumitomo could get from the Government in exchange for absorbing Long-Term, which has about $10.4 billion in bad loans. Sumitomo, which itself has $8 billion in problem loans, said today that it had no plans to take over Long-Term's bad debt.
Atsushi Takahashi, president of Sumitomo, said he had received assurances from the governor of the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, and from the commissioner of the Financial Supervisory Agency, that Sumitomo would receive full support if it absorbed Long-Term.
"We don't set a deadline for the merger," Mr. Takahashi said at a news conference. "I think the merger would be better if it comes earlier."
In fact, there has been concern that Long-Term may be burdened by problems with its affiliate leasing and financing companies, which bankers say have billions of dollars worth of outstanding loans -- many of them property-related.
Bankers say one reason for Sumitomo's decision to negotiate with Long-Term may have been that it, too, has large amounts of outstanding loans to affiliate companies of Long-Term. So, by rescuing Long-Term, Sumitomo may be seeking to avoid greater troubles of its own.
In any case, Mr. Takahashi made it clear that if the talks succeeded, Sumitomo would run the operation.
Some analysts worried that the proposed takeover was a reversion to the old style of arranged unions. Others suggested that if the Government created a bridge bank that took over Long-Term's bad loans, and if Sumitomo received public money to help it manage the expanded institution, then Long-Term's shareholders might lose out and the value of their shares could plummet.
In contrast to the United States, where investors generally like to own stocks in companies that are rescued, in Japan, the opposite could happen.
"If it is decided that LTCB shareholders lose everything, then immediately, the market will divide the Japanese banks into the predators and the prey," said Brian J. Waterhouse, financial analyst at HSBC Securities Japan Ltd. "And the prey, you don't want to own."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Is Viktor Orban Too Old to Lead Hungary?

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
Viktor Orban, the Prime Minister-designate of Hungary, celebrated his 35th birthday last month, and many are wondering if power has not found him too late. Across the former East Bloc some of the most dynamic, Westernized politicians are relatively youthful. The most influential are Sergei Kiriyenko, Russia's 35-year-old reformist Prime Minister, and his deputy Boris Nemtsov, 38. In American terms they are free-market Republicans on economics, liberal Democrats on social issues. Mr. Orban, whose statist politics are just the reverse, was like them once, back when he was young.
In the early 1990's Mr. Orban's party, the Federation of Young Democrats, or Fidesz, was the most popular in Hungary. Its selling point was that it was open only to those under 35. Hungary's youth grew up in a free and Westernized country by Communist standards, without the listlessness of those who lived under a harsher regime. To voters, youth meant energy and efficiency. It meant Europe. 
 Fidesz was born at a Budapest college that Mr. Orban and several other students established in the early 1980's so they could study democracy, largely in English. Once Communism fell, the students formed Fidesz. Hungary already had a party of Vaclav Havel-type dissidents, but many Hungarians considered them soft and naive, and disdained their warnings about the shallowness of capitalist society.
"For years, the dissidents based their politics on morality, not the political game," Mr. Orban told me in an interview in 1992. "That is in the nature of the underground, and they have not been able to change."
Fidesz, by contrast, was a party of Thatcherite sharks. Led by the brash and arrogant Mr. Orban, its politicians dressed like models -- one parliamentarian posed for a Levi's ad -- and held campaign rock concerts. While other parties' TV ads resembled the old Commie spots urging increased potato production, Fidesz ads looked like MTV. They were produced by the East Bloc's first political consulting firm, which Fidesz, touchingly naive about its cynicism, publicly touted as a great stride westward.
But in the next elections, in 1994, Fidesz did poorly. Hungarians liked the image of Fidesz, but in an era of economic trouble did not want to see their social programs cut. Mr. Orban began to revise his ideas. Some Fidesz members split off and joined the traditional dissident party. Those who remained emulated Mr. Orban's about-face. He is now an economic populist and on social issues takes a conservative Catholic line. The party no longer has an age limit.
As Prime Minister he will lead a coalition that includes a party of small farmers, which has endorsed such dubious ideas as a ban on foreign ownership of land. Mr. Orban himself has made some alarmingly nationalist statements and unrealistic economic promises. The day after the elections, Hungary's stock market dropped 8.7 percent. Now he is once again shifting positions, trying to reassure foreign investors that they should keep flooding Hungary. The stock market has bounced back.
Mr. Orban's politics may yet lurch a few more times before his career is over, but so far, political expediency seems to have trumped youth. Age is not a foolproof predictor of politics. The worst leader in the former Communist world is probably Belarus's President, Aleksandr Lukashenko. A former director of a state farm, he speaks of his admiration for Hitler and Stalin. His policies are firmly frozen in the 1950's. He is 43.

HEADLINE: A Clear Ruling on Harassment

 BODY:
With a pair of 7-to-2 decisions yesterday, the Supreme Court ended its term on a constructive note by strengthening the law governing sexual harassment in the workplace. The rulings, in cases from Boca Raton, Fla., and Chicago, reasonably interpreted Title VII of the Civil Rights Act to hold that an employer can be held liable for sexual misconduct by supervisors, whether or not the employer knew about it. The Court also said the employer can be liable whether or not the employee suffered adverse job consequences for refusing a supervisor's unwelcome advances.
The rulings properly recognize that language in the statute defining the term "employer" includes both employers and their "agents." They are also an acknowledgment that sexual harassment causes serious harm even when there is no provable job retaliation or economic loss. However, the Court's balanced approach left room for employers to mount a successful defense by, for example, showing that employees had "unreasonably failed to take advantage of any preventive or corrective opportunities provided by the employer." 
 The ruling seems unlikely to have much impact on Paula Jones's sexual-harassment suit against President Clinton. Her lawyers hope to be helped by the Court's holding that victims who suffer no tangible economic harm may still bring a lawsuit. But in dismissing her case, Federal Judge Susan Webber Wright found that Mr. Clinton had never made a clear threat, which remains a prerequisite for her claim of harassment.
The new rulings make an earlier sexual harassment decision by the Court this week look all the worse. That ruling, applying an analogous statute, effectively deprived students harassed in school of any effective legal remedy. Congress still has the power to correct that mistake, and it should.

HEADLINE: Bolivia's Crackdown on Coca Growers Becomes Increasingly Deadly

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: VILLA ROSARIO, Bolivia

 BODY:
Coca growers ambushed a drug-eradication team near this rebellious hamlet one day early this month, leaving one policeman dead and three wounded. The next day 600 soldiers and policemen barreled through the jungle in a show of force.
With two armed helicopters hovering overhead, the security forces slashed 10 acres of coca bushes with machetes. The hamlet was virtually empty but the police arrested a single straggler who they said was carrying a dynamite fuse. 
 "We've returned to show the cocaleros we will not be stopped," Army Lieut. Col. Jorge Antello, 44, the commander of the operation, told a reporter, as soldiers trained their rifles at the surrounding foliage.
Such expressions of determination in the battle against cocaine represent a break from the past -- even though many of the soldiers did take dried coca leaves from town to chew, then or later.
Still, the official determination to do away with coca is a change. Only six years ago, a Bolivian President wore a pin shaped like a coca leaf on his lapel, symbolizing years of half-hearted efforts against drugs that drove United States officials to distraction. Last year, Washington came close to denying Bolivia the label of a country committed to fighting drugs and cutting off tens of millions of dollars in aid, but at the last moment La Paz fulfilled a United States-set coca eradication quota.
Then suddenly, in January, the new Bolivian President, the retired general Hugo Banzer Suarez, pledged to wipe out every illegal coca plant by the end of his term, in 2002. In Bolivia, illegal plants are defined as those planted since 1988, in areas where international traffickers operate. After six months, his stepped-up efforts have won praise from the Clinton Administration and United Nations officials.
But the efforts have set off increasing violence by coca growers, including blockades of crucial roads and ambushes against the security forces here in Chapare, a region the size of New Jersey where one-quarter of the world's cocaine supply originates.
Under President Banzer's program, 90,000 acres of coca fields will be destroyed in the next four years at a cost of $108 million, with another $700 million going to providing basic improvements like roads and granting credits and training of farmers to grow alternative crops. Government officials said they expect that much of the funding will come from the United States, along with sizable contributions from the European Community and the United Nations.
In a reversal of past Government policy, President Banzer has pledged to phase out payments to coca growers for voluntarily eradicating their illegal crops. During the last several years, coca farmers have been paid $2,500 for every 2.5 acres they eradicate, in a program that has cost American taxpayers nearly $100 million over the last decade.
But United States and Bolivian officials said many of the farmers took the money and then cultivated just as much coca acreage deeper in the jungle. Bolivia had 113,200 acres of coca under cultivation in 1997, according to the Central Intelligence Agency, just 3 percent less than it had in 1993. State Department officials, tired of subsidizing coca growers, pushed hard for the policy change.
Under the new strategy, farmers will be paid nothing and smaller payments will go to the communities for resettlement and social programs until there is a complete cutoff in 2002. Government officials said the savings will go into law enforcement and economic development, but they concede that the policy is unpopular among coca farmers.
"By the year 2002, cocaine will be worthless in Bolivia," the Interior Minister, Guido Nayar Parada, asserted in an interview. "The armed resistance by the cocaleros only shows that we are having an impact and we will not be deterred from applying the law."
While United States officials here love to hear such unqualified commitment, they caution that it will take much to overcome years of disappointments. A State Department official said that despite improvements in eradication, only 1 percent of the cocaine base now being produced in Chapare is being intercepted. The figure is so low, he said, because the police patrol traffickers' routes during the day but not at night, and because corrupt police officers are allowing illegal cargoes through road blocks.
United States officials note that although cultivating new coca fields has been illegal since 1988, only a handful of the 40,000 coca growers in the country have been arrested.
And while United States officials compliment the Government for pressing projects to replace coca crops with legal crops like pineapples and bananas, they warn that it will be difficult to wean peasants off a coca crop that is resistant to tropical funguses and floods, offers a predictable market, and can be harvested four times a year with little effort.
Meanwhile the Americans say that ambushes of the police -- there have been nine since April 2, killing 3 policemen and wounding 15 -- have slowed eradication efforts. The Bolivian Government is now forced to mobilize far larger forces in eradication sweeps, which are slower and more costly. Leaders of six coca grower unions say 12 growers have been killed during confrontations with the security forces in recent months, while the Government admits to only two.
But United States officials also see reasons for optimism. They note that a growing number of peasant groups are signing agreements with the Government to eradicate their coca crops. And a Bolivian anti-terrorism unit, trained and financed by the C.I.A., began operating in the Chapare recently and is making an impact.
The unit has captured a list of terrorist leaders and a code book for terrorist operations belonging to one of the six coca unions that are planting illegal crops in a national park, according to Bolivian Army and State Department officials.
President Banzer's ambitious plan comes at a time when Bolivia's role in the drug world is going through a rapid transformation. Only three years ago, traffickers from the Cali cartel in Colombia bought coca base and paste from Bolivian middlemen and moved it to Colombia for processing. The drugs then moved through Mexico and the Caribbean to the United States market.
But with the arrests of the top Cali leaders and Peru's decision to shoot down cocaine flights, smaller Colombian organizations that have replaced the cartel have stepped up coca cultivation at home. That has made Bolivian coca far less important to international traffickers. The trend should help President Banzer's efforts, even if it is unlikely to make a dent in the drug trade on the streets of American cities.
"If we can't achieve our objectives in Bolivia with the help we are getting from this Government," a senior United States Embassy official said, "we can't succeed anywhere in South America."

HEADLINE: Money and Other Hardening Positions in Strikes at G.M.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., June 26

 BODY:
Losses to the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union from strikes at two parts factories here have soared far beyond the actual money involved at the factories, making it harder with each passing day for either side to paint an eventual settlement as a victory.
Wall Street analysts now estimate G.M.'s after-tax costs from the strikes at $1 billion, and rising by $75 million a day, while the U.A.W.'s members have lost more than $150 million in pay. Based on previous strikes, G.M. and its workers can expect to recoup up to half their losses through extra production and overtime pay in the months after the strikes. But the rest of the losses are likely to be permanent, as customers buy Ford Expeditions and Toyota Camrys instead of Chevrolet Suburbans and Luminas. 
 By contrast, the issues in the strike negotiations here involve sums in the tens of millions of dollars. But as the strikes lengthen, each side has also begun to see them as a showdown over the future course of labor-management relations at the world's largest auto maker, making it much harder to settle.
For the U.A.W. to declare victory after the strikes, it must be able to reassure members that it is doing as much as possible to slow G.M.'s steady elimination of jobs in the United States. But the union faces a difficult task in controlling the expectations of workers who, much more than the union's leadership, see the strikes as a way to force G.M. to back away from its plans to expand production overseas.
G.M. faces a more difficult task. It must convince skeptical institutional investors and Wall Street analysts that a settlement here will allow it to shrink its work force at other factories without further costly strikes. "I want to be able to sleep at night knowing that G.M. can downsize without having a strike," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Companies with steady increases in earnings, quarter after quarter, have been rewarded by Wall Street with fast-rising share prices. Mainly because of 16 strikes over the last five years, G.M.'s quarterly earnings have zigzagged unpredictably, with record profits alternating with heavy losses.
With the U.A.W. now threatening strikes in Indiana and Ohio after any settlement here, G.M.'s stock has been weakening, and its price has dropped 11.4 percent since the first strike June 5, even as the share price at its rival the Ford Motor Company has risen 6.2 percent.
Wall Street analysts assert that G.M. needs to shrink its work force because the auto maker's uninspiring designs are capturing a shrinking share of the market. G.M. held 40 percent of the market a decade ago but has been bouncing around 30 percent in the last year. That means G.M. needs to produce about 1.5 million fewer vehicles even in good years, so fewer workers are needed. G.M. closed some factories during the last recession in the early 1990's, but still has the manufacturing capacity and work force to supply 35 percent of the market, rather than 30 percent.
Auto analysts look at these figures and want the strikes to end with an acknowledgment by the U.A.W. that G.M. is in trouble. "What is necessary is a public recognition by the union leadership, that is communicated to the rank and file, that G.M.'s situation is serious enough that we need to all collectively work together to put the company back on a competitive footing," said Joseph S. Phillippi at Lehman Brothers, who predicted today that the strikes could last at least until mid-August.
G.M. has taken the unusual step in the strikes of publicly criticizing the union's leadership in a bid to convince U.A.W. members that the company has a problem. On Thursday, G.M. gave television stations here a videotape in which a top Flint factory manager explained how inefficient work practices cost the company money.
This strategy has predictably infuriated top U.A.W. officials, who were angry at G.M. even before the strike. Union leaders have said for months that workers are punished for bad decision-making by G.M. executives, such as the company's only now getting around to developing a sport utility vehicle and a midsize sedan for Saturn, its most successful brand. The union has also been upset that G.M. is trying to cut costs while still making some profits and paying top executives large bonuses.
The confrontational stance of G.M. executives has been the last straw for the union. "You've got some heroes in G.M. that are all of a sudden becoming stars and want to talk about they're going to do this and do that -- they're just not making any sense whatsoever," Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, said on Thursday evening.
But the union's only weapon for fighting the company is a blunt one that hurts workers, too. A strong economy appears to have produced very strong auto sales this month, and G.M. dealerships had scant supplies of popular models when the strikes began. G.M. faces further loss of market share this summer for lack of cars and light trucks to sell. The strikes also threaten to delay G.M.'s introduction this fall of new full-size pickup trucks, a mainstay of its profits. And union leaders in Brazil warned today that some huge and highly profitable factories there might have to close soon for lack of parts from the United States.
Workers on the picket lines here recognize the costs of the strikes on all sides and are worried about the eventual settlement. "I don't think anybody's going to win," said one, Doris Motley, an operator of computerized stamping equipment. "They'll compromise, but that's about it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Alexander, left, and Christ LaRowe on the G.M. picket line in Flint, Mich., where it is getting harder for either side to paint an eventual settlement as a victory. (Agence France-Presse)
