PUB-DATE: June 27, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1864 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Crisis in Banking Is Japanese, But Implications Are Global

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN and NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 26

 BODY:
When finance ministers and investment strategists have nightmares these days, they often involve huge financial institutions that are hardly household words in the West.
Yet if names like Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank or Ashikaga Bank trip on Western tongues, there is a growing apprehension that Japanese financial institutions like them may threaten the boom on Wall Street and even the stability of the global economy. 
 Japan's economy is in recession, its stock market is down 60 percent over eight years, and its currency has cascaded 43 percent from its high point in 1995. There is increasing consensus among Japanese politicians -- though not among economists -- that the problems center on a challenge that the Government is only beginning to confront: the mountain of bad debts at the nation's banks.
Now there is an emerging sense that the next few weeks may mark a turning point for the banking crisis -- and, indirectly, for the global economy to which it is connected.
"The situation in Japan is a source of very considerable concern," Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said in Washington after his return this week from a trip to Japan in which he twisted Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's arm to get him to face up to the debt crisis. Mr. Summers added that this was a "pivotal moment for Asia and the global economy."
United States policy makers fear that Japan is a weak link in the international economy. Burdened by bad debts from a property market that has tumbled up to 90 percent, some of Japan's largest banks are in a tenuous position. Merger talks involving the Long-Term Credit Bank, one of the most troubled institutions, and the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company, a stronger bank, were confirmed today. Mr. Hashimoto says the solution to the problem is what he describes as the "Total Plan." That is certainly a misnomer, for the plan is neither total in addressing the economy's problems, nor fully formed. It is instead a vague idea to peel bad loans off bank books and resell them in the marketplace -- much as the United States tackled the savings and loan crisis of the late 1980's by empowering the Resolution Trust Corporation to sell off bad assets from the institutions.
The centerpiece of the Total Plan would be the creation of a Government "bridge bank" that would take over the loan portfolios of failing banks, reselling good loans and writing off bad ones, with taxpayers absorbing the losses. The bridge bank would also look after customers of failing institutions, offering them a bridge to get by until they can establish a relationship with another bank.
Mr. Hashimoto has said that he will summon Parliament for a special session late next month to pass legislation on the plan. The question being asked by bankers, diplomats and businessmen increasingly is no longer whether Mr. Hashimoto will act. It is whether he will do enough, and whether the proposed cure will rescue the economy or cripple it with more Government intervention.
"The politicians are certainly starting to talk volubly about something having to be done even before the elections," said Minoru Makihara, the chairman of the Mitsubishi Corporation, referring to parliamentary elections on July 12. "That is something that they didn't talk about earlier."
L. William Seidman, former head of the Resolution Trust Corporation, has talked with Japanese politicians about the banking crisis. "I told them that there's no way they can do this harmoniously," he said. "It will involve some pain."
Japanese banks are dimly understood in the West, yet they are colossal -- the biggest bank in the world is Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, with $564 billion in total assets, compared with $364.7 billion for the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the biggest in the United States. In a few cases, the Japanese banks are tottering. It was the frailty of these vast institutions that led President Clinton and Mr. Hashimoto to order joint intervention in the currency markets last week to bolster the yen.
There is concern not simply about the collapse of any individual bank or the difficulties of its depositors, but also about the consequences for the entire economic structure. In an increasingly globalized economy, there is a possibility that bank runs could touch off a liquidity crisis that could race around the world in minutes, sending markets plunging and ultimately provoking an international economic slowdown.
Nervousness about the banks is in large part responsible for the decline of the yen. The joint intervention on June 17 bolstered the yen initially, but now it is slipping again, having weakened 0.14 yen today in New York, to 142.44 to the dollar. If the yen falls further, it could escalate the Asian crisis to a new level, particularly if China devalues its currency.
Japan's big banks generally suffer from similar problems. All have far more bad debt than would be acceptable in the United States, but some are stronger than others. Bad loans as a percentage of equity range from 90 percent at Sanwa Bank to 371 percent at Nippon Credit Bank -- compared with an average of 58 percent at the 22 largest United States banks during the height of the American savings and loan crisis in the late 1980's. Among the stronger banks, Sumitomo Bank is a part owner of Goldman, Sachs, while Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, is viewed as fundamentally sound.
Anxieties have been raised in the last couple of weeks over the status of Long-Term Credit Bank, an institution set up after World War II to provide long-term loans to help finance economic rebuilding.
Traditionally, the Government dealt with ailing banks by merging them with stronger ones. Thus, the current banking landscape is a kaleidoscope of banks piled upon banks.
Long-Term Credit's search for a merger partner has reportedly included talks with Nippon Credit Bank, which was essentially bailed out more than a year ago with an injection of new capital, and with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, itself the result of a rescue merger between Dai-Ichi Bank and Nippon Kangyo Bank. Other market-moving reports said that Long-Term Credit was turning to the ailing Daiwa Bank. American regulators ordered its United States operations shut down in 1995, after a bond trader incurred more than $1 billion in losses and then tried, along with the bank, to cover up the losses.
Long-Term Credit may have found a match. Today it confirmed that it was discussing a possible merger with Sumitomo Trust and Banking, a smaller bank specializing in money management for institutional investors that has been forging ties with foreign companies like Citibank.
Not everyone gets rescued, as Yamaichi Securities, a brokerage firm, discovered when it went under last November. Back then, Fuji Bank, a giant, somewhat wobbly bank that is also the Government's paying agent, was Yamaichi's main banker, and its decision not to save Yamaichi was considered rational by the market. But a few months later, tradition got the better of Fuji when it stepped forward to support Yasuda Trust and Banking, an ailing trust bank in Fuji's group of companies.
How did Japan's banks come to be so weak?
During the "bubble economy" of the late 1980's, Japanese land prices soared to ridiculous levels, and it was said that the Imperial Palace grounds in central Tokyo were worth as much as all of California. Japanese banks went on a lending spree, expanding their loan portfolios by $3.6 trillion -- a figure equivalent to 72 percent of the entire Japanese economy -- and in many cases taking buildings as collateral.
The real estate market collapsed under its own weight, with prime Tokyo properties falling to perhaps 10 percent of their peak values. The result is that perhaps $600 billion in loans may be unrecoverable.
Banks have been reluctant to sell property at these prices, and so there is almost no active real estate market. No one knows the market price or the true level of bad loans.
"The market is very inactive," said Teizo Taya, a managing director at the Daiwa Institute of Research. "There are no buyers."
The Government did little about the loans for eight years, thinking that if only property prices would rise again, the problem would right itself. And, indeed, if property prices soared again, borrowers could make payments and the bad loans would then become good.
"I don't see a quick turnaround," said Osamu Aoi, director at the Eiwa Real Estate Company. "I'm covering the downside. I'm very pessimistic. You have to have maximum pessimism toward Japanese real estate in order to survive."
Another problem haunting the banking system is that lending in Japan has been a murky process. Loan documents are short and scanty, if they exist at all, and bankers often performed little analysis on the creditworthiness of the borrower or on the viability of the project.
Often they lent simply on relationships, or because they owned shares in the companies asking for loans. That in turn makes collecting on bad loans a bit awkward.
"The banks have been avoiding drastic change," said Heizo Take naka, professor of economics at Keio University. "Even the president of a bank doesn't understand his own loan portfolio."
So far, the banks have been reluctant to write off bad loans, partly because they do not have enough in profits or in capital to absorb those losses. "They have a lot of loans on their books at the original value and they may have to write them off at 20 to 30 cents on the dollar," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "They don't want to acknowledge the fact that 70 to 80 percent of the value of those loans has disappeared."
The banks are also reluctant to foreclose on loans, seizing property, evicting clients and being publicly branded as heartless capitalists.
Some bankers are also afraid of foreclosing on properties occupied by anyone affiliated with the Yakuza, the Japanese mafia, who have set up shop in many buildings that are the collateral for loans.
In 1994, an executive director in the Nagoya branch of Sumitomo Bank, one of Japan's most innovative and largest banks, was fatally shot. News reports suggested that his murder might have been related to efforts to try to collect on bad loans related to the Yakuza.
The bad loan crisis has done more than create risks about the future. It has also had some direct effects on Japan's real economy, exacerbating the recent recession.
The most alarming problem for many ordinary Japanese businesses has been a credit squeeze. Banks are calling loans from small and medium-sized businesses, or even from the affiliates of their big clients, and this is crimping investment.
Paradoxically, the credit squeeze has been intensified by the Government's efforts to liberalize the banking sector. The Government has been trying to restructure the financial industry, imposing stricter rules and embarking on a broad program of liberalization called the Big Bang. In the process of preparing for these changes, Japanese banks have been trying to trim their assets to meet capital adequacy requirements.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE INVESTORS;
No Executives on Trip, a Hint That Commercial Ties Are Maturing

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
To learn more about the state of relations between the United States and China, look at a few of the things that are not happening during President Clinton's nine-day trip to China.
Though he has an official delegation of 1,000 people, not one represents an American company. Some United States companies will sign contracts during the visit, but Mr. Clinton does not plan to attend that ceremony. The President considered stopping by a new General Motors Corporation auto factory in Shanghai, but decided against it. 
 None of that means business has fallen off the United States-China agenda. In fact, Mr. Clinton may be downplaying commercial links precisely because they have become such a dominant bilateral issue: The political scandal made up of China's business ambitions, high-tech exports and campaign contributions has dogged him at home.
More broadly, the fact that the President's trip focuses on diplomatic strategy, culture and tourism instead of commerce is a sign that business ties have in some ways outgrown the contract-by-contract nurturing required during the 1980's or the early 1990's, when many visiting American dignitaries traveled with planes full of chief executives seeking high-level contacts.
"China is not exactly virgin territory for American business," said Robert A. Kapp, president of the United States-China Business Council. "They are there in force. It is not as though they need the President to let them in on the best kept secret in world trade."
Since the mid-1980's, when the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the former American Motors and a handful of other pioneers first planted stakes in China, investment has gone from adventurous to ordinary. More than half of the Fortune 500 companies have operations there, and smaller companies are also active, down to entrepreneurs whose only business is in China. In the early part of this decade, many companies set up factories in China to manufacture goods for export or began aggressively marketing their products in China, a spree that shows few signs of letting up despite China's slowing economic growth.
Last year, American companies had two-way trade with China valued at about $75 billion. They have invested a cumulative $36 billion, eight times as much as they had committed when President Bush visited China in 1989, the last American leader to make the trip. Among Asian countries, only Japan has a bigger business relationship with the United States.
Like the broader relationship, the state of commercial ties has long been described in absolutes. Chinese Government officials are seen as either friends or foes of business. The China market is called a salvation for some companies and a sinkhole for others.
But after two decades of investing, hyperbole has given way to sober assessments of the pluses and minuses of doing business in what many call the world's most challenging emerging market. American companies have been runaway successes; others have proven dismal failures. Most big companies say they are there for the long term and are prepared to take their lumps along the way.
The Eastman Kodak Company is a good example. The company struggled for years to distribute its film there, while many local companies sell lower-grade product and enjoy Government protection. But earlier this year, Beijing approved Kodak's longstanding request to buy out three Chinese competitors, to open two factories and to put its bright yellow boxes on store shelves nationwide. Kodak has announced plans to invest $1 billion over the next two years.
"It took us several years to get the deal we wanted. You have to have patience and the willingness to stick it out," said David Swift, president of Kodak's China operation. "But since we got the license, everything has been superb."
Kodak claims to sell more film in China than any other company, domestic or foreign. Moreover, China has become Kodak's No. 3 worldwide market, behind the United States and Germany and ahead of Japan.
Vast advertising has helped many American brands gain ground in China. Four out of five Chinese consumers surveyed by the Gallup Organization knew Coca-Cola, more than recognized any other foreign brand name. The Procter & Gamble Company's Head and Shoulders shampoo and the Chrysler Corporation's Jeep sport-utility vehicle, made in China by the American companies, were also in the top five.
Profits have followed, though not as reliably as some investors might have hoped. Figures are hard to track, as many United States multinationals decline to break out sales and profits by country. But the evidence suggests that businesses can operate profitably in China provided they do what they would need to do anywhere else: Develop good business plans, make products people can afford to buy and beat the competition.
One survey conducted by A. T. Kearney, a Chicago-based consulting firm, asked the bosses of 70 multinationals how their ventures in China were performing. They responded that two out of five of their China ventures -- many have more than one -- were operating in the black.
They said they expected the rest to break even within three years of their start-ups.
The Finance Ministry has reported similar results. A survey completed last year found that 40 percent of foreign businesses earned profits in 1996. The rest broke even or ran losses. Given the huge volume of investments in the mid-1990's, which funded tens of thousands of new ventures along China's eastern coast, some analysts say they are surprised that so many can operate profitably.
"I don't think anyone finds it easy," said Rich Miskewicz, Kearney's managing director for greater China. "But they are sticking it out and many are reaching profitability within the time frame they planned, sometimes even faster."
But for every success story there is at least one bitter memory.
The Ameritech Corporation, the Chicago-based Baby Bell, sought to get into the business of providing cellular phone service in China, investing $20 million in a venture there. But last year the company pulled out, citing persistent regulatory obstacles.
Caterpillar Inc., the heavy equipment maker, gave up on a troubled joint venture with a Shanghai company, saying it had badly overestimated the market in China for diesel engines. It remains committed to China, however, with several other factories there. The Whirlpool Corporation opened four factories in China to make household appliances in the mid-1990's, but closed two last year. The company said the local competitors proved tougher than anticipated.
Among other persistent complaints, businesses say China has a weak legal system that does not enforce contracts reliably.
American companies lose billions of dollars a year there because Chinese companies make illegal copies of Prozac, Windows 95 and "Titanic," and many famous drugs, software, movies and music that carry American trademarks and copyrights.
Moreover, some areas where American companies have shown themselves to be fierce competitors elsewhere in the world are effectively off limits to foreign investors in China. Retail and distribution, banking and transportation are a few industries where bans or restrictions make it difficult to invest. American officials complain that such barriers help China run a $50 billion trade surplus with the United States, second only to Japan's, creating political waves in Congress.
Virtually all investors in China face some political risk, both in China and at home, though many have learned to keep their heads down when tensions rise. Some companies expanded through the political repression during and after the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989.
Those that have withdrawn have sometimes regretted it. Levi Strauss & Company closed up shop in 1994, saying Beijing's violations of human rights made it an unfit place to invest. The company returned this spring, saying it wanted to "untie its hands" and resume doing business in one of the world's biggest market for jeans.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
Tiananmen Comment Leads to Clinton-Jiang Debate

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Saturday, June 27

 BODY:
President Clinton and the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, on live television, engaged in an extraodinary, and at times heated, debate today over China's human rights record.
In a joint appearance after a two-hour summit meeting, the two Presidents announced a sheaf of agreements, but offered sharply different interpretations of the Tiananmen Square protests nine years ago that ended in the deaths of hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators. 
 Mr. Clinton said that China was "wrong" to violently crush the demonstrations and said that China's political and economic development -- and its acceptance by the rest of the world -- were threatened by an excessive search for internal order.
Mr. Jiang retorted that Mr. Clinton was viewing events in China from the luxury of America's wealth and long history of social stability.
And he said of the Tiananmen "disturbances" of June 1989, "The Chinese people have long drawn its own conclusion. Had the Chinese Government not taken the resolute measures, we could not have enjoyed the stability we are enjoying today."
Mr. Jiang said that China is a socialist country with a different political and social system than the United States. And he pointedly noted, "No country's human rights situation is perfect."
The Chinese President offered Mr. Clinton a chance to respond, which he eagerly seized. Mr. Clinton said that he understood China's desire for social stabilty because of centuries of upheaval, disruption and anarchy. But he said that advanced societies accepted a compromise between freedom and order.
"If you have a lot of personal freedom, some people may abuse it," Mr. Clinton said. "But if you are so afraid of personal freedom because of the abuse, and if you limit personal freedom too much, you pay an even greater price."
The debate followed a welcoming ceremony on Tiananmen Square, the vast expanse through which modern Chinese history has flowed, from the declaration of the Communist state in 1949 to the crushing of protest 40 years later.
Although Mr. Clinton defended his appearance before the Great Hall of the People on the edge of Tiananmen Square as the expected behavior of a state visitor to China, in his remarks later, the President referred to the site of the 1989 student-led demonstrations that ended in terror and bloodshed.
"For all of our agreements we still disagree about the meaning of what happened then. I believe, and the American people believe, that the use of force and the tragic loss of lives -- was wrong. I believe, and the American people believe, that freedom of speech, association, and religion are, as recognized by the U.N. Charter, the right of people everywhere and should be protected by their governments," the President said.
He did not abandon the human rights issue, but went on to say:
"We have developed a relationship of openness and candor. When we differ, as we do from time to time, we speak openly and candidly. It is well known that the principal area of our difference in recent years is over questions of human rights."
Beyond human rights, much of the remainder of the joint news conference in the Great Hall was devoted to the announcements of a series of agreements including a pledge to redirect the nuclear-tipped ballistic missiles now aimed at each other's cities.
The step is largely symbolic, because such weapons can be changed back in a matter of minutes.
Mr. Jiang also agreed that China would "actively study" joining the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international agreement governing the sale of certain missiles and missile technology. China has resisted the pact because missile exports are a key money-maker for the military. No timetable was set for China's actually joining the regime.
The two countries also announced an agreement on a joint statement on the nuclear arms race now under way in South Asia, including pledges not to export to India or Pakistan any missiles, missile equipment or materials capable of delivering nuclear weapons. The agreement covers only medium- and long-range missiles.
China has also agreed to permit inspections of Chinese sites receiving high-technology equipment from the United States to assure that it is being put to its intended use and not diverted for military purposes.
This provision has gained increased importance in recent weeks with disclosures that China may have used commercial satellites for military communications, and earlier revelations that computers supposedly for industrial applications had been diverted to military installations.
But there was no concrete progress on a number of American human rights concerns, including the treatment of Tibet and an accounting for hundreds of political prisoners.
An American official involved in the summit talks said he was hopeful that signs of progress on rights might come in the weeks and months after Mr. Clinton leaves China.
"Sometimes things are not announced at the summit, but happen afterward," this official said.
The leaders also agreed to expand the Peace Corps presence here and to work toward new cooperation on legal reforms, environmental programs and a new clean-energy project to reduce the emissions of coal-burning power plants.
The summit results amount to a "pretty substantial package," the official said. But many of the military and nonproliferation items were expected and represented at best incremental steps.
At this morning's ceremonies Mr. Clinton stood stiffly as the People's Liberation Army band played "The Star-Spangled Banner" and an evocative 21-gun cannonade rang out across the square. The gunfire continued through the playing of the Chinese national anthem, "March of the Volunteers."
When the two Presidents finished reviewing the troops, they turned and walked along a red carpet toward the steps of the Great Hall of the People, smiling and chatting. In 13 minutes, the ceremony, which stirred such memories and generated such controversy, was over.
The ceremony came at the start of a one-day summit meeting that has already been marred by the detention and harassment of several Chinese political dissidents.
The dispute forced the President and his senior aides into a defensive crouch and threatened to undermine China's central goal of the summit -- a portrait of a "new China" of greater economic and personal freedom.
Mr. Clinton's appearance on the square this morning dramatized this nation's struggle between memory and forgetting.
The Chinese leadership hopes to consign to history the events of the spring of 1989, when indelible images of blood-letting in the streets and of a lone protester standing before a column of tanks were broadcast around the world. The events are the subject of a continuing dispute in China, even at high levels of the party.
In a letter to the party's Central Committee, Zhao Ziyang, who has been under house arrest since he was ousted as Communist Party chief at the time of Tiananmen, challenged the nation's leaders to admit that the incident was reprehensible as well as an immense political blunder.
Mr. Clinton, harshly criticized in the United States for lending his prestige to Beijing's leaders by attending the ceremony, hopes that his presence here will force the world to remember that bloody night.
On Friday, the White House sharply criticized Beijing for the harassment of dissidents on the first day of Mr. Clinton's state visit, calling the detentions "thoroughly unacceptable."
But the President did not take steps to impose any punishment or withhold any favors in response.
Using unusually harsh language, Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said the Chinese internal security apparatus was "doing what comes naturally" by harassing outspoken opponents of the Government who officials fear might embarrass Beijing during the President's visit.
"People are not debris to be swept up for a visitor," Mr. Berger said at a briefing for reporters on Friday in Xian, before the Presidential entourage flew to Beijing for the summit meeting. "We certainly will not accept this."
Human rights groups reported that four dissidents were detained in two Chinese cities and one removed from Xian in the hours before Mr. Clinton's arrival Thursday night.
China demonstrated little concern about the detentions, denying that anyone had actually been "arrested" and offering American diplomats no explanation for their actions. Chinese authorities routinely round up dissidents and other potential troublemakers before important events.
Mr. Berger tried to explain Beijing's crackdown on dissidents as a remnant of its police-state past, a preference for order over political freedom. He said the repression was diminishing, if slowly.
"China is changing, but there are still forces that are pulling the other direction, that are resisting," Mr. Berger said. "I think China's human rights record is terrible. I think China is an authoritarian nation, as I've said before. I think there's been some progress in human rights, but it has been not nearly enough.
"In the area of public dissent, they are still totally unacceptable. I don't think this is directed at President Clinton. The fact that it happens generally in connection with these kinds of visits, it is not appropriate, it is not necessary," he said.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton said he found reports of the detentions "disturbing," but gave no indication that he would change his approach to China in response. "I think it makes the case, it makes it all the more important that we continue to work with the Chinese and engage them."
Mike Jendrzejczyk, director of Human Rights Watch Asia, said the Administration's unwillingness to respond with more than words was a sign that the White House was "desperate not to offend the Chinese."
The White House has been pressing for China to permit the live, nationwide broadcast of Mr. Clinton's Monday speech, in which the President is expected to deliver his strongest message on human rights.
Beijing has resisted, and White House officials said today that it appeared possible that the speech would be seen everywhere but China.
By the same token,at today's ceremony, even the most ardent fans barely got a glimpse of the ceremony. The central area of Tiananmen Square itself was swept clean of any spectators, who were kept on the north side of the square by the entrance to the Forbidden City.
"We couldn't see anything," said Wang Jie, 32, a shoemaker. "It would have been better to watch TV."
Mr. Wang's colleague, Li Changping, said most Chinese have warm feelings for Mr. Clinton and wanted to see him. "We got up at 3 in the morning to come here," said Mr. Li. "We like Clinton a lot."

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
AFRICA: A Biography of the Continent, by John Reader. (Knopf, $35.) An impressive synthesis of recent geological, climatological and paleontological discoveries that bear on both Africa's prehistoric boom and its bad luck lately.
 
A BEAUTIFUL MIND, by Sylvia Nasar. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The author, who writes about economics for The Times, chronicles the remarkable life of John Nash, the developer of game theory, following him from his brilliant early career through crippling schizophrenia, mysterious recovery and a Nobel Prize.
 
CARDOZO, by Andrew L. Kaufman. (Harvard University, $55.) A distinguished biography of a distinguished American jurist (Chief Judge of New York 1926-32, Justice of the Supreme Court 1932-38) whose legal and personal thought and conduct manifested an extraordinary purity.
 
COLD NEW WORLD: Growing Up in a Harder Country, by William Finnegan. (Random House, $26.) With great sympathy but no pity, a journalist profiles four young people who have mortgaged their futures for drugs, crime and extremism; through their stories he examines the social forces that compelled their desperate choices.
 
GAIN, by Richard Powers. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) An erudite, penetrating novel that deals with the evolution of American industry and commercial practice over two centuries, and with one of its casualties, a woman who (rightly or wrongly) blames chemicals for her cancer.
 
LOST LAKE: Stories, by Mark Slouka. (Knopf, $21.) Beautiful and mysterious fiction with a dreamlike sense of life in death and death in life, set in a summer community in upstate New York.
 
LOVES THAT BIND, by Julian Rios. (Knopf, $24.) In this epistolary novel first published in Spain, the narrator dreamily chronicles a slew of past sexual encounters in a series of letters to his (current) beloved, for whom he is searching in London. Beloved's response is not recorded.
 
RIVER ANGEL, by A. Manette Ansay. (Morrow, $24.) An eloquent novel that sets the rotten behavior of bored teen-agers against the domain of spiritual belief, represented here by a possible miracle that seems both awesome and trivial.
 
SOMEONE ELSE'S HOUSE: America's Unfinished Struggle for Integration, by Tamar Jacoby. (Free Press, $30.) An unrelenting, discouraging examination of three cities -- New York, Detroit and Atlanta -- where people of good and ill will combined to defeat the hopes of the 1960's.
 
A WORLD AWAY, by Stewart O'Nan. (Holt, $23.) Domestic hostilities in a Long Island family proceed under a thin camouflage of brilliantly realized World War II period detail in this grim novel by a proven master of grimness.

HEADLINE: Get to Work!

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the author of "The End of Affluence" and the editor of Challenge magazine.

 BODY:

The Productive Edge
 How U.S. Industries Are Pointing the Way
 to a New Era of Economic Growth.
 By Richard K. Lester.
 368 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95. 
 Richard K. Lester believes that America has much more to do to get its economy back on track. For those who read the nation's financial pages, this may come as something of a surprise. Wall Street keeps telling us that the economy is as good as it gets. Alan Greenspan agrees. And the White House takes every opportunity to boast about its financial helmsmanship.
"The Productive Edge" is a necessary corrective to all this economic triumphalism. Despite low rates of unemployment and inflation, Lester reminds us, the economy's long-term health and the nation's standard of living require the revitalization of labor productivity -- the output of goods and services per hour of work. Lester quotes the economist William Baumol: "In terms of human welfare, there is nothing that matters as much in the long run."
But after increasing at a rate of 2.3 percent a year on average from 1870 until the early 1970's, the rate of productivity growth has slowed to about 1 percent a year. The stronger growth of the last two years has not changed this trend. In fact, the current economic expansion, which began in 1991, remains the slowest in the post-World War II period. Family income adjusted for inflation is still no higher than it was in 1989.
In other words, if there really is a new, fast-growing, computer-driven economy, as everyone keeps saying, it has yet to show itself. Even the increase in America's exports, Lester notes, has depended more on the fall of the dollar in the late 1980's and early 1990's than on rising productivity.
Don't think Lester is one of those pessimists American businessmen love to hate. He is, in fact, a resolute optimist. But as the director of M.I.T.'s Industrial Performance Center, he has found that only a small part of what is so enthusiastically preached in corporate America has actually worked. Take highly touted managerial reforms like "total quality management," which emphasizes fulfilling the customer's every desire. "A survey of 500 American manufacturing and service companies," Lester points out, "found that only a third felt that their T.Q.M. programs were having a significant impact on their competitiveness." Or consider corporate reengineering, which eliminates specialized tasks in favor of involving workers in the whole production process. "A detailed analysis of 20 re-engineering projects," Lester says, "revealed that while many had achieved sizable efficiency improvements in individual processes, only a small fraction had delivered significant benefits to the bottom line." And what about all those lay-offs in the name of corporate restructuring? Lester sweepingly concludes that there is "no evidence" that they have raised the competitiveness of American companies.
What Lester makes clear is that the modern business environment, with its many new products and marketing techniques, its mobile capital and far-flung competition, is more volatile and uncertain than it had been for the hundred years of America's industrial development after the Civil War, when mass production was dominant. He claims that business's key task now is to learn how to deal with ambiguity, volatility and profound change.
In such an environment, Lester finds that there are few hard-and-fast rules for success. In the 1980's, for example, the small, often evanescent companies of the semiconductor industry were widely criticized for being too unstable to compete with the large, vertically integrated producers in Japan. It turned out that the entrepreneurial vigor of these companies (perhaps with some assistance from the Federal Government) helped revitalize the industry, enabling it to overtake the Japanese. By contrast, the successful development of the cellular telephone industry is owed to large, well-capitalized businesses like Motorola and Lucent Technologies in the United States, Nokia in Finland and Ericsson in Sweden. Lester recounts in detail the success stories of five such industries to "illustrate the tremendous variation in the processes of industrial transformation that are at work."
Nevertheless, Lester believes there are several "best practices" that can successfully transform America's corporations. What has enabled companies to stand out in an uncertain business environment, he reports, is not widely applauded profit-mindedness so much as a clear, confident vision -- a new product line, an untested technology, an innovative marketing approach, a way to increase quality dramatically. Such companies take risks that often cannot be easily quantified. They learn to use their workers' creative and innovative skills. They break down traditional organizational hierarchies into "small, autonomous units" that can react quickly. They adopt not one or two changes in the workplace but a battery of reforms. They build trust in their employees.
Lester's suggestions admittedly read more like instructions for how to paint a picture or play baseball than for how to achieve business success. They certainly aren't a contemporary equivalent to Frederick Taylor's hard-nosed "scientific management." Still, if the advice sounds warm and fuzzy, it may be all that can be said in this new age. What Lester convincingly shows is that we now live in an economy where innovation matters most, where even the largest companies must emphasize creativity and imagination to compete.
On the other hand, I don't think Lester faces up to the full implications of the uncertain environment. In an economy that needs creative input, it may well be difficult to raise productivity rates very much, no matter what one does. Among the greater ironies of the computer age is the fact that information is cheap and accessible, and so no longer very valuable. What is valuable is what one does with it. And human imagination cannot be mechanized.
This doesn't mean that we can't do better. Lester's sections on work-force reforms and research and development are particularly strong. He also sees a role for government investment in research, as well as in education and infrastructure. He thinks employee benefits like pensions should be made portable. At this point in the nation's overenthusiastic public conversation, it is refreshing to hear several cogent ideas, free of the customary bombast, about how we can genuinely improve matters.

HEADLINE: Paradise Lost

BYLINE: By Paul Raeburn; Paul Raeburn, a senior editor at Business Week, is the author of "The Last Harvest" and a forthcoming book on Mars.

 BODY:

THE ECOLOGY OF EDEN
 By Evan Eisenberg.
 612 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $30. 
 Imagine gazing across a jagged landscape where coils of steam hiss from the ground, hundreds of creatures gather at watering holes and fierce competition determines rank. Depending on whether the steam rises from geothermal vents or manhole covers, this place could be either Yellowstone National Park or Times Square. Yet one represents wilderness, the other civilization, and that dichotomy is the subject of "The Ecology of Eden," a broad rumination by Evan Eisenberg on the fragile state of the earth's natural environment and what might be done to protect it. In this ambitious work, Eisenberg tries to step beyond old arguments, in which civilization and wilderness always seem to be at odds. He argues that the health of planet Earth depends on the health of both: "The human condition is (among other things) the state of trying to keep one's balance on the shifting soil between these two domains. That balancing act is what this book is about."
His story begins with humanity's expulsion from Eden. But it is not about the ecology of Eden; it's about the ecology of what humans were stuck with after being thrown out. Denied Eden's riches and forced to earn a living, humans spread across the globe, building civilizations and mostly ignoring the seemingly endless wilderness. As Eisenberg notes, that was a mistake. Wilderness frightened our ancestors -- but it was also what kept them alive. "Taking over the world is something like taking over a company," he writes. "Either you leave most of the workers in place, or you replace them with others who can get the job done." In the takeover of the world, the "jobs in question are ecological services -- the cycling of water and nutrients; the flow of energy; the dispersal of pollen, seeds and other propagules; the regulation of climate; the balancing of gases in the air -- without which most creatures on earth . . . would perish." During the last 10,000 years, "we have gutted the buildings, fired the employees, sold off the assets," and "the shiny new equipment we have brought in" cannot be trusted to supplant ecological services provided by nature. "By the time we know for sure what the effects are, it will be too late to do much about them."
In the first of the book's four sections, Eisenberg describes changes that have swept over the earth since that expulsion from Eden. He begins with the passage of human ancestors from forests to grasslands and discusses the emergence of agriculture. Then he seems to ricochet all over the place. One minute he talks about the evolutionary origin of cells, then the destruction of topsoil, then the release of starlings in Central Park by a misguided Shakespeare buff who wanted North America to have every species of bird mentioned in the playwright's works.
Eisenberg tries to summarize the current environmental crisis quickly before moving on to a search for a way out of it, a search that occupies most of the book. However, his analysis of the problem relies on poorly chosen examples that don't add up to very much. In recent years, researchers have tried to document rates of species extinction, to show how and where natural habitat is being lost, to monitor pollution and to assess other environmental threats. Inclusion of some of that research would have given strength and currency to Eisenberg's case, but he largely ignores it.
In part two, he takes a long detour through mythology, asking "what ecological facts the myths reflect, cover up or help create." It's an intriguing idea: Perhaps literature and mythology will reveal important insights that haven't been reflected in science. In part three, Eisenberg roams through human history for clues. And in part four, he uses what he has learned to suggest answers to current environmental problems.
I would like to report what he learned, but I am still reeling from one of the most impressive uses of metaphor I have seen. Nowhere does Eisenberg use a simple, descriptive phrase where a metaphor will suffice. Wilderness and civilization become "The Mountain" and "The Tower." "The World Mountain is mythic shorthand for an ecological fact. There are certain places on earth that . . . are spigots for the circulation of wildness through places made hard and almost impermeable by long human use." In one breath, Eisenberg describes the Central Park starlings as "winged mice . . . airborne rats, or great speckled bees . . . leaving a white and malodorous honey behind." Discussing the value of hedgerows and windbreaks as migratory pathways for wildlife, he says "such corridors would turn the walled garden inside out so that, like a Klein bottle, it would contain the universe."
One of the lessons Eisenberg says he learned from mythology and history is that we should collaborate with nature, not fight it. He calls that collaboration "Earth Jazz," and it goes like this: "A good model for the planet might be a bebop quartet led by a saxophonist. . . . If you translate time into space, the sax player into humankind, and the three sidemen into other taxa -- making the piano, say, the nonhuman animals, the bass the plants, the drum set a catchall for fungi, protoctists and bacteria -- you get a lesson in how humans can work with nature." Translation: The hills are alive -- with the sound of music.
At one point he compares nature to the economy, observing that nature is guided by an invisible hand that "sometimes makes a hash of things." But he does not address the serious issue of how commerce and the economy impinge on the environment. Maybe the explanation for the PCB's at the bottom of the Hudson River has less to do with The Mountain and The Tower than with General Electric's unwillingness to pay for the cleanup.
He neatly dismisses most environmentalists as either "deep ecologists" or "planet managers." Deep ecologists hold that "humans have no right to a larger role in nature than raccoons." Planet managers "are the crazed futurists, the sort of people who would make cows legless milk-dispensers, conveniently stackable." One might have hoped for more insightful descriptions.
Eisenberg does have a serious point to make, and it has something to do with collaboration with nature. Without thriving cities, he argues, "the tide of human population must soon overwhelm whatever wilderness is left." That's a useful observation, but he takes it too far. "Cities are natural. Even their unnaturalness is natural, for it springs from our nature." Times Square, in other words, is as natural as Yellowstone? Send in the clowns.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 12; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 918 words

HEADLINE: The Capitalist;
Bottom-Fishing Time?

BYLINE: By Walter Russell Mead; Walter Russell Mead is a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.

 BODY:
As Indonesia's new president, B.J. Habibie, settles into office, soldiers are returning to their barracks and students to their dorms, and some hardy American investors are mulling over returning to Indonesia.
For investors, getting in on the ground floor of an Indonesian recovery would be a bonanza. In the last year, political instability and Asia's economic turmoil combined to reduce prices of Indonesian debt and equity to almost derisory levels. Bottom-fishing investors can now buy what were once well-regarded companies and financial assets for pennies on the dollar; an economic rebound would make millions for those daring enough to fish in Indonesia's murky, choppy markets.
With Washington and Tokyo seemingly determined to stabilize the yen and promote a regional recovery in Asia, this might look like a good time. But Indonesia's troubles run deep, and what looks like an opportunity today may become a disaster in the not-too-distant future. 
 Indonesia, an archipelago of 13,000-plus islands, is the largest Muslim country in the world and the fourth most populous country overall. Nevertheless, the Indonesian state is fragile. Its 214 million people speak hundreds of different languages. Their backgrounds range from the ritualized and ancient Javanese civilization to tribal cultures of Irian Jaya. As with many African countries, the only thing many of Indonesia's peoples had in common at independence was the experience of colonial domination by the same nation. In Indonesia's case, that was the Dutch, who finally withdrew in 1949.
Bad as the former President, Suharto, was in many respects, he ran a stable regime that kept Indonesia's disparate elements in place. He also steadied a turbulent region while helping to balance China's growing power. The climate of peace and cooperation that Suharto promoted -- notably with his neighbors in Malaysia and Singapore -- did much to set the stage for the region's explosive economic growth.
Suharto relied on the armed forces and the economy to hold the country together. Both were built up -- primarily through patronage and corruption -- under his long reign and both now face the difficult task of gaining popular trust and legitimacy.
That won't be easy, and the main reason is the economy. Indonesians -- like Americans -- seem willing to tolerate presidential hanky-panky when the economy is strong. And for most of Suharto's tenure the economy was extremely strong. Thanks to family planning and economic growth, per capita gross domestic product rose by an average of 4.3 percent annually from 1965 to 1988. As the Far Eastern Economic Review points out, this was one of the highest sustained increases in living standards in the world. The poverty rate dropped from an estimated 70 percent of the population in 1970 to about 15 percent two decades later. At the same time, however, Suharto allowed the Chinese minority in Indonesia -- about 3 percent of the population -- to control an estimated 70 percent of the national economy.
Now that the economy -- and living standards -- are in free fall, there are widespread calls to investigate the Suharto family's extensive web of partnerships and cross holdings. Because Suharto did so much of his business with ethnic Chinese, and because the Chinese prospered so greatly during his tenure, calls to investigate and return Suharto family wealth could turn into something like a general assault on the Chinese businessmen who largely control the economy.
The trouble, however, is that once the Indonesians start picking at the threads of economic corruption and political cronyism, the whole fabric of their national life could unravel. It isn't just a few bankers and real-estate developers who are tied to the former ruling family; the whole business class was implicated in an economic development that was systematically perverted to favor the Suharto clan. And it isn't just a handful of generals who participated in repression and corruption under the ancien regime; over the last 30 years, Suharto reshaped the Indonesian armed forces in his image.
Meanwhile, a vicious circle is likely to develop as economic turmoil leads to more anti-Chinese agitation and to calls for new trials and investigations that a weak Government may be powerless to resist. This would further undermine confidence among the country's business elite, leading to more capital flight and more economic turmoil. Having repressed moderate politicians and prevented responsible opposition leaders from developing strong national organizations, Indonesia's elites may now face an inexorable rise of popular fury as living standards continue to fall.
If this scenario unfolds, both Indonesia and the region are in for much more tumult than we have yet seen. Indonesia could well be in the early moments of a two-stage revolution -- like the Russian and Iranian revolutions. In Stage 1, the old emperor goes out; in Stage 2, an ineffectual transitional regime is overthrown by a radical and more permanent successor.
Czarist Russia was a promising emerging market and a friend of the United States before its October Revolution. Indonesia, many of whose people rightly accuse Washington of supporting Suharto through decades of repression, could yet emerge as a world-class foreign-policy and economic headache. Without a quick economic recovery, Indonesia could all too easily slide into chaos or move toward an anti-Western radicalism, conceivably with Islamist overtones.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Avant le deluge. Suharto posed with his oldest daughter, youngest son and newest in-law at the end of the wedding feast last year. (Photograph by Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 5; Page 13; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: Harry and Bess at Home

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN; SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, a former Times correspondent, lives in Kansas.

 BODY:
AMID suburban sprawl and six lanes of traffic whizzing along Highway 71 just south of Kansas City, Mo., the simple sign seemed to peek out from the past. "Truman Farm. Next Right," it announced. I swung off, following the ramp past the sign welcoming me to Grandview, Mo., then under the railroad overpass and up to Blue Ridge Boulevard. A strip mall on the corner offered Arby's, White Castle, Blockbuster Video and more. As I continued southwest along Blue Ridge, the unadorned backside of the Truman Corners Shopping Center was on the left, Pizza Hut on the right.
Finally I picked out the somber white farmhouse amid the endless stretch of franchises and low-slung commercial buildings. I drove into what remains of the 600-acre farm where Harry S. Truman learned to plow a straight row behind a team of horses and dealt with the frustrations of an early life that brought him neither financial nor career success. 
 Visiting the places that formed the 33d President of the United States, and to which he returned for the final two decades of his life, means making the trip back in time through traffic jams, commerce and blight. Nevertheless, I found that with a little planning it was possible to immerse myself in life as he lived it and hardly notice the end of the 20th century zooming by.
I took along David McCullough's book "Truman" (Simon & Schuster, 1992). Although I grew up a bare 30 miles away and the Truman name was a fixture in my life, opening the book to the sections about his life in Missouri was like being accompanied by an enchanting storyteller as I traveled from the farm in Grandview north to Independence and the famous white Victorian house where he spent summers during his Presidency and where he lived in retirement, then to the library and museum built in his honor after he left the White House in 1953. This was a timely moment to make a Truman pilgrimage because the library has mounted a yearlong exhibition that is a tonic for cynicism about love and Presidents. "Dear Bess . . . Love Letters from the President," is a wonderfully moving sampling of the 1,300 letters Truman wrote to Bess during their long courtship and marriage, coupled with a display of 15 of her letters to him. Although his letters have long been available to researchers, this is the first time that Margaret Truman Daniel has allowed any of her mother's letters to be exhibited.
Just three or four acres of land now surround the Grandview farmhouse, which was restored and opened to the public four years ago. It was not yet open for the season on the day in mid-February when I visited, but I strolled the grounds at leisure and peeked through the lace curtains at the windows. A few dilapidated farm buildings, including the outhouse, are scattered in the back. It was tempting to become angry about the garden apartments under construction almost against the fence on one side of the farm and the helter-skelter commercial development everywhere else. A Roosevelt or a Rockefeller might have preserved these lands intact, maybe as a park rolling down toward the Blue River. But for Harry Truman and his brother, Vivian, and sister, Mary Jane, that was not an option. They needed the money provided by suburban development on the land inherited from their mother, Martha Ellen.
"Take care of the land, and it will take care of you," one of my grandfathers used to say as he worked his own land a county removed from that of the Trumans. Certainly the sale of the farm brought Harry Truman a measure of financial security in the years before Congress granted a pension to former Presidents.
The farm was passed down from the Youngs, Harry Truman's maternal grandparents, who settled it in 1867. The Trumans lived here with them during Harry's early years, then moved away -- to farms of their own at various times, to Independence and also to Kansas City -- before returning. This was the family's refuge during years of struggle, the place to which it came back when all else failed. Lacking the money to go to college, Harry Truman went to work in a bank after high school, but in his mid-20's he had to return to help on the farm.
From the farm I followed Blue Ridge Boulevard, which rambles north and slightly east into Independence, less than 20 miles. Despite its scenic-sounding name, Blue Ridge teems with with urban grit and suburban sameness. But the old heart of Independence is largely intact and, despite some decay, it remains a charming place, just 15 miles east of the skyscrapers in downtown Kansas City.
The logical starting point is the house at 219 North Delaware Street, surely one of the most nostalgia-inducing houses in America and once the embodiment of the expression Summer White House. Bess Truman grew up in the house, which had been passed down from her grandparents. Across the street is the plainer one where Harry Truman's beloved cousins, the Noland sisters, lived, and from which he set out to return a cake plate in 1910, an act generally considered the beginning of his courtship of Bess Wallace.
The National Park Service guides visitors through the screened porch at the back and into the house through the kitchen. The simplicity of the Trumans' lives is revealed in the kitchen with its apple-green cabinets and the matching table, with some of the paint nicked off its legs. The Trumans ate breakfast together here in the years after the White House. The dining room, though small, is more elegant, with ornate silver pieces from Bess's family.
Typical of houses built in the 19th century, it has a parlor and a sitting room off the center hall in the front of the house. There is also a small study lined with books, where Bess and Harry spent many hours during their later years. Stress cracks have appeared in the ceiling of the formal parlor, where five United States Presidents came to call at various times, and water stains show through the wallpaper of the sitting room. The upstairs is still reserved for their daughter, though she hasn't used it for years. Harry's hat and raincoat hang on hooks by the side door, along with one of Bess's coats.
Among the small-town qualities preserved by Independence, which now has 112,000 people and is surrounded on three sides by Kansas City, is being able to walk to many places of interest. From the Truman house, you can stroll north along Delaware for several blocks and see the other impressive houses from early in the century. I walked east four blocks along Maple, as Truman often did -- to Independence Square.
Dominating the square is the Independence branch of the Jackson County Courthouse, a two-story red brick structure with a white cupola and a statue of Harry Truman outside. As a local politician, Truman was responsible for the renovation of the building in 1933. Although most county business is conducted from the new annex nearby, it was fun to walk the halls of the old building. The office that was once Mr. Truman's -- No. 109 -- is preserved as a historic site and open to the public two days a week, but it was not open the day I was there.
I set aside most of a day to visit the library and museum, about a dozen blocks north and west of the square. The low, two-level modern building is arranged around an open-air courtyard where Harry and Bess are buried. What catches the eye on entering is the Thomas Hart Benton mural, "Independence and the Opening of the West," depicting the kinds of people who came to and through Independence in its formative years -- Indians, French trappers, white settlers from the East, black slaves, outlaws and others. The crusty Truman hadn't been an admirer of the paintings of his equally crusty fellow Missourian, but a common friend brought them together, and before the two-year project was finished they were bourbon-drinking buddies.
Through the doorway, a glass case displays the small wooden sign that sat on the Oval Office desk: "The buck stops here." Straight ahead through the next door is the re-creation of the Oval Office of the early 50's. An audio recording of Truman comes on as you step through the office door, and he welcomes you and mentions several items of interest.
First elected to the Senate in 1934, Truman became Vice President 10 years later after unseating the incumbent, Henry Wallace, in an open floor fight at the Democratic Convention in Chicago. He became President in April 1945, on the death of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. It fell to him to make the decision to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in August 1945 to bring the war with Japan to a quick end. He also dealt with such enormous issues as the economic recovery of Europe, the beginnings of the cold war with the Soviet Union, the creation of the state of Israel and the racial integration of the United States armed forces. Many of the objects, both small and grand, that fill the rest of the museum are connected to these events.
Nothing, however, reveals Harry Truman's personality like the selection of letters covering his relationship with Bess from 1911 until his death, in 1972. In the early letters, he could have been any young Missouri farmer of his time, complaining about having to rise early and labor long. On June 22, 1911, he said the long dry spell was going to make water and potatoes "as much a luxury as pineapples and diamonds." Then he suddenly changed his tone: "Speaking of diamonds, would you wear a solitaire on your left hand should I get it?" He went on to say that, at the moment, he was "only a kind of good-for-nothing American farmer," but that he had always had "a sneakin' notion that some day maybe I'd amount to something."
She turned him down, but his return letter on July 12 suggested that he wasn't giving up. He said he "really never had any desire to make love to a girl just for the fun of it, and you have always been the reason." But two years later she decided she was in love with him, and he wrote back suggesting a secret engagement. Meanwhile, he was pursuing financial success with mining and oil exploration ventures in Kansas and Oklahoma. They did not succeed, and on May 27, 1917, he wrote: "I seem to have a grand and admirable ability for calling tails when heads come up."
That summer fate intervened. Harry's National Guard regiment was mobilized and sent first to Fort Sill, Okla., then to the battlefront in Europe. As he prepared to leave, he wrote: "Bess, I'm dead crazy to ask you to marry me before I leave but I'm not going to because I don't think it would be right for me to ask you to tie yourself to a prospective cripple -- or a sentiment." He added: "If you don't marry me before I go, you may be sure that I'll be just as loyal to you as if you were my wife."
The young man who had been unable to get into West Point because of his bad eyes distinguished himself on the battlefields and came home a captain in early 1919. Both now pushing 35, they had agreed -- finally -- to get married. Bess wrote before he left Europe that he could "invite the entire 35th Division to our wedding if you want to."
A few years into marriage, he wrote her from summer reserve officers' camp that he had not slept well the night before because "I wanted someone to keep me covered up and to hug." She wrote back the next day, calling him "Dear old Sweetness." Even after he went to Washington, the letters reveal two people who never stopped missing each other when they were apart. They talked about things as mundane as new seat covers for the family car and as extraordinary as the formal dinner he gave for Churchill and Stalin during the Potsdam Conference in 1945. At times when he was alone in Washington and she was caring for her ailing mother in Independence, he would send handwritten letters by regular airmail, with the White House as the return address.
Sometimes Truman wrote even when they weren't apart, as he did in an anniversary note on June 28, 1948. "Twenty-nine years! It seems like 29 days," he wrote, adding "You still are on the pedestal where I placed you that day in Sunday School in 1890. What an old fool I am." On their 38th anniversary, in 1957, after they were back in Independence, he wrote a note summarizing the highlights of each year of their married life and added that there were "only 37 to go for the diamond jubilee."
They didn't make it that far. He died Dec. 26, 1972 at age 88: she died on Oct. 18, 1982, at 98. But they left a diamond in these letters. For that, and for letting us come into their house through the kitchen door, I can almost forgive Harry Truman for selling off the farmland.
 
From Missouri to the White House and back, with a stop at the soda fountain
 
What to See
Truman Home, 219 North Delaware Street, Independence, Mo., (816) 254-9929, is open year round Tuesday through Sunday and daily in summer, with tours starting every 15 minutes from 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Visitors buy tickets at the ticket center, at Main Street and Truman Road, then walk or drive the five blocks west to the house. Admission is $2; children under 16 are free.
Harry S. Truman Library and Museum, U.S. Highway 24 and Delaware Street, Independence, (816) 833-1400, is open every day except Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. except Sunday, when it opens at noon, and Thursday, when it stays open till 9. Admission: $5, $4.50 for those over 62, and $3 for those under 18.
Truman Office in the Old Jackson County Courthouse, Independence Square, Independence. Room 109, Truman's office at the beginning of his local political career, is open Friday and Saturday, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission: $2, $1 for those under 13.
Truman Farm, 12301 Blue Ridge Boulevard, Grandview, Mo. Open Friday, Saturday and Sunday from May 8, Truman's birthday, through the end of August. Tours from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., (816) 254-9929. Admission is free.
 
Where to Stay
Woodstock Inn Bed-and-Breakfast, 1212 West Lexington Street, (816) 833-2233 or (800) 276-5202. The inn, which is where I stayed, was a turn-of-the-century doll and quilt factory. The 11 rooms, all with private baths, are decorated with chintz and traditional furnishings. Prices range from $54 to $79 for a two-room suite. It is about four blocks from the Truman Home and a slightly longer walk to most other attractions around Independence.
Serendipity Bed-and-Breakfast, 116 South Pleasant Street, (816) 833-4719 or (800) 203-4299. Near the historic sites in Independence, the Serendipity is a three-story Victorian house with two two-room suites and three rooms in the main house, plus a carriage house with two suites, all with private baths. Doubles range from $45 to $85.
Several modern motels are clustered at Interstate 70 and Noland Road, just outside the historic area. They include the American Inn at 4141 South Noland Road, (816) 373-8300 with doubles at $49; the Howard Johnson at 4200 South Noland Road, (816) 373-8856, where doubles with king-sized beds start at $75, and the Red Roof Inn at 13712 East 42d Terrace, (816) 373-2800, with doubles at $60.99.
 
Where to Eat
Stephenson's Old Apple Farm Restaurant, 16401 East 40 Highway, at Lee's Summit Road, (816) 373-5400, just outside the city limits, was a favorite place of Harry and Bess Truman's. Set amid a huge apple orchard, Stephenson's is known for its ham dishes, apple fritters and apple butter, and for serving free cider while people wait for tables. Main courses start at $6.95 for lunch and $12.95 for dinner; Sunday brunch is $12.95.
The Rheinland Restaurant, 208 North Main Street, (816) 461-5383, a block from Independence Square and across the street from the Truman House ticket office, serves good German food. Main dinner courses, which include jaegerschnitzel, roastbraten and sauerbraten, start at $9.95 and go to $14.95.
Clinton's Old Fashioned Soda Fountain, at 100 West Maple on a corner of the square, (816) 833-2625, has hot dogs and several kinds of sandwiches, phosphates (soda pop made the old-fashioned way) and ice cream sodas and sundaes. The building once housed J. H. Clinton's drugstore, where Harry Truman had his first job at 14. SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN

HEADLINE: Money on the Mind

 BODY:
De Tocqueville observed that envy of one's economic betters is America's peculiar disease, and your issue on money offers evidence that the patient is in intensive care. While an obsession with "getting and spending" often seems to result in anxiety and dissatisfaction, charity toward those lower on the economic ladder yields just the opposite. Judging from the chorus of whiners depicted in your magazine, the current boom has produced more millionaires than philanthropists.
 
Andy Borowitz
White Plains

HEADLINE: Money on the Mind

 BODY:
If protest is out of style, as Michael Kazin suggests, maybe it's because fewer people today swallow the egalitarian fallacy that some people have less because others have more. 
 Risking your own money on the stock market does not deprive others of the use of their money. The profit that risk-takers reap does not impose on them new moral obligations toward non-risk-takers.
 
Anthony Flood
New York

LENGTH: 1250 words

HEADLINE: Aiding the Poor With Low-Interest Loans

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN in 1983 several Roman Catholic Religious Orders in the New York City area decided on moral ground -- opposition to the practice of apartheid -- to divest their stock holdings in corporations doing business with South Africa, a question about money arose. "What are we going to do with the proceeds from the stock, which amounted to $325,000," said George C. Schmitz, a brother of the Holy Cross, a French religious order with American headquarters in New Rochelle. The answer they came up with was, "Let's put it to use in our own communities at the disposal of nonprofit organizations working with the poor."
And so the Leviticus 25:23 Alternative Fund was founded as a nonprofit community development revolving loan fund by several religious members of the Tri-State Coalition for Responsible Investment. The name of the fund was taken from the Book of Leviticus, in which God calls the people to a jubilee that restores the earth and protects common lands as well as the poor. The charter members of the fund were 27 Catholic religious orders, including 11 from Westchester, which were coalition members. The concept of the revolving loan fund, an offshoot of the divestment strategy, was that its members should pool their money and invest it locally, providing loans at below-market value to community organizations that were striving to meet the basic human needs of the poor, said Mr. Schmitz, the fund's first paid employee. 
 Mr. Schmitz was recruited to become the fund's executive director 13 years ago while he was serving as director of international students at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind. "Before that I was the principal of a Catholic high school in Connecticut," he said. "That's where I gained my business experience.
"Membership in the Leviticus Fund is open to faith-based organizations, which support our mission of socially motivated lending through alternative investment.
"Combining financial return with social concern is our motto. Member organizations make a minimum loan of $5,000 to the fund for five years, in return for which they receive an annual interest rate of 2 percent. Currently, we have 78 members, 13 in Westchester, and they represent 4 religious denominations, including Episcopal, United Methodist and Reformed Church as well as Roman Catholic. Individuals can also participate -- associate members who make a minimum loan of $1,000 to the fund for one year. Their interest rate is also 2 percent, far below a conventional investment where they might be expected to earn 5 percent or more. So you see that members and associates of Leviticus Fund place as much importance on the social return on their loan as they do on the financial return."
The fund's first loan, made in 1984, was for $10,000 to a sweat equity group, which was converting a tenement into 16 housing units on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. "Since then, we've closed 96 loans, totaling over $4 million, loans that have been instrumental in leveraging over $37 million in public and private dollars for our 68 borrowers," Mr. Schmitz said. "Twenty-one of the loans we've made have been to organizations in Westchester. To date, our lending in Westchester totals $12 million."
The loans have aided the development of 540 affordable-housing units, 9 day-care centers and 4 small businesses. When asked about the fund's losses, Mr. Schmitz said they were modest. "In 15 years, we've only had to write off $58,000, or 1.3 percent, which I think makes us the envy of any conventional lender."
The Leviticus Fund, which is not government regulated, Mr. Schmitz said, is a patient lender. "We can be more flexible than conventional lenders," he said. "We make allowances for extenuating circumstances. For instance, if borrowers run into unforeseen difficulties and need more time, we will work with them to develop repayment schedules."
If such a considerate approach does not sound businesslike, nothing could be further from the truth, said G. Anthony Hoeltzel, an Episcopal priest and executive director of the Sharing Community in Yonkers, a borrower from the fund. He is also a member of the board of the Leviticus Alternative Fund.
"The business practices of the fund are conducted on a high, professional level," he said. "Borrowers must supply a well-documented business plan. The risk level comes under serious review, and there must be someone responsible and knowledgeable at the head of the borrowing organization."
The Sharing Community has received two loans from the fund, one in 1993 and another in 1995, both to buy property in Yonkers to build affordable housing for single people who are homeless.
"Leviticus Fund is an absolutely fantastic organization that closes a critical gap in the system," Mr. Hoeltzel said. "Ours is a common problem. Although we had a $2.5 million grant from the state for two buildings for permanent and transient residents, the catch was that we needed about $250,000 in order to buy the land, get approval for the building plan and the license. The way the state grant award was constructed was that we had to have all those things in place before the state money kicked in. Without the loan from Leviticus, it's hard to imagine what we would have done."
The 1995 loan was a bridge loan, which has already been repaid, Mr. Hoeltzel said, "The 1993 loan was converted into a six-year construction loan," he said. "The buildings, six stories high -- two stories for transient residents and four stories for permanent residents. Every person has a private room and bath. Two people share apartments. Tenants come from all walks of life. We've had former cops, divorced women ranging in age from 25 to 65. Men and women are equally divided, and rents are based on whatever the recipients receive from Social Services."
The Sharing Community also provides job-training counseling and other programs to those in need.
What is heartening, Mr. Hoeltzel said, is the turnover in permanent residents, which is "100 percent since we opened the doors."
He continued: "What it means is that we have succeeded in helping people find their way back into the mainstream. They find jobs, and they leave and set up their own homes."
In January, Leviticus started a $920,000 program to make low-interest loans to day-care centers. "It is in response to a study that showed an increased demand for child-care centers because of welfare reform," Mr. Schmitz said. "The loans provide construction financing and working capital for startups and funding to expand and upgrade other child-care centers."
Citibank, Chase Manhattan and the Republic National Bank have given grants and loans to the program. To be eligible for a loan of up to $150,000, a child-care center must be licensed by the state, with at least 50 percent of the children from low-income families. Nonprofit and for-profit organizations are eligible. The loans carry a 5 percent interest rate, well below the prime rate of 8.5 percent. "The rate has been set deliberately low to help those in an industry that traditionally operates on a low profit level," Mr. Schmitz said.
A program allowing minority businesses and female business owners to borrow up to $25,000, at 2 points over prime, has also been started, Mr. Schmitz said.
"In order to be considered for a loan, potential borrowers must present a business plan they have developed through a program such as the one given by the Small Business Development Corporation," he explained.
