LENGTH: 1418 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
Flex Buildings for High-Tech Companies Proliferate

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR three decades the 273,000-square-foot bakery and corporate office structure was a fixture on Riverview Drive in Totowa. But the bakery, where Thomas's English Muffins were once made, shut down 18 months ago and the site later was sold to new owners who plan to convert it into a high-tech building.
The buyer was Cambridge Hanover L.P., a real estate investment company based in New Canaan, Conn., made up of a group of New York City developers. It acquired the property last April for $6 million and plans to invest at least another $4 million to redevelop it. The seller -- Bestfoods of Englewood Cliffs, which owns Thomas's -- leased back 100,000 square feet of space, primarily for office use. The building is a quarter mile north of Route 46. 
 The conversion of the building, for which approvals still must be secured from Totowa's Planning Board, is expected to start this fall and take six months to complete. The project is one of a spate of high-tech buildings that are being built or converted or areplanned across the state by developers hoping to attract companies that want the flexibility such space offers.
These low-rise structures, also known as flex buildings, generally offer office, research, light assembly and storage space. The space can be carved into individual units, each with its own entrance and utilities.
A few of the projects, like the one in Totowa, include the reuse of former industrial structures. Others involve new buildings being developed on speculation or as build-to-suit deals for specific tenants. In all, the projects will produce some 889,000 square feet of new and renovated space.
Like the state's office and industrial sectors, the high-tech market, which encompasses about 35 million square feet, is benefiting from a strong local and national economy that continues to spur new companies to form and existing ones to expand. That expansiveness, along with the lack of new construction in the last few years, has caused the vacancy rate in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey market to fall to 14 percent as of the first quarter, down from 22 percent a year ago, according to Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage.
Developers and brokers say tenants in the market for such space include biotech, telecommunications, electronics and pharmaceutical companies within the state. But there is also a growing interest from European concerns in those industries looking to set up offices in New Jersey, which is home to such drug and communications giants as AT&T, Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb, said Timothy R. Comerford, area development manager at Public Service Gas & Electric. The utility is a partner with the state in retaining and attracting businesses.
Many concerns see high-tech buildings as a less costly alternative to pure office space, said Robert L. Sticht, senior vice president at the Edison office of Grubb & Ellis, which represented Bestfoods in the sale of the Totowa property and is now marketing it for Cambridge Hanover.
In turn, an increasing number of tenants are interested in using much and sometimes all of the space in a building for offices, he said, noting that a key ingredient in making these projects successful is to provide sufficient parking.
RECYCLING the Totowa building works because it sits on 17.3 acres and "there is no question that there is a need for reasonably priced single-story office space in that area that is flexible enough to accommodate different kinds of users," said Jonathan Garrity, general partner of Cambridge Hanover.
The partners plan to demolish up to 50,000 square feet that was once part of the bakery, reducing the size of the building to 223,000 square feet and allowing room for additional parking. The rest of the space will be upgraded, adding a new facade, new landscaping and new mechanical systems -- all of which will be done while Bestfoods Baking Company is a tenant within the building.
The 100,000 square feet Bestfoods occupies contains back office space, a retail store and a depot for delivery trucks. The baking operation was consolidated into two other sites in Greenwich Conn., and Frederick, Md.
"Since we no longer needed the majority of the building the logical thing for us to do was to sell it," said Thomas DiPiazza, a company spokesman. Staying in a location "that works for us" and with competitive rents also made sense, he said.
The remaining 123,000 square feet of space, which could be divided into areas as small as 18,000 square feet, will be marketed to both single and multiple tenants, said Mr. Sticht of Grubb & Ellis, noting that rents had not yet been set. Occupancy is expected by the first quarter of 1999.
At Commercenter/Totowa, farther down Riverview Drive, Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Cranford, has just completed a 30,600-square-foot building and is nearing completion on a second one with 39,000 square feet.
In late 1995, the company purchased the 47-acre business park, where 330,000 square feet of high-tech space had already been constructed. It is 95 percent leased by tenants taking, on average, 8,000 to 10,000 square feet, said James G. Nugent, senior vice president of leasing at Mack-Cali.
His company pressed ahead with development, Mr. Nugent said, because "there is so much demand for this kind of space in that area." He said that the smaller of the two new buildings was already leased and that once the second one was rented the plan was to start, possibly by the fourth quarter of this year, the final 65,000-square-foot building in the park. Rents are $14 for office space and half that for nonoffice space.
In Parsippany, Wellsford Commercial Properties Trust of Chatham plans to begin work this fall on converting the former Estee Candy warehouse on Lackawanna Avenue into the Morris Technology Center, which will contain 225,000 square feet of space. The company bought the empty, single-story warehouse, set on 21 acres a half mile north of I-80, last December for $7 million and will spend $23 million on renovations.
THE work includes reducing the size of the old warehouse by 42,000 square feet to 127,000 square feet and adding two-story 50,000-square-foot wings on either side of it. The new building will be given a glass-and-masonry facade and a skylit lobby.
Explaining the company's strategy, Richard R. Previdi, its chief operating officer, said:
"We're taking an infill location and renovating it to provide space that will be designed as high-quality offices to meet the demand from tenants who do not want to pay premium rents, but also will be able to accommodate users that want the flexibility of combining offices with other uses." In addition, he said, there is a scarcity of this kind of "hybrid space" in Parsippany.
The project, to be completed in the first quarter of next year, will be marketed to both single users and multiple tenants. Asking rents are expected to range from $18.50 to $23.50 a square foot, depending on tenant improvements, Mr. Previdi said.
Seeing a niche for smaller users, Kessel Associates of Bergenfield broke ground last week on two speculative flex buildings on Wilson Drive off Route 15 in Sparta. Each of the 12,000-square-foot buildings will be able to be divided into areas as small as 3,100 square feet, said Jeffrey Kessel, a partner.
Mr. Kessel said he expected the buildings to draw tenants, many of them start-up companies, from Morris and Passaic Counties and possibly from Orange County, N.Y. Rents will be $12.75 a square foot for office space and $6.75 for nonoffice space.
At the Technology Center of New Jersey along Route 1 in North Brunswick, construction began earlier this month on a 60,000-square-foot building, occupancy of which is expected next spring. It will be the fifth building in the 50-acre park, designed to meet the needs of emerging research and development companies involved in biosciences, micro-electronics, communications technologies and other pursuits.
In the two and a half years since the state, through the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, began developing the center, using public and private funds, 130,000 square feet of space has been constructed, all of which is leased, said Rose M. Smith, spokeswoman for the authority. Base rents at the center, which eventually will contain 800,000 square feet, are $25 a square foot, about 15 percent lower than the rent for comparable space in the area, she said.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Allan H. Weis;
Contest Helps Internet Work for Students

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AS someone who was involved at Ground Zero with the start of the Internet, Allan H. Weis cringes when he encounters news accounts of the bad aspects of the Web for children, including pornography and lack of content. As president and chief executive officer of the Armonk-based Advanced Network and Services and with a lot of extra money on hand, Mr. Weis and his company decided to do something to change that.
Three years ago, Advanced Network began its yearly Thinkquest contest, where students 12 through 18 are invited to form teams that design Web pages and are eligible for $1 million in prizes and scholarships. The top prize is $25,000 a student on the winning team, $5,000 for the coach and $5,000 for a designated school or library. About 2,000 teams of two or three students each and a coach are completing entries for the August deadline of what has become an international competition. 
 Further information about Thinkquest -- or the company's newest contest for younger students, Thinkquest Junior -- can be found at its Web site: www.advanced.org/thinkquest/. The site also has a library of contest submissions from previous years.
Mr. Weis, who has lived in various places in Westchester but now lives in Greenwich, worked for International Business Machines for 30 years before retiring and starting Advanced Network and Services. From 1990 through 1995 the nonprofit company helped build the Internet. In 1995 that part of the company's business was sold to America Online for what Mr. Weis says was "quite a bit of money." As a company dedicated to advancing education by accelerating the use of computer networking applications and technology, it looked for a way to spend the money appropriately.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Weis:
Q. Why did you start this contest?
A. We sat down several years ago and said, What do we want this company to do? We're fortunate enough to have quite a bit of money. We struggled with the question for a long time and came up with: we want to advance education through the use of computer networking technology and applications. Once we decided that, we asked, how will we get the greatest leverage to do that?
Q. What was wrong with what was out there in the way of educational software?
A. I took a look at what the power of Web and the Internet could really bring to education, and there wasn't a lot there. There wasn't a lot of content out on the Web that students and teachers could use in their everyday classroom for a variety of subjects. And the content that was out there -- most of it was built by adults with the mindset of adults rather than the mindset of a kid. Students think differently than adults. They play computer games. They explore. They learn through exploration. They learn through a combination of hand-eye coordination and doing things. And I wanted to get some of that thought and learning process into learning tools. And I thought there was no better way to do that than have the students do it.
I was also a little concerned that students from some of the better schools were moving faster than students that were lower on the informational technology ladder. So I wanted to see if we could couple students across schools on the informational technology ladder into teams so they could help each other, learn from each other. We decided to use a contest as the format to create a library -- and we have a wonderful legacy of what the students have done there, which is very heavily used worldwide.
Q. Are people other than contestants visiting your library of home pages?
A. Absolutely. Some days we have had almost two million hits. It's used regularly in the schools around the world. For example, if you want to learn the computer programming language C++, there is no better tool anywhere in the world than the page done by one of last year's winners. It's used by companies such as Lockheed. The Air Force Academy uses one of the entries to teach economics. Our pages are used all around the world not only in high schools but in industry to teach a variety of subjects.
These kids really have developed very good language tools. And there is another legacy in that the teachers who have acted as coaches have really been exposed to a whole new way of learning. And this is really good. All too often you read the bad things about the Internet. Very rarely do we see that this is a very powerful tool for students to use as a research tool, as a development tool, to give them the ability to sort of be more competitive in their lives in a dozen ways.
Q. How much does it cost your company to run these contests?
A. Take Thinkquest and Thinkquest Junior and that's about $1.5 million in scholarships and cash awards. But there are several additional million dollars behind it. We help teach the teachers so they're not afraid to bring the technology into their classrooms. We give out hundreds of thousands of CD-ROM's to schools all around the world that contain some of the entries and good software for development of entries. And we run the server, which is a very large job when you get so many hits a day. We spend on K-through-12 programs pretty close to $5 million a year.
Q. Your judging criteria include extra points for co-ed teams from different school districts, different countries, different ages. Why?
A. That's how we fine-tune the contest. We wanted more women to be involved, that's why we put the gender in. We wanted to encourage international teams. But we didn't want to encourage those things to the point of hurting the original goal of making sure there were high-quality educational tools. So we just give it little points for these things. Still the way you become a winner is you get every point. One of the teams last year that won first place in the Sports and Health category had a student from Virginia, another from Alaska and the third one from Russia.
Q. The judging must be so hard.
A. We use the Internet Society, and they do a spectacular job for us. They have hundreds of people who spend hundreds of hours on this. And many of them do it out of their heart, because they absolutely love being involved and love seeing what the students do. Each entry is looked at three times before it makes the semifinals and then a couple of times before it makes the finals. And then the judges sit with the students at the finals and talk to them for about an hour, going through their entry. They look at the codes the students have written and ask questions why they did it one way and not another way. The judges continue to be amazed by the students, and the students continue to be impressed with the judges.
Q. Have the judges been impressed with the depth of the topic or how the Web page was built?
A. The thing that impresses me the most about the winners is their imagination. They've really picked good topics, and they have good reasons to pick the good topics. For example, the students who did C++ said that was a language that was so important to learn and it wasn't being taught in schools. So they wanted to create a tool that was useful to other students.
And if you pick up a book and try to learn C++ the first thing you have to do is read the book, and then you may have to go out and get the software and install it on your computer. What they did was make it so if you have a computer you can get to their tool, and it will teach you and let you write a program and it will execute that program for you and see if it works. So it was really a brilliant implementation with great ideas and great motivation behind it. We've had other wonderful topics: the Himalayas, diseases, music. We have such a rich library of different subjects. It's really wonderful.
Q. What do you think participants get out of this contest?
A. I've talked to students who say, I can build a home page, and they build a home page and they say, Gee I want to make it look better, so they learn Java. And they say, I can't do everything I want with this, what I'm going to do is learn the programming language C, and then I'm going to learn this and I'm going to learn that and all of a sudden they've learned a lot about computer science, and they're interested in computer science. And they have something they can make a lot of money with during the summer. I think it has really helped bring a lot of students new jobs and maybe even a new outlook on life.
It has been the most rewarding program I've ever worked on in my life.

HEADLINE: Dance;
Dancer Alert: Pilobolus Holds an Open Audition

BYLINE: By TERRY TEACHOUT; Terry Teachout is the music critic of Commentary and a contributing writer for Time.

 BODY:
WEDNESDAY, MAY 27, 11:30 A.M.: Forty barefoot women are lined up along the dingy walls of City Center's fourth-floor rehearsal hall, waiting to improvise a 30-second dance that could change their lives. Some look alert, some nonchalant, a few terrified. All are here in response to a terse notice posted in a handful of New York dance studios and published in the trade press: Pilobolus Dance Theater is holding open auditions, starting today.
Between now and Friday, one of these women will crash through the blank wall of anonymity and win a place in one of the world's most popular modern-dance troupes. Not only will audiences across the country applaud her, but she will also earn a living wage, perhaps for the first time in her career as a professional dancer. 
 Most dancegoers know Pilobolus as a company famous for its wit and sensuality. These qualities will be on display in the three programs being presented during the group's annual monthlong season at the Joyce Theater, which opens Tuesday night with the New York premiere of "The Hand That Mocked, The Heart That Fed," a new dance featuring an original score by the noted jazz composer Maria Schneider. (Two other dances, "Apoplexy" and "Orangotango," will receive their New York premieres during the run.)
But professional dancers also know Pilobolus as one of the few modern-dance troupes that provides a regular paycheck, a rare commodity in a profession whose members regard unemployment benefits as an integral part of their skimpy incomes. Last season, the company's six dancers performed about 130 shows and were paid 45 weeks out of 52. That's one reason more than 200 people showed up today to compete for the jobs of Tamieca McCloud, Trebien Pollard and Mark Santillano, who are leaving at the end of the season to pursue their own projects.
Though the company's four artistic directors are in the enviable position of being able to take their pick of some of the best dancers in the business, they know their requirements are unusually idiosyncratic. Many otherwise talented dancers are baffled by Pilobolus's elusive style, a homegrown blend of gymnastics, modern dance and performance art; moreover, the company's dances are choreographed collaboratively, with the dancers playing a key role in the creative process. "We aren't looking for conventional dancers," says Jonathan Wolken, the executive director and one of the company's founders in 1971. Just as important, he adds, is the need to hire mature men and women who are capable of getting along during the many weeks they will spend together on the road. "It's a tightly knit family, and the emotional weather is very important," he says.
Over the years, Mr. Wolken, Robby Barnett, Michael Tracy and Alison Chase have devised a system that allows them to sift more or less efficiently through the large numbers of dancers their auditions invariably attract. In the first stage, the dancers learn a phrase, then perform it in groups of eight, after which they are allowed to improvise briefly on their own. "It's grueling," Mr. Wolken says, "but it's also fun to watch, a kind of human circus."
THURSDAY, 10:45 A.M.: Ten women and nine men were called back for the second day of auditions. Rebecca Anderson, a friendly faced blonde who is Pilobolus's dance captain, is concentrating on the women this morning. "I'm looking for somebody with some spark to her," she says. "And of course she has to be able to lift me, and I her. We had to cut some of the bigger women yesterday just for that reason." (Ms. Anderson is 5 feet 4 inches.)
Ms. Anderson and Ms. McCloud demonstrate a phrase from "Duet," an intricate exercise in female partnering. Then the women pair off and repeat it. "Watch the way they lift each other, and the way they're lifted," Mr. Wolken whispers. "Who's a sack of potatoes? Who's a part of a sculpture? Who's doing Rodin? Who's embarrassed?" A petite dancer with exotic features is singled out for special treatment, and as Ms. Anderson helps her polish the phrase, you can see the other women trying to decide whether their chances for success have gone up or down.
NOON: The directors and dancers huddle briefly and make the next cut. Then the six men and six women who are left are told how Pilobolus works. Members are expected to live near the company studio, in rural Connecticut; there are no understudies, so everybody must be willing to dance hurt; relationships with significant others are often strained by the lengthy touring schedule; some dances involve full or partial nudity. "You're going to be lonely, hurt, poor and naked," interjects Matt Kent, Pilobolus's class clown. Everybody laughs; nobody leaves.
FRIDAY, 10:30 A.M.: Ben Pring, one of the remaining male dancers, is taken to the back of the hall for a whispered conference while the other men continue to improvise. Michael Tracy and Robby Barnett offer him a job. "We think you'd be really good," says Mr. Tracy, "and I think you'd find this a good dance job." (He will accept over the weekend.)
11:45: Josie Coyoc, the elfin dancer who was singled out Thursday morning, has now emerged as one of the two front-runners among the women. An elegant performer whose demeanor is quiet and self-contained, she has spent the last five years with Bill T. Jones's company but is concerned about its financial stability. "I want to keep dancing," she says, "but I also want to be able to pay my bills -- I'm actually going into debt -- so I told Bill in February that I was going to have to look for something else. It was hard. But I love what Pilobolus does -- all the partnering, and the beautiful movements." Suddenly she starts to cry. "It's like leaving one family, perhaps to go to another."
12:15 P.M.: The other front-runner is Jennifer Binford, a tall, ebullient woman who makes fetchingly funny faces as she improvises. "This is the most creative audition I've ever had," she says excitedly. "I feel like I fit in, like I can be myself. I'm having a great time!" Then she sheepishly confesses that she hasn't slept for two days.
1 P.M.: One man and three women are sent home. Each is taken aside and gently given the bad news. "Dancers are always telling us: 'You treat us like humans; you actually talk to us!' " Mr. Tracy says after they leave. "Which gives us some idea of how things must work at other companies' auditions." He shudders.
3:30 P.M.: Another male dancer is sent home. The rest line up side by side as Mr. Wolken barks out a series of unlikely commands: "Look straight out. Relax your face. Now show us pure, unmitigated hatred . . . falling asleep . . . one drink too many . . . horrified . . . flabbergasted . . . you just walked through poison ivy . . . dignified!" The dancers dissolve in laughter, then sit down for more talk. "Do any of you keep a journal?," Mr. Wolken asks them. "What do you read?" The answers range from "One Hundred Years of Solitude" to "The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People."
4:20 P.M.: The directors and company members excuse themselves and begin an intense, sometimes testy debate. Otis Cook, an extroverted improviser with a shaved head, is called over for a few more questions; the group then decides to offer him the second male slot, which he accepts at once. Choosing between Ms. Binford and Ms. Coyoc proves more difficult. "Rebecca was right when she said that it's basically going to be an esthetic decision," Mr. Barnett says. "Jennifer and Josie are both excellent dancers, they can do all the moves, but they're very different in size, appearance and character. So what do we want the company to look like? Where do we want to go as a group?" After 20 minutes of increasingly heated talk, a compromise is reached: the company will assemble in Connecticut next week to make a final decision, having had the weekend to think it over.
AFTERWARD: The members of Pilobolus reconvened the following Monday and voted unanimously to ask Ms. Coyoc to join them. "I needed a day to let it wash over me," she says a few weeks later. "Then I accepted." She speaks wistfully of telling her soon-to-be-former boss that she will be leaving his company: "I think Bill understood it was a choice I had to make, so I could continue to do what I love."
Ms. Coyoc, Mr. Cook and Mr. Pring will report to Connecticut on Aug. 10 for their first rehearsal. "I think we have a terrific looking new company," Mr. Barnett says. "We have a lot of faith in our audition process. It's not infallible, but it gives us an unusually good sense of who we're working with, and we've never had to let anyone go. On the basis of those three days, I think all of us are positive and enthusiastic about the year to come."

GRAPHIC: Photo: TRYOUT: Josie Coyoc, middle, at the Pilobolus Dance Theater audition. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%);

ORGANIZATION: PILOBOLUS DANCE THEATER NEW YORK (56%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK CITY; UNITED STATES (91%); NEW YORK, USA (91%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%);

PERSON: TEACHOUT, TERRY JONATHAN WOLKEN (70%); REBECCA ANDERSON (64%);

PUB-DATE: June 28, 1998

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2023 words

HEADLINE: A Steady Critical Eye on Film's Shifting Currents

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
SIXTEEN years into his marathon run as the film critic for The New Republic, Stanley Kauffmann sat down in 1974 to write an essay to answer the two questions he was most often asked: How many films do you see in a week? And don't you get bored?
Zero to 12 and no, Mr. Kauffmann answered in that essay, "Why I'm Not Bored." A film may be boring, but the idea of going never is. Boredom is incompatible with hope, Mr. Kauffmann wrote, and hope is more of a constant in film than in virtually any other art in America. 
 "No matter how much I know about a film's makers or its subject before I go, I never really know what it's going to do to me," he wrote. "Depress me with its vileness, or just roll past, or change my life in some degree, or some combination of all three, or affect me in some new way that I cannot imagine."
Twenty-four years later, Mr. Kauffmann is still at it. At age 82, he is celebrating his 40th anniversary at The New Republic this month, still trotting off to screenings and filing his literate, independent-minded, intelligent if not entertaining, very grown-up brand of reviews almost weekly.
A lot has happened in film during Mr. Kauffmann's time as a critic -- the advent of the French New Wave and the rise of the great Italian, Scandinavian and Japanese directors, the flourishing of American movie-making in the late 1960's and 1970's, the onset of the blockbuster, the dying of cinephilia.
Film criticism, too, has been transformed. Andrew Sarris imported the auteur theory from France. Pauline Kael emerged as the first critic-celebrity. Wars between critics broke out. Broadcast film reviewers entered the game and changed it. Now, in the "Armageddon" age, gloom engulfs the field.
Some critics, like David Denby of New York magazine, feeling drowned out by the din of the Hollywood marketing machine, seem despondent to a degree verging on despair. Column inches dwindle while movies multiply. Worthwhile films cannot get distributed. What can be worth saying, some critics wonder, about "Lethal Weapon 4"?
Yet Mr. Kauffmann carries on, seemingly unfazed, immune to both pessimism and hype. In an era of "blurb whores," his hyperbole-resistant style is rarely quoted in movie ads (a point of perverse pride for his editor). He remains afloat, buoyed by an old-fashioned commitment to the art, not the business, of film.
Not long ago he chose to review a film he figured almost no one would see: "Chronicle of a Disappearance," by a Palestinian director, Elia Suleiman. It appeared fleetingly in a small film museum in lower Manhattan. It reminded Mr. Kauffmann of Ionesco. He thought it was one of the best films in years.
"I thought, I'm derelict in my function if I don't record that that film passed through," he said in an interview in the penthouse apartment in lower Manhattan where he has lived with his wife, Laura, for 31 years. "Utility is not the only criterion. Otherwise, I'd be writing about 'Deep Impact.' "
"Highfalutin as it sounds, there's a point at which your obligation to the art must come into play, or else you're just a reporter," he said. (Then he added gently, apparently in deference to the delusions of the reporter in his living room, "Forgive me.")
Unlike many of today's film critics, who started young, Mr. Kauffmann began reviewing movies in middle age. Born and reared in Manhattan, he had majored in dramatic arts at New York University and had spent 10 years as an actor and stage manager with a repertory company that specialized in Shakespeare.
He had published extensively -- 40 one-act plays, 7 novels, articles for magazines. And he had worked as a book editor; he discovered and edited "The Moviegoer," by Walker Percy, while working at Knopf. In 1957, a friend moving out of the country handed over to Mr. Kauffmann an opportunity to write film reviews for a magazine called The Reporter. Thus Mr. Kauffmann became a film critic.
One day early on, he sent off a review to The New Republic. Two weeks later, a check and a copy of the magazine with his review in it arrived in the mail (followed, two days after that, by a letter from the editorial secretary: Thanks for the offer but we cannot use your review).
"I said, 'This is for me!' " Mr. Kauffmann recalled gleefully. Six months later, he was the magazine's regular film critic.
His timing was excellent. American movies were uninspired in those days, but European cinema in particular had entered a period of brilliance. Mr. Kauffmann became one of a handful of critics in the early 1960's who helped convince educated Americans that they could take film seriously as art again.
He especially admired the Italian directors. He championed Michael angelo Antonioni for "making a new art form." He called Federico Fellini "incapable of committing a stale or careless shot to film" and Vittorio De Sica "perhaps the outstanding example of the wedding of theatrical and cinematic mastery."
He also wrote about the likes of Akira Kurosawa in Japan and Satyajit Ray in India; he described Ingmar Bergman's films as ambitious, stimulating failures. "The Swedish director is now established as a Divine Amateur: enormously gifted, often technically dazzling, essentially undisciplined," Mr. Kauffmann wrote in 1959.
He mocked the French New Wave. In a review of Agnes Varda's "Cleo from 5 to 7," he parodied the New Wave style: "Use freakish faces for minor characters (this is candor). Use a little nudeness (this is maturity). Include long walks through a city, preferably Paris; just long, pointless walks."
After admiring "Breathless," he turned against Jean-Luc Godard's later films. He made fun of Godard's admirers (who happened to include Mr. Sarris and Ms. Kael), calling Godard "a magician who makes elaborate uninspired gestures and then pulls out of the hat precisely nothing."
Mr. Kauffmann's strengths as a critic are said by both admirers and detractors to consist of a literate, cultivated approach; a deep knowledge of theater and strong feeling for acting; an economical writing style, and a refusal to conform to anyone else's doctrine.
He never subscribed to the auteur theory promoted by Mr. Sarris, who many now credit with changing the way Americans think about film, emphasizing the role of the director above all. (Mr. Kauffmann nevertheless says he learned from it.) Nor did he ever admire film as popular culture, as opposed to art, to the extent that Ms. Kael and her followers did.
GREG TAYLOR, who teaches film studies at Purchase College, SUNY and is writing a book on postwar film criticism, calls Mr. Kauffmann "one of a group of stalwarts whose heyday was the 60's" and who concerned themselves with the esthetics of film.
"Their work was not strictly directed at highbrows but at a broader middlebrow audience," Mr. Taylor said, listing Dwight Macdonald and John Simon among the group. "And they really explicitly tried to educate and elevate taste in movies."
Which they and others did. By the late 1960's, American movie making had begun to change. Beginning around the time of "Bonnie and Clyde," in 1967, a group of artistically ambitious directors like Francis Ford Coppola, Robert Altman, Martin Scorsese and Brian De Palma began making movies that not only were profoundly popular and entertaining but were also widely seen as more stylish and complex than what had come before.
The climate of filmgoing had changed, too. Richard T. Jameson, the editor of Film Comment, calls the period "an era of enlightened filmgoership." Americans were eager to read in depth about film. Critics became important cultural figures, speaking on college campuses, their work widely discussed.
Bloody feuds broke out in print. Ms. Kael took on Mr. Sarris and the auteur theory; there were viciously argued differences over New Wave directors like Godard. Later, John Simon attacked Ms. Kael and Mr. Sarris. Mr. Sarris, given an opportunity to respond in the pages of The New York Times, fought back, calling Mr. Simon "the Count Dracula of critics."
Ms. Kael also took occasional swipes at Mr. Kauffmann ("the UnKael," as Louis Menand called him in a 1995 article about Ms. Kael in The New York Review of Books). In reviews of films like Truffaut's "Jules and Jim," she would quote Mr. Kauffmann's opinions, then witheringly dismiss them.
(When asked recently about each other, neither Mr. Kauffmann nor Ms. Kael would comment. "I think I'd rather not," Ms. Kael said. Looking suddenly distraught, the avuncular Mr. Kauffmann said: "I don't want to go into it. It's the sort of thing I disliked so much in the 1960's.")
Out of that period Ms. Kael emerged as the dominant critic, arguing that many American movies of the 70's were art as much as or more than those of the European model that audiences had been taught to respect. As Peter Rainer, the film critic for New Times Los Angeles, puts it, there was value in the subversiveness of those American movies, "not just to thrill us but to take us to a higher plane."
Mr. Kauffmann, by contrast, was less than swept away. He was unimpressed by "The Godfather" and "The Godfather Part II." He compared "Nashville" to "a superior book-club novel." If "Chinatown" were shorter and less paradigmatic, he wrote in 1974, "it would be a good sinister thriller."
The late 1970's and 80's brought another revolution, this time in movie marketing, with the rise of saturation distribution and a growing reliance by studios on television publicity. That, in turn, transformed the experience of being a critic, not to mention the movies themselves.
The industry needed blockbusters that could open in thousands of theaters at once. Studios turned increasingly to television talk shows and other venues to promote them. These days, by the time a movie opens and a print critic weighs in, the studios have already been spreading the word for months.
Most critics feel that good movies are still being made but that it's harder for the films to get the public's attention. Foreign and independent films disappear for lack of publicity or distribution. To write only about small masterpieces that few readers will see strikes some critics as courting irrelevance.
"If you're talking about movies as an art, you're just out of it," complained Mr. Denby, who recently wrote an article in The New Yorker bemoaning the dying of the film culture. "The business conversation is the hip conversation, the knowing conversation, the dinner-table conversation."
Some critics have changed their focus. J. Hoberman, the senior critic for The Village Voice, said that he had started out in film criticism much more interested in the esthetics of film but that like others, he had shifted his attention to the sociological, political and historical implications of movies.
But that approach, too, had its drawbacks, said Mr. Rainer, who had tried it. "It's just that if that's the only way that you can really sink your teeth into movies time and time again, you become famished," he said. "Because so much of what brought us into movies as budding critics was the wonderfulness of movies, not the social context."
Mr. Kauffmann, meanwhile, has no plans to retire. (He stopped just once, in the late 1960's, to spend eight months as the theater critic for The New York Times.) Some fellow critics say his tastes have grown stuffier over the years. Mr. Jameson, the editor of Film Comment, said Mr. Kauffmann represented "comparatively speaking, a kind of fuddy-duddyism." But Roger Ebert calls him the best critic working, the only one who makes Mr. Ebert reconsider his own view.
And Jon Wilkman, a 55-year-old documentary filmmaker in Los Angeles who first read Mr. Kauffmann in the early 1960's at Oberlin College, credits Mr. Kauffmann with inspiring Mr. Wilkman's own filmmaking, in part by introducing him to the work of the Italian neo-realist director Ermanno Olmi.
"I will go to a movie knowing nothing except that Stanley liked it," said Mr. Wilkman, who has never met Mr. Kauffmann. "I would say to my wife, 'Stanley likes this, we should go.' And she would laugh at me for my excessive dependence."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Tours to Indonesia Postponed for Many

 BODY:
Although the violence has subsided in Indonesia, the political and economic situation remains unsettled, and the State Department, in a June 11 public announcement, advises Americans to avoid crowds and areas where violence has been reported. The announcement replaced a June 3 travel warning urging Americans to defer non-essential travel to the country.
While Jakarta, Indonesia's capital and the site of most demonstrations against former President Suharto -- who resigned May 21 -- is not included on most group-tour itineraries, many tour companies are rescheduling or canceling their tours to other sections of the country. For example, Volcano Tours canceled its Indonesian trips scheduled for June and August, with full refunds. Overseas Adventure Travel also canceled its trips to Indonesia for the rest of the year, with a full refund plus $200 toward any other trip during 1998. 
 Bali has not experienced violence, although there have been some demonstrations on the island. Spice Island Cruises, which offers trips that originate in Bali and then travel to remote islands, has not had any cancellations or drop in bookings, according to Jill Potash, a spokeswoman, and sees no reason not to conduct business as usual, far removed from the disturbances.
Journeys Off the Tourist Track in Fairfax, Calif., canceled one trip to Bali for June, but still plans to take two groups there in August. Travelers booked on a trip to Indonesia through Asia Transpacific Journeys in Boulder, Colo., have been given the option to reschedule. One tour set to depart the weekend after the disturbances in Jakarta was canceled, and refunds were offered. Since then, the company reports almost no cancellations, but its bookings to Indonesia have been lower than usual this year, it said.
Updated information on Indonesia is available from the United States Embassy in Jakarta, www.usembassyjakarta.org. Call (202) 647-5225 for recorded travel information on any country. Consular Information Sheets for all countries can be accessed through the State Department's Internet site, travel.state.gov.

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
Taking a Potshot at the Game of Golf

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; David Bouchier is an essayist and commentator on public radio.

 BODY:
THE game of golf has always been a great mystery to me. But it's time to learn. Golf is becoming the only industry on eastern Long Island. All residents of Suffolk County will soon be required to play at least one round a day, just to keep the economy afloat.
Every day, it seems, farms and farmhouses vanish like Brigadoon, to be replaced by these strange alien landscapes. Instead of fields and crops, the landscape sprouts artificial lakes, tiny sandy deserts and vast stretches of improbably green grass. Even in the most unpromising weather, people can be seen creeping through these bleak open spaces in electric carts or striking with sticks at balls that, from any appreciable distance, are invisible. 
 It looks about as much fun as a root canal. Yet clearly golf is one of those games that seizes on its victims with the force of an addiction. I've been to some all-male luncheons where my companions could talk about nothing else. They relentlessly share their thoughts on clubs and balls, considerations on the subtle differences (invisible to the untrained eye) between one golf course and another, arcane knowledge about tournaments, scores and the weather at St. Andrews, Scotland.
Even fully employed men with families and mortgages seem to think nothing of flying to Florida or Arizona in winter, so they can keep batting those little white balls around without losing them in the snow. Just as the hippies of the 1960's rebelled against work so that they could pursue peace and love, so the businessmen of the 1990's seem to have given up work in favor of golf.
As golf is obviously in my future, I turned my mind to unraveling its mysteries. Clearly there is more to this pastime than meets the untutored eye. As I'm sure others have realized, golf is a metaphor for life. It's a competitive activity, played in pursuit of a dream called beating "par," the ideal score. Golf divides the game of life into 18 more or less equal stages; let's assume that each stage, or hole, represents four years. The hole is your life goal for that period. The clubs represent the different choices you must make in order to get there. The little round, hard object that you try to push along and occasionally lose is yourself. The water and sand traps stand for the hazards of life. And your handicap is, well, your handicap. One of the most refreshing things about golfers is the way they talk so frankly about their handicaps, without whining or expecting to be pitied as victims.
The metaphor of golf and life is almost without limits. You have to wait your turn to play, and if you happen to be stuck behind a really large group -- the 70 million baby boomers, for example -- you can wait forever to get your shot. There are long stretches of tedium between brief moments of excitement, and your score at the end is never what you hoped it would be at the beginning.
When you reach the final hole, you move on to the 19th, which presumably represents paradise, or retirement to one of those golfing communities down South.
However, like most metaphors, this one is not perfect. Life is not actually divided into 18 equal stages; the hazards are not predictable; the playing surface is never smooth. And this set me thinking about my own golfing experience, which happened a long time in the past.
Every summer my family would go to a seaside resort for our vacation. And because it rained most of the time, we found artificial amusements. One of these was miniature golf. If you want a true metaphor for life, miniature golf is much closer to the mark. That's what life is really like: over the bridge, through the elephant's trunk, round the corkscrew, down the funnel of the steam engine and into the bottomless pit; never a nice clean drive down an empty fairway. Instead of being off to the side, the hazards are piled up directly in your path, just as they are in real life. You get only one club, and it's a putter, not a driver. There is no such thing as par for the course.
Miniature golf is definitely my kind of game.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (P.C. Vey)

LENGTH: 1397 words

HEADLINE: State of Commuting: Stalled and Getting Worse

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
MARK MEYER spent so much time stuck in traffic when he commuted from Milford to Port Chester, N.Y., that he took the opportunity to learn a new language. Stuck on the Connecticut Turnpike, he listened to language tapes, studied a textbook and became quite fluent in Italian. And he always had time left over to read the morning newspaper as well.
But Mr. Meyer never mastered commuting. It made him so miserable, he said, it was a major reason that he left his job for one where he works mainly out of his home. 
 On the Merritt Parkway, Mark S. Graham has gotten to know other commuters -- at least by their faces and cars. On his daily 17-mile trip from Trumbull to Westport, he said, they are all "stuck in the same moving parking lot." It can get "a little surreal," he said. For instance, he might be laughing at a joke told by radio host Howard Stern, and the driver sitting in the car next to him is laughing at the same time. They give each other a look. Same program?
But when Mr. Graham, a marketing executive, needs to get to a meeting and he's stuck in traffic, he isn't laughing.
Traffic in southern Connecticut is a concern of business leaders, state transportation officials, politicians and environmentalists, as well as the people stuck in it. "It's getting worse, not better, and people can see that," said Matthew Nemerson, president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce. It is a factor that businesses and individuals consider when deciding whether to locate or stay in an area, where to take vacations and when to plan meetings, he said.
"Some people won't go to Stamford before 10 o'clock and after 2 o'clock," said Mr. Nemerson. "It can't be good for the fastest-growing area of the state to be temporarily redlined." So, state officials are trying to get at least a portion of the cars off the Greenwich-to-New Haven stretch -- the Connecticut Turnpike (I-95), the Merritt and Wilbur Cross Parkways (Route 15), and U.S. 1 (Post Road).
The state is not spending new money to do so, though. There won't be massive road projects to add highway lanes or build new roads. Instead, $58.4 million in existing state and Federal transportation funds is being reallocated over seven years, explained Stuart D. Leland, director of inventory and forecasting in the State Department of Transportation. The goal is a 5 percent reduction, some 8,600 cars, from than 1997 levels. And, Mr. Leland said, "it's 5 percent plus the growth that would occur. That's more like a 12 percent total."
The plan relies on a combination of tactics: encouraging more intrastate train riders by increasing railroad parking spaces, improving train schedules and bus service, coordinating train and bus schedules, and counting on voluntary actions by employers, such as instituting flexible schedules so that people can travel to work in off-peak periods. Commuters like Mr. Meyer and Mr. Graham expressed doubt that all this would make a noticeable difference. But business leaders involved in forming the plan are optimistic.
Mr. Nemerson said "when you look at the huge difference a little rubbernecking can make, or how a busy entrance ramp can slow down traffic for miles, you understand the power of taking off a few cars."
Joseph McGee, vice president for public policy for the Southwest Area Commerce and Industry Association, said that on holidays when many businesses close, peak-hours traffic drops about 5 percent and "traffic flows freely."
Mr. Leland of the Department of Transportation said that "it will make a difference," but that "I don't know how big a difference."
He said that exorbitant costs and interest in retaining the character of the Merritt Parkway eliminated the option of expanding roads.
"If you were to add another lane to 95, you're talking billions. So that's out of the question," he said.
The 5 percent goal was established because it was considered to be realistic and attainable, said Harry P. Harris, the state deputy commissioner for public transportation.
"If you were going to set the figure at much higher, you would have an even bigger hurdle to overcome," he said.
Mr.McGee said that said studies have shown that traffic in the area increases by about 1.5 percent a year.
The railroad portion of the plan is designed to get 1,750 more people to commute by train, already the predominant mode of transit used by commuters to New York City.
Now, the emphasis will be on luring intrastate commuters, particularly to Stamford, "the biggest destination outside of Grand Central Station," Mr. Harris said.
Train travel has to be seen as a convenient, cost-effective alternative, and since most railroad parking lots are already filled, more riders can not be attracted without additional parking, Mr. Harris said. Parking garages for 1,200 cars each are being planned in Stamford and New Haven.
New free parking, additional trains, and lower rates are in the works for Bridgeport to encourage more commuters to travel from there, Mr. Harris said. A 750-car parking lot between the railroad station and the new HarborYard baseball stadium is due to open around Labor Day and will provide free parking for five years for people with weekly or monthly rail commutation tickets. The fenced lot will have 24-hour security guards as well as closed circuit TV surveillance.
Starting Aug. 24, two new trains will originate in Bridgeport with limited stops to Grand Central Terminal.
One train will start at 6:34 A.M., with stops in South Norwalk, Rowayton, Darien, Noroton Heights and Stamford and will arrive at Grand Central at 7:54.
A 7:01 A.M. train, with stops in Fairfield, Southport, Greens Farms, Westport and East Norwalk, will arrive at Grand Central at 8:26 A.M.
Fares are being reduced to narrow the gap between Bridgeport and Fairfield rates, Mr. Harris said. For example, monthly commutation tickets from Bridgeport will drop from $283 to $271. The Fairfield monthly rate is $254.
"By lowering fares and eliminating parking fees, it will be cheaper to take the train from Bridgeport than from Faifield," Mr. Harris said.
An additional 1,500 parking garage is part of a planned Federally-funded transportation center for Bridgeport.
Mr. Harris said there is a focus on Bridgeport because there is a 1,700-person waiting list for parking in neighboring Fairfield, and a proposed two-deck parking garage for Fairfield is facing opposition from town residents.
Parking expansion for about 60 more cars is planned for Milford, and planned expansion for 55 cars at Talmadge Hill in New Canaan has received local opposition, he said.
Meanwhile, officials in West Haven, the only town on the shore between New Haven and Greenwich where Metro-North trains do not stop, have asked the D.O.T. to build a railroad station and adjacent parking lot in that city, he said.
He said people have to be convinced that it's more economical to use public transportation by comparing the total cost of using a car every day in terms of wear and tear and maintenance, not by just looking at the price of gasoline versus the cost of a train ticket and railroad station parking.
Gov. John G. Rowland has enthusiastically endorsed the plan, something of a departure from his position last year when he proposed eliminating three rail lines in the state: the Danbury, Shoreline East, and Waterbury branch lines. (The General Assembly rejected his proposal.)
The most unpredictable part of the plan is the voluntary element that relies on businesses to encourage employees to take public transportation, join car and van pools, work different schedules, and do some telecommuting, Mr. Leland said. One carrot for taking action is a Federal tax break for companies that provide free parking for car poolers and subsidies for rail or bus users.
Some businesses are already taking steps. For instance, Mr. Graham, a partner in Gray & Graham, a Westport marketing firm, permits employees from the Naugatuck Valley to avoid the congestion by arriving at work earlier and leaving earlier.
Of the entire plan, Mr. Nemerson, of the New Haven Chamber, has his fingers crossed. "We just have to hope that it works because we really have to have it successful in order to convince companies that southern Connecticut is going to offer them an attractive environment in five or 10 years for their workers," he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Building Boom Unleashes a Conservation Backlash

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
DEVELOPMENT stoked by a robust economy has arrived at many Connecticut towns unaccustomed to large-scale home construction.
In the process, it has created a backlash of local land conservation initiatives that are spreading in numbers and intensity through upper Fairfield, lower Litchfield and New Haven Counties, manifesting itself particularly in six communities. 
 Woodbury, for example, is awaiting a decision from its owner on the sale of the 685-acre Flanders Nature Center to a Waterbury software company or to the nature center itself, which has been leasing it.
Shelton and North Branford have adopted ordinances permitting the two towns to buy development rights from local farmers and forest land owners to preserve open space.
In Guilford, the local land trust is seeking to purchase a section of the Trap Rock Ridge area to prevent the development of a housing subdivision and Sherman is pondering ways to offset the loss of a 289-acre farm to a real-estate developer.
In Wallingford, developers protested the Town Council's decision in April to purchase by condemnation 100 acres under contract for residential development. A suit by one developer charges that the decision was made to protect the homes of the Mayor and two town council members whose homes abut the sites.
In April, the Town Council voted to buy two tracts of residentially zoned land totaling 100 acres for $4.5 million, claiming them for open space and, possibly, a golf course. But last Tuesday, under pressure, the Council rescinded that vote.
Last month 3,000 signatures, 500 more than required, were gathered on a petition for a referendum on the appropriation. "I don't like the idea of the town taking property by eminent domain," said Frank Ciccone, a local resident who spearheaded the petition drive. "Nor do I like spending that much money for no specific purpose."
Sixty of the acres involved had been approved last November for construction of 79 homes. Since then, the developer, Steven Temkin, head of the T & M Building Company of Torrington, has built a road into the property and poured four foundations, and is completing two houses as models.
"We opened on June 14 and took six deposits," he said, "returnable if the land is taken by the town."
The remaining 40 acres across town have been optioned by Richard Fiske, president of the Ravenswood Development Corporation in Cheshire. He expects to build 38 houses adjacent to a 131-home subdivision that he has completed. He filed suit on June 3 in Superior Court in Meriden against the town, saying that "the true purpose of taking the land is not conservation but to stop development for an improper motive."
While they were not named in the suit, Mayor William W. Dickinson and Ray Rys Sr. and Richard Centner, Town Council members, were accused by some residents at public hearings of attempting to protect their own homes by taking the adjacent properties for open space.
Mr. Fiske said he was not dropping his suit until he is convinced that the town will not try to condemn his optioned property alone.
"A lot of this comes down to what the town will look like in 30 years," Mayor Dickinson said before last Tuesday's meeting. Explaining the Council's choice of land, he said:
"Our Conservation Commission reviewed all suitable pieces in town and provided us with a list of worthwhile properties. We found no one was willing to sell. None of those properties abuts mine -- one Councilman may be in that position. I'm not sure there is a lot of substance to those charges."
IN Sherman, the Trust for Public Lands and Sherman's Naromi Land Trust have pressed the Justice Department to sell them the Carlson Farm since 1994, when the Federal Government seized the property as part of the assets of the defunct Bank for Credit and Commerce International.
"It is unusual for the Justice Department to be involved in land sales, but this was a takeover resulting from a bank scandal and had to follow the Government's bidding procedure," said Valerie Talmage, director of projects at the Trust for Public Lands' regional office in Boston.
Bids were accepted and made public early this year, among them one from the trust on behalf of Sherman and another from the 890 Realty Company of Ridgefield. The Justice Department gave the trust an opportunity to submit a counteroffer, but, within its authority, would not disclose the realty company's high bid.
Sherman lost the property to 890 Realty Company, whose bid was $100,000 more than the trust's $2.5 million offer.
According to Donna Tuck, First Selectman of Sherman, the sale will not be final until $2.6 million is paid by the end of July. Meanwhile, the town hopes to minimize development through its zoning regulations. The developer, she said, "is talking golf course and a limited number of high-end homes; that's better than 80 houses."
Along Guilford's section of Connecticut's Trap Rock Ridges lies a rugged wilderness called Bluff Head, the site of a proposed 18-lot subdivision on 80 acres just south of the Durham line. Durham is concerned that a new road required to connect the site with Route 77 will generate a flood of commuter traffic.
Red Erter, president of the Guilford Land Trust, said the trust was "partnering with the town" to buy the parcel. The subdivision application by Walter Nichols of Orange and David Chase of Manhattan is pending before the Planning and Zoning Commission. It has also been submitted for advisory review to the Durham Planning and Zoning Commission and the Midstate Regional Planning Agency.
"We have land-acquisition funds," said George Kral, Guilford's Town Planner, "and this is part of an open-space corridor planned for many years."
In Shelton, a Farmlands and Forest Preservation Act has been adopted through which landowners may sell development rights to the city in return for payment based on a formula adjusted for each site. They also get a reduction in property taxes, but the land can never be sold for development.
Terry Jones, owner of the Jones Tree Farm in Shelton and co-chairman of the city's Conservation Commission, helped craft the ordinance. He has put 92 of his 400 acres into the program. After agreeing to take $1 million less than the appraised price, he received $300,000 from the city and $800,000 from the state.
Mr. Jones urged other landowners to join the program and wherever possible make similar concessions. "Our goal," he said, "is to preserve at least 1,500 acres of forest and farm land."
Under the city's agreement with the state and Federal governments, the Federal Department of Agriculture will reimburse the state for $400,000 of the Jones payment. The money must go into a fund for buying more development rights.
"The state only has X number of dollars for its own development-rights program," said Rick Schultz, Shelton's Planning and Zoning Administrator. "Many farms go after the money -- it's very competitive. We are ahead of the game because we have a funding source in place."
The city's annual contribution is $100,000 and there are additional payments from developers of subdivisions, who are required to set aside 10 percent of the land for open space or contribute its value in cash.
The program has also been adopted in North Branford.
THE Flanders Nature Center in Woodbury, part of a 1,300-acre wildlife sanctuary, has been leased from the Whittemore family trust for 30 years, providing hiking trails, educational programs and resources for plant and animal research. "When I die," said Robert Whittemore, 77, "the trust ends, and the property would go undivided to family members, which is an extremely undesirable way to handle real estate. It makes more sense to see that it goes into good hands while the trust is still in existence. I would like to see it remain as much as possible undeveloped forest land."
Arthur Milnor, executive director of the Flanders Nature Center, is contacting individuals, foundations, corporations and the state to support the center's offer to buy the 685 acres. A second offer has been submitted by John Haested, president of Haested Methods of Waterbury, a software company. "They are not too far apart, and in the general area of the asking price," said Mr. Whittemore, who is in no hurry to make a decision.
"I want to do awesome things that Flanders should be doing, but isn't," Mr. Haested said. He outlined a plan for a 30,000-square-foot building containing his business, plus a day-care center, tennis courts and homes for himself and his two top employees. His staff of approximately 100 would live elsewhere.
"It would all look like it was built in 1860," he said, "confined to about 200 acres." Walking and jogging trails would be open to the public, and the rest of the land, he indicated, "would be donated to a trust that we might form."
"If we went for this clean industry," said Peter Hughes, Woodbury Town Planner, "a zone change would be needed." Mr. Haested has not initiated any action, just describing his plans briefly. First Selectman Richard Crane, who is on vacation and unavailable for comment, has said in local newspaper reports that he feels the Haested company is noninvasive and that the Selectmen are interested in increasing the town's tax base.
In just the last six months, resistance to development of Connecticut's remaining open space has stiffened markedly. The resistance was triggered, said Mr. Kral, Guilford's Town Planner, by a sudden awakening to a surge of construction following a depressed housing market that ended about 18 months ago.
In commenting on the loss of the Sherman property, Ms. Talmage of the Trust for Public Land said: "There are pieces of land that people thought would always be preserved, central to the character of New England towns. All of a sudden, these pieces are being proposed for housing and golf courses."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 3; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1226 words

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Waiving Contract Clauses

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
IT is hardly news that the real estate market in the New York City area is about as hot as it has been in quite a while. And since the heat seems to be generated by the friction from buyers bumping into one another chasing sellers, there has hardly been a more appropriate time to apply the first rule of the open market: "Let the buyer beware."
"People do strange things when they're under pressure," said William Selsberg, a real estate lawyer in Stamford, Conn., noting that buyers who are anxious about losing the house of their dreams had a tendency to become careless with what might be the most significant investment of a lifetime. "And if you're careless, you're probably going to get kicked." 
 For example, Mr. Selsberg said, some clients have suggested in recent months that they would be willing to waive one or more of the common contingencies inserted into a contract of sale -- things like home inspections, and requirements that a mortgage must be obtained and that an existing home must be sold before the buyer is required to complete the purchase.
"I tell them that waiving things like that can end up costing them a fortune," Mr. Selsberg said.
Waiving a home-sale contingency, for example, might seem safe when a person buying a new home already has a signed contract to sell the current one. Many people reason, Mr. Selsberg said, that if the sale of their existing home falls through, they will be able to safely exit from the contract for the purchase of the new one because mortgage commitments themselves are generally contingent upon the sale of an existing home.
But that is not necessarily the case, Mr. Selsberg said, because it can be argued quite convincingly that the mortgage contingency clause in the buyer's contract to purchase the new home was fully satisfied when the mortgage commitment was issued, even though the commitment was contingent upon the sale of the buyer's existing home.
"That contingency is between the buyer and his lender," Mr. Selsberg said. "As far as the seller is concerned, the mortgage contingency has been met and the buyer has to go through with the deal or lose his deposit."
As a result, Mr. Selsberg said, he has a stock answer for clients who suggest waiving a standard contingency: "Don't you dare do that," he tells them. "You can never skip a step."
In fact, one of the more common steps that buyers seem willing to skip is the home inspection. And that can have costly consequences.
"People think that if they insist on a home inspection, someone will come and steal the house out from under them," said Maryann Murphy, director of Housemaster, a nationwide home inspection company based in Bound Brook, N.J. But an inspection by a qualified inspector, Ms. Murphy said, can uncover problems that even knowledgeable buyers might miss, things like water seepage, the presence of asbestos, radon gas or lead paint or a leaking underground oil storage tank.
And while such problems cost a buyer money only when they are successful in purchasing the house, there are some risks that can occur when they are unsuccessful.
As the number of available apartments decreases, particularly in Manhattan, "the waiving of mortgage contingencies by apartment buyers has suddenly emerged as a widespread practice in New York City," said Gordon Shanks, managing director of Home Mortgage Acceptance Corporation, a Manhattan-based mortgage broker. "They know that if they don't win the bidding the first time, it might be months before they find another apartment."
But waiving the mortgage contingency is generally considered risky because the deposit can be lost if a mortgage cannot be obtained and the buyer can't go through with the deal. But it is possible to eliminate that risk, Mr. Shanks said, if a buyer can get a mortgage commitment before entering into a contract of sale.
"These buyers apply for a mortgage and get a commitment letter before they actually find the apartment they want to buy," Mr. Shanks said. "When they find an apartment, they can bid on it immediately and waive the mortgage contingency."
Neil Bader, president of Skyscraper Mortgage in Manhattan, said that while a buyer with a commitment in hand might safely waive a mortgage contingency, those who have only been "prequalified" or "pre-approved" should proceed with caution.
Prequalification, Mr. Bader said, is merely an indication that a lender is likely to grant a mortgage. That, however, is based only upon the information provided by the prospective borrower. Generally, he said, prequalifications do not take into consideration significant factors like credit history, employment history, and the special scrutiny given to income generated by self-employment.
"Prequalification certainly isn't enough for a buyer to safely waive a mortgage contingency," Mr. Bader said.
Pre-approval, on the other hand, does provide some measure of assurance because most factors are accounted for. But the problem with pre-approval is that it doesn't take into consideration one factor of great significance to a lender -- the appraised value of the property.
"If the appraisal comes in too low, the mortgage will probably not be approved," said Mr. Bader, noting that the buyer would be paying more than the lender believed the property was worth. And that, he said, can result in the loss of the buyer's deposit if there is no mortgage contingency clause to provide an escape route.
Diane Saatchi, an agent with Dayton-Halstead Real Estate in East Hampton, L.I., said that property owners there were addressing that issue by agreeing to share the risk.
"Buyers are waiving the mortgage contingency only if sellers will guarantee the appraisal value," said Ms. Saatchi. "If the appraisal comes in too low, the buyer's lack of a mortgage contingency doesn't matter because the seller's guarantee gives him another out."
But how likely is a low appraisal?
"Very likely," said Peter Bell, chief executive of Balch Buyers Realty, an exclusive buyer-broker in Mamaroneck, N.Y. "There's such tremendous competition for listings now that if a seller wants to list his house for $50,000 more than it's worth, a broker might take the listing anyway because he knows that if he doesn't take it, another broker will."
And that, Mr. Bell said, coupled with low interest rates, high salaries, dual incomes and generous bonuses can result in purchase prices being driven upward by what buyers can afford to pay today, rather than what the real value of the property would be in a less robust economy.
Eric Davis, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, agreed.
"In the late 80's, people buying real estate believed that the good times would last forever and that the market would never stop expanding," he said. "But the market contracted, and people lost their jobs or had to move, and some of them couldn't even sell their apartments for the outstanding balance on their mortgage."
As a result, Mr. Davis said, buyers whose dream home is appraised for less than what they are about to pay for it should take a deep breath and contemplate whether the low appraisal is a blessing in disguise.
"When you get intoxicated with a particular piece of real estate, you tend to make decisions that are emotional rather than reasonable," he said. "And buying real estate should always be a function of sobriety."
