HEADLINE: To Lead A Community

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN

 BODY:
LUIS A. PEREZ drove his 1989 Honda Accord through the high iron gate of Drumthwacket in Princeton this month and felt disbelief and exhilaration as he took in the expansive lawn with sycamore, linden and beech trees leading up to the 19th-century Greek Revival mansion that serves as the Governor's official residence.
"I'm somebody from the ghetto, and to go to a place like this was beautiful," said Mr. Perez, one of 35 people who graduated that night from a program that teaches leaders from urban neighborhoods how to develop their skills further to help those neighborhoods. 
 "My wife and I were looking at each other," he recalled, "like, 'How far I've come!' "
Mr. Perez, 41, and his wife had driven from Union City, where they live with their 16-year-old son and 12-year-old daughter. But the real distance he was talking about was a different kind, one along a hard road to survival and salvation from a troubled past in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, where he was a heroin addict and a member of a gang called the Puerto Rican Henchmen.
Now he was here, the leader of an organization in Union City that tries to save troubled young people much like his younger self, about to receive a certificate for completing the eight-month program called the Neighborhood Leadership Initiative, sponsored by the Community Foundation of New Jersey.
The foundation, a statewide organization that supports community involvement to promote neighborhood development, created the initiative in 1992 under Christine Todd Whitman, who was the foundation's president at the time. The state Department of Community Affairs was instrumental in setting it up and has been a strong supporter ever since.
The graduates, or fellows, as they are called, who were honored on June 5 numbered 27 women and 8 men, a diverse group from around that state that included four ministers, a school board member, a tenant liaison for a nonprofit housing corporation, the director of social services for a community action program, the president of a block watch group and an information project manager for AT&T.
With their graduation, the Neighborhood Leadership Initiative has returned 250 people to their communities with grants of up to $5,000 and a better knowledge of how to use the assets of those communities to improve the quality of life there, create concrete workable programs and obtain the money to support them.
As the evening came to a close, the fellows were asked to talk about explain their feelings about going back into the community.
"We are soldiers learning to tap into the government and private sector for resources in order to fight our battles in the war on drugs, poverty and the exploitation of our communities," Mr. Perez said.
"I have grown from a soldier to a general," he added, "ready to declare war on anything that will destroy the fabric of my community."
 
Lessons in Turning Dreams Into Reality
From a fading 17-room Tudor Revival mansion dating to 1916 that is leased from the Morris County Park Commission, the Community Foundation of New Jersey quietly goes about collecting money from individuals, corporations and private foundations for projects throughout the state. Two former governors, Thomas H. Kean and Jim Florio, have served on its advisory board.
James C. Kellogg, the current president, said the idea for a neighborhood leadership initiative grew out of discussions between Mrs. Whitman, when she was president, and Sheila Campbell Williamson, a founder of the foundation in 1980 and its longtime executive director until her death in 1994. Melvin R. Primus Jr., a Camden mayor who was Community Affairs Commissioner in the Florio administration at the time, joined them in the planning, Mr. Kellogg said.
Ira Resnick, the foundation's chief program officer, said of the philosophy behind the initiative, "The idea was to identify emerging leadership in a number of diverse neighborhoods and provide training at a statewide level, mentoring and peer support, and then give the people grants of about $3,000 to $5,000 to initiate community projects."
The current Commissioner of Community Affairs, Jane M. Kenny, was a vice president for corporate and community affairs at Beneficial Management Corporation in Peapack at the time and was asked to work on the program committee for the initiative.
"We wanted to get at the community activist who didn't have access to those programs that maybe a corporation person would have, or a government official," she said. "We knew there were people out there who were frustrated and didn't know where to go and how to make changes."
She added, "What we were trying to do was teach them how to become an advocate for their community rather than an irritant whom no one would listen to, how to a point across and turn it into change."
The program adopted by the Neighborhood Leadership Initiative begins with an overnight retreat in October, continues with one full Saturday each month at locations around the state, and ends with a graduation at Drumthwacket in June that Mr. Kellogg describes as more "exuberant and festive" than most.
"I was introduced as Mr. Corn Flakes by one graduate, who claimed it was a slip of the tongue," he said good-naturedly.
The first night at the retreat, the fellows make charts identifying the four events in their lives that have had the greatest impact on their identity. They are also asked to determine what effect, if any, the events had on their wanting to be leaders.
The next day, they take part in physical tests that call on teamwork, trust and problem-solving skills. One exercise requires 10 people to stand on two logs and lift ropes in unison to "walk" the logs across a field.
"You can really see the personalities working," said Faith A. Krueger, the foundation's chief administrative officer. "Someone's a take-charge person, and you have another take-charge person. All of a sudden they have to learn to say, 'Listen, we both can lead a group, but we need to work together on this or we're never going to get across that football field.' "
Their all-day classes once a month take the students to different sites around New Jersey. This year's sites included the Summit Bank in Jamesburg, the New Visions Community Center in Trenton, and the Delaware River Parking Authority Building and the New Jersey State Aquarium in Camden.
The curriculum focuses on teaching fellows how to recognize and develop the talents of the people in their neighborhoods, and how to identify all the institutions that can be enlisted to work for a better neighborhood, including churches, banks, schools, businesses and community groups. They are also taught how to apply for money from foundations and other agencies.
At a gathering of fellows here in Morristown last week, one of this year's graduates, Joyce Cook, acting director of social services and programs for the New Community Corporation in Newark, brought laughs when she said of the extensive travels, "Being with N.L.I., you find yourself traveling the entire state of New Jersey."
Then she detailed the benefits.
"You may have thought your problem was just unique to your own little pocket, but you find there are common problems all over the entire state, and you look at effective ways that other groups of people and individuals have attacked the problem, and you say, 'O.K. I can borrow that idea and take it back to my community.' "
 
A Personal Investment In Lessons on Finance
When Carrie Askew graduated from the program in 1995, she came up with the idea for "ABC's of Finance," a course in money management she created for young people in the Paterson area. She also urges their parents to come, too, so they can get something out of the eight-week course she conducts in a room at the church she attends, the Agape Christian Ministries.
"In the urban areas, we are taught little or nothing about money," said Ms. Askew, an income maintenance worker for the Passaic County Board of Social Services. "People have to learn to budget and learn the principles of money management."
Ms. Askew, who holds degrees in business and sociology from William Paterson College and has worked in the business world, starts by having her young students open bank accounts with money they have earned -- no matter how little -- and progresses from there. A highlight of the class is a trip to the New York Stock Exchange.
At graduation, she began giving each student a $25 saving bonds, and after her grant from the leadership program ran out, she started using her own money.
After Beatriz Bueno, a health promotion coordinator for the Morris County Hispanic Affairs Organization in Dover, graduated in 1997, she started a Spanish literacy program to teach immigrants to read and write in their own language.
Ms. Bueno, who in 1994 immigrated with her family from Argentina, where she was a medical doctor, realized the need for the program when she saw a survey of 200 Latinos in the area showing that 20 percent could not read or write.
Her program employs two teachers, plus a baby sitter, and provides transportation to the classes, which meet twice a week for three months.
Although her program has produced only 13 graduates so far, she tells the story of an elderly woman who has learned to write to her daughter in Colombia. "She is so happy," Ms. Bueno said. "That to me is the most important thing."
Uriel Burwell, who graduated last year, was senior tax assessor in Newark until he resigned a month and a half ago to start a community development corporation called New Visions in his neighborhood on the Newark-Irvington border.
Mr. Burwell, a 1993 graduate of Drew University, built the nonprofit organization on a grass-roots group that had coalesced around him six months earlier to handle a number of issues, including crime.
The new organization, devoted to building low- and moderate- income housing, has already set up a council of 50 homeowners. Mr. Burwell is approaching foundations for other projects, including one to help people start their own businesses.
Another 1997 graduate, Joseph J. Keenan Jr., director of the Elizabeth Public Library, said he learned how important it was for all of a community's institutions to work well independently, and to work together creatively to make society better.
To that end, he and the Neighborhood Leadership Initiative organized a meeting of groups that provide after-school programs for young children to explore common concerns.
"Many organizations working in the same geographical area serving the same children in the same business had never talked with each other before," Mr. Keenan said.
Mr. Resnick, the chief program officer for the Community Foundation, said that most applicants accepted for the program in the past were doing projects on their own but that more and more applicants are now coming from community action programs, churches and other groups that can provide structure and support for their ideas.
 
Practical Information And Emotional Support
Whether this year's graduates were new at leadership or old hands, or working alone or in groups, all said they received something invaluable.
Mr. Perez, an AIDS counselor at Jersey City Medical Center and president of the Positive Latino Association, said meeting other leaders created "a sharing of ideas."
Linda J. Lewis, a former branch chief of the Federal Education Department's Office for Civil Rights and a member of the Union Township Board of Education, said, "You gain a confidence that is not arrogance, but it provided you with an informed assertiveness that allows you to go forth and make contact that you normally would not have made."
Jose R. Cuevas, president of the Elizabethport Block Watch and a longtime community organizer in New York City, said an exchange of ideas could reinvigorate people who were burning out.
"It's almost like we established a support system for each other," he said."When I finished this course, I felt a lot more energy as a result of all the positive people I was around."
Donna Cherry, executive director of the Inner City Crime Prevention-Reduction Project in Newark, said, "Well I learned that there's a difference between being an activist and a leader." An activist may respond to a problem, she said, but a leader sees the larger picture.
"There was a lady in my complex that was abducted and shot at gunpoint," Ms. Cherry said. "And from that point we decided we can't let people come into our neighborhood and do these things to us. We have to network and form a block watch. And then what?
"Later, we saw so many other problems we just hadn't paid attention to, like the stolen cars in the area, like a police presence not being in the area," Ms. Cherry said.
"You can't just go say, 'Well, we want this.' You have to make a set plan and bring in the police department and bring in the city council and bring in some other movers and shakers into our meetings," Ms. Cherry said. "And then plan."
Bevelyn Bland, tenant liaison for Brand New Day in Elizabeth, said the courses brought out strong emotions.
"This '98 class was loving and caring," Ms. Bland said. "And the most important part of working in communities, you have to have that loving and caring spirit."
In an evaluation of the Neighborhood Leadership Initiation several years ago, the Center for Social and Community Development of the School of Social Work at Rutgers University wrote that the fellows "are well received in their communities, and report successes ranging from community support and positive outcomes to providing needed services, improving community capacity. collaboration, empowerment and experiencing personal growth."
And Ms. Kenny, the Community Affairs Commissioner, called it "a wonderful program" that dovetails with the administration's urban initiative.
"There's more to do," she said. "It's a big state, and there are a lot of people. But yes, I feel there is an enormous energy that you feel in the cities and when you have grass-roots community leaders, you see the difference they are making in the lives of their respective neighborhoods."
 
Heading Back To Home Base, Ready for Action
BACK in the community, the Leadership Initiative takes many directions. Here's a look at the plans of several 1998 graduates pictured on page 1.
 
BEVELYN BLAND is an Elizabeth resident who works with Brand New Day, a nonprofit corporation that provides affordable housing for low- and moderate-income residents of the Elizabethport area. She also is involved with a tutoring program for 65 youths at the Elizabethport Presbyterian Center. With her grant money, she hopes to unify various efforts to benefit young people in the community.
 
DONNA CHERRY is senior outreach officer for the International Youth Organization, based in Newark. She will be involved with the Constructive Youth Council, which does neighborhood-based planning in public safety, education and other areas.
 
JOYCE COOK of East Orange has worked for 14 years at New Community Corporation in Newark, where she is acting director of social services and programs as well as central outreach coordinator. She hopes to use her grant award, in part, to work with teen-agers.
 
JOSE R. CUEVAS is president of Elizabethport Block Watch and the Puerto Rican Society, as well as a member of several other community organizations in Elizabeth. He would like to start a program to teach young people about mortgages and other financial issues. He is also interested in developing a charter school.
 
LINDA J. LEWIS of Vauxhall, a former official of the Federal Education Department's Office for Civil Rights, is now working as a consultant. Her community activities include membership on the Union Township Board of Education, the Union Public Library Board and the local Americans With Disabilities Act Committee. The projects on which she will be working include a program called Tumbling for Success and the Ministry of Professional Development at her church, the First Baptist Church of Vauxhall.
The deadline to apply for the Neighborhood Leadership Initiative class of '99 is Aug. 1. Information is available from the Community Foundation of New Jersey at (973) 267-5333.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Central Islip Nonprofit Helps Renew a Neighborhood

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP

 BODY:
THE frame Cape Cod at 48 Cypress Street in the Lowell Avenue section of this community had been vacant for three years, its boarded windows hiding a bleak interior of decaying and water-damaged rooms.
Now fully renovated, the bright and gleaming three-bedroom house became the home earlier this month of Angel and Wanda Rosado and their two children, Angel Jr., 23, and Alex, 14. The couple purchased it for $79,500, needing only $2,000 for a down payment and $1,500 for closing costs. 
 The event, celebrated on June 11 by a ribbon cutting co-hosted by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Central Islip Civic Council, marked more than the start of homeownership for the Rosados, who had been living in a nearby rental apartment.
It also demonstrated that an unusual partnership program formed a year ago by H.U.D. and the Civic Council, a community-based nonprofit group representing this hamlet's 25,000 residents, can indeed work.
H.U.D. acquires houses when owners default on mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration. Under the Central Islip program, H.U.D. turns over its properties within the hamlet directly to the nonprofit group at a lower price than it might get from a private buyer.
The Civic Council, in turn, renovates them and resells them to qualified, moderate-income first-time buyers with annual incomes of $30,000 to $50,000.
The goal is to deplete the inventory of vacant H.U.D.-owned houses that are now blighting local neighborhoods while bringing homeownership opportunities to families like the Rosados who, with an annual income of $30,000, have always found owning a house beyond their reach. The Rosados now pay $966 a month for their mortgage and taxes. As renters, they paid $1,000 a month for a two-bedroom apartment.
So far, three houses priced from $69,000 to $79,500, have been renovated and resold by the nonprofit group and an additional six will be completed within the next four months. Prices for those will range from $65,000 to $95,000. There are 135 names on a waiting list.
"We have been trying to do something like this for a long time, but we were never able to work on H.U.D. homes before," said Nancy Manfredonia, the executive director of the Civic Council, which previously has been involved with new housing in partnership with the Town of Islip.
"Foreclosures were something we identified years ago as a major problem in Central Islip," she said, "but we weren't able to do anything about it."
When H.U.D. houses did come on the market, prices were too high to allow them to be renovated for the moderate-income buyers her group serves, she said.
The team effort between H.U.D. and the Civic Council grew out of an initiative begun two years ago by Robert J. Mulvey, director of the Center for Neighborhood and Regional Planning at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury.
Mr. Mulvey, who also heads a private consulting group called New Directions Community Services, has been working with faculty and students at the college's School of Architecture and Design on revitalization proposals in local communities.
In 1996, he began bringing together planners, lenders, government agencies and local civic groups, inviting them to collaborate with the college in addressing problems confronting needy neighborhoods.
At one of a series of three breakfast meetings, H.U.D. officials offered to work with the Civic Council after Mrs. Manfredonia brought the high number of foreclosures in the Central Islip community to their attention.
"This kind of program is being done in very few places right now," said Bill de Blasio, who heads H.U.D.'s New York-New Jersey office.
"We have been thinking increasingly about ways to involve community-based nonprofits on a broader scale in the disposition of H.U.D. homes," he said. "This is a very good example of how partnering with local community groups can work, and we certainly are looking to doing it more broadly."
Last year H.U.D. foreclosed on 451 houses in the New York City metropolitan area, about half on Long Island.
A NATIONAL policy proposal to turn H.U.D. foreclosures over to the private sector for disposition is under consideration, "but proposals also allow part of that market to be handled by nonprofits," Mr. de Blasio said.
The Central Islip Civic Council has so far focused its efforts on the Lowell Avenue neighborhood where most of the community's foreclosures are occurring.
The 50-year-old subdivision of modest, yet solidly built, ranches, Cape Cods and high ranches has about 1,500 homes. Of those, 50 are vacant houses that have been foreclosed on by lenders, said Mrs. Manfredonia, adding that half of those are owned by H.U.D.
The housing agency periodically sells off its vacant properties but often to the further detriment of the community, said Mrs. Manfredonia. In some cases they are bought by speculators who resell them at a high profit to unqualified buyers allowing the sad cycle of foreclosure to repeat itself, she added..
"We can guarantee that the new people going in can afford the house and that when they take occupancy, all the repairs will be done," she added.
In other cases, foreclosed houses have been purchased by investors who rent them out, often as illegal multiple dwellings, said Mary Ann Huston, the president of the Lowell Avenue Civic Association. "When the Civic Council refurbishes these homes, we will know they will be sold as one-family houses to people who are going to live in them," she said.
The nonprofit group renovates the houses using H.U.D.'s so-called 203K program under which a house can be purchased with a federally-insured mortgage sufficiently large to cover needed repairs and other redevelopment costs, as well as many of the closing costs.
The financing package allows a house needing extensive repairs to be purchased and renovated with a very small cash outlay -- typically about $6,000 for closing costs, said Andrew Thaw, a partner of Whitman Thaw & Associates, a Melville mortgage banker that has been providing 203K financing to the Civic Council.
The home buyer under the Central Islip program can either assume the Civic Council's 203K mortgage or get new financing that may have better interest terms. In either case, Mr. Thaw said, "the consumer is walking into a very low downpayment situation, and they are getting a property that has been totally renovated and that has a lot of equity built in."
The Civic Council paid H.U.D. $25,000 for the 48 Cypress Street house now owned by the Rosados. The $65,170 mortgage it received from Whitman Thaw under the 203K program included $36,000 for refurbishing the house and $1,500 for landscaping.
The nonprofit group needed $7,000 in cash for closing, carrying and administrative costs. The $79,500 sale price to the Rosados gave the Civic Council a $7,000 profit, which will be used to purchase other houses. The Hauppauge-based Long Island Housing Partnership, another nonprofit housing group, has also been providing loans to the Civic Council for the purchase and renovation of houses.
Mrs. Manfredonia said she was also hoping to acquire properties owned by Suffolk County that were seized for nonpayment of taxes and those owned by private lenders who have foreclosed on defaulting owners. She said her group could handle up to 40 houses a year, which would make a significant difference to neighborhoods like Lowell Avenue.
Complementing the housing program will be an architectural and sociological survey of the area, which is being conducted with the help of an $8,000 grant to New Directions Community Services by Citibank.
As part of that survey, New York Institute of Technology architectural students are working on design proposals for improving the neighborhood's aging housing stock. O. Andrew Collver, an associate professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, is simultaneously preparing a profile of the community that will help bring its concerns to the attention of government agencies.
As an exultant Mr. Rosado welcomed visitors to his new house on Cypress Street, he struggled to express how he felt about achieving the family's long dream of owning a house.
His work as a mechanic in a Copiague machine shop and his wife's job as a packer for a pharmaceutical company in Hauppauge had never paid enough to make homeownership possible until now, he said.
Sylvia Barnes, a single mother of three who works in an underwriters' lab in Melville, purchased her $75,000 three-bedroom Cape Cod on Birch Street from the Civic Council in December.
"Now I'm paying for something I own," she said. "I'm investing in my future and in my children's future, not someone else's future."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
In This District, Routine Document Is Anything But

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
The scene in front of P.S. 20 on Essex Street Tuesday night was a regular who's who of downtown radicals. The squatters, looking grungy and grumpy, were there in force, holding banners and smoking hand-rolled cigarettes. The pirates, as in radio, also made an appearance, gossiping about a crackdown on an illegal station in Philadelphia. And there was the Lower East Side Collective, a group of college-educated activists who favor khaki and mountain bikes.
The occasion was the monthly meeting of Community Board 3, and what united the crowd was opposition to a little known piece of bureaucratese known as the District Needs Statement. The statement, which each of the 59 community boards file with the city every year, is a broad outline of the state of the district along with general economic, political and social service goals for the coming fiscal year. It is usually ignored by most community district residents. But in the case of District 3, the fiscal year 1999 version was likened to an act of war. 
 Squatters took offense at the statement's description of them as "usurpers" of the abandoned buildings they live in. Organizers of the needle exchange on Avenue C and East Third Street were unhappy to see their project labeled a "misguided social service experiment." And community gardeners interpreted the statement's strong support for new housing as an implicit threat to the abandoned lots they have turned into public greens.
"The District Needs Statement is a common assault on all of us," said Michael Shenker, who squats in a building on the Lower East Side. "We are united by a common enemy, and that enemy is a community board that does not truly represent this community."
The statement, written by the board chairwoman, Susan Vaughn, also caused strife among board members. "The board chair took tremendous liberties," said David Walsh, an architect who has served on the board for two and a half years. "The opinions of all the elected officials who appointed her are at odds with the opinions expressed in the statement."
City Councilwoman Margarita Lopez, who reappointed Ms. Vaughn to the board last spring, said she has long supported the needle exchange program and opposed eviction of squatters. "I was absolutely appalled by that statement," she said.
Ms. Lopez said she was particularly concerned that the statement endorsed expansion of the Work Experience Program, which requires welfare recipients to work for the city to qualify for benefits.
But the board rejected Mr. Walsh's attempt to rescind several sections of the needs statement.
"This is not Susan Vaughn speaking, this is Community Board 3," Ms. Vaughn said. "I don't think there was anything in there that was not supported by board votes."
She added, however, that she regretted the use of "usupers" in reference to the squatters, and that she would seek more collaboration from board committees in drafting the statement for fiscal year 2000. JESSE McKINLEY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KINGSBRIDGE;
A Return to '08 Prosperity?

BYLINE: By MARINA LAKHMAN 

 BODY:
When the city extended the IRT to West 231st Street and Broadway in 1908, the Kingsbridge area became a vibrant commercial district, attracting residents from throughout the northwest Bronx. Ninety years later, the area below the el is marked by garbage and graffiti, and its stores draw few nonresidents.
Now legislators, community activists and property owners are edging closer to reviving the commercial area by forming the Kingsbridge Business Improvement District. 
 "The key to the ongoing success and viability of the Kingsbridge shopping district is our ability to attract shoppers from beyond the immediate community," said Assemblyman Jeffrey Dinowitz, a proponent of the plan.
Connie Dennis, owner of Columbia Florist on West 231st Street, said, "I believe we have a very strong neighborhood here and it just needs a pick-me-up."
The Kingsbridge Business Improvement District has just received the blessing of Community Board 8 and is preparing to enter the formal approval process, which includes reviews by the Department of City Planning and the City Council. If approved, it will become only the fourth BID in the Bronx.
The Kingsbridge-Riverdale-Van Cortlandt Development Corporation, which has been promoting the BID idea for three years, has the support of 55 percent of the district's business-property owners. The BID will run from West 230th to West 236th Streets along Broadway, and West 231st Street from the Major Deegan Expressway to Corlear Avenue. While no one actively opposes the BID, 45 percent of the district's property owners say they plan not to join it. But if the BID is approved, they will have to pay assessed fees to support it.
With a proposed BID budget of $235,000 a year, the Development Corporation plans to finance additional sanitation and graffiti-removal crews, better security and holiday lights for the area.
Supporters hope that the BID, by attracting new businesses, can help alleviate a chronic vacancy problem. Although the area has only a 5 percent vacancy rate, empty storefronts are an eyesore and may hinder the area's economic viability. Woolworth's recently closed a large store on Broadway, for example.
But a Duane Reade drugstore has just opened on West 231st Street, and Ponce de Leon Federal Savings and Loan Association is renovating a branch of Chemical Bank that closed when Chemical merged with Chase.
Moreover, "a funny thing happened on the way to the BID -- it has changed gross perception in the area," said Bruce Feld, the corporation's BID consultant. As the BID idea has grown, he explained, supporters have been able to showcase the fruits of cooperation.
Last year, for example, two merchants who are on the BID steering committee pitched in to finance Christmas lights for the district. MARINA LAKHMAN

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A High-Yield Alternative To the Money Markets

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON

 BODY:
AT a time when many money market funds are yielding more than 5 percent, and some more than 5.5 percent, investors could be forgiven for yawning at a fund that threw off just 5.1 percent. So what makes the Heartland Short Duration High-Yield Municipal fund a heart-thumper? It's in the tax-free category, making its yield the equivalent of 8.4 percent to someone in the top 39.6 percent income tax bracket.
A money market-like fund with a junk bond-like yield is the idea behind this offbeat offering, the brainchild of Thomas J. Conlin, 44, and his partner, Greg D. Winston, 33. They moved from Strong Capital Management to Heartland Advisors Inc. in 1996 and managed to persuade William J. Nasgovitz, the firm's president, to try their approach. 
 Their aim was to take advantage of a potentially profitable anomaly in bonds: the near absence of a market for junk-rated muni bonds with very short maturities.
Other mutual funds often buy long-term bonds to reap their higher yields. For example, the other fund managed by Mr. Conlin and Mr. Winston, Heartland High-Yield Municipal Bond, has a yield of 6 percent. But it has to make a trade-off in the so-called effective duration of its bond portfolio. Duration is a measure of a bond's economic life; the higher the number, the more sensitive the bond is to interest-rate swings.
The Short Duration fund has an effective duration of 2.2 years, versus 7.4 years for High-Yield Municipal Bond. "In the past, there hasn't been anyone who's interested in the securities that we're looking at," Mr. Winston said. Bank trust departments, for example, buy only high-quality short-term debt.
That leaves the Heartland portfolio as one of only a few customers for such bonds. "This is a good concept," said Alice Lowenstein, fixed-income editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, the investment newsletter. She said she knew of no other similar funds -- at least not yet.
Since it started in January 1997, the Short Duration fund has delivered an average annual return of 6.6 percent, through May 31, the same as the Lehman Brothers One- to Three-Year High-Yield Municipal Index, which tracks these relatively scarce bonds.
In some ways, the fund looks like a money market fund. Its net asset value is relatively steady, having varied only slightly from the $10 initial offering price; shares are currently worth $10.13. Check-writing is also offered, in minimum amounts of $250. But checks amount to a redemption of assets and can thus incur capital-gains taxes.
"We view this clearly as a money-market alternative," said Mr. Conlin, the more effusive partner. But Mr. Winston, the quieter partner, interrupted: "We have to be careful with our phrasing. We manage for a low degree of share-price variation, but not for a stable net asset value." Mr. Winston, who counts exercise and music as his outside interests, admits to being "a little more risk-averse" than Mr. Conlin, who is a recreational pilot.
The counterbalancing of personalities is reflected in the fund's management style. Both men must agree to buy a bond, but either can force a sale. "If Greg wakes up and something bothers him about a bond, and he comes in and says, 'I want to sell it,' it's gone," Mr. Conlin said. "We think that's a nice check in our process."
How do the two reduce credit risk in what, despite its tame interest-rate exposure, is still a junk-bond fund? They start by focusing on bonds that underwrite essential community services.
"We like projects that affect a large number of people, like water and sewers," Mr. Winston said. "We try to avoid projects that affect a more limited number of people, like a golf course or an aquarium." The latter type is more likely to sour, he said, especially in a recession.
The partners also like borrowers with relatively little debt and plenty of cash flow to service it -- and they prefer bonds with legal covenants that protect bondholders' capital.
The fund often buys short-term portions of issues that also include longer-term bonds. Relatively little yield is lost: The spread between long and short rates in the junk muni market is about 72 hundredths of a percentage point, compared with 95 hundredths in the high-quality universe.
One such issue is the Connecticut Development Authority's 6.875 percent bonds due to mature on Aug. 15, 2004, issued on behalf of a nursing home in Southington, Conn., that specializes in treating Alzheimer's disease. The bonds' structure gives them an effective duration of only three years.
"We have a first mortgage on the facility and a first lien on revenues," Mr. Conlin said. "We think it's well-managed and, best of all, it's 100 percent occupied, with a waiting list."
Sometimes "junk" is a misnomer: More than half the time, the bonds in the fund are simply unrated by agencies like Moody's and Standard & Poor's. Issuers must pay to have their bonds rated, so small issuers can save by selling unrated paper, even if they have to pay junk yields.
An example is a 5.4 percent industrial revenue bond of Topeka, Kan., due April 1, 2005, issued on behalf of Reser's Fine Foods, a food processor based in Beaverton, Ore. Topeka is home to the biggest factory operated by the company, which makes potato salad and other prepared foods.
"This is a family-owned business whose president has been there since the 1950's," Mr. Conlin said. "They cover their niche very well, and their financial numbers are outstanding -- 1997 revenues are just shy of five times debt-service coverage."
The fund also buys longer-term bonds nearing maturity. An example is the 8.2 percent bonds issued in 1984 by O'Hare International Airport of Chicago on behalf of United Airlines. The bonds are rated as junk by S.& P. because the airline, not the city, stands behind the revenues generated from lease payments on landing gates. "Our belief is that if United misses a payment, there will be countless other airlines lining up to take those gates and make those payments," Mr. Conlin said.
The bonds are callable on May 1, 1999, at $103 per $100 face amount. The fund bought them last month for a price that gives an effective yield to the call date of 4.8 percent. "If we were to go buy a money market security we'd get 3.25 percent, and here we're getting 4.8 percent," Mr. Conlin said. "This is perfect."
The men see themselves as value investors who aim to buy cheaply, usually because a bond is under a cloud for some reason. "We buy things when they're down," Mr. Conlin said. "Then we're very patient. We both understand it takes a lot of time for your credit stories to play out."

HEADLINE: A Warming Trend For Canadian Stocks?

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
START with a strong, rebounding economy. Add an apparently undervalued stock market. Throw in a national currency that seems to have been pummeled by one Arctic blast after another.
To many investors, that sounds like a recipe for bargains. And it explains why some are hungrily watching the Canadian stock market. 
 The mere mention of Canada, though, can stop some otherwise eager American investors cold. Over the years the nation to the north has produced enough seedy mining companies and dubious oil stocks to fill the St. Lawrence Seaway. Its smaller stock exchanges have reputations for lax regulation and even slacker enforcement. And deep frustration can await an investor who tries to get the same kind of detailed information about a Canadian company that is readily available about companies whose stocks are traded in the United States.
But many analysts see in Canada something hard to find in the United States: plenty of upside potential.
Canada's domestic economy could hardly look more promising. Growth is strong, inflation is low and upward pressure on wages is almost nonexistent. And the weakness of the Canadian dollar, which reached an all-time low in mid-June and was worth about 68 American cents on Friday, is bolstering the country's exports. They will soon account for half the country's total output.
Still, valuations of Canadian stocks have lately lagged behind those of their American cousins. According to Fred Sturm, portfolio manager of the Ivy Canada mutual fund, business prospects for companies in sectors other than natural resources, Canada's traditional strength, are still attractive, but their stocks are currently trading at levels 10 percent to 20 percent below those of their south-of-the-border counterparts.
And because Canada's commodities businesses depend heavily on exports, now depressed by the disruptions in Asian economies, Canadian natural-resource stocks are even cheaper, trading at discounts of 20 to 30 percent to similar American stocks.
Canadian stocks generally would be more appealing to Joseph M. Scarella, a portfolio manager at Oppenheimer Capital, if he could see a "spike-like bottoming" in commodity prices in three to six months. Those prices are low because of worldwide oversupply as well as the Asian situation. But he said improvement would be gradual.
Andrew Root, who works at Goldman, Sachs as an analyst of paper and forest-product companies, likes Donohue, Domtar and MacMillan Bloedel, Canadian companies in that field. But he said he did not expect their stock prices to crawl out of their trough "until the market gets its hands around the situation in Asia."
Mr. Sturm, whose Ivy Canada is one of the few Canadian-oriented mutual funds available to American investors, says low commodity prices have created a buying opportunity. He reasons that commodities have nowhere to go but up and that when they do, Canadian natural-resource companies can be expected to outperform the broader market, as they have in the past.
Mark Chandler of Goldman, Sachs Canada pointed out that the falling value of Canada's currency had helped to offset the damage from the commodity slump, keeping Canadian output competitively priced.
Because of strong prospects for the overall Canadian economy, Mr. Chandler said, Canadian stocks should return about 10 percent over the next 12 months, just as they have over the last 12. Such a steady pace may not look like much compared with the 28 percent run-up of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the last year, but it could be soothing to investors who worry that the United States market is due for a meltdown.
There are signs that profits for Canadian companies have not yet peaked. For the first quarter of 1998, they accounted for just 8.9 percent of Canada's national income. "That tells us that corporate profits aren't yet overextended," Mr. Chandler said. "The historical average is closer to 10 percent."
ONE way for cautious investors to play the Canadian stock market is to invest in companies that generate a high percentage of their revenue outside Canada. Robert Reiner, who helps manage the BT Investment International Equity fund, sees that advantage in three of his four favorite Canadian stocks.
BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, is one of the few big telecommunications companies that also has a well-situated interest in the telephone equipment industry, which is booming worldwide.
Cadillac Fairview, which owns and develops commercial real estate, has almost a fifth of its assets in the United States, something that he suspects most investors haven't noticed.
Newcourt Credit is currently Mr. Reiner's top pick. The company arranges asset-based financing for large companies and institutions, most of them outside Canada, and is the biggest pure play in its field, which is led by GE Capital, Mr. Reiner said. He expects Newcourt's earnings to grow 50 percent next year.
His fourth recommendation, the Royal Bank of Canada, is somewhat surprising. Canadian bank stocks have run way up recently, posting much bigger gains than the S.& P. banking index showed this year and last, and some investors might feel edgy about parking money in the sector.
But the Royal Bank is a leader in consolidating and has a merger pending with the Bank of Montreal. And, unlike banks in the United States, Canada's banks dominate the domestic mutual fund industry, which is just taking off with consumers.
According to Lori B. Appelbaum, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, Canadian bank stocks are trading at a discount of 10 percent to 15 percent to those of their American counterparts, even though expected earnings growth is just as strong, at 12 percent to 13 percent annually. She likes Canadian Imperial Bank and Toronto Dominion as well as Royal.
But there are two clouds on the horizon for Canadian bank stocks, according to Mr. Scarella at Oppenheimer Capital, and they both emanate from the Bank of Canada, the country's central bank. Interest rates could be raised to stem the slide of the currency, and there could be a move to block the Royal Bank merger with the Bank of Montreal. "I think this merger has only a 50-50 chance of happening," Mr. Scarella said. "There's a lot of momentum building up against it, especially among rural Canadians who think it will cause banks to close up offices."
But money managers like Mr. Reiner remain bullish. "There's this bias that all you can buy in Canada are commodity stocks, when in fact the country has some of the best banks, industrials and technology companies in the world," he said. "There are a lot of overlooked stocks in Canada, and for the most part, U.S. mutual fund managers still haven't discovered them."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
For Cool Hunters, Tomorrow's Trend Is the Trophy

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
WHEN the Ladies Who Lunch at Bergdorf ask Claire Ramsey where she found that faaaabulous outfit, she knows that she's on to a trend, and that she has just earned a few hundred bucks.
Ms. Ramsey, a 30-year-old New York University graduate student in public health, works as a cafe hostess at Bergdorf Goodman in Manhattan. But she is also a "cool hunter" -- a person whose taste is so ahead of the curve that a trend analysis firm pays her a $200-to-$500 bounty for helping to identify the Next Big Things to sweep popular culture. 
 No one knows how many cool hunters are prowling America's malls and streets, but cool hunting is one of the latest trends in trend analysis.
Beginning in the late 1960's, marketing research pioneers like Yankelovich Partners and Roper Starch Worldwide measured opinion by conducting scientific polls, following up with focus-group research.
Now firms like Iconoculture, Sputnik, Agent X, Lambesis and Youth Intelligence, which employs Ms. Ramsey and nine other part-time cool hunters aged 14 to 30, are incorporating cool hunting, an anthropological field-study approach to trend spotting.
The hunters prowl inner-city basketball courts, fashionable nightclubs and houses in the Hamptons, observing the arbiters of coolness whose tastes may eventually be adopted by the general populace. (Hey, someone had to be the first to wear a baseball cap backward.)
These firms report to a corporate Who's Who that includes Coca-Cola, MTV, General Mills and Wendy's International. The companies, in turn, use the information to formulate new products and to devise marketing campaigns that grab the attention of the crucial youth market.
"The trendsetters are the ones breaking new ground in consumer product areas, and they give you insights into what will be widely developed down the road," said Janet Taylor, director of college marketing for Sprint and a client of Youth Intelligence, a firm based in New York.
Three years ago, when Youth Intelligence's analysis suggested that tattoos would become popular, Sprint wound up luring students to a calling-card promotion with marketing that included temporary tattoos. Sprint declined to discuss exact figures for the campaign but said it had produced twice as many sign-ups as had been expected.
Jim Wicks, the director of the Sony design center in San Francisco, said the company had made use of cool-hunter insights when designing a new Walkman, the Freq, for young athletic users.
"It uses special graphics, it uses special materials to hold it to the body, and the Freq logo is more prominent than the Sony logo," Mr. Wicks said. "It was using heavy-duty clips, much like chains you see them wearing.
"Cool is the reason people buy things," he added. "A shirt is a shirt and it fulfills a function, but you buy the one with the logo you think is cool."
JUST as the qualities of cool are hard to pin down, so are the criteria for becoming its hunter. The firms say their hunters have a taste level that is avant-garde but not so far out that it won't become mainstream.
Jane Rinzler Buckingham, the founder of Youth Intelligence, for example, saw Ms. Ramsey in a cafe about four years ago wearing Mhendi -- an intricate Indian henna-based skin decoration -- ahead of the pack that would soon follow. Ms. Buckingham asked about the Mhendi and found Ms. Ramsey articulate about why she liked certain items and fashions. And that was it.
"It wasn't just about her taste -- it was that she didn't care about trends yet naturally anticipated them," Ms. Buckingham recalled.
For Ms. Ramsey, the job isn't work. She and other hunters file their reports informally, and not on a regular basis, though if Youth Intelligence does not hear from a hunter it will call at least three times a year.
One of Ms. Ramsey's research methods is to be her own laboratory rat. "I can't necessarily afford the high-end fashion, so I make my own things up," she said. If a particular item draws comments, it may make her list.
She also has a knack for spotting up-and-coming fashions on others. Three years ago, she noticed an elderly woman wearing an attractive ring. It was a Lalique ring, and Ms. Ramsey ran out and bought one, reporting this to Youth Intelligence. "Recently young people started buying them," she said. "There are all of these plastic knockoffs of it."
Though being a cool hunter sounds, well, cool, trend analysis companies consider the term derisive, applying it only to hired hands like Ms. Ramsey. Cool hunting, the firms say, doesn't require sophisticated analysis of why an item is cool, a service that the research firms provide. One firm, Sputnik, refused to discuss the topic without a guarantee that the words "cool" and "hunter" would not appear in the article.
Still, there is a career track for former cool hunters.
Tru Pettigrew, 30, started out surveying schoolyards for cool as research for Converse, the sneaker company. But now, at Arnold Communications, an advertising agency in Boston, he is the "Voice of the Consumer" -- a broader job researching youth culture. Between that position and his publication of Tru Flava, a quarterly newsletter on youth trends, Mr. Pettigrew said he earns $40,000 to $60,000 annually.
Mr. Pettigrew plies his trade scouring schoolyards and clubs for new cool -- he says, for instance, that clothes with big logos are old news.
"Kids are getting away from having a Hilfiger all across the chest," he said. "They want the smaller logo. They don't want to look like they are trying too hard."
He also runs informal focus groups, taking products -- and, sometimes, company executives -- out on the street for a sort of urban cool safari. Mr. Pettigrew has a retinue of teachers and coaches in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Baltimore, Houston, Chicago and Boston who put him in contact with teen-agers. Though the young people are seldom paid cash, they usually receive products, he said.
Cool-industry specialties are popping up, too. For instance, Richard Rushfield and Adam Leff founded Agent X, a cool-hunting firm in Los Angeles that advises the entertainment industry exclusively. "We help them decide what movies to make because they are working on projects for two and three years down the road," Mr. Rushfield said.
Mr. Rushfield, a former political consultant, and Mr. Leff, who wrote screenplays including "The Last Action Hero," offer their clients trend tours, showing studio executives what is hot. More often they lecture, then field questions.
"They ask, 'Will pirates be in?' " Mr. Rushfield said. The answer is no -- witness 1995's epic pirate bomb, "Cutthroat Island."
But Agent X gives a thumbs-up to upbeat road pictures and films embracing "traditional community values." Each genre, in its own way, is an escape from complex moral choices, Mr. Rushfield said; road movies are "a subset of the trend toward a desire for fun removed from a moral context," while traditional-value films appeal to audiences "looking to go back to simple, basic ways."
That means that future cinematic good guys are less likely to be businessmen, who may be seen as morally tainted, than firefighters, whose image remains largely uncorrupted, Mr. Rushfield said.
"Firemen represent simple, straightforward decency," he said.
THE pair work by traveling to big cities around the country, using their radar to spot cool stuff. They compile much of it into a one-page chart, called "Intelligence Report," that runs occasionally in Vanity Fair magazine. Now at work on a humorous how-to book on spotting trends, the pair say their firm will bring in $1.2 million next year.
Back in New York, Ms. Ramsey cannot claim such a hefty payday. Still, she appreciates the money she does get.
"It's pennies from heaven," she mused. "I can rely that it's there, but I can't rely when it's coming."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Every Second Counts Even More

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
WHO says economics is the dismal science? O.K., O.K.: just about everybody. Who but an economist, after all, would insist that unemployment can be too low or that the stock market can be too high?
But nobody ever accused the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas of spreading doom and gloom. Indeed, the Dallas Fed is probably best known for a study showing that poverty in America is largely a statistical misunderstanding. 
 Perhaps not surprisingly, that take on poverty never passed muster with the gatekeepers of the economics establishment. But the same researchers, W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm, are at it again. And this time the good-news guys are apt to raise fewer hackles with their paean to the virtues of technological change and productivity growth.
"Time Well Spent: The Declining Real Cost of Living in America," an essay by Mr. Cox and Mr. Alm that is part of the Dallas Fed's 1997 annual report, is short on hard-core analysis. But the then-and-now statistical comparisons, showing how much more the average American can now buy with so much less effort, are fun to check out.
For the record, the Dallas Fed economists are not the first to take issue with the idea that prices are far higher today than they were, say, a century ago. Indeed, the argument about long-term price comparisons is well-known to Econ 101 students as the Sears Catalogue Paradox.
If prices are really so much higher today, the premise goes, it follows that most people would prefer to spend $1,000 on goods from a century-old Sears catalogue at 1898 prices than go on a $1,000 shopping spree for today's goods at today's prices.
In fact, most people would choose the second option. While it would be nice to be able to buy a pound of nails or a dozen spools of cotton thread for a few pennies from the old catalogue, hardly anyone would want to own the primitive sewing machines or bicycles from the 1898 catalogue at any price. (For the sake of this discussion, set aside their value as collectibles.)
Besides, many things that make life pleasant, even bearable, simply weren't for sale in 1898. "No amount of income would make my life better if I couldn't buy my arthritis drugs," noted Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
On the other hand, said Mr. Krugman, the author of "The Accidental Theorist" (Norton), the Sears Catalogue Paradox misses part of the point because it looks backward rather than forward. The variety and quality of goods that Americans take for granted today could not be had at any price in 1898, but staples -- food and shelter -- have certainly risen in price since the 19th century.
Brad DeLong, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, put it another way. As new, improved products come along, he noted, "the rich substitute out of whatever luxury goods they were consuming like bandits." But a peasant in, say, Haiti, would happily give up access to antilock automobile brakes or computer games that he can't possibly afford in return for rice, cooking oil and shoes at 1898 prices.
Mr. Cox and Mr. Alm don't mess around with such ambiguities. They have a simpler point to make -- that "the real cost of living isn't measured in dollars and cents but in hours and minutes we must work to live."
And by this yardstick, living has become a lot easier. Consider that staple of modern life, the television set. Back in 1971, the average worker had to toil 174 hours to earn enough money for a 25-inch color receiver. In 1997, a much more reliable TV cost just 23 hours on the job.
Or consider the three-pound chicken that every American used to put in his pot before Pizza Hut opened at the mall. That chicken cost $3.15 in 1997, almost triple the price in 1919. But it took the average worker just 15 minutes to earn that chicken, compared with 158 minutes in 1919.
What has happened, of course, is that technology, education and machinery have made workers far more productive than their counterparts of 20, 50 or 100 years ago. Mass-produced bits of silicon have replaced exquisitely formed (yet short-lived) vacuum tubes in TV's. And chickens, which used to scratch out a living behind the barn, are now scientifically assembled from vegetable protein and antibiotics.
About the only items that have become more expensive in terms of work time are movie tickets and college degrees.
Just why movies (and thus movie tickets) cost more in recent years is a genuine puzzle. One hypothesis is that the shift in power from the studios to the stars has undermined competitive pressures that would have kept Hollywood salaries down.
Soaring tuition is also a bit odd. The opportunities for increasing productivity are generally more limited in service industries (as opposed to manufacturing): As William Baumol, an economist at New York University, is fond of pointing out, it takes as many musicians just as long to play a Mozart trio today as in the year it was composed. Still, with college tuition such a high-profile issue, one might have expected labor-saving improvements in education over time.
But the Dallas Fed economists have a simpler explanation. In both cases, they assure us, the product has been improved.
Who, after all, would rather watch a bunch of actors in shades of gray when they could watch Godzilla take a bite out of the Empire State Building in glorious Surroundsound? And who could resent the $150,000 price tag of an Ivy League education that lands them on the Wall Street gravy train?
If Mr. Cox and Mr. Alm had stopped about here, few would be inclined to quibble. But they cannot resist tossing in a bit of ideology. This life-enhancing bounty of the modern economy, they contend, depends on the wide differences in living standards between rich and poor.
"Without society's wealthy, fewer new goods and services would find their way to the rest of us," they write.
"Far from being a blight on society, unequal income distribution is instrumental in driving society forward. It's a natural resource."
Marie Antoinette couldn't have said it better.

HEADLINE: Uttering the P-Word With Social Security

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
AN idea that sounded heretical only a year or two ago is suddenly popping up in all corners.
Privatizing Social Security -- having individuals divert a portion of their payroll taxes into personal retirement investment accounts -- is part of the overhaul plans offered by Democratic and Republican leaders, from moderates like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, to conservatives like Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. 
 It is also at the core of a plan proposed in May by the National Commission on Retirement Policy, a private group formed by the Center for Strategic and International Studies and led by Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, and three other members of Congress. The plan has become a focus of debate over privatization in part because of its influential bipartisan support and because its detailed provisions have been scrutinized by Government actuaries.
According to its proponents, privatization will help cure Social Security's financial and philosophical flaws -- among other things, giving young workers, who have grown disillusioned with the New Deal program, a shot at earning a fair return on their payroll tax dollar.
But a growing chorus of economists says the benefits of privatization are illusory. The critics contend that private accounts will not help achieve long-term solvency and, counterintuitive though it seems, that they will not outperform the sad-sack Social Security trust fund into which payroll taxes now go. Indeed, on a level playing field, the critics argue, private accounts as a whole are bound to do worse than the trust fund. And all this change, they add, poses a needless risk, because Social Security is only mildly out of fiscal whack.
It isn't difficult to understand why the political ground has shifted so quickly. Republicans have controlled Congress since 1994, and Social Security, as a gargantuan Government program, has never been the darling of conservatives. Another reason is that the program is running out of money; in about 20 years, when the baby boomers begin to retire, the system will be paying out more in retirement checks than it will be collecting in payroll taxes. So some kind of fix is needed.
Moreover, the stock market has been soaring, just when Americans are becoming accustomed to investing some of their retirement money in self-directed 401(k) plans. Many, especially younger workers who don't expect Social Security to survive until their retirement, are unhappy about seeing their payroll contributions tied up in the low-yielding trust fund rather than some high-flying stock fund.
And so, like other would-be reformers of Social Security, the commission set out both to restore the system to solvency and to create a new political constituency for a national retirement system.
 
A Crisis With 2 Solutions
The so-called crisis confronting Social Security is this: It would take a reserve of $3 trillion today to pay the difference between benefits that will be distributed and taxes that will be collected over the next 75 years. This ominous-sounding number is cited by those who advocate extensive changes. But the defenders of the current system say the budget hole is not formidable, and can be filled by raising payroll taxes by about two percentage points, to about 14.5 percent.
Crisis or not, the commission, unwilling to buck the anti-tax mood in Congress, would achieve long-term balance by cutting benefits. The cuts could, for example, reduce the first-year benefits of an individual born in the 1980's by about 30 percent.
The most striking provision calls for raising the normal retirement age to 70 by 2029 and the early retirement age to 65 by 2017. Thereafter, the commission calls for these retirement ages to rise in line with life expectancy. In other words, as medical breakthroughs allow people to live longer, the commission would have them spend all of the additional years at work.
Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, a co-chairman of the retirement commission, says the commission proposes raising retirement ages in this way to avoid "imposing higher payroll taxes or substantially reducing retirement benefits."
Critics of this proposal, like Peter Diamond, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, call the proposal "unrealistic." It runs counter to "a century of trend toward earlier retirement," Professor Diamond said.
Though the commission's initial round of benefit changes would, by themselves, achieve long-term financial balance for Social Security, the 24-member panel does not stop there. Instead, it adds a proposal to partially privatize the retirement system. Workers would deposit 2 percent of their earnings in private accounts, choosing among widely diversified stock and bond funds authorized by the Federal Government. That would leave 10.4 percent of earnings in the trust fund.
In part, the idea is to restore younger workers' faith in Social Security, explained Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, a co-chairman of the commission. Workers who think of their payroll tax contributions as an investment often see the Social Security trust fund as a raw deal: For every $100 that young workers pay into the fund today, they are likely to get back at retirement 30 years hence only about $150, an annual rate of return of between 1 and 2 percent after taking account of inflation. Senator Gregg said private accounts would "offer much higher rates of return."
The commission also wants to turn Social Security into a national savings program, a change from the current approach of paying today's retirees with today's workers' taxes. The commission's idea, Senator Gregg explained, is to encourage workers to save and invest, helping the economy grow richer and making tomorrow's workers better able to afford the burden of supporting their parents. He acknowledges that merely diverting existing taxes into private accounts does not raise national savings. But the commission also invites workers to deposit up to $2,000 a year extra into these tax-advantaged savings vehicles.
 
Cuts That Run Deeper
The rub is that privatization -- which, remember, is not needed to "save" Social Security -- would worsen the system's financial balance, at least temporarily, by diverting payroll taxes that would otherwise be available to pay current retirees.
The commission's solution is to propose a second round of temporary benefit cuts for retirees who are not poor. It would set each year's benefits for new retirees at between 98 and 99 percent of the previous year's figure. While cuts of less than 2 percent sound small, they add up. By the 20th year of the program, the benefit of a middle-class family, now about $1,000 a month, would have fallen about 20 percent.
Yet the commission, pointing to actuarial projections, says workers would fare better with privatization because income from the investments would more than make up for its second round of benefit cuts.
But critics say privatization won't really benefit workers or the economy.
That sounds bizarre: After all, how can a portfolio of stocks and bonds yielding, say, 5 percent above inflation, not beat the trust fund's 1 percent return? The critics say the comparison is misleading.
The trust fund looks bad in part because, unlike private accounts, under current law it can't invest in stocks. Also, returns on the trust fund look measly because it bears the burden of paying off unfinanced claims -- $9 trillion in benefits that the system has promised to pay but against which it has accumulated no reserves. The private accounts bear none of this burden.
If it were not for the fact that private accounts would be allowed to invest in stocks -- and critics have a lot to say about the misleading nature of that advantage -- they would provide no financial benefit to workers.
In a forthcoming book on overhauling Social Security, the economists John Geanakoplos of Yale, Olivia Mitchell of the Wharton School and Stephen Zeldes of Columbia University point out that, with or without private accounts, workers must pay for the system's unfinanced claims -- unless Congress does the unthinkable and breaks its promise to several generations of retirees. Either lawmakers will tax the necessary money out of the new private accounts, reducing their yield, or they will cut future benefits for today's young workers.
These economists argue that the extra profit that workers earn on the dollars they deposit into their private accounts is exactly offset by the extra loss that they suffer on their deposits into the trust fund -- assuming, still, that the private accounts invest in the same low-risk securities held by the trust fund. So the income of retirees would not change, the economists say.
But proponents of privatization counter that most individuals will invest in stocks and outperform the trust fund. The actuaries' projections bear them out. Individuals who invest in stocks under the commission's plan are likely to have slightly more income upon retirement than they would under the current system once it is brought into long-run balance.
But critics warn that comparisons among yields on private and public retirement funds don't take into account that stock purchases would expose workers to risk that the trust fund does not.
A fair test would compare private accounts to a trust fund that would, as many economists propose, invest in corporate stocks and bonds. By that standard, Mr. Diamond, along with Henry J. Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution, contend that the trust fund would actually outperform private accounts. Private accounts, these economists say, would be more expensive to administer.
Just think, they say, of the costs of more than 140 million itsy-bitsy accounts versus one giant Government investment fund.
Mr. Aaron worries, too, about exposing the retirement income of individual workers to the risks of investing in the stock market. He would rather see the Social Security trust fund build reserves -- his preferred way to bolster national savings -- and invest in corporate stocks and bonds while continuing to pay a set level of benefits to retirees.
"Why move to a system that produces, after taking account of administration expenses, lower returns and subjects the elderly to unwanted risk?" Mr. Aaron asked scornfully. Besides, he added, privatization plans like the commission's would inevitably widen the gap between rich and poor because poor workers could be expected to load their accounts with low-yield bonds while the wealthier and more knowledgeable focus on stocks.
 
About Those Surpluses
The critics' arguments veer quickly from arithmetic into politics, as do those of the proponents of privatization.
Some economists who favor privatization -- notably Professor Martin Feldstein of Harvard, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan Administration -- vigorously oppose any plan that has a Government-run retirement fund buy big chunks of American business. He fears political manipulation of investment decisions -- for example, by ruling out the purchase of shares in tobacco companies -- though Mr. Aaron and other liberal economists say Government investments could be insulated against that threat.
The Feldstein plan, broadly embraced by Senator Gramm, would make up for the 2 percent of earnings workers could put in private accounts by directing $1 trillion in Federal surpluses over the next decade into the Social Security fund. At retirement, workers would collect a benefit from the trust fund equal to that of the current law, plus 25 percent of the money that has accumulated in their individual accounts. The balance of the private accounts would be turned back to Social Security.
Everyone, Mr. Feldstein says, would come out ahead, countering Mr. Aaron's worries about exposing the elderly to unwanted financial risk. Mr. Aaron dismisses the plan's rosy outcomes as distorted by its tapping of temporary Government surpluses. The windfall could be used at least as effectively, Mr. Aaron suggests, to build up reserves in the trust fund.
 
Irreconcilable Differences?
The political distance between the combatants appears at least as great as the economic distance.
Senator Gregg embraces private accounts, saying they "will create a sense of ownership and control."
"You know, that is the capitalist system," he said. "You take a personal interest in what you personally own."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, calls the existing program "the most successful Federal program ever enacted" and says privatization would "risk turning Social Security into social insecurity."
Economists are no more reconcilable. Mr. Aaron says tough-minded safeguards would allow Government to buy perhaps 15 percent of the equity on Wall Street, free of political influences. Mr. Feldstein refuses to seriously entertain the notion, no matter what safeguards Mr. Aaron concocts. So what starts out as a fight over actuary tables becomes a battle over the role of Government. The numbers will no doubt be easier to resolve.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Gains or Illusions?"
If the Social Security trust fund and proposed private retirement accounts invest in the same kinds of securities, the privatization plan at best comes out even with the existing system, many economists say. That is because money still must be diverted to pay for the $9 trillion in unfinanced benefits owed to current and future retirees. Critics say any advantage that the private account would enjoy by investing in stocks and bonds could be realized more efficiently by the trust fund. Chart describes the current system and the partially privatized system. (pg. 12)
