HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton and Jiang Debate Views Live on TV, Clashing on Rights

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 27

 BODY:
The United States-China summit meeting ended tonight with a formal state dinner after an extraordinary live televised exchange between President Clinton and Jiang Zemin, the Chinese President, over human rights, Tibet and China's path to the future.
The two leaders announced a number of agreements, including a pledge to retarget their ballistic missiles quickly so that neither side is aiming nuclear weapons at the other. 
 The two nations also announced modest progress toward China's adherence to an international missile proliferation agreement and steps toward China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
But the drama of the meeting came in a remarkable 70-minute news conference, carried live on nationwide Chinese television, in which the two Presidents differed sharply on the nature of personal freedom, the role of the state and the meaning of the Tiananmen Square demonstrations that were violently suppressed by the Chinese Government in June 1989.
Some American officials expressed concern after today's exchange that the Chinese might not permit the broadcast of Mr. Clinton's speech on Monday to students at Beijing University, the rhetorical centerpiece of the President's nine-day visit to China. But they said the President had made his point in unvarnished terms before a potentially huge audience.
Because few Chinese knew that the news conference would be televised live, it was unclear how many had actually seen it, although by the evening news of the debate appeared to have spread widely. .
The meeting was the first time a foreign leader had squarely confronted the painful legacy of Tiananmen Square on Chinese soil -- and on Chinese airwaves.
American officials were jubilant because the news conference allowed Mr. Clinton to speak without filters to the Chinese people of American concerns about China's human rights record. It was also, in their view, a powerful response to critics in the United States who said that Mr. Clinton should not have rewarded the Chinese Government with a high-profile summit meeting even as its Communist leaders continued to suppress political speech and the free exercise of religion.
American officials said they did not signal to the Chinese in advance of the news conference that Mr. Clinton planned to speak out forcefully on the Tiananmen Square tragedy. They said they did not want to force Mr. Jiang into a defensive posture, or, more importantly, cause the Chinese to pull the plug on the live broadcast of the event.
The spirited exchange recalled earlier confrontations between top American officials and Communist leaders, including the "kitchen debate" between Richard M. Nixon, then Vice President, and Nikita S. Khrushchev and an early meeting between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It also echoed a similar debate on human rights when President Jiang was in Washington last October. But at today's news conference, the back and forth was more forceful and animated.
Mr. Clinton flatly told the Chinese leader that his Government had been "wrong" to use force to end the peaceful demonstrations of the spring of 1989 and that broad personal freedom and political expression were the price of admission to the world community of the 21st century.
"For all of our agreements, we still disagree about the meaning of what happened then," Mr. Clinton said in his opening statement, referring to the violent crackdown on Tiananmen Square the night of June 3-4, 1989, that left hundreds of protesters dead.
"I believe, and the American people believe, that the use of force and the tragic loss of life was wrong," the President said as a stone-faced Mr. Jiang looked on. "I believe, and the American people believe, that freedom of speech, association and religion are, as recognized by the U.N. Charter, the right of people everywhere and should be protected by their governments."
When asked by a reporter about Mr. Clinton's remarks on Tiananmen Square, Mr. Jiang appeared ready with an answer. He defended the use of the army to end what he called the "disturbances" of 1989 as essential to maintaining order.
He said the United States and China had different social systems, ideologies, histories and cultures. "So it's nothing strange that we may have some difference of views over some issues," Mr. Jiang said.
Becoming more emphatic in his expression and gestures, he added, "I have stated our position that with regard to the political disturbances in 1989, had the Chinese Government not taken the resolute measures, then we could not have enjoyed the stability that we are enjoying today." He then offered Mr. Clinton an opportunity to reply.
Mr. Clinton said that the American system was based on a delicate balance between personal liberty and central authority, with liberty the paramount value.
"So the question for all societies going forward into the 21st century is, which is the better gamble?" Mr. Clinton said. "If you have a lot of personal freedom, some people may abuse it. But if you are so afraid of personal freedom because of the abuse that you limit people's freedom too much, then you pay, I believe, an even greater price."
On Tibet, Mr. Clinton urged Mr. Jiang to initiate a direct dialogue with the Dalai Lama, the mountain region's religious leader, in return for recognition that Tibet is part of China. He also urged Mr. Jiang to respect the "unique cultural and religious heritage" of Tibet.
Mr. Jiang insisted that religious freedom was protected in Tibet and said Beijing had invested millions of dollars in the economic development of Tibet and restoration of historic shrines.
But he expressed bewilderment that many educated Americans and Europeans would believe in Lamaism and blindly support the Dalai Lama's calls for greater autonomy.
Mr. Clinton, permitted the last word, said: "Let me say something that will perhaps be unpopular with everyone. I have spent time with the Dalai Lama. I believe him to be an honest man, and I believe if he had a conversation with President Jiang, they would like each other very much." The audience, both Chinese and American, laughed.
At the state dinner in the Great Hall of the People, the leaders wore business suits and Hillary Rodham Clinton a bright yellow pants suit.
In toasting Mr. Clinton, Mr. Jiang noted that the relationship between China and the United States had seen "some twists and turns" but was nevertheless moving forward. He acknowledged differences on some fundamental issues, but added, "What is important is that the common interests between the two sides far outweigh their differences."
In his toast, Mr. Clinton said, "We Americans appreciate the mutual respect of our relationship -- a relationship based on cooperation, candor and recognition of each other's values and traditions."
The agreements announced today offered no breakthroughs in United States-China relations. Rather, they were incremental steps across a broad range of issues.
The two nations will work more closely on fighting disease and environmental health problems, on combating drugs and on clean energy programs. They will cooperate on legal reforms, including the use of the legal system to insure the observance of human rights.
They agreed to work together to reduce and eventually eliminate the global use of antipersonnel land mines. And they pledged to jointly press India and Pakistan to walk back from the nuclear brink by halting all nuclear tests.
"I think this has been quite an extraordinary day in the evolution of U.S.-China relations," said Samuel R. Berger, the White House national security adviser. "This is a summit that produced substantial results that will make life more secure and improve lives in other ways for the American people and for the Chinese people.
"We also saw today a truly historic press conference that for the first time witnessed the leader of the United States and the leader of China discussing and debating a range of issues, but most particularly human rights, to a live audience across China and the United States."
On Sunday morning, President and Mrs. Clinton attended services at Chongwenmen Church, the largest officially-sanctioned church in Beijing, with nearly 3,000 members.
The congregation presented Mr. Clinton with a bilingual Bible and invited him to speak to the overflow crowd.
"We celebrate with you the growth of the practice of our faith in China," Mr. Clinton said in remarks that lasted less than five minutes. "I believe our faith calls upon us to seek unity with people across the world with different backgrounds and races and creeds."
The President added, "I believe Chinese and Americans are brothers and sisters as children of God. We come here in that spirit today."
The President's schedule for Sunday included a tour of the Forbidden City palace in Beijing and a trip to the Great Wall. In the evening, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang were to hold a private dinner at the Zhongnanhai government compound.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Poised for a Sweep: Yankees Trounce Mets Once Again

BYLINE: By BUSTER OLNEY 

 BODY:
A choice ticket to the series between the Yankees and Mets could bring $600, scalpers said. Six hundred dollars, to see the competitive and emotional series, to see crosstown rivals fighting for bragging rights in the world's biggest city.
But with another Yankees rout in progress by the bottom of the seventh inning yesterday, much of the crowd of 53,587 abandoned Shea Stadium, and whole sections of $600 seats were all but empty, as were the bleachers, and even the owners' box next to the Mets dugout. The series is in a full recession. 
 The Yankees won for the second consecutive day, 7-2, seizing on defensive lapses by the Mets, and like so many Super Bowls, this series is a bust, falling far short of expectations. Masato Yoshii, the Mets' struggling right-hander, will try to prevent a Yankees sweep tonight, pitching against Orlando Hernandez.
But the series, as an event, has lost its essential lure; the Yankees have clinched the series, even if they lose tonight. Two teams supposedly playing for intracity dominance are left now to pursue their own distinct destinies.
The Yankees are 55-19, and if the idea of 120 regular-season victories seemed absurd two months ago, then consider this: They have almost completed the toughest part of their schedule, 48 of their last 88 games will be at home, the sluggers Bernie Williams and Chili Davis are expected to rejoin the lineup in the weeks ahead -- and the Yankees are still on a pace to win 120 games.
"They've played like a great team, no doubt about that," said Mets Manager Bobby Valentine, who only hours before learned that Al Leiter, arguably the team's best pitcher, would miss at least four to six weeks and perhaps the rest of the season after tearing a tendon in his left knee. Leiter suffered the injury moving to cover first base in the pivotal inning of Friday's 8-4 loss.
The Mets (42-34) are in the thick of the National League's wild-card race, but they must proceed without Leiter, and with major issues haunting the club. Valentine must soon decide how he will incorporate Todd Hundley, a popular player close to returning from elbow surgery, back into the Mets' lineup, at the risk of offending other regulars, such as Bernard Gilkey and Butch Huskey. The club must decide if it is willing to invest as much as $100 million in re-signing catcher Mike Piazza, who is playing Hundley's natural position. And once again, the Mets are starved for competent relief, and runs have been difficult to come by.
"This is the type of team," Piazza said, "that can't go toe-to-toe with the Yankees, as far as slugging the ball around and hitting home runs. We can play with them, but we've got to play our game, and we can't defeat ourselves."
Which is exactly what they did yesterday. The Mets created excitement in last year's series by shutting out the Yankees in the first game and playing well, even as they lost the last two games. They played miserably yesterday.
Bobby Jones pitched well and the Mets caught everything early. Jones needed just 41 pitches in the first three innings, Piazza threw out Darryl Strawberry on an attempted steal, and John Olerud fielded a grounder and started a double play. All very crisp, very well done.
With one out in the fourth and the left-handed-hitting Paul O'Neill at the plate, the Mets' infield shifted notably, shortstop Rey Ordonez moving toward second, so that he was playing almost directly up the middle. When O'Neill bounced a roller a few feet to the first-base side of second, Ordonez was perfectly positioned, scooping the ball and throwing to first, head high.
Olerud reached up to take the throw, his hands as good as anyone's in the league -- and the ball hit the webbing of his glove and bounced away. He simply dropped the throw, and Olerud explained later that he lost sight of the ball momentarily. "We'll play the rest of the season," Valentine said, "and not see John drop the ball."
Ordonez looked at Olerud. And looked. And looked.
O'Neill led off first, Olerud holding him there, and Strawberry slapped a curveball through the first-base hole. If you believe that Jones would have pitched Strawberry the same way whether there were runners on base or not, then there is this -- if Olerud had not dropped the throw, if O'Neill had not been at first, then Olerud would have been in position to field Strawberry's grounder and the inning would have been over. "Embarrassing," Olerud called his mistake.
Instead, the Yankees had two runners on base and Tino Martinez at the plate. Jones threw a curveball to the Yankees' first baseman, and Martinez lifted a line drive that barely cleared the eight-foot fence in right field and landed in the Mets' bullpen. Whether Yankees fans made up 20 percent of the crowd or 50 percent, they made 100 percent of the noise at that moment, standing and roaring; as Martinez stepped on home plate and deliberately gave Strawberry a double high-five, a cloud of confetti dispersed from the upper deck.
The Mets disintegrated in the seventh. Martinez hit a high, looping line drive down the right-field line, and Butch Huskey ran a flag pattern for the ball -- directly toward the line, then toward the corner, and it carried over his head for a double. After Jorge Posada bunted for a hit, surprising the Mets, Chad Curtis hit a fly ball, and Martinez tagged up and scored, with Posada taking second.
Scott Brosius then pulled a grounder to Ordonez, Posada breaking for third base. Ordonez often throws to third for outs successfully, and he tried again, to get Posada -- and hit the Yankees' catcher in the middle of the back, an error. It was the wrong play to make: a throw to first would have been the second out, and Yankee pitcher Andy Pettitte (9-5) was due to hit next.
"Two easy plays," Valentine said, referring to Olerud's drop and Ordonez's throw. "We don't usually do that."
Strawberry said, "We've done a great job of capitalizing on those kind of mistakes."
Derek Jeter drove in two runs with a bloop hit and O'Neill singled home a run, and with the Yankees winning, 7-2, fans raced for the exits, the series recession in full bloom.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 
TODD HUNDLEY, who has been far away from this weekend's Mets meltdown against the Yankees, got a single in four at-bats last night in the fourth game of his minor league rehabilitation assignment with Class A St. Lucie in Florida. Hundley played left field for St. Lucie for the second game in a row, and again survived intact. He is 3 for 13 in his four games, with one home run. . . . GEORGE STEINBRENNER was not in the Yankees' box, next to the dugout, and club officials say they have no indication he will attend today's game, either. . . . JERRY SEINFELD threw out the first pitch before yesterday's game. On Friday night, Seinfeld attended the game with the former Met KEITH HERNANDEZ. . . . AL LEITER may be out of action for a while, but he did tip his cap toward the Yankees and the way they battled him Friday night. "What impressed me most is that they were taking pitches that most guys don't take," he said. "I understood that they took a lot of pitches coming in, because I watched a lot of tape. But even when they were in a hole, it felt like most of the guys were really sticking to their game plan."

HEADLINE: SIGNOFF;
An Artistic Anchor for Teen-Agers Adrift

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Vienna Steiner-Stammen says she approached her documentary on improving children's lives through involvement in the arts with a healthy dose of skepticism. Could pursuits like glass blowing, ballet or video making help rescue young people from despair?
So far, that appears to be the case, as presented by "Fire, Risk and Rhythm: Stories of Arts for Change," a documentary to be shown tonight at 7 P.M. and on Wednesday at 10 P.M. on Bravo as part of its national campaign called Start Smart. "What we wanted to say in the program," said Ms. Steiner-Stammen, the executive producer and creative force behind the documentary, "is you can really learn to express yourself and focus on things and get different projects done and kind of realize yourself with an appreciation of the arts." 
 More and more school districts, including New York City's, are seeking to restore arts education in light of the upturn in the economy and studies in the last decade suggesting that music and art programs can bolster academic achievement over all. Although experts say much more research is needed to identify what works and what does not, advocates have plenty of anecdotes to support the benefits of arts education. And "Fire, Risk and Rhythm," told without narration in quick scene cuts and interviews with students and their mentors, adds to them.
The program, shot earlier this year, focuses on three teen-agers, selected for diversity but not necessarily aptitude, who offer street-flavored testimonials on the power of the arts.
There is James Kinnard, an 18-year-old participant in Hilltop Artists-in-Residence, a four-year-old program in Tacoma, Wash., in which low-income children deemed likely to drop out of school or get involved in crime learn and practice glass blowing. In several scenes, teen-agers like Mr. Kinnard, once considered among the toughest vandals on the block, are shown in protective jackets and gloves, delicately swirling molten glass into decorative bowls and vases.
Leaning against a fence outside the school that houses the program, Mr. Kinnard bluntly assesses where he had been headed. "Instead of me being out here trying to sell dope, I can be in there making glass," he says, though at first he thought, "These kids are crazy for playing with hot glass, you know what I'm saying?"
Leslie de la O, 16, the daughter of Mexican immigrants living in Florida, has been transformed by Dance: The Next Generation, a dropout-prevention program affiliated with the School of the Sarasota Ballet. The discipline of mastering pirouettes and leg-bending twists has changed her from a shy girl who hardly ever spoke to a confident teen-ager shown shaking hands with ballet patrons. The program, she says, has taught her to "express herself in other ways, and speaking in public comes with it."
Dahlia Weinstein, a 19-year-old at the alternative Repertory School in New York City, gets a creative spark through the Art Start: Media Works Project, a school program run by volunteer artists that exposes students to film, video and other media. There, she and other teen-agers are shown developing a public-service announcement against racism that is being offered to various television stations. "I wrote this and I see it on TV," says Ms. Weinstein, who appears baffled by the prospect that her work will bebroadcast. This fall, she is entering Hunter College in New York City to study film.
Not everyone, though, sees practical benefits to the arts.
"In the future I don't know what glass blowing has to offer," says Mr. Kinnard's mother, Joyce Armstead. "If you ask me, it's swinging a bar and a tool. Where can that go?"
Alberta Canada, a community activist in Tacoma, comments later, "They may not end up in the art world, but they certainly will have a heightened appreciation."
Quincy Jones, the record producer who began his career as a trumpeter and is host of the Bravo program, helps sum up the message on a personal note: "I was one of these kids until I found music."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Peekskill, N.Y.;
Bringing a Hudson City Back to Its Prime

BYLINE: By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
TO stand today under the more than 2,000 red and yellow bulbs of the renovated marquee of the Paramount Center for the Arts, which opened as the Peekskill Paramount in 1930 with Maurice Chevalier and Claudette Colbert in "The Big Pond," is to sense how this riverfront community once shone.
"We've tried to bring the theater back to its prime at the same time that the whole city is doing the same," said Gladys Muller, president of the center's board of trustees. 
 The renovation of the marquee at a cost of about $60,000, completed two years ago, was the final touch in the restoration of the theater. The center has offered live entertainment and revolving art exhibitions since 1982.
Peekskill was a thriving riverfront manufacturing community in the 19th century. It had three docks on the Hudson, a chemical company that produced the first Crayola crayon, several lumberyards, including the N. Dain's Sons Company, which still exists, and seven foundries that shipped nearly 200,000 stoves in 1894, according to John Curran, the city historian.
The city continued to prosper during the first half of the 20th century, but went into economic decline in the 60's and 70's.
"There's no question that Peekskill has come back," said Mayor Frances S. Gibbs. "It's a little different than what it used to be, but we're moving very strongly in a very positive direction. We're intent on preserving Peekskill's historic past while at the same time moving into the next century."
About 50 new businesses, many of them digital technology companies, have opened in the downtown area in the last four years, she said. Meanwhile, the waterfront, the downtown area and several historic sites have been restored.
Allison Tapley Thompson, a chemist at the pigment division here of the Engelhard Corporation, a leading provider of specialty chemical products, , said she felt part of the city's revitalization. Her grandparents were among the first 100 black families to move to Peekskill. Though she was born and raised in Peekskill, she went away to college, lived abroad and then in North Carolina.
"But this is always home, I knew I'd come back," Ms. Thompson said. "I believe Peekskill is a good, hard-working gem of a community. I like the diversity. This part of the Hudson Valley is also so picturesque that it improves your outlook no matter what you do. It's not a concrete jungle."
"The housing market in Peekskill is very strong right now," said Suzanne Macci, a saleswoman at Prudential Richard Albert Realtors in Croton-on-Hudson. "It's one of the few areas in Westchester where you can get a house with character with a provocative community that's still affordable. Here, Victorians can go for in the $200,000 range. If you go to another area in Westchester, they're $400,000 plus. That's a big difference."
About half of Peekskill's housing stock is from the Victorian era, said Eileen Yajure, co-chairwoman of the Friends of Historic Peekskill, a citizens' history group. Patricia Wilson, a sales associate at Coldwell Banker in Croton-on-Hudson, said that "the fineness of the Victorian houses has gotten out and yuppies are coming here from the Bronx and Brooklyn to restore them."
IN addition to the Victorians, the city has many well-priced starter homes, Ms. Wilson said. Two- to three-bedroom, 1,300-square-foot Cape Cods or colonials built in the early 20th century are on the market at from $100,000 to $150,000. Newer larger homes, including ranches and raised ranches, range from $150,000 to $200,00, she said.
There are also rambling Tudors and contemporary ranches in what Ms. Wilson called the Mortgage Hill section of the city, where many bankers used to live. These homes sell for $250,000 to $350,000, she said.
In addition to single-family housing, there are 867 multifamily dwelling units in Peekskill. There are also 1,493 units in 13 condominium complexes. They range from a two-bedroom unit in Hillcrest Park for $75,000 to a newer two-bedroom unit in either Chapel Hill or the Woods III, each of which includes a pool and clubhouse, for $150,000, said Marilyn Pfaller, a broker/owner at ERA Hudson View Realty in Cortlandt Manor. The Society Hill II complex is built on the former estate of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, the brother of Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin."
There are also four co-op complexes with a total of 691 units. Ms. Pfaller said co-op prices ranged from $30,000 for a two-bedroom, 900-square-foot unit in The Commons to $159,900 for a three-bedroom, 2,000-square-foot penthouse overlooking the Hudson River in Tower Ridge. Tower Ridge has a pool and tennis courts.
There are also 13 rental complexes with a total of 1,552 units. Five of the complexes are public housing and one is for the elderly. Ms. Pfaller said that a two-bedroom apartment could run from $750 a month in the Parkway Plaza to $950 a month at the Chateau Rive, which has a river view.
Some of the most sought-after apartments in Peekskill are the 20 new two-floor, 1,200-square-foot live/work artists' lofts in the downtown area, which begin at $900 a month, said Ralph DiBart, development consultant to Peekskill. He said 40 more were planned in the next year, with some available as condominiums.
It was the school system that attracted Evelyn and Tony Garcia from Union City, N.J., to Peekskill four and a half years ago. Mr. Garcia owns a products distributing business, and Mrs. Garcia is a teacher's aide.
"I heard about Peekskill through friends and liked the idea that there was a lot of room for parent involvement in the schools," Ms. Garcia said. "I also liked the idea of having a very good mix of children in the system. They're not just taught about different cultures. They learn about them by sharing them and living them." She said her 5-year-old son now knows about Hanukkah and Kwanza, as well as Christmas.
The Peekskill City School District had 2,850 students last year, 48 percent of whom were black, 34 percent white, 16 percent Hispanic and 2 percent Asian.
"I think we're a good example of how urban education works," said Salvatore Corda, superintendent of the district. "We're dealing with many of the issues that affect large urban centers. We continually try to provide whatever support is necessary for our students to succeed, whether it's academic support provided above and beyond the school day or something else."
Peekskill High School offers advanced placement courses in 10 subjects and has a planetarium that is available to the community. Of the school's 146 graduates last year, 63 percent went on to higher education.
AMONG the schools in the district are the Oakside Early Childhood Center for pre-kindergarten and kindergarten. Students attend one of three elementary schools for grades 1 through 5, move on to Peekskill Middle School and then to Peekskill High School, from which Gov. George E. Pataki graduated in 1963.
There is also an alternative secondary school in the district that serves 120 middle and high school students. In addition, there is the pre-kindergarten to grade 8 Roman Catholic Assumption School, where annual tuition is $1,535 for parishioners and $2,235 for others.
To serve the diverse population of Peekskill, the city has more than 20 houses of worship, including African Methodist Episcopal, Roman Catholic, Methodist, Presbyterian, Seventh-day Adventist, Lutheran, Baptist and Pentecostal churches.
The restaurants in the city also mirror its diversity. Among them are Italian restaurants, like Hugo's, Capri I and II; Caribbean Spice, Rafiki's Natural Foods and Cafe; pubs like P.J. Kelly's; Zephs' and Crystal Bay Restaurant on the Hudson for fine dining, and Susan's Restaurant, a bistro.
Named for a Dutch settler, Jan Peek, in 1685, Peekskill was a command headquarters during the Revolutionary War. In 1777, the village was attacked twice by British troops and sacked and burned the second time. Peekskill became an incorporated city in 1940 when it separated from the Town of Cortlandt. The Peekskill Museum, an 1875 Queen Anne house, has 19th-century furniture, clothing and domestic artifacts. The city's trading history with the West Indies and China can be learned at Charles Point in the library/gallery of the National Maritime Historical Society, a nonprofit organization that helps preserve historic ships all over the world.
During the summer, concerts are held in the 15-acre Riverfront Green park, which offers a playground, waterfront trail, a public boat launch, kayaking and boat excursions. The 205-acre Depew Park offers an outdoor swimming pool, five tennis courts, two playgrounds and walking and running trails. It adjoins the Blue Mountain Reservation, a county park in Cortlandt.
Ms. Thompson, who frequents the parks with her 6-year-old daughter, Imani, said: "I dream that Imani will have the opportunities I've had in this town, which have been pretty broad, being exposed to so many different people. I also hope she'll continue to enjoy a comfortable, safe sort of environment where people care and look out for each other as much as expected in the 90's. But maybe a little more."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 5, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption last Sunday with an article about living in Peekskill, N.Y., misidentified a housing development. It is Forest View, not Fairview Homes.

Chart: "GAZETTEER"

THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD: In 1850, the Fugitive Slave Act was passed requiring that slaves escaping from the South be captured and returned to their owners. Many people in the North defied the law and set up stations along what was known as the underground railroad to help the slaves. Peekskill is cooperating with New York State and the National Park Service in identifying, documenting and marking stations. "We know the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church was a transfer point for fugitives," said John Curran, Peekskill historian. "Oral and written history confirms it and Harriet Tubman, the black abolitionist, was involved in that church organization in New York City." Another station was the Peekskill estate of Henry Ward Beecher, the brother of Harriet Beecher Stowe, said Mr. Curran.

LENGTH: 2971 words

HEADLINE: Nathan Glazer Changes His Mind, Again

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub is a contributing writer for the magazine. He has written about Kofi Annan, Webster Hubbell, Floyd Flake and others.

 BODY:
Nathan Glazer has had more second thoughts in his lifetime than most people have had thoughts. He is the most modest (and the least tendentious) of the brilliant Jewish boys who attended City College 60 years ago and later came to be known collectively as the New York Intellectuals. The City College crowd helped chart postwar America's ideological frontier; like many of his classmates, Glazer journeyed steadily rightward for decades, from Trotskyist to social democrat to neo-conservative. But lately, Glazer has begun to adopt -- though scarcely embrace -- some strikingly liberal positions. This spring, Glazer wrote in The New Republic that without affirmative action, hardly any blacks would gain admission to top colleges; and that, he argued, would "undermine the legitimacy of American democracy." Glazer seemed resigned rather than enthusiastic, but it was nonetheless a startling reversal from a scholar who two decades earlier wrote "Affirmative Discrimination," a stinging critique of racial (and other) preferences.
Such is Glazer's prestige, and his reputation for intellectual honesty, that in some liberal precincts his anguished turnaround has been celebrated as a portent of a conservative crack-up, at least on issues of race. Well, perhaps. But it's also possible to read in the 50-year arc of Glazer's career a terrible dashing of the hopes that liberalism itself once rested upon. In books like "Beyond the Melting Pot," which he wrote with Daniel Patrick Moynihan, and in countless essays, Glazer, who for nearly 30 years has been a sociology professor at Harvard, advanced a vision of a pluralistic culture that offered a niche to each new group that came to our shores, while encouraging -- at times compelling -- assimilation into the larger society. 
 No living intellectual is more associated with this optimistic and peculiarly American self-conception than Glazer is. In recent years, however, pluralism has come under attack both by the practitioners of identity politics on the left and by nativists on the right. Now Glazer himself seems to have suffered a loss of faith.
When I went to see him not long ago in his home a few blocks from Harvard Yard, I asked if he had concluded that the dynamic of assimilation and progress that appeared to apply to every American simply does not apply to blacks. Glazer is usually quick with an answer. Now he stopped and started, fumbled and fumfered. At last he said: "As a matter of fact, that is the position. The American mind has placed them in a different category." It was obviously a very painful thing for Glazer to admit -- not so much to me as to himself.
A buoyant documentary about Glazer's crowd at City College, "Arguing the World," has lately been making the rounds of art houses and college campuses. As it happened, the film was screened in Cambridge the night before I was to visit Glazer. It was a big Harvard event -- Derek Bok, a former president of the university, showed up, as did the historians David Landes and Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom.
The film traces the divergent intellectual paths of Glazer, the social theorist Daniel Bell, the conservative luminary Irving Kristol and the literary critic Irving Howe. In the movie, Glazer describes himself as "a junior member" of the City College club. He was born, in fact, several years after Bell and the two Irvings. But listening to his muted, wistful on-screen comments about ancient antagonisms, you can tell that he was also less self-dramatizing -- and less self-aggrandizing -- than his classmates.
Almost alone among the group, Glazer has never written an extended autobiographical passage. (He claims that he has a bad memory.) Bell describes Howe and Norman Podhoretz, another mainstay of the New York Intellectuals, with the Yiddish word farbrent, or "burning"; Glazer, he says, was "always less zealous." After the screening, Bell and Glazer answered questions from the crowd. Bell, still glib and voluble at 79, answered virtually every question first; Glazer sat back, often simply confirming Bell's view.
With his great spray of white hair and his boxy, Kennedy-era tortoise-shell glasses, Glazer looks, at 75, like an over-age quiz kid. He doesn't have much of a public manner; he tends to speak in a monotonous mumble. His manner is gentle, self-deprecating, even a bit plodding.
Glazer's origins are virtually canonical. His parents were Polish immigrants who spoke Yiddish at home; his father operated a sewing machine, and the family lived in tenements in East Harlem and the East Bronx. "We were on our own in terms of making arrangements with the American world," Glazer recalls. The public schools and City College were his ticket to the mainstream, though at City he took the obligatory tour through radical politics. When I asked what line he followed in the factional struggles that raged across the City College cafeteria, Glazer responded, with a good deal of irony, "Luxembourgian, spontaneous, non-Leninist but revolutionary in some obscure way." Glazer never quite had the spirit of the barricades. "Even at City," Irving Kristol says, "he was never much of a radical.
World War II made it plain to the City College crowd that Fascism was a much greater threat to human happiness than capitalism. They had always been fierce anti-Stalinists, but the war placed America in a much more favorable light, and thus largely put an end to their radicalism. Glazer aligned himself with the new anti-Communist left. Writing in the journal Commentary, he criticized Senator Joseph McCarthy in remarkably mild terms. A strain of patriotic optimism ran through much of Glazer's work in the 50's. In 1954, he wrote that, despite a streak of "nostalgia" for Old World identities, "the complete identification of the overwhelming majority" of immigrants in American values "is assured."
In 1960, Glazer began writing a series of articles about New York's ethnic groups. These essays were eventually collected and published as "Beyond the Melting Pot." Moynihan contributed the chapter on the Irish, and most of the conclusion, and between Moynihan's moxie and Glazer's amiability, the two were listed as co-authors. (The book itself is now widely known, to Glazer's amusement, as "Moynihan and Glazer.") "Beyond the Melting Pot" was one of the most popular, and most influential, works of sociology of its time. Glazer and Moynihan showed that immigrants were not getting ahead by shedding their ethnic identities -- that they continued to behave in identifiably "ethnic" ways. But they were getting ahead, each through their own distinctive strategy. Glazer and Moynihan treated blacks and Puerto Ricans as two of New York's ethnic groups, assimilating more slowly than the Irish, the Italians and the Jews, but assimilating nonetheless. "New York will very likely in the end be an integrated area," they wrote.
This was, as it turned out, the high-water mark of Glazer's optimism; the Black Power movement was beginning to challenge the old civil rights consensus just as "Beyond the Melting Pot" appeared. In a 1965 essay, he described the typical pattern of ethnic progress and assimilation, and then wrote, "The militant Negro and his white allies passionately deny the relevance or even the truth of this history." Such critics insisted that racism was so integral to American culture that simply leveling the playing field through civil rights legislation would not be enough to give blacks a fair chance. The old demand for equality of opportunity was giving way to a new demand for equality of results -- an escalation that, Glazer felt, would lead to a new politics of resentment and competitive victimization.
Glazer passionately believed that the militants were wrong, that black prospects were improving, and that racism was not insuperable. But Glazer has always been just as interested in understanding the grounds of his adversaries' convictions as he has been in refuting those convictions. He began to realize, he says now, that the historical experience of black Americans made it impossible for them to completely absorb immigrant values. "In a way," Glazer says, "the attitude of blacks was so fully shaped by their experience of America that they could not shed it. What was available to them in terms of education and work experience that would satisfy an immigrant group would not have satisfied them. They didn't say, 'The Italians have moved up out of ditch-digging jobs; great, now we can get good ditch-digging jobs.' Their ambitions were greater than their formal capacities permitted."
During the Kennedy Administration, Glazer served with the precursor to the Housing and Urban Development department; later he worked as a consultant on the ill-fated Model Cities program. The failure of so many of the well-intentioned programs in the War on Poverty led Glazer to be deeply skeptical about sweeping schemes of reform directed by Washington -- a view he ultimately codified in an influential book, "The Limits of Social Policy." As Glazer saw it, "The breakdown of traditional modes of behavior is the chief cause of our social problems." Like Moynihan, he had come to believe that poverty had to be attacked at the level of the family; but he had less confidence than Moynihan had in government's ability to address those problems.
In 1969, Moynihan helped Glazer secure a teaching position at Harvard that was one of five created by the Ford Foundation to focus intellectual energy on the problems of the cities. But Glazer was moving further and further away from the new liberalism. In "Affirmative Discrimination," and in other essays from the time, Glazer insisted that not only would affirmative action do nothing to alleviate black poverty; it would also undermine the values that had made America's unique experiment in cultural pluralism possible. "The rising emphasis on group difference which government is called upon to correct might mean the destruction of any hope for the larger fraternity of all Americans," he wrote. Glazer insisted, as he long had, that values and behavior, not prejudicial treatment, accounted for most of the difference in outcomes among various groups.
And yet Glazer never quite fit in on the right. He refused to sign a well-known "Democrats for Nixon" ad in 1972. In fact, he voted for George McGovern, and for Jimmy Carter in 1980. And he was dovish on Israel, violating a neo-con article of faith. Glazer says that he was never asked to serve on the board of the conservative committees he had signed up for. "They felt," Glazer recalls with a hint of pride, "that I was not to be depended on -- I would see the other side, or some such thing."
In 1990, Glazer agreed to serve on a committee to revise the social studies curriculum for New York State. The group's job was to repair the damage done by the report of an earlier task force, which had denounced the Western bias of the schools and advocated a new curriculum that would focus on the achievements of marginalized peoples and on the sins of the nation's founders. The historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. also served on the committee. But Schlesinger despaired of reaching an acceptable conclusion, and ultimately responded by writing "The Disuniting of America," a passionate diatribe against the craze for multiculturalism. Glazer, characteristically, engaged with the multiculturalists, and ultimately accepted a draft with less strident language and a somewhat more balanced assessment of American history. "I couldn't find it my heart to turn against it," Glazer says.
Out of this experience came "We Are All Multiculturalists Now." In this book, which appeared last year, the note of ruefulness that had begun to creep into Glazer's work becomes almost weirdly dominant. Glazer writes, "I feel warmly attached to the old America that was acclaimed in school textbooks," and notes that he remains worried about "the fixing of lines of division on ethnic and racial bases." But he concludes that, for better or for worse, his side has lost. Among his own students, white as well as nonwhite, Glazer writes, "assimilation" has become a dirty word. And multiculturalism, with its emphasis on group identity and on building self-esteem through learning about the achievements of one's own group, has become the norm in public schools.
But "We Are All Multiculturalists Now" only appears to be about ethnicity. It is really about race. Glazer observes that the overwhelming majority of the immigrants in whose name multiculturalism is promoted are indifferent or even hostile to its tenets. Multiculturalism, he writes, is largely a black agenda; and behind Glazer's book-length shrug of the shoulders is the sense that the black feelings of exclusion he first addressed 30 years earlier had now become fixed and irremediable. "There's a tremendous alienation in this group from the notion of school, from the notion of whites, from the notion of whites telling them things," Glazer says. "They do not want to hear about things different from them that they cannot connect to; they want to hear about their lives."
Glazer sounds as if he is making a painstaking effort to fathom something that bewilders him. But it's deeply unsettling to hear the great pluralist speaking the kind of language normally associated with the outer fringes of identity politics. The truth is, Glazer hasn't had much direct contact with black children or parents.
By contrast, the sociologist Alan Wolfe interviewed dozens of black middle-class parents for his book, "One Nation, After All," and found that most favored a "five minutes on everyone" form of multiculturalism, rather than the extreme ethnocentrism that Glazer sees as the new black norm. Wolfe says that Glazer "may have confused what certain elements of the elite think with what most African-Americans think."
Wolfe describes Glazer as "a role model" for an engaged academic like himself, and speaks of him almost with reverence; and yet he says that he found "We Are All Multiculturalists Now" disturbing and "defeatist." Wolfe wonders if Glazer has been disabled by his power of sympathy. "The greatest way you can respect any group," he says, "is to argue with them and to point out when you think they're wrong." Farbrent, too, has its claims.
"We Are All Multiculturalists Now" outraged conservatives. In a review in The Weekly Standard, Dinesh D'Souza accused Glazer of "cowardice," of surrendering his principles in order to get along at Cambridge cocktail parties. But it's figures like Wolfe, who think of themselves as occupying "the vital center," embattled from the left as well as the right, who were the most deeply pained and mystified by the book. Glazer's steadfast faith in the assimilating powers of American culture had, after all, helped define that center. Jim Sleeper, author of "Liberal Racism," was appalled by Glazer's change of heart. As he puts it: "Nat is succumbing to an unspoken fatalism about black capacities and prospects. Even more egregious, it's a complete faintheartedness about a truly liberal political agenda." Diane Ravitch, a historian of education, says, "One of the things that engaged intellectuals like Nat have done has been arguing to push the world in a certain direction." Accepting a curriculum that turns history into therapy, she says, is like accepting high rates of teen pregnancy or smoking.
Glazer rejects the charge of defeatism, but behind his turnabout lies a new view not only of black aspirations but of black prospects. Glazer takes seriously the statistical evidence showing that black economic progress began to stall in the mid-70's, and has not substantially resumed. He sees this as painful proof that the immigrant model is not working. Moreover, he traces this failure, at least in part, to the unwillingness of whites to permit blacks to assimilate. Most of the people who make this argument -- people like Andrew Hacker, the author of "Two Nations" -- call for a wholesale redistribution of power and resources to overcome racial inequities. Glazer, however, has not changed his view that government activism on behalf of the poor is largely self-defeating. He is thus in the awkward position of accepting the left's diagnosis of black prospects while denying the efficacy of its proposed cure.
It is this quandary that accounts for the tone of resignation and discomfort that runs through some of Glazer's recent work. He has not changed his view that affirmative action constitutes a form of discrimination, and he says that "a lot of the arguments for affirmative action are weak and illusory." He does not see affirmative action as a solution to the gap in educational attainment; it is, like multiculturalism, a concession -- a stopgap -- that a fair-minded and sympathetic person, in the absence of anything better, ought to be willing to make. It is hard even to recognize, from this distant outpost, the optimism that once defined Glazer's politics.
And yet glazer is not a gloomy character. He is amused by the new friends he has been collecting as an icon of repentant neo-conservatism. He has recently been invited to address "Diversity Day" events at college campuses, where he gives cautionary talks about the need to avoid intolerance. At the moment, he seems to be experiencing the giddy sense of disorientation that comes of not quite knowing where you're headed.
"You begin to break with orthodoxy, and then you see other challenges to it," Glazer said to me. "They don't seem so outlandish or threatening as they once did." Raising an eyebrow at the terrifying strictures of yore, he continued: "It reminds me of the old Leninist line, 'Who says A, must say B.' From saying B, you'll go on to C, D and you'll end up at Z. There's no stopping

SECTION: Section 7; Page 31; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1595 words

HEADLINE: BOOKEND; Guess Who's on the Backlist

BYLINE: By Richard Cohen; Richard Cohen is the managing director of Richard Cohen Books.

 BODY:
The received wisdom in the publishing community is that backlist -- books published some time ago but that keep on selling -- is the bread and butter on which a publishing house thrives. Ask Farrar, Straus & Giroux, with Isaac Singer, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn and John McPhee, or Penguin, whose backlist regularly contributes more than 60 percent of its North American sales.
However, there can be surprises. In 1985, when I took over as trade publishing director of Hutchinson, an English publishing house, I started to research the 98 years of Hutchinson's history and discovered that (excepting best sellers by Kingsley Amis, Anthony Burgess, Ruth Rendell and Frederick Forsyth) Hutchinson had only five books over four years old that still had reasonable sales. One was a business book, "Getting to Yes," first published in 1981. Three of the others were collections of religious light verse by an American, Helen Steiner Rice. The remaining title was "Mein Kampf," Hitler's apologia, composed in prison in 1924. Its original title was "A Four-and-a-Half-Year Struggle Against Lies, Stupidity and Cowardice," but Hitler's publisher, Max Amann of Franz Eher Verlag, who had been Hitler's company commander during World War I, persuaded him to use the shorter version. By the time of Hitler's death, after which publication of the book was banned, more than eight million copies had been sold in Germany. 
 Hitler had granted his German publishers world rights, and as Eher Verlag regularly used the literary agency of Curtis Brown to handle its sales in Britain, Curtis Brown took over the German Chancellor's book. As the agency says now, "He was a respectable head of state, democratically elected." In America, Eher Verlag decided to handle the rights themselves, and sold the book to Houghton Mifflin. The small firm of Hurst & Blackett, later to be subsumed into Hutchinson, bought the British rights, paying just 350. In October 1933, the book was published in an abridged version in both the United States and Britain, with a translation heavily censored by the German Embassy in London. The German version had 781 pages, the English-language edition 297. Even so, the book's main message was clear. The reviewer in The New York Times noted, "It is with sadness, tinged with fear for the world's future, that we read Hitler's hymn of hate."
In January 1939 Hutchinson published a translation of the full text. Three years later the Americans commissioned their own version, from the highly respected translator Ralph Manheim. None of this was sanctioned by Berlin. The American and British editions went ahead throughout the 1930's without any contract with the author -- almost as if war had already been declared.
After the war there was a lull. The book was seen as largely unreadable, and there was little interest in it even as a historical document. Then, toward the end of the 1950's, another literary effort by Hitler, written in the late 20's, was discovered and published as "Hitler's Secret Book." It created considerable controversy, and what Hitler had written before coming to power suddenly became a subject of interest.
By this time Hutchinson was run by the eccentric Robert Lusty, who set about resurrecting "Mein Kampf" from the backlist. The whole project took time, with various plans for either a new abridged version or a heavily annotated complete text. By the mid-60's questions about the book were being raised in the House of Commons, and sections of the British Jewish community were claiming that "Mein Kampf" would be a focus for anti-Semitism. Donald Cameron Watt, the political historian who had been commissioned by Lusty to write a new introduction, wrote an article in The Spectator accusing Hutchinson of loss of nerve. Eventually the complete text was republished, in 1969, and it has been in print in Britain ever since. Each new edition has prompted a letter of complaint from the German Government.
The questions we faced at Hutchinson were, what were a publisher's responsibilities when confronted with such a book, and should we do anything to try to increase sales? Our sales manager acknowledged it was not like selling any other work on the list but asked if we could use a slightly more attractive cover than the solemn two-color jacket the book then had, and it was arranged that at the same time we should update the blurb. The editor responsible checked the revised material with the company's new managing director, who complained that it had to be changed. The wording contained the phrase "this evil book." That wouldn't do. "We can't say a book is evil if we ourselves are publishing it," the managing director argued. The editor demurred, not least because the reprint was overdue and changes had to be kept to a minimum. By the time the final version was published, the phrase had been changed anagrammatically to "this vile book" -- a triumph of publishing economics.
"Mein Kampf" still sells its regular 3,000 copies a year in Britain. All royalties are channeled through the Curtis Brown agency, which does not take a commission but passes the money on to a suitable charity. When the agency first tried to find a recipient for the money, the West German Government refused it, and so did all Jewish charities based in Germany, regarding the royalties as tainted. Who now receives the money? Curtis Brown declines to say. As the agency explains, "If the name of the charity who receives the money were made public, they'd immediately have to announce they could no longer take it."
In America, the book has been continuously in print with Houghton Mifflin since its original publication. Until the United States entered the war, royalties were sent directly to Eher Verlag; then, under the Trading With the Enemy Act, they were paid to the State Department. In 1979 Houghton Mifflin was allowed to stop paying any royalties. By then the United States Government had received over $90,000.
In January Houghton Mifflin will publish a new edition -- the Manheim translation, but with a fresh introduction by the historian John Lukacs. Houghton Mifflin's present publisher is Wendy Strothman, who says: "It's difficult to imagine being in the position of the editors who originally decided to release a book that they profoundly disagreed with. But I admire their prescience. At that time, without the diversity of media we possess today, the book served a function that could be carried in part by other means of communication now. I'd also argue that nowadays it is one of the most powerful rebuttals we can deliver to Holocaust revisionists."
Houghton Mifflin is not publishing the book purely for academic study, but for the general reader. Shouldn't the book be published in a special way -- with the literary equivalent of a public health warning? Here Strothman is adamant: "I defer to our own First Amendment. Ideas are sometimes messy, but it's far more dangerous to suppress them in fear of their falling into the wrong hands than to reveal them for what they are."
Meanwhile, the publishing world itself is changing. In Britain, Hutchinson has long since been purchased by Random House. But dog eats dog, not always aware of what has gone to make up its meal. Random House is in the process of being purchased by the vast German conglomerate of Bertelsmann. Thus Hitler's racist tract, unavailable in German bookstores, will shortly be published throughout Britain and the Commonwealth by a German company.
THE head of Bertelsmann's North American trade book operations, Peter Olson, was surprised to learn that Bertelsmann was now the publisher of "Mein Kampf." "It certainly wasn't the motivation for buying the company," he said with a laugh. "I don't imagine anyone's going to be delighted to hear about it," he added. "I admit I have to suppress a twinge of uncomfortableness, but there's not going to be a call by me, or any of my German colleagues, telling Hutchinson they shouldn't publish it. There's not going to be any central interference on a book because of political concerns. If Hutchinson decides they don't want to publish it, that's O.K. by me. If the opposite, that's O.K. too. It's an interesting question whether Bertelsmann would choose to publish 'Mein Kampf.' Probably not."
While Bertelsmann remains secure in its policy of editorial noninterference, the fate of "Mein Kampf" is far from an academic matter in the world at large. Earlier this year, the book was banned in Portugal, the publishing house Hugin Editora having reached an agreement with the German Embassy for all copies of "Mein Kampf" to be recalled and pulped. The Federal State of Bavaria, which controls all rights to the book except the English-language editions, has also caused it to be banned in Sweden, Norway, Latvia, Switzerland and Hungary. In Israel there had never been an edition available until 1995, when Academon, an imprint of the Hebrew University, issued a limited edition. The publisher was sharply criticized, and the book is now out of print. For the time being, in Britain at least, Bertelsmann remains Hitler's publisher. Which leads to a further irony. Last year Random House purchased from Reed Elsevier the Heinemann general list. Among the backlist authors is Winston Churchill; so Churchill and Hitler may shortly nestle next to each other on Bertelsmann's backlist -- as they do on Houghton Mifflin's. "Mein Kampf" is now published by Hutchinson's sister imprint, Pimlico. There is a new blurb on the back cover -- with "this evil book" reinstated.

HEADLINE: Clinton Gamesmanship

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Leonard Garment ("Perhaps Washington Needs a Shot Clock," Op-Ed, June 23) overlooks the basic reasons that the spectators are not loudly booing the Clinton "clock-freeze" on Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor. They like the way Mr. Clinton has played the rest of the game -- the economy is healthy and the country is not at war. 
 More important, they regard the Lewinsky business as nit-picking nonsense not worthy of impeachment consideration, and the Whitewater mess as a shoddy real estate deal that happened long before Bill Clinton entered the White House. Essentially, the public perception is that Mr. Starr is not investigating the type of high crimes committed in the White House by Richard M. Nixon.
Mr. Garment views the political-cynicism issue from the perspective of the team that is losing the game. Most other people believe that Mr. Starr is playing political "gotcha" rather than exercising reasoned discretion about presumed crimes worthy of prosecution against a President.
 
NATHANIEL J. PARISH
New York, June 23, 1998

HEADLINE: Investment Site Co-Founder Is at Home on the Internet

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
On a white board in the newsroom of TheStreet.com, an investment news service published on the World Wide Web, employees keep a running list titled the "self-importance meter." The entrants vary, but, inevitably, somewhere in the ranking is the name James J. Cramer.
Mr. Cramer happens to be the service's co-founder, as well as one of its marquee columnists. He writes three bombastic missives daily, dispatched via E-mail to 18,000 subscribers, under the rubric "Wrong!" 
 His reach extends well beyond the computer terminal and this has made Mr. Cramer a kind of Zelig of the information age, cutting across all media and raising the issue of his own involvement in the market as the manager of a $350 million private investment firm. Mr. Cramer, 43, appears as a commentator on "Good Morning America" on ABC, as a guest co-host on CNBC and in print with regular columns in GQ and The New York Observer; he also has alliances with on-line ventures including America Online and Yahoo.
It is the Internet, he said, that provides immediacy to match his frenetic pace, and That of the financial markets he covers. "I've been waiting for this medium to be built all my life," he said.
From the offices of his investment fund on Wall Street, he monitors the markets from a bank of computer terminals that proffer data and news, zipping off E-mail between trades in an environment which makes a typical newsroom appear sleepy.
"I'm not capable of thinking of anything in terms other than stocks," he said. He described a meeting with an executive at Disney, which owns ABC and whose Web site TheStreet.com supplies with financial news; he also recently did a television pilot for the company. "All I could think about was, "Disney's stock is down today," he recalled.
Mr. Cramer is betting on the notion that the rapid ups and downs of the stock market make for compelling Internet fare, matching the rapid-fire pace of the new medium. Mr. Cramer is hoping that the growing sector of home investors, as well as the financial professionals, who comprise 60 percent of the customers who pay $9.95 a month for his wisdom, will translate into a publishing success.
Those who follow the world of on-line business news said it would be a difficult market to win.
"You've got a huge number of competitors and some of them are extremely well funded, everything from The Wall Street Journal Online, to brokerages that are looking at ways of putting content on line," said Mike Gazala, an analyst with Forrester Research in Boston. He expressed doubt that TheStreet.com, with a staff of 30 and little brand recognition, could amass a large enough audience to succeed.
"Beyond Jim Cramer, I don't think there's much there," Mr. Gazala said. "If you took away Jim Cramer, you wouldn't have too many people visiting that 'street.' "
Clearly, Mr. Cramer remains the allure. Recently, he and his co-founder, Martin Peretz, the owner and editor in chief of The New Republic, received $10 million in venture capital financing from a syndicate led by the investment firms Flatiron Partners, Chase Capital Partners and Softbank Technology Ventures, who are now minority stakeholders in the business.
"This is a very important trend," Jerry Colonna, co-founder of Flatiron Partners, said of the quest for investment information on line. He said Mr. Cramer's cantankerous, shoot-from-the-hip style of presentation was a big reason for the investment.
Dave Kansas, editor of TheStreet.com, conceded that Mr. Cramer's involvement as manager of an investment firm presents an editorial challenge. Some prospective employees have been concerned, he conceded, that Mr. Cramer's dual life as a money manager and journalist sullies the credibility of the financial news service.
"We've had people we've tried to hire who said they're not comfortable with the perception," Mr. Kansas said.
When he first conceived of TheStreet.com, Mr. Cramer said, he approached the Securities and Exchange Commission to ask advice on how to set up the business to avoid conflict.
The issue of conflicts of interest is not a new one for Mr. Cramer. In 1995, while a contributor to Smart Money magazine, Mr. Cramer was widely criticized for an article that he wrote recommending the stocks of several small companies in which he owned large stakes. The article did not make note of those holdings. As a result of the incident, Smart Money changed its policies, restricting contributors from writing about stocks in which they own large positions or which are thinly traded and adding disclosures about the stock holdings of contributors.
At TheStreet.com, rules were instituted under which Mr. Cramer would not have any editorial control beyond his column. All his columns, writings and television appearances are accompanied by disclaimers of some kind.
That does not mean he skirts controversy, however. In January 1997, Mr. Cramer, through his fund, bought up 1.1 million shares of Dow Jones stock, and was one of three big stockholders using their investment to push the company to sell Telerate, its financial information business. He sold off most of his shares five months later when it became clear the sale would not happen. (Mr. Cramer said he took great pleasure in the fact that Dow Jones ultimately did sell Telerate earlier this year.)
For Mr. Kansas, the scrutiny of the medium in which he publishes is a bigger issue than critics of Mr. Cramer's possible conflicts. "To me, " he said, "the mainstream medium likes to harp on the potentially scary issues relating to the Internet. We have to work very hard to rise above that."

HEADLINE: Steady Growth Of Revenue Is Energizing Newspapers

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The newspaper industry, the hypochondriac of the information age, is as healthy as it has been in a decade.
The migraine headaches brought on in the mid-1990's when the price of the industry's basic raw material, paper, jumped by 30 percent for two consecutive years, are but a memory. High-margin classified advertising is surging, bringing with it a revenue rush that is energizing the entire industry. 
 Perhaps most important, the early returns indicate that 1998 will be the first year since 1986 that the industry's ever-more-anemic circulation figures will go up, not down.
And though readers have declining trust in the accuracy of newspaper articles, investors for most of the last 18 months have shown increasing faith in newspaper company stocks -- at least until mid-April, when steady but unremarkable earnings growth made some analysts nervous about the sustainability of industry profits.
So newspaper publishers might be pardoned for the pleasure they take in the process. "Newspapers always come back," said John Carroll, the editor of The Baltimore Sun, which is owned by Times Mirror. "And newspapers do make a lot of money."
And though it is hard to find a happy hypochondriac, the old nervousness is being replaced in city after city with a certain cockiness. Some newspaper partisans, long bruised, now think they can give as good as they get.
Do William H. Gates and Microsoft want to devour the classified advertising business, luring automobile ads into their on-line Carpoint service? Let them try. Last year, newspaper companies including Knight Ridder, Times Mirror, the Tribune Company and the Washington Post Company pooled their resources to back the Chicago-based Web enterprise Classified Ventures L.L.C.
Do direct mailers want to pull more supermarkets and drugstores into their orbit? Maybe newspapers, including The Arizona Republic, seek to go direct mail one better. The Republic, owned by Central Newspapers Inc., is preparing a series of experiments in delivering advertisements to subscribers' doorsteps just as direct mailers do.
Still, for all the brave talk, the news industry cannot avoid the sobering reminders of where it stands among news consumers. About 80 percent of those surveyed in April by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, the Washington-based research organization, said they regularly watched television news, down from 81 percent in 1996. How many read newspapers? About 68 percent, down from 71 percent in 1996.
When newspaper readers were taken alone, there was a more telling gap. Younger readers in this generation have much less interest in newspapers than their counterparts in the 1960's. In 1965, a Gallup poll indicated that in the 21-to-35 age group, 67 percent of those surveyed had read a daily newspaper the day before. In 1990, a similar survey by Pew showed that number had dwindled to 39 percent. This spring, it was 31 percent. Even in the over-50 group, readership figures are down to 63 percent, from about 74 percent in 1990.
And some large advertising agencies still find that for national ads, newspapers are a cumbersome and expensive vehicle. Although newspaper revenues from national advertisers like airlines and Hollywood studios are up over the decade, "for most national advertisers, their first choice is television -- and that's getting more so," said Stacey Lippman, the media director at the New York-based advertising agency TBWA Chiat/Day, which is owned by the Omnicom Group.
The newspaper industry's standard response is that its readers are a relatively upscale demographic group compared with radio or television audiences. The Pew survey bears this out: 60 percent of those surveyed with family incomes of $75,000 annually read newspapers; 58 percent watched television news. College graduates were also slightly more likely to get their news from newspapers.
Yet while those demographics are likely to whet advertisers' appetites, editors like Gregory E. Favre of The Sacramento Bee, one of the original papers owned by the growing McClatchy Newspapers Inc., are nervous about making too many journalistic decisions based on such data.
The economic downturn of the early 1990's coincided with buyouts among retailers -- which then had no excess cash for advertising -- and competition from companies selling newspaper inserts to supermarkets and other local advertisers. The bottom line: at least 10 percent of display advertising revenues were lost; they have not returned.
Just when things might have started to move back up, newsprint prices rose by almost 70 percent, peaking in 1995 and 1996, and forcing another round of belt-tightening and price increases at newspapers. And since 1995, the various viruses that have killed dozens of evening papers picked off The Baltimore Evening Sun, The Norfolk Ledger-Star, The Rochester Times-Union and The Phoenix Gazette.
But if 1987 and 1988 were the golden years for the industry, 1997 was at least gold-plated. Total revenues, according to the figures compiled by the Newspaper Association of America, were $51.4 billion -- $41.3 billion (up 11.3 percent over 1996) from advertising, and $10.1 billion (up about 1 percent) from circulation. The overall revenue improvement is less impressive when inflation is taken into account. In real dollars, 1997 circulation revenues lagged more than 15 percent behind their 1987 high. Last year advertising revenues, led by retail display advertising and classifieds, inched back near 1987 levels.
Perhaps most important, psychologically: readers have stopped deserting. The March report from the Audit Bureau of Circulations showed widespread, though marginal, gains. The Atlanta Constitution, owned by Cox Newspapers, and The Minneapolis Star & Tribune, recently bought by McClatchy Newspapers, each picked up more than 4 percent.
Just 3 of the the top 25 circulation leaders showed declines of more than 1 percent: The Washington Post, The Chicago Tribune and The Miami Herald.
By comparison, in the years from 1994 through 1996, when there were widespread price increases, overall newspaper circulation declined at an annual rate of 2 percent or more.
"Promotional spending is back," said John Murray, the newspaper association's vice president for circulation and marketing. "Your pricing is slowed so you don't have the immediate losses you'd get with a price increase. Equally important, newspapers have put much more of a focus on zoning for local news and on niche coverage -- sections on health or personal finance."
Certainly in cities like Sacramento and Phoenix, where newsrooms have been downsized over the decade, the focus is local. "I believe our major franchise is local news," said Mr. Favre, the editor of The Sacramento Bee. "We spend more of our resources on that than anything else."
Despite the industry's generally good news, a paramount concern is classified advertising. "Classifieds definitely are driving the revenue increases that we're seeing," said David G. Alley, The Republic's advertising director. And what is driving classified advertising, he said, is the tight job recruitment market.
Yet classifieds are peculiarly vulnerable to the Internet's capacity to permit one-to-one communications across great distances.
Some competitors have joined forces with newspapers. The National Association of Realtors created realtor.com, a Web site to hawk its own wares in 1996; now The San Diego Union-Tribune and USA Today, as well as NBC and America Online are its partners. Classified Ventures runs the sites apartments.com and cars.com, which feature ads from 135 daily newspapers. Realfind.com, run by the newspaper association, has links to more than 300 newspaper real estate sections.
But executives like Angus H. Twombly, the vice president for marketing and strategic planning at The Portland Press-Herald in Portland, Me., remain cautious. "I don't think it's time to be cocky," Mr. Twombly said. "We are having to adapt more in this decade than in either of the two decades before. Having this flood of classified advertising is giving us a little flexibility and a little time, but isn't buying us peace of mind."
