HEADLINE: We, the People Of the Internet;
Cybercitizens Debate How to Form On-Line Union, Perfect or Otherwise

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
These are the times that try a cyberpatriot's soul.
Consider Jon Postel, who has served as the unflaggingly serene citizen-sentry of the Internet's address system since he began keeping track of it on a piece of notebook paper in 1969. But Mr. Postel is weary these days, and a little bit grumpy -- and not because the Internet has doubled in size yet again in the last year. 
 It is because Mr. Postel, a University of Southern California researcher, has recently been anointed a founding father of the network's nascent political structure -- a move toward Internet "self-governance" that is being propelled by various governmental, commercial and social forces.
For nearly three decades, Mr. Postel's work has been supported by a combination of contracts from the Federal Government and consensus by the Internet's ad hoc technical community. But now, as a de facto delegate to what is shaping up as a constitutional convention in cyberspace, Mr. Postel suddenly finds himself accused of seizing illegitimate power, threatened with lawsuits and bombarded in E-mail wars.
His critics include Jim Dixon, president of Euro Internet Service Providers Association, a trade group of 600 Internet companies in Europe. "You have a small group of people asking that they be given a large amount of power simply because they've been there for a long time," complains Mr. Dixon, noting that Europe wants more say in how the Internet will be run.
His concerns are shared by many Internet industry leaders outside the United States, who have made their feelings known to Mr. Postel and the United States Government via E-mail.
Mr. Postel cannot help but feel besieged. "I'd rather be doing the technical stuff," he said recently with a sigh. "But there are so many questions that need to get answered. How do we form a representative board? How do we make it international? How do we find enough agreement to move forward?"
Far from being Mr. Postel's private agony, these are among the questions that are bound to be debated at a meeting near Washington this week, at another in Geneva later in July and at various other caucuses, conferences and on-line sessions this summer. The partisans of the Net are working toward a Sept. 30 deadline for the United States Government to hand over control of a key portion of the Internet to an as-yet-unformed nonprofit international group.
Even for many Internet users who do not care much about the specific job at hand -- determining who gets to register whom for which types of Internet addresses -- the need to create a governing system for that task has been given a sense of urgency and common cause to representatives from the Government and industry, as well as the libertarian technologists who have historically supervised the Internet. Though they may have competing goals, all share a belief in free-flowing communication and in the value of electronic commerce, which the Department of Commerce recently reported was growing twice as fast as the rest of the economy.
While no one is sure how it should work, the idea is that a uniquely participatory medium like the Internet -- one that transcends national borders and whose fast-evolving technology can be shaped to fit social policy -- ought to be able to come up with its own semiofficial political structure. Regulation by more traditional means, the thinking goes, would stifle electronic commerce and the free flow of ideas.
The stakes are sufficiently high to elicit a recent emotional appeal from David Farber, a professor of computer science at the University of Pennsylvania, who is a widely respected E-mail pamphleteer with nearly 25,000 subscribers.
"If we blow it, the result will be governance by Governments with all the negatives that holds for the future evolution of the net," Professor Farber recently wrote to his E-mail constituents. "What do we do. We could act grown up!! We could coordinate the meetings and make it appear like we are organized. I wonder if the net establishment is indeed willing to be grown up, or will they fight till there is nothing left."
His recent missive was a cry from the heart. "This is a defining moment," Professor Farber said in an interview. "If we can't pull it together on something like this, governments are going to get together and decide this is too important to their economic health to leave in the hands of chaos. They'll start writing treaties, and we'll end up with a very slow mechanism."
Mr. Farber is himself an Internet founding father. He was Mr. Postel's thesis adviser in 1969 and assigned his student the task of cataloguing Internet addresses. That academic exercise eventually became a full-time job as the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority, financed by the Department of Defense. While Network Solutions Inc., a Reston, Va., company, has had an exclusive Government contract to register addresses under the most popular domains -- the suffixes on Internet addresses like ".com," ".net" and ".org" -- Mr. Postel has been responsible for insuring that each address corresponds to a unique string of digits that all of the Internet's computers can recognize.
And now Mr. Postel finds himself being swept toward that Sept. 30 deadline -- the date the Clinton Administration recently set for handing over control of the distribution of Internet addresses to whatever international nonprofit group has formed by then. The Administration's report on the matter earlier this month prompted the announcement of at least two meetings by competing factions, with others rumored to be in the works. One, to take place in Reston, Va., begins on Wednesday. The other, in Geneva, will start July 21.
With the Administration and industry seeming to have more faith in technology and market forces to regulate cyberspace than legislation, the effort to supervise Internet addresses has become the first test of the self-governance movement.
The parties with cross-cutting interests include large trademark holders, who want to limit the number of domains -- ".com," ".net" and ".org" -- to reduce the opportunities for others to co-opt their brand names. It is one thing for Coca-Cola (www.coke.com) to make sure no one is trying to do business as www.coke.org. It might be far harder to police dozens of domains, to ferret out coke.web or coke.store, for example. But small businesses and individuals would like to see more domains created to increase the odds of obtaining their own preferred addresses. Meanwhile, there are many entrepreneurs intent on making a profit out of registering domain names -- and perhaps just as many domain democrats who would rather see registration be a strictly nonprofit enterprise.
To some extent, the struggle is also between the old-guard technical wizards like Mr. Postel and the new commercial interests that have begun to assert themselves as the Internet expands. Tamar Frankel, a law professor at Boston University who has taken a leading role in organizing this week's conference in Reston, has been accused by some Internet traditionalists of being an interloper with no credentials -- or worse, a promoter for Network Solutions Inc., a unit of the Science Applications International Corporation, which assigns the domain names that Mr. Postel helps catalogue.
To such criticism, Ms. Frankel replies: "The issues now before the Internet are not technical. They are political, they are structural, they are organizational. What I find is that people who are tremendously sophisticated in the technical workings of the Internet are not necessarily knowledgeable in how to create an organization -- especially one that has no clear model."
But a growing number of academics, industry and Government officials and so-called netizens who are not entirely convinced that a new electronic order will emerge on its own have begun to seek a clear structure for the process. Today, for example, Martin Bangemann, the European Union Commissioner for Industry, is convening a conference in Brussels for industry representatives to discuss his proposal for an international charter to coordinate Internet regulation of electronic commerce. Next month, the faculty of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard will discuss the subject.
"The Internet overlaps with geographical governments, but it also floats above them," Joseph Nye, dean of the Kennedy School, said. "So trying to work out governance is quite difficult, and no analogy quite fits."
Ira Magaziner, a senior White House policy adviser, was the chief architect of the recently issued hands-off policy on domain names. "What we believe is the ideal kind of coordinating structure of the Internet is not to have an intergovernmental organization, but to have a number of private nonprofit international groups that have specific charters," Mr. Magaziner said.
But so far private industry has made little progress in self-regulation. Some critics say that even an effective industry effort would not necessarily safeguard the principles of democracy. "My fear is that there won't be any accountability," said Andrew L. Shapiro, a fellow at the Center for Internet and Society at Harvard. "Your common Internet user doesn't know diddly about Internet domain name registration, and those people need to be represented. It runs the risk of being intensely skewed toward private, for-profit interests."
But some proponents of self-governance argue that the participatory nature of the Internet will allow a bottom-up approach to decision-making that has little precedent in the world of parliaments and industrialists. David R. Johnson, director of the Internet Policy Project at the Aspen Institute in Washington, points to Mr. Farber's call for peace as an example of what he calls the Internet's tendency toward natural "self-ordering." After Mr. Farber sent out his appeal he received vows of cooperation from many sides. There is talk of a series of meetings around the world, to which various factions would send delegates.
"See, one of our senior moral leaders calls on the Net to grow up and there's already progress in that direction," said Mr. Johnson, a lawyer who was influential in drafting the Government's domain-name policy.
Drawing on recent research at the Santa Fe Institute and elsewhere that holds that any complex system, whether technological or biological, will spontaneously order itself, Mr. Johnson predicts that the Internet will produce its own social order -- one that, because it arises from the network itself, will have its own legitimacy. Such an order would not rely on the delegation of state power to representatives, but rather on contractual agreements between Internet users who would then be responsible for their own decisions.
"Some people mean by self-regulation a small number of industry players adopting voluntarily or even under duress some codes that match what the Government could legislate," Mr. Johnson said. "What I think the Net holds out as a possibility is a very different mechanism."

HEADLINE: Catherine Kennedy, 51, Dies; Ran Home for AIDS Patients

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
Catherine Kennedy, who after a long struggle established one of the nation's first nursing centers for AIDS patients, died on Tuesday at her home in New Haven. She was 51.
The cause of death was pancreatic cancer, family members said. 
 Not long after moving to New Haven with her family in 1983, Mrs. Kennedy became aware of the lack of nursing centers and services for people with AIDS. Many were turned away by nursing homes. Some were being kept, at enormous expense, at hospitals essentially unequipped to treat them. Others were homeless.
She resolved to open a nursing center for AIDS patients but constantly encountered obstacles. She waged an eight-year struggle against financial and political obstacles to establish the home. Her experiences, which became a case study for the Harvard Business School, exemplified how someone involved in social entrepreneurship could overcome great odds.
After two years of research and attempts to raise money, she received a $60,000 grant from the Merck Family Fund. When she sought help from the State Legislature, she encountered indifference and fear of AIDS among the public, as well as hostility from legislators more interested in cutting health-care funds than increasing them.
But she gained the help of Lucie McKinney, the widow of Representative Stewart McKinney, who had died of AIDS, to plead her case with Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
The Governor was persuaded and, with others, gained passage of a bill to provide special funding for her project that included daily patient costs that were substantially less than full hospitalization and $3 million to renovate an old factory in New Haven.
In 1995, the home opened in the reconverted factory as Leeway Inc.; Mrs. Kennedy ran it until last fall, when she was forced to resign because of her illness. In that time about 150 patients have been treated.
Catherine Urwin Kennedy was born on Feb. 12, 1947 in Wallsend, England. She received a bachelor of arts in economics and a master's in economic history from the University of East Anglia in England, where she later taught. She also earned a master's degree at Yale's school of management.
She married Paul Kennedy, the author and Yale historian, in 1967. Besides her husband, she is survived by three sons, James and Matthew, of New Haven, and John, of New York, and two brothers and two sisters, all of England.
It was through her affiliation withYale that she was able to apply for her patients' participation in the university's experimental research in AIDS medication and treatment.
Mrs. Kennedy's original goal was to build a home to shelter and care for dying patients. But today, Leeway staff members said, nearly half of the patients can be sent home with reasonable chances of survival. Among them was Fred Tyson, who is going back to work as a casting director in Hollywood.
"She got us involved," he said of Catherine Kennedy. "And I truly believe I would not be alive if it weren't for her."

HEADLINE: True Delbert Morse, 102, an Eisenhower Official

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
True Delbert Morse, a former Agriculture Department Under Secretary and an architect of agricultural price support policy, died on June 3 at a retirement home in Sun City, Ariz. He was 102 years old.
He served in the Agriculture Department during the Eisenhower Administration and was also president then of the Commodity Credit Corporation, the multibillion-dollar agricultural price support program. 
 Mr. Morse was born into a farm family near Carthage, Mo., in 1896. He started a 400-acre dairy farm to support himself at the College of Agriculture at the University of Missouri, where he graduated in 1924. Upon graduation, he joined Doane Agricultural Service in St. Louis, which provided farm appraisals, agricultural research and also had an editorial service that produced feature articles for farm publications. Mr. Morse became president of Doane in 1943, editor of The Doane Agricultural Digest and later the company's chairman.
During Mr. Morse's tenure at Doane, he also performed a study for an Arizona governor's committee that resulted in the allocation of Colorado River water to Arizona and led to the Central Arizona Project, a $3 billion venture that was intended to bring Colorado River water to Phoenix, Tucson and Arizona cotton farmers.
Originally a Democrat, Mr. Morse switched his party affiliation and became head of the National Republican Farm Committee for Dewey in 1948 and, in 1952, contributed to the Republican platform's farm plank. At that time, he became acquainted with Ezra Taft Benson, the Eisenhower choice for Agriculture Secretary, who picked Mr. Morse as his Under Secretary.
In 1953, he was confirmed as Under Secretary as well as head of the Commodity Credit Corporation, which provides loans to support farm prices. In that capacity, he was the chief United States delegate in negotiating international commodity treaties for wheat and sugar. He opposed government regulation of agricultural properties in the years after World War II, and warned about the dangers of inflation and speculation in farmland from the abnormal agricultural profits of that era.
Mr. Morse left Government service in 1961.
Mr. Morse's wife, Mary Hopkins, died in 1983, and his son, James, died in 1993. He is survived by three grandsons, and six great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Rubin Could Find China The Easiest Part of His Trip

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 28

 BODY:
Visiting China may pose thorny political issues for President Clinton. But for Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who peeled off from the White House delegation today to visit Asian countries with troubled economies, China could turn out to be the smoothest part of his trip.
Arriving here this evening Mr. Rubin had to face a fresh volley of the continuing criticism of the United States from Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who accused the American Government of plotting with Wall Street to take over Asian economies. 
 "They accuse us of practicing cronyism," Dr. Mahathir said on Saturday in a speech at a political gathering here. "The cooperation between the U.S. Government and Wall Street is cronyism."
Dr. Mahathir, a relentless critic of the West, drew world attention in October, when he delivered a denunciation of George Soros and the fraternity of global financiers. He blames the financial crisis on currency traders, who, he says, played havoc with the region's currencies. And he says the United States Government is standing by while Wall Street buys Asian companies at fire-sale prices.
For Mr. Rubin, a Wall Street executive before moving to Washington, such charges are a painful reminder that the Asian financial crisis is generating intense frustration among some leaders in the region. The message that Mr. Rubin is expected to deliver on Monday in a meeting with Dr. Mahathir is quite unlikely to soothe his feelings.
"The international community has a great deal of work to do," Mr. Rubin said in a briefing on his flight from Beijing to Kuala Lumpur. "These problems are not going to be solved quickly. But it is absolutely imperative that we deal with these problems and work with the countries that are affected."
Mr. Rubin's trip began on a positive note, with assurances from Chinese leaders that they do not plan to devalue their currency, the yuan. But now he is in Southeast Asia, which has suffered a wave of crippling devaluations. In addition to Malaysia, he will travel to Thailand and South Korea.
Mr. Rubin declined to discuss specific remedies for Malaysia before his meetings on Monday. But the Treasury Department generally favors the International Monetary Fund economic prescription for Asia, which calls for tight fiscal and monetary policy, coupled with a wholesale reform of the banking system and the often corrupt relationships between executives and officials.
Critics contend, though, that the cure has worsened the pain in Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand. By insisting that those countries maintain stable currencies, even if that means raising interest rates, the critics say the I.M.F. has choked off credit to businesses. The economies of all three countries contracted in the first quarter of the year, and analysts say they are sliding into severe recessions.
Malaysia has not asked for the help of the I.M.F., though it has adopted a plan with features like those that the fund requires. Like its neighbors, Malaysia has an economy that shrank in the first quarter, a 1.8 percent contraction that was all the more traumatic because it followed 6.9 percent expansion in the previous quarter.
The reversal in fortunes has sparked a remarkable public debate at the top levels of the Government. On one side is Dr. Mahathir, who argues that the central bank should lower interest rates to jump-start the economy.
On the other side is Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who opposes such a step because he fears that it would erode the Malaysian currency, the ringgit.
Mr. Anwar has long been regarded as Dr. Mahathir's probable successor. But political experts here said the dispute had frayed their relationship. Last week Dr. Mahathir appointed another close adviser, Daim Zainuddin, to a new Cabinet post to oversee the economy. Economic trouble-shooting had been Mr. Anwar's brief, and it is unclear how he will emerge from this shakeup.
"The debate over interest rates is really part of a broader debate over globalism versus nationalism," said one executive here, who insisted on anonymity. "Anwar still has faith in the global markets, while Mahathir is playing to nationalist sentiments."
As a leading emissary for the global economy, Mr. Rubin will have to wade into this debate, if only for a day. He met briefly with Mr. Anwar this evening and will hold separate meetings on Monday with Mr. Anwar and Dr. Mahathir. Mr. Zainuddin will participate in at least one session.
Analysts say the internal tensions have been aggravated by the turmoil in nearby Indonesia, where President Suharto was forced out after economic hardship led to riots and looting. Although Malaysia's situation is nowhere near as dire as that of Indonesia, analysts said Dr. Mahathir was deeply concerned about the unrest that can stem from deprivation.
For his part, Mr. Rubin said he would focus on a "social safety net," which he said was critical "so that you can maintain your public and political support for what needs to be done."
"You've got wrenching changes in countries that are in very difficult circumstances," he said.

HEADLINE: Alioune Blondin Beye, 59, Envoy for U.N.

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Alioune Blondin Beye, a United Nations envoy on a diplomatic mission aimed at averting renewed bloodshed in Angola, was apparently killed on Friday night in the crash of a light plane near Abidjan, the capital of the Ivory Coast. He was 59 and was based in Lusaka, Zambia.
The authorities at the crash scene yesterday did not make official identification of the remains found by a search team near the wreckage of the plane, a chartered twin-turboprop Beechcraft 200, which went down in an area of forests and mangrove swamps. 
 But searchers found passports belonging to Mr. Beye, a Malian, and others who had been on the plane. Reuters reported that the plane had been flying from Togo to Abidjan carrying Mr. Beye and five other members of the United Nations observer mission in Angola. It also had three crew members on board, officials in Togo said.
A United Nations spokeswoman in New York, Judith Modeste, said yesterday: "The rescue team reached the site of the crash, collected the passports, but there was no evidence of survivors. They have called off the rescue efforts for today and will continue on Monday."
On Saturday, Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations said Mr. Beye had been "traveling in the region in yet another attempt to seek support of African leaders in overcoming the present crisis" over the agreement that ended Angola's long civil war.
A former Foreign Minister of Mali, Mr. Beye was a highly regarded lawyer, diplomat and political figure, known for his energy and quick-wittedness. In 1993 he was designated by Boutros Boutros-Ghali, Mr. Annan's predecessor as Secretary General, as his special representative for Angola.
Mr. Beye began mediating efforts toward peace between Angolan rebels and the Angolan Government. He oversaw the negotiations that led to a 1994 peace agreement under which the rebel group known as the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, agreed to yield control of the large area it had taken over during Angola's more than two decades of intermittent civil war.
But the rebel group has lagged in carrying out its obligations under the pact, and last month Mr. Beye threatened to quit his envoy's post. He contended that neither Unita nor the Angolan Government possessed the "political will" necessary to see peace efforts through to conclusion.
Before being named as a United Nations envoy, Mr. Beye held various posts. He was Mali's Minister of Youth, Sports, Arts and Culture in 1977 before serving as Foreign Minister from 1978 to 1986. He was legal counsel to the President of Mali from 1986 to 1988, and in subsequent years he was Secretary General of the African Development Bank in Abidjan and the head of its legal department.
He lectured on international public law at the University of Dijon, France, and was a member of the Dijon bar. He was also a professor at the National School of Administration in Bamako, Mali, and appeared in Malian courts as chief of the Government legal department.
He was married and had four children.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. in a Jam Over Move Against Teamster Election

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
With a Federal monitor asserting that he cannot supervise the teamsters' presidential election because Congress has cut off his financing, Republicans in Congress are finding themselves in a pickle.
Not only do Congressional Republicans appear to be blocking a monitor whose job is to prevent election fraud in a union long synonymous with corruption, but the financing cutoff is alarming James P. Hoffa, the front-running candidate who is considered friendlier to the Republicans than are the union's current leaders. 
 The Hoffa forces fear that the decision to bar financing could delay the vote for months and could result in an election that is run by anti-Hoffa incumbents rather than the Federal monitor.
"We don't trust the current administration to conduct a fair election," Thomas Pazzi, Mr. Hoffa's campaign manager, said. "There is no evidence they would do so."
Congress, however, does not want taxpayers to pay for a union election, and many teamster officials say that Congressional Republicans are also trying to punish the union because it has backed Democrats in recent elections.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters is being run by Tom Sever, the secretary-treasurer, who was elected on the slate led by Ron Carey, the union president who is on a leave of absence while under investigation in a campaign-finance scandal.
Mr. Carey narrowly beat Mr. Hoffa in the 1996 race, but that victory was nullified and a new election was ordered when Federal monitors discovered that Carey aides siphoned more than $700,000 in teamster money to help his campaign.
In the new election, ballots are scheduled to be mailed out in September and counted on Oct. 14. But Michael G. Cherkasky, the Federal monitor, said he had so little money that vendors would not sign contracts with his office to do needed activities, like print the ballots.
Last Thursday, he filed an urgent request with Judge David Edelstein of Federal District Court in Manhattan, asking him to order the Federal Government and the union to agree on a plan by Tuesday to finance his office. Mr. Cherkasky asserted that the financial crisis would jeopardize the long-standing Federal effort to clean up the teamsters.
In his appeal, he wrote, "It would be astounding, and a stunning waste of decades of effort spent fighting organized crime and labor racketeering, if the current paralysis over funding resulted in the abandonment of this law-enforcement effort."
Under a 1989 consent decree that the teamsters signed to settle a racketeering lawsuit, the union agreed to hold elections every five years and to allow Government supervision of the union and its elections.
The consent decree required the Federal Government to pay for supervision in the 1996 election. But Congressional Republicans, led by Representative Peter Hoekstra of Michigan, were so angry about the Carey campaign-finance scandal and about having taxpayers finance a union election that they barred money for supervision.
Some teamster officials say that in orchestrating the financing prohibition, Mr. Hoekstra was trying to hurt the Carey camp and bolster Mr. Hoffa. But the cutoff has hurt Mr. Hoffa instead.
Steven Trossman, a spokesman for Mr. Hoffa's main opponent, Tom Leedham, said, "It's ironic that Congressman Hoekstra, with the Hoffa forces cheering him on, has made a mess of funding this election."
The Federal Court of Appeals in Manhattan has ruled that the Government must pay to conduct the election if it chooses to supervise the vote. The court left the alternative that the Government could choose not to supervise the election and let the union conduct and pay for it. That alternative is opposed by Mr. Cherkasky, the Justice Department, the teamster incumbents and Mr. Hoffa.
Justice Department officials say they are lobbying Congress to agree to provide the $8.6 million Mr. Cherkasky says he needs.
Some officials who are following the negotiations said that Congressional Democrats who originally supported financing the monitor's office have been strangely quiet about the money. These officials suggest that the Democrats are happy to see the Republicans stew over the matter.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Hoekstra said he was reluctant to make money available because Mr. Cherkasky, in his view, has not done enough to stop teamster officials from using union resources and money to help their preferred candidates. He has also indicated he would like Mr. Cherkasky to remove Mr. Sever from office for participating in the campaign-finance fraud. Teamster officials deny that Mr. Sever has had any involvement.
Mr. Cherkasky has said that he has no power to suspend Mr. Sever and that he was already working hard to prevent the misuse of union resources in the campaign.
But Mr. Hoekstra is skeptical. "My concern here is with the taxpayer," he said. "The system is not yet in place to conduct a fair election. I don't want to pour another dollar or $8 million into an election that in three or six months we'll have to overturn again. That sounds pretty dumb to me."

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Congress Breaks for the Fourth, Perhaps Content to Forgo Fireworks

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
Congress has left town for its Fourth of July recess, seemingly content that the annual negotiations over how to spend the taxpayers' money will resolve themselves to everyone's benefit in this election year.
But battles loom over a number of issues, some of them old, like home heating assistance for the poor, and some new, like how to conduct the census in 2000. 
 There are only 35 legislative days before Congress adjourns on Oct. 9, and even less time before the next fiscal year begins on Oct. 1. By then, 13 different spending bills must be signed into law to keep the Government running.
Views vary as to how it will all come out. The Clinton Administration likes to portray the Republicans in the House as extremists, ready to throw the Government into chaos at a moment's notice.
"The placid surface conceals a very, very turbulent time ahead," said one Democratic negotiator.
But many others involved with the spending bills on Capitol Hill say there is little appetite for chaos in an election year. Even the conservatives seem reluctant to shut down the Government, as they did to disastrous political effect in 1995.
Representative Sherwood Boehlert, a moderate Republican from Utica, N.Y., said, "The wingers -- the right wing, the left wing -- are getting most of the attention, but the moderates are shaping public policy."
House and Senate committees are still working separately on the bills and have not begun to negotiate their vast differences. They have to do that before presenting their final proposals to the President, who has his own set of priorities.
Some of the early skirmishing has a familiar ring. As they have since they came to power in 1995, the Republicans, whose strength derives from the South and West, have proposed lopping off programs that benefit urban dwellers in the Northeast. This includes financing for Amtrak.
They have proposed cutting heating aid for the poor, summer jobs for disadvantaged youth, and several environmental and education programs dear to President Clinton. They would also knock out Americorps, the national service program, and the Legal Services Corporation, which provides lawyers for the poor.
But this year offers some twists.
Perhaps the biggest change is that both Congress and the Administration are living under a virtual freeze on new spending because of last year's balanced-budget agreement. The spending limits are the guiding principle -- not the projected budget surplus and strong economy, which, along with talk of tax cuts, give the false impression that Washington has lots of extra money on its hands.
In reality, the budget agreement barely allows for inflation. And tax cuts can come only from entitlements, not from the discretionary spending that is the subject of the 13 appropriations bills. So spending, a favorite election-year activity, is limited this year, prompting members to be especially creative.
Republicans have shown that, despite their complaints about past Democratic pork-barrel spending, they are just as eager to direct money to hometown projects.
The spending bills include billions of dollars spread across most districts and states for local projects such as refurbishing courthouses, controlling floods and beach erosion, providing construction work for the Army Corps of Engineers, keeping open military bases that the Administration wants to shut, and financing 22 projects, like better dining halls, at various military installations. Most are in the home states of members of the House and Senate appropriations committees.
The Republicans have also included big-ticket items for high-ranking members, like money for a helicopter carrier to be built by Litton Industries in a shipyard in Pascagoula, Miss., the hometown of Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, and millions of dollars for cargo planes to be built by Lockheed Martin Corp. in Marietta, Ga., the hometown of Speaker Newt Gingrich.
The Republicans have earmarked new money for basic medical research, granting the National Institutes of Health a whopping increase of 9 percent over its current budget. They would provide more money to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more for anti-drug programs to counter their failure to pass anti-tobacco legislation, and would expand Federal mortgages for low-income home buyers.
Democrats have not complained about these priorities as much as they have complained about the Republican cuts. Most notably, they have highlighted the conservatives' recurring attempt to block money for the National Endowment for the Arts. But Republican moderates in the House have joined with Democrats to keep the money in, signaling that the moderates -- 40 to 60 members of the House, depending on the issue -- could have a strong say in the final spending proposals.
One of the most contentious issues shaping up is not a spending matter but one of the many policy rulings that are often tucked into spending bills. This is the question of the census. Republicans want an exact head count. Democrats want to use statistical sampling, which would make up for people who are hard to find, like blacks in the inner city, Hispanic migrant workers and the homeless. This matters to both parties because the census determines Congressional boundaries for the next decade and determines how much Federal aid each region receives.
How these conflicts will be resolved may depend on the answers to some central questions:
How deeply split will the Republicans be? Will the conservatives and the moderates compromise -- with each other and the Administration?
And how much sway does President Clinton have on Capitol Hill? How readily will he meld his views with those of the Republican majority? Perhaps most important, which issues will he be willing to fight for?

Clinton Stresses Freedom In a Speech to Students
President Clinton made his last public appearance in China's capital with speech at Beijing University, where he proclaimed personal freedom to be the "mandate of the 21st century." The United States does not seek to impose its vision on China, he said, "but we are convinced that certain rights are universal." A1

Speaking from Kashmir, where he visited Tibetan refugees, he said the event sent a signal that Tibet is an issue whose time has come. A1
 
South Africa's Unlikely Alliance
A new multiracial party in held its first congress in South Africa, formally electing leaders and adopting a platform. With little more than a year to go before elections, the party, called the United Democratic Movement, has surprised many political analysts by making headway in its challenge to the governing African National Congress, which is largely supported by blacks. A6
 
Italian Leader to Visit Iran
Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy is scheduled to make an official visit to Iran this week, the first by a head of Government from the European Union since the country's Islamic revolution in 1979. Mr. Prodi is expected to meet President Mohammad Khatami and former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani. There are no plans for Mr. Prodi to meet Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, officials said. A4
 
Abortion Vote Fails in Portugal
Too few voters appeared to have turned out for a valid referendum on easing Portugal's abortion laws, among the most restrictive in Europe. The participation of at least half the electorate was required. But with voting nearly complete, the National Electoral Commission said that only about 20 percent of voters had turned out. (AP)
 
Crash Kills 11 in Mexico
Mexican authorities said a helicopter on a drug-eradication mission crashed in southern Guerrero state, killing two police officers and nine soldiers. They said the helicopter went down on Saturday after a mechanical failure, but did not elaborate. Guerrero has been the site in recent weeks of fighting between the army and leftist rebels and is believed to be one of the country's largest drug-producing areas. (AP)

Among African-Americans, AIDS Is a Quiet Epidemic
Seventeen years after AIDS was first recognized among gay white men in New York and San Francisco, the disease in this country is becoming largely an epidemic among black people and all but ignored by leading black institutions, say public health officials. African-Americans make up 13 percent of the nation's population but now account for about 57 percent of all new infections with H.I.V., according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. A1
 
Pleas were made at the opening of the 12th World AIDS Conference in Geneva for national leaders to muster the political courage to carry out strong prevention programs to stop the global epidemic of AIDS. A13

LENGTH: 380 words

HEADLINE: Straight Talk in Beijing

 BODY:
President Clinton's forthright language on individual freedom and Tibet has helped quiet American fears that China would exploit his presence to sanitize its abysmal human rights record. On Saturday Mr. Clinton characterized the Chinese Government's use of force against the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy demonstrators as "wrong," listed "freedom of speech, association and religion" as necessary components of national success and urged a dialogue with the Dalai Lama over Tibet. 
 Mr. Clinton's remarks at Beijing University, and the lively question-and-answer session that followed, continued to explore the theme of human rights. His declaration to the students that democracy is the "mandate of the new century" used the language of Chinese history to make a contemporary political point. While the speech itself could have been more pointed, the ripple effect in China of the weekend's events should not be underestimated.
The formal summit produced the usual agreements on issues from Chinese missile exports to the Asian financial crisis. Most were mainly symbolic, including the pledge by Beijing and Washington to stop targeting nuclear missiles at each other.
Far more important was Mr. Clinton's human rights message to audiences in China and the United States. In a notable departure, Chinese television aired his Saturday give-and-take with President Jiang Zemin live and uncensored. That welcome innovation probably reflected China's gratitude for the Clinton Administration's persistence in seeking better relations despite strong, and sometimes justified, criticism in the United States. After he returns home, Mr. Clinton will still be obliged to account for his Administration's lax monitoring of satellite sales. Also, Mr. Jiang's public denials of any attempts to influence American politics do not remove the need for a thorough investigation.
China's future human rights performance will also affect the relationship. While Mr. Clinton spoke plainly on that issue, encouraging Chinese citizens who want a freer society, Mr. Jiang's responses evoked familiar justifications of past and present repression. Chinese leaders may now be somewhat more relaxed about American human rights criticism, but they still run an unyielding police state.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton, at Beijing University, Presses Call for Liberty

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Monday, June 29

 BODY:
President Clinton proclaimed personal freedom the "mandate of the new century" in a broad defense of human and economic liberty today in a speech at Beijing University.
In his last public appearance in the Chinese capital, the President said the United States did not seek to impose its vision of society on China or any other nation. 
 "But we are convinced that certain rights are universal," the President said, "not American rights or European rights or rights for developed nations, but the birthrights of people everywhere, now enshrined in the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights -- the right to be treat with dignity, the right to express one's opinion, to choose one's own leaders, to associate freely with others and to worship, or not, freely, however one chooses."
Administration officials called today's speech, which was carried live on Chinese television, a philosophical discourse addressed directly to the Chinese people, after a weekend that featured a remarkable series of public and private discussions with President Jiang Zemin, and a visit to Beijing's largest Protestant church.
Speaking to several hundred students and faculty members in a freshly painted auditorium at China's most prestigious university, Mr. Clinton sought to broaden his audience from the Chinese leadership to a new generation that will shape the future of the most populous country on earth. Beijing University, which is celebrating its centennial this year, has been the nurturing ground of successive movements for political change in China.
He said liberty was not a luxury to be enjoyed only by wealthy nations, but a necessary element of human and economic development.
Acknowledging China's centuries-old fear of internal disintegration, he said all societies craved stability.
But, he said, personal freedom strengthens a nation's security, rather than undermining it, as the Communist Government has maintained.
"We believe, and our experience demonstrates, that freedom strengthens stability and helps nations to change," Mr. Clinton said. "China's greatest source of strength resides in the minds and hearts of its citizens. It is therefore profoundly in your interest, and the world's, that young Chinese minds be free to reach the fullness of their potential. This is the message of our time and the mandate of the new century and the new millennium."
He hailed the rapid economic growth that has swept across China in the last decade, as the Government has loosened controls on private entrepreneurship and begun to close down inefficient state-owned enterprises. He said growing incomes brought more options to the Chinese people: foreign travel, access to cable television and the Internet, new career opportunities, a higher standard of living.
"But true freedom includes more than economic freedom," the President said. "In America, we believe it is a concept which is indivisible."
Mr. Clinton spoke for 30 minutes, then took questions for another half hour.
Asked whether the United States sought to isolate China through security agreements with Japan and arms sales to Taiwan, he answered: "It is not fair to say that either Japan or the United States have a security relationship that is designed to contain China," and added that American policy posed no obstacle to the peaceful reunification of China and Taiwan.
Another student followed up with one of many surprisingly challenging questions, this one about whether the President, despite his smile, intended to pursue a policy of containment of China.
"The answer is no," Mr. Clinton said. "I'm not hiding another design behind the smile. That's what I really believe."
Another questioner asked whether there remained problems in the United States in realizing it ideals of democracy and human liberty.
Mr. Clinton replied that the United States is still plagued by violent crime and racial and sex discrimination. "So we Americans need to be sensitive not only to preserve the freedoms that we hold dear, but also to create an environment in which people can build a truly good and free life," he said.
Mr. Clinton appeared somewhat taken aback by the students' suspicions about American motives in engaging the Chinese leadership in discussions while continuing to support Taiwan and maintaining a strong strategic alliance with Japan.
The Beijing University speech offered a coda to a series of weekend meetings with President Jiang and other top Government leaders here.
On Sunday evening, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang continued their dialogue at a private dinner, exploring in greater depth the growth of the United States-China relationship and possible paths of China's future.
The dinner was the last meeting of the two Presidents on Mr. Clinton's nine-day, five-city visit to China, which has seen a significant step forward in relations both between the two nations and between their leaders. Aides called the evening "very casual and very lively."
The dinner, in the Zhongnanhai compound for Beijing's political elite, included discussion of the Asian financial crisis, development of an independent judiciary in China and American movies.
"They went way beyond what people thought were the possibilities of having this kind of discussion," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said of the two days of meetings between the two Presidents. "We have moved the relationship into a qualitatively and quantitatively different direction."
Ms. Albright and other American officials were still clearly elated by the news conference on Saturday in which Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang engaged in an animated debate on topics that for years were not the subject of public discussion -- religious freedom, Tibet and the role of the individual and the state.
"The press conference was a truly remarkable event and one that is going to have long-term repercussions -- positive ones," Ms. Albright said in a session with reporters at the Diaoyutai state guest compound here. But in a reminder that not everything has changed in China, American security officials had posted a notice on the wall of the room where Ms. Albright spoke, reading, "The walls have ears."
Ms. Albright and two other American officials -- Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, and James Sasser, the Ambassador to China -- said today that 600 million Chinese had seen the news conference, carried live on China Central Television, the state network.
That number seemed a significant exaggeration, given that there are an estimated 300 million television sets in China and there was no advance notice that the news conference would be carried live. It was difficult to find Chinese who had seen the live broadcast, and state television rebroadcast only selected portions.
Earlier on Sunday, the President and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, attended services at Chongwenmen Church, the largest officially sanctioned Protestant church in Beijing, with more than 2,000 members. The congregation gave Mr. Clinton a bilingual Bible and asked him to speak to the overflow crowd.
"We celebrate with you the growth of the practice of our faith in China," Mr. Clinton said in remarks that lasted less than five minutes. "I believe our faith calls upon us to seek unity with people across the world with different backgrounds and races and creeds."
The Clintons and their daughter, Chelsea, spent Sunday afternoon touring the Forbidden City and the section of the Great Wall at Mutianyu. The authorities cleared the Forbidden City complex for the Clintons, only the third time they have done so, American officials said. The previous times were for a tour by President Richard M. Nixon and for the making of the film "The Last Emperor."
Mr. Clinton called the wall "quite unbelievable."

HEADLINE: The More the Books, The Fewer the Editors;
As Publishing Pressures Rise, So Do Errors

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
In the winter, Wally Lamb typed the last period of his aptly named manuscript, "I Know This Much Is True." He slumped to his knees, touched his forehead to the floor and, he recalled, tearfully thanked "whatever had allowed me to finish the story without killing me first."
By the time his novel hit the nation's bookstores this month, Mr. Lamb, a best-selling author, had recruited a freelance editor, hired a personal copy editor and turned the work over to his editor at a top publishing house who was so preoccupied with other sales and marketing duties that she confessed she longed to quit. 
 "It's all become a big, fat, screaming, mean, vicious, greedy, rude and crude fest," said Judith Regan, Mr. Lamb's editor and publisher at Regan Books, an imprint of HarperCollins. "So little of your time is spent doing creative work that I'm seriously considering leaving."
These days, an editor's sharp pencil can be a luxury in the consolidating industry of large trade publishing houses, which through the 1990's have undergone a significant contraction in their editing staffs. These are the editors who shape, tighten and polish American literature and the copy editors who detect grammatical gaffes and rescue writers from creative spelling.
In this decade, the work force of book publishing professionals in New York, who are largely editors, has declined by 16 percent, to 2,714 from 3,218, according to data from the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. But at the same time, the number of books published in the United States has surged, and so have the complaints about the quality of books carefully bound for posterity with dangling modifiers, typographical errors and misspelled words.
With publishing cycles compressed, leaving less time for editing, and editors distracted by other corporate duties like acquiring new titles, writers are increasingly recruiting hired pens -- independent editors who sharpen text or copy editors who correct grammar, inconsistencies and spelling errors for fees ranging from $1,000 to $25,000.
"I see every level of error: typographical, syntactical, factual and lack of internal consistency," said Elizabeth Sifton, a veteran editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, who worries that old-fashioned practitioners of the art of editing are coming to be regarded as woolly mammoths.
The decline of editing standards in American literature is an enduring lament, one that tainted even Maxwell Perkins, the celebrated editor of Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald. In 1920, he published "This Side of Paradise" with so many errors that a newspaper columnist made a parlor game of spotting mistakes.
And some publishers speculate that today's complaints are simply a subtext for deeper fears in an industry that has been roiled by consolidations like the merger of Random House and Bantam Doubleday Dell by the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann and the breakup and sale of Simon & Schuster's education division to Pearson P.L.C. of Britain.
Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Doubleday, said that some prominent authors resist editing, which affects the quality of the outcome. "I think that clearly we're in a period of momentous change on various levels, and I think people are terrified of change," he said. "And when they start whining, they're throwing editing into it. In some cases they're justified, and in some cases they're not."
The staffing level of editors is not a topic that large publishing houses dwell on, with few ever publicly revealing cutbacks. For example, Bantam Doubleday Dell does not disclose employment figures. Stuart Applebaum, a company spokesman, said he could not recall a period of deep reductions among the industry's ranks of editors and suggested that the editing staff might actually have expanded at his company with the creation of a new publishing imprint.
That view, however, is not shared by many writers and agents. Although complaints about editing may be as old as clay tablets, there is a new edginess, which has inspired counterstrategies.
Authors with a yearning for the romantic ideal of an editor as a confessor and critic are recruiting informal editors to shape up their manuscripts before submitting them to publishers -- a defensive effort to prevent early rejection or late cancellation for unsatisfactory work.

Less Time, More Pressure
Literary agents are also beginning to offer the services of in-house editors or are urging clients to hire their own editors. And the top publishing houses are continuing their practice of contracting with independent editors when their employees are too busy to do the work.
Speeded by computer technology, manuscripts that were more leisurely published in a standard nine months after submission are now edited, corrected and printed in as little as four to six months. (Authors are encouraged to submit manuscripts on computer floppy disks, which accelerates the process.) Editors are expected not only to improve prose but also to acquire books and shepherd titles through meetings on marketing, sales and publicity.
"There's much more pressure," said Peter Gethers, an editor at Random House who just started the company's Library of Contemporary Thought series of novella-length books. The window of opportunity for editing has shortened. "Every publishing company is on a 3-, 6- or 12-month business plan," he said. "And so if you get a big book and it's not perfect, you're being pressured from all sides. It's not that you can't fix it, but there are others who want it out."
Mr. Lamb, the author, hired a copy editor at the suggestion of his literary agent, Linda Chester, who estimates that within the last two years almost 60 percent of her clients have hired their own editors.
 
Bringing In Outside Editors
"If it's not 100 percent, I bring in an outside editor," Ms. Chester said of the quality of manuscripts. "Publishers should be allowing clients to do the best possible work that they can so that their books can be read for generations, but what's happening is that publishers are concerned with getting the book out in the right period to maximize sales."
Complaints about editing come from a range of writers -- from a best-selling author who is reluctant to talk publicly about her hired freelance copy editor to a first-time biographer like Bob Thomas, who spotted 14 errors in the final production stage of his manuscript, some of which made it into his book about the golfer Ben Hogan.
Mr. Thomas said his book, "Ben Hogan's 'Secret': A Fictionalized Biography," had been shifted among at least four editors at Macmillan before its publication in 1997. "We still left typos in there," he said. "In the author's note, there's a word called 'skill," and it should have been 'shill.' "
John Michael, a former executive editor at Macmillan, did some of the editing and then departed to take a new post before the book was published. He is frank with his authors about what they can often expect in the current publishing climate.
"I tell authors that there will always be 1 or 2 percent of errors that get in," said Mr. Michael, who added that editing had deteriorated over the years, but so gradually that "it's like dirt on your glasses: it starts out a little bit at a time and all of a sudden you take them off and think, 'How could I see?' "
Critics are also taking note of sloppiness. A reviewer at Time magazine, for instance, helpfully provided the page numbers for errors in a May critique of "The Unfinished Presidency," Douglas Brinkley's biography of Jimmy Carter, published by Viking. For example, the book refers to a Pakistani billionaire who suddenly becomes a Palestinian billionaire.
"Books are not perfect; authors are not perfect; editors are not perfect," said the editor of the biography, Wendy Wolf, who added that as more books were published, more manuscripts were submitted that were not in perfect shape. "We have neither infinite time nor infinite budgets, and everybody does their best."
Readers are also weighing in with withering criticism of flaws that could have been corrected with editing. Some posted reviews of Toni Morrison's latest novel, "Paradise," on the Amazon.com Web site complaining about tangled plot lines, undeveloped characters and confusing passages.
Ms. Morrison was unavailable for comment, her assistant said. But in a January interview in U.S. News and World Report, she responded to general criticism about "Paradise" by expressing the desire for more time to "step back" during the period between submitting the manuscript and final publication.
Her publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, speeded up the publication of "Paradise" from the spring to last January to take advantage of heavier holiday bookstore traffic. Her editor, Erroll McDonald, said that Ms. Morrison's book was one of the special cases involving speed, but that in his experience most titles were turned around in the old standard of nine months. The author, Mr. McDonald said, could have made the same comment about more time even "if she had nine more months."
Agents and writers say that editors in contemporary publishing used to have more time to send detailed letters explaining how to fix or improve a manuscript. But often they are now too preoccupied to take this intermediate step, and decisions are simply made to buy, reject or cancel a manuscript.
"I have an author who's struggling with the writing, but the editor would look at drafts and would provide comments that were far too general," said a literary agent who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Instead, he said, he ended up charging his author an extra fee to help with reorganizing and rewriting.

Seeing a Need Ro 'Hit the Target'
Last April, Michael V. Carlisle left his job of 18 years at the William Morris Agency to open a literary agency for authors. One feature of his agency is a newly hired in-house editor, Neal Bascomb, who will work closely with fiction writers.
"Fiction manuscripts have to hit the target absolutely squarely," Mr. Carlisle said. "Editors are under such pressure. They are looking to acquire books for a list, to make money, move forward, to keep their jobs. But by and large, if consolidation points to anything, it's not to old-fashioned red-pencil editing. It's to economies of scale and efficiency of product."
With some authors pining for more intensive editing, several loose groups of independent editors have formed in New York, and consultants have also established bases far from the publishing hub in places like Santa Fe, N.M., and the Berkshires of Massachusetts.
Barry Werth, a nonfiction writer, hired a personal editor to work on his latest book about a medical malpractice case, "Damages," after receiving what he characterized as minimal editing on his first book, "The Billion-Dollar Molecule." He recruited Chris Jerome, a former magazine editor who runs a freelance editing service from her home in Ashfield, Mass., and frequently proofreads manuscripts for Knopf authors like Ms. Morrison.
"I sent the manuscript, and she sent it back with detailed notes in a 10-page memo," Mr. Werth said. "What my New York editors do is buy books and move them through the process."

HEADLINE: Media Convergence

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Billions of dollars and a bold high-technology vision are fueling the AT&T Corporation's plan to buy Tele-Communications Inc. The merger, announced last week, is the latest in a rising wave of corporate deals sweeping up telecommunications, cable television and media companies as these industries become increasingly dependent on the digital technology of computing.
The business logic behind the trend is that companies now face a once-in-a-corporate-lifetime choice of getting in early to become leaders in the new markets of the information age or being relegated to also-ran status. Earlier this month, two major media companies -- the Walt Disney Company and the NBC unit of the General Electric Company -- applied that logic in making significant investments in popular sites on the Internet's World Wide Web. 
 Whether any of these deals make sense, or make money anytime soon, will depend largely on the economic behavior of people like Charles Vandagriff of Oakland, Calif.
Mr. Vandagriff, his wife and two daughters are the kind of well-off, technologically fluent family earmarked first by phone, media and computer companies in their consumer marketing campaigns.
Someday, AT&T wants families like Mr. Vandagriff's to turn to the company for one-stop shopping for not only all of their telephone and cable television services but new information services as well. And AT&T's purchase of TCI, the nation's second-largest cable television company, is seen as a big step toward realizing AT&T's vision of becoming an all-in-one digital delivery system.
The 49-year-old Mr. Vandagriff is a furniture designer, and his wife, Kathy Sinsheimer, is a psychotherapist. Their household has three personal computers, four phone lines, a cellular phone and two pagers.
There are 16 million such wired families in America, typically with incomes of $70,000 or more, at least one PC and often more than one telephone line, according to the Yankee Group, a research firm. "No new technology or technology marketing plan will succeed if it doesn't succeed first with families like that one," observed Howard Anderson, the Yankee Group's managing director.
By acquiring TCI's cable-television system, AT&T gets a higher-speed network for sending telephone, video and Internet services directly into consumers' homes, including 1.3 million TCI customers in the San Francisco area like the Vandagriffs. It was this vision of a phone-entertainment-Internet supercarrier that C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman, and John C. Malone, the chairman of TCI, were extolling last Wednesday when they announced their $31.8 billion deal.
Mr. Vandagriff remains skeptical. "I'm sure these companies are trying to think ahead, but it's not clear to me what they are going to try to sell us really," he said. "I have so many services now -- Internet, cable, phone, cellular and pagers -- that I can't imagine I want any more. I'll wait for the future to arrive."
Telecommunications and media companies do not believe they have the luxury of waiting. The rapid advances of technology, they say, are forcing them to act now. The main engine is the spread of digital technology that enables text, sound and video all to be expressed and distributed in the form of the elemental building blocks of computing, the electronic 1's and 0's called bits (short for binary digits).
Though all forms of information can be reduced to bits, text requires the fewest bits, while sound and video consume many more. One letter in a word can be rendered in eight bits, while a few seconds of movie-style video may require millions of bits. Most of the new services companies hope to market eventually -- from video phones to movies on demand -- are expected to be multimedia offerings that require high-speed connections into homes.
So today, companies are puzzling over both how to carry more bits into homes and how to package those bits into new entertainment, information or shopping services that people may actually want. In simple terms, telecommunications companies can be thought of as the pipes and media companies as the programmers.
It will be costly and time-consuming to upgrade the existing bit-delivery mechanisms. Phone lines are skinny pipes, but they are two-way networks that can both send and receive data; cable systems offer fat pipes, but must be converted from one-way to two-way systems. It will, for example, take AT&T nearly five years and $9 billion to upgrade the entire TCI network, the Yankee Group estimates.
As with most new technologies, from the telephone to the personal computer, companies will be able to pay for high-speed Internet service first, before costs come down to make it common in homes.
The impact, many experts predict, will be sweeping. Nicholas Negroponte, director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory, insists that for all the attention the Internet has received, the power of the technology is still not understood. "The Internet is wildly underestimated," Mr. Negroponte said. "It will grow to be the enabling technology of all media -- TV, radio, magazines and so on."
A longtime Internet enthusiast, Mr. Negroponte advises many of the nation's leading media and telecommunications companies. What gives his counsel added weight, though, are the recent trends in household computer and Internet use.
By January 1998, the share of American households with personal computers had reached 42 percent, up from 31 percent in 1995, according to Odyssey L.P., a research firm in San Francisco. Over the same three-year span, the percentage of households on line has increased to 23 percent from 7 percent.
"A few years ago, the Internet was a geek network," noted Kate Delhagen, an analyst at Forrester Research Inc., a technology research firm. "Now, the Internet equals consumer network, something that is increasingly part of day-to-day life."
As more people go on line, the Internet attracts more advertisers, increasing the potential for electronic commerce. For example, on-line purchases of airline tickets, hotel rooms and other travel services tripled last year to $654 million, Forrester estimates. By 2001, it projects on-line travel sales will reach $7.4 billion, as the number of on-line shoppers increases fourfold to 43 million people.
With new-media startups beginning to attract large audiences to their sites on the Internet's World Wide Web, the established media companies are taking notice, starting to move beyond experiments to make sizable investments. Two weeks ago, for example, Disney announced that it would buy 43 percent of the Infoseek Corporation, an on-line directory service, in a deal worth about $900 million.
The most popular properties on line, from the Yahoo directory service to America Online Inc., are likely takeover candidates, industry executives say. Indeed, AT&T did talk to America Online recently, though the overture was rebuffed. The Internet media business is expected to follow the pattern of cable television, where entrepreneurs created CNN, ESPN and MTV and were later bought out by Time Warner Inc., Disney and Viacom Inc., respectively.
"It's inevitable that you will see increased concentration in the new-media field as it matures, just as you did in every other media business in history," said Mike Slade, chief executive of the Starwave Corporation, the Web developer that built Disney's ESPN and ABC News sites.
Someday, people will look back on the recent telecommunications and media deals as either shrewd or premature depending on how quickly the anticipated new business develops. History, both recent and more distant, suggests some caution is in order.
In December 1992, Mr. Malone of TCI declared that as early as 1994 his company would install digital compression technology enabling customers to receive as many as 500 channels on their televisions and many of the interactive shopping and information services that people are today saying will be delivered via a supercharged Internet.
Back then, television was declared the engine of the so-called information highway. "Television will never be the same," Mr. Malone said. "Our ability to deliver program services is limited only by our imagination."
Following a slightly different avenue of technology, Mr. Malone may be proved correct, though his timetable was overly optimistic. Over the years, the technologies that have truly transformed the way people live required some time to spread.
For example, it took 70 years from the first consumer sale of a telephone in 1876 to the year when half of the nation's households had phones, in 1946, according to a study by Technologic Partners, a research firm in New York. It took the automobile 29 years, from 1895 to 1924, to reach half of American families, while it took the television only 8 years, from 1946 to 1954.
"Unless you keep some technology history in mind, you are setting yourself up for disillusionment," said Richard Shaffer, a principal of Technologic Partners.
Mr. Shaffer's own guess is that it will be 5 to 10 years before most Americans will find that communications or media offerings have changed markedly.
In the meantime, analysts expect that combinations like AT&T-TCI will focus on consolidated marketing of existing services. Such telecommunications supercarriers want to offer local and long-distance phone and cellular service, cable TV and Internet access -- all on one bill with a price discount for buying all these services from one company.
Now that is an innovation that intrigues Mr. Vandagriff in Oakland. "If they could simplify all this, put it on one understandable monthly bill and then offer me a discount of 20 percent or so, I'd say, 'O.K., you've got my attention,' " he said.

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
Eurosongs That Verge On an American Style

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
The Northern Italian singer Paolo Conte is a private man in a public man's outfit. With tuxedo and bow tie, he came onstage for a rare New York performance at the Supper Club on Thursday night as part of the JVC Jazz Festival and seemed snug in his own geometry of ritual: he kissed his watch, brushed his gray mustache, touched his ear. He repeated these actions during the performance, and never talked between songs except to introduce one of his band members.
Widely known in Europe and lionized in Italy, Mr. Conte is a former lawyer, now in his early 60's, who has just been introduced to the United States with the recent album "The Best of Paolo Conte" (Nonesuch/ WEA). He plays a kind of unified-Europe cabaret music -- a mixture of Weimar, tango, habanera rhythms and French chansonnier style -- that is, oddly, a stone's throw from a recent American singer-songwriter tradition. 
 Randy Newman has approached this boozy, poetic zone, as have Tom Waits, Van Dyke Parks and others. But Mr. Conte's version is more jazz-specific, referring to the Ellington jungle-band style of the late 20's. And where American practitioners grow fuzzily content, idealizing a lost innocent America when doing this middle-aged songster routine, Mr. Conte presents songs filled with tetchy observations, mild xenophobia and actual poetry. It's perfect film music (Mr. Conte has composed for Lina Wertmuller movies) but easy to understand on a soigne concert stage.
His economically constructed songs were played with an octet, including bandoneon, guitar, bass, drums and a three-man horn section. Mr. Conte sang in Italian, with a narrow, crumbly growl, occasionally performing a jazz scat solo through a kazoo, and played dry piano solos with two fingers (he used to be a vibraphonist). He has beautiful ideas: one was about the secret relationship between artist and song, imagining an internal speech given by an Argentine musician to the form of the music itself: "You'll have me, green milonga, because you were written for me, for my sensitivity, my polished shoes, my timing, for my taste, for all my tiredness and my ham acting."
In Mr. Conte's world, the minutes pass slowly, with long gaps for self-analysis, and events outside of one's immediate environment may well be a waste of time. One song on the Nonesuch album, which he didn't perform, theorizes queasily about making the journey to Genoa, though it is only 50 miles from his hometown of Asti: people are different there, and he's not quite sure why one should feel compelled to visit. And in one song he did perform, "Chi Siamo Noi," he sang of Vasco da Gama and other travelers, repeatedly asking, "Who are we, and where are we going?"
