HEADLINE: Scientist at Work: Steven Chu;
Master of Molecule Manipulation Works on the Wild Side

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ; James Glanz writes for Science magazine.

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
AN atom can be here, there and somewhere else all at once; it can be going both this way and that way; it can be rattling with internal energy and quiet. Such are the quirky freedoms of the quantum microworld that do not apply to automobiles, apples or people. But if there is an exception to this rule, it would be the mind of Dr. Steven Chu, the master of manipulating atoms and molecules who shared the most recent Nobel Prize in Physics with two other researchers.
Dr. Chu, a professor at Stanford University, ranges so widely among topics of interest to him that any attempt to keep up leaves a blurry succession of visual images, like a slide show inadequately describing one's dream vacation. 
 Here he is clutching a Reuben sandwich while filling a steno pad with sketches of an experiment to stretch DNA molecules like knotted rubber bands. Here, he is in the back of a cab where he is alternately shouting instructions to the driver and quietly rationalizing his mega-celebrity status in Taiwan. This one shows him explaining the cosmological theory of multiple universes to the Dalai Lama. And finally, here, in his lab, Dr. Chu is pointing through the window of a vacuum chamber to a hovering blob of atoms that are trapped and supercooled by the forces of laser light -- the achievement for which he won the 1997 Nobel Prize.
On a recent day in his Stanford office, the 50-year-old, aggressively trim Dr. Chu, wearing khaki trousers, a pullover shirt and scruffy tennis shoes, sat on a puffy couch and held court for his students and research associates. He bounced between taking phone calls and bantering about projects that combine conceptual simplicity with a faint air of unbelievability. In one experiment, the drop of a "fountain" of atoms is clocked to measure gravity so precisely that the technique could be used like a petroleum dowser to find hidden pockets of oil. In others, a single DNA molecule marked with fluorescent dyes is dragged about as a video camera mounted on a microscope captures the reptilian motions.
"I'm drawn towards the wilder, science-fiction-type stuff," said Dr. Chu, who grew up in Garden City, Long Island. "It's much more fun for me to learn completely new things than it is to sort of ice the cake," he said. "Well, that's part of the reason one is a scientist. It's not to just crawl into a little corner of some field and go to all of the meetings that all 50 of you in the world go to. 'Oh, this person twiddled that and look what happened.' After a while it becomes a little rococo, if you know what I mean."
That adventurousness is reflected in Dr. Chu's recent moves from his original field of atomic physics into polymer science, chemistry and biology. But unlike the average scientific dilettante, Dr. Chu sees to it that this crosscutting work always bears the mark of his experimental dazzle and intuition for pay dirt. "What Steve brings to science is an incredible technical virtuosity -- a sort of technical showmanship," said David Pritchard, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. "There is this terrific scientific taste," added Daniel Kleppner, also of M.I.T. "He has the vision to see new areas emerging. He's a damn good experimenter, but he's also highly creative."
Those who work most closely with Dr. Chu say he also has the incalculably useful ability to see the complex interactions of the microworld directly, rather than relying on the equations that thicken the chapters of physics textbooks.
"He doesn't have to resort to those formulas," said Cheng Chin, one of Dr. Chu's doctoral students. "He has atoms in his mind."
Steven Chu emerged from a cauldron of academic overachievement. His father, who emigrated from mainland China to study chemical engineering at M.I.T., retired as a professor at Brooklyn Polytechnic University and is a member of the Academica Sinica, Taiwan's most distinguished scholarly society. His mother studied economics at M.I.T. and a prestigious university in China. Two brothers and four cousins eventually generated three M.D.'s, four Ph.D.'s and a law degree. And that doesn't count the aunts and uncles.
"I was to become the academic black sheep," Dr. Chu wrote in a biographical sketch for the Nobel Foundation. There is still an edge to his voice when he recalls that for years in his father's eyes, he never lived up to the dizzying scholarly achievements of his older brother, Gilbert Chu, an associate professor at Stanford School of Medicine.
With what he described as a "relatively lackluster" record at Garden City High, Dr. Chu was not accepted into Ivy League colleges. Instead, he attended the University of Rochester, where his intellectual appetite exploded, leading to undergraduate degrees in physics and math and a doctorate in physics at the University of California at Berkeley.
An encounter with the late Richard Feynman's "Lectures in Physics," a comprehensive and idiosyncratic introduction to basic physics, ignited an interest in theoretical physics. Not until later, well into graduate school, did he start fiddling with equipment in physics laboratories at night. It was like Nat King Cole finding his voice: So long, jazz piano. "I said, 'Well, it's ridiculous, sneaking in and making play experiments, and I'm ignoring my theoretical problem,' " Dr. Chu explained. Experiments became the day job.
He quickly began a long-term relationship with the powerful light source called the laser. His method was to juice up the inadequate equipment he could buy off the shelf, which let him stay ahead of the beat scientifically. That improvisational approach served him well when he moved to the old AT&T Bell Laboratories, the famed center of technical and scientific innovation in New Jersey.
"He would come into my office with these great ideas, all excited, and scribble stuff up on my board," said Dr. Douglas Osheroff, who shared the previous Nobel Prize in Physics and is now a professor at Stanford. (The university has raked in five physics Nobels in the past 10 years.)
As to the cross-disciplinary flair Dr. Chu would develop, Dr. Osheroff said, "that was a very standard approach at Bell Laboratories and almost part of the culture there."
It was at Bell Labs that Dr. Chu met Arthur Ashkin, who was trapping microscopic particles with laser light and who dreamed of trapping atoms. Dr. Ashkin and his colleagues were the first to demonstrate that particles would "stick" to the laser beam for nearly the same reasons that dust sticks to a glass rod that has been charged positively by rubbing it with cat's fur. Even though a dust mote has no net charge, its negative charges -- electrons -- crowd over to the side closest to the rod, being pulled toward it like vacationers waving at the rails of a docking ship. That leaves a positive excess on the opposite side of the mote, but because the negative charges are closer to the rod, their attraction wins out and the mote sticks. In the Bell Labs apparatus, the dancing electric fields of laser light take the place of those static electrical charges, attracting a particle to the most intense parts of a laser beam. Instruments that move particles around with lasers have come to be called "laser tweezers."
After adding this technique to his repertoire, Dr. Chu expanded on it by "gluing" tiny polystyrene beads, which he could grab and move with laser tweezers, onto strands of fluorescent DNA. By stretching the DNA and dragging it through a soup of other DNA molecules, he and colleagues at Stanford later helped confirm theories developed by Pierre-Gilles de Gennes, the Nobel Prize winner at the Ecole Superieure de Physique et de Chimie Industrielles in Paris. Dr. de Gennes had predicted that any such long molecules, called polymers, should "reptate," or change directions like a snake, whose entire body follows the same path without cutting corners.
"We've had theories of that kind of thing for years," said Bruno Zimm, a chemistry professor at the University of California, San Diego. "Actually seeing it is something else."
Among other things, reptation helps explain the toy-store mystery of why Silly Putty bounces and squishes. If a child hurls it against a wall, the impact comes faster than the polymers in the putty can move along their tortuous paths, so the putty acts like a solid and bounces. But a slow squish gives the polymers time to slither around. Academics call such materials "viscoelastic."
Still more recently, using a different method for manipulating the polymers, Dr. Chu and his colleagues, Thomas Perkins and Douglas Smith, took virus DNA that was in a naturally coiled state and stretched it. They found that identical polymers beginning from the same state can uncoil in different ways, getting hung up in strange knots and bends -- behavior Dr. de Gennes called "molecular individualism."
This effect could be important in everything from the extrusion of plastics to the flow of oil in pipelines, where squirming, free-floating polymers reduce the drag when they are added to the oil -- improving the flow for reasons that are still poorly understood. And, noting that with every unraveling of the virus DNA polymers they used "you have the same virus and the same genes and very, very different outcomes," he said with a laugh, "So maybe you can take that as a moral in life -- that it's neither nature nor nurture."
"Polymer physicists were goo-goo, ga-ga over it," Dr. Chu said of the DNA work.
But the loudest applause came when Dr. Chu used laser light to chill atoms, so that they -- like the beads -- could be trapped. At room temperature this would be a hopeless task, because atoms are moving at thousands of miles per hour.
In 1985, Dr. Chu and his colleagues at Bell Labs cooled a cloud of atoms to 240 millionths of a degree above absolute zero with what he called "optical molasses." They did it by bathing the atoms in laser beams fired together from all directions, which created a kind of drag that slowed the atoms to inches per second, corresponding to the low temperature. That achievement finally allowed atoms to be laser-trapped.
"When I first heard about it, I said, 'That's incredible,' " recalled Dr. Kleppner of M.I.T. "And the next thing was, 'But of course; why not do that?' " The molasses analogy was a brilliant way of seeing through the immense technical challenges posed by the optical cooler, he said.
Dr. Chu shared the Nobel Prize with William Phillips of the National Institute of Standards and Technology and Claude Cohen-Tannoudji of the Ecole Normale Superieure in Paris. All three have made enormous contributions to the science of atom cooling and trapping. The traps have become standard equipment for creating the ultraprecise timepieces called atomic clocks. The techniques are also often a starting point for outlandish physics experiments, such as when scientists at the University of Colorado, Boulder, created a new state of ultracold matter called a Bose-Einstein condensate two years ago.
Like a juggler whose hands become ever more difficult to follow over the years, Dr. Chu has continued playing tricks with trapped atoms. In one experiment, for example, he and Mark Kasevich of Yale University used laser pulses to put atoms into "split personality" states predicted by quantum theory. Both states feel the tug of gravity as they move on slightly different trajectories. The degree to which those states are compatible when the split atoms recombine gives a measure of gravity's strength to about a part in a billion. That is fine enough to detect underground geological features, like oil pockets.
Dr. Chu has also continued the push into biology, partly in collaboration with Jim Spudich, chairman of the biochemistry department at Stanford. This aspect of Dr. Chu's work has become so well known that he was almost lured away by another university's fetching offer to co-direct a new cross-disciplinary institute. "I was tempted," he said.
He turned down the offer because of the difficult decisions the move would have entailed for his two sons, ages 13 and 16. Dr. Chu is divorced and shares in their care.
"Fundamentally, I'm happy here," he said in his office. "I'm very much against people trying to leverage themselves and their institutions. I don't want to see academics go into a state of free agency."
As high as his star has risen in the United States, it is nothing compared to his profile in Taiwan. His friend Yuan Lee -- yet another Nobel Prize-winning physicist -- now heads the Academica Sinica, of which Dr. Chu is a member. The combination of Dr. Chu's ties to Taiwan, his particular brand of charisma and a society that still lionizes scholars has led to hordes of cameras and reporters' shadowing him in public.
"One time he came back and said: 'Taiwan is crazy for me,' " Mr. Chin recalled. A Taiwanese professor joked that Dr. Chu's popularity was second only to Leonardo diCaprio's for a time. "DiCaprio is first by a whole lot," insisted Dr. Chu, who said that he speaks only basic Chinese with a heavy American accent.
Even the Dalai Lama found an opportunity to talk physics with him a few years ago. "He was obsessed with finding out what physics could say about time," Dr. Chu said. "I'm surmising why," he explained. "If you're a Buddhist, you believe in reincarnation, and there's this conservation-of-souls problem," referring to the question of where new souls come from as the number of living beings in the world keeps expanding.
In his moments with the Dalai Lama, the exiled leader of Tibet, who wore his maroon and saffron robes for the public conversation, Dr. Chu outlined the speculative theory that the universe is just one of many that are appearing and disappearing like bubbles in a champagne glass. (The theory is notably championed by another Stanford physicist, Andrei Linde.) That way, as vast amounts of time passed and whole universes became inhospitable to life, souls might flit from one universe to another and keep the total number constant, Dr. Chu suggested.
The Dalai Lama's reaction?
"He just listened," said Dr. Chu. "Juuuuust listened."

HEADLINE: Young Dancers Pounce Into Battle;
Sports Meets Art at an International Competition in Mississippi

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., June 27

 BODY:
It is a marvelous anomaly that many of the world's finest young ballet dancers spent the last two weeks performing in this otherwise somnolent capital city of some 200,000 people. Jackson, after all, can lay claim to some cultural sophistication as the home of Eudora Welty, but it is still small and rural enough that the lead newspaper article one recent day was about vandalism at a hog farm.
"There's some irony in a relatively obscure Southern town hosting this event," the Mayor, Harvey Johnson, acknowledged in an interview. And virtually everyone in town agreed it felt sort of odd to have the dancers here, though they have been to Jackson before. 
 The event was the sixth U.S.A. International Ballet Competition, which ended this weekend. Every four years or so since 1979, it has brought ballet coaches, company directors and choreographers from five continents here to view dancers they might not have a chance to see anywhere else.
Indeed, at a time when international competitions are proliferating around the world -- there are now about 15 of them, including the triennial one in New York, the sixth of which will occur in June 2000 -- Jackson's, astonishingly enough, may well be the best-attended, most fiercely contested of them all.
"This is now the world's premier competition," said Bruce Marks, artistic director emeritus of the Boston Ballet, implying that in ballet these days, even the competitions compete. Mr. Marks has a bias; he has served as chairman of the jury for the last three competitions in Jackson. But he isn't necessarily wrong. Past grand prix winners in Jackson have included Jose Manuel Carreno, the Cuban dancer who is now a principal at American Ballet Theater, and Andris Liepa, the former Bolshoi and Kirov star.
In any case, for many ballet companies, it is their best opportunity to fill openings. And for many dancers, in this country and overseas, it is their best opportunity to be seen, to assess their standing in the world of dance, perhaps to earn a little prize money and, most important, to find a job.
This year, 87 dancers from 26 countries (including New Zealand, Australia, Mongolia, Cuba and South Korea, as well as Eastern and Western Europe and South America), all selected from applications and videotapes, joined the competition. There were three rounds, with dancers eliminated after the first two. By round three, 37 dancers remained.
"It was important to me to get to the third round, so I would get to perform all the solos I prepared," said Lenaig Guegan, 22, a French dancer who is a member of the Royal Danish Ballet in Copenhagen, and was hoping, with her boyfriend and fellow dancer, Bernard Courtot de Bouteiller, 24, to attract the attention of other artistic directors. "We're a bit bored where we are," she said. He added, "If we could get a contract somewhere, that would be great."
It was a provocative thing, throughout the week, to hear the dancers routinely referred to as "competitors," to see the women's senior gold-medal winner, a 24-year-old Russian dancer, Anna Antonicheva, burst into tears like a beauty pageant winner at the announcement of her triumph, and to see Ms. Guegan so obviously despondent after winning a merit award but not one of the main prizes. She and Mr. Courtot were among many at the event who decried the idea of applying the numerical standards of sport to an art form, though everyone conceded that the audition was no less competitive in its way and that all performers needed a competitive spirit to match their expectations of themselves.
 
Competing, But With Whom?
"I don't believe that in dance you should compete for a title," said Elisabeth Carroll, a coach and former dancer with American Ballet Theater and the Joffrey and and Harkness Ballets. "You compete with the audience, and in that sense you have to win every night. The difference is you make your competitors happy. Here you want to make them sad."
Competitive events discourage the expression and feeling that are the main business of art, the argument goes, and encourage dancers to be sensational and superficial, to rely on the gravity-defying athletic leaps and diverse turns on toe that draw gasps from an audience -- "the flash and bash," in the words of the prominent dance coach David Howard -- but have little to do with the evocative grace of the art; jumping, after all, is not dancing.
"I've often wondered if we lived in outer space, would we be trying so hard to get to earth," Mr. Howard said. For the audience, too, a competition is an odd experience.
What was presented in Jackson was not a finished ballet performance, with its arcs of narrative and music and variety of choreographed passages. Rather, the evenings consisted of individual dancer after individual dancer (with the occasional pair thrown in), each offering a few minutes from the 19th-century classical repertory (solos from works like "Esmeralda," "Don Quixote" and "Paquita," and pas de deux from "Sleeping Beauty" and "Le Corsaire") and later, something contemporary.
They were bite-size ballet nuggets filled with leaps and turns, the dance equivalent of a football highlight film or an Olympic gymnastics event. And when Renata Pavam Maia, a 16-year-old from Brazil who would win a silver medal, danced the final round with a bandaged ankle, wincing through her performance and weeping as she took her bows, it seemed an echo of Kerri Strug.
At the same time, everyone acknowledges that the competitions are effective professional tools, clearinghouses where dancers' talents can be displayed, discussed and bartered. And for all their ambivalence, dancers do want to win, because with winning comes the imprimatur of supremacy.
All this puts an unusual burden on the judges, who must try to see beyond the flash and bash of each dancer in order to assess his or her artfulness. The 13 judges, all from different countries, awarded no grand prix this year.
"All that means is that we didn't think anyone was ready to leap onto the stage at the Metropolitan Opera at just this moment," Mr. Marks said. "We definitely saw the potential for that, though."
They did award some $60,000 in prizes and scholarships to 21 dancers, including Ms. Guegan (a merit award in the name of Robert Joffrey, the jury chairman of the first competition), Mr. Courtot (who won a silver medal) and Rasta Thomas, from Washington, who won the top prize in the senior men's division, though he is only 16. (The junior division was ostensibly for dancers 15 through 18; the senior, 19 through 26.)
Mr. Thomas, a principal with the Hartford Ballet, doesn't even want to be a dancer. A student of martial arts with aspirations to attend the Yale School of Drama, he exhibits a supernaturally flawless charm ("The pleasure is all mine" he is wont to say after a handshake), and he intends to be the next Hollywood action hero. "I want to inspire, I want to be a legend, I want to be President of the United States, I want to be so much," he said.
 
Begun With Energy And Fund-Raising
Major international competitions date back to 1964, when the first one was held in Varna, Bulgaria, and eventually expanded into a series of contests that rotated annually among Varna, Moscow and Tokyo. (When Tokyo withdrew in the early 1980's, it was replaced by Helsinki, Finland.)
It was in the mid-1970's that a well-known New York ballet teacher named Thalia Mara, who just turned 87, moved to Jackson to run the local ballet company. It was her fund-raising and energy, along with that of Joffrey and the dance critic Walter Terry, that brought the American version of the event here. The event pumps some $6 million into the city's economy, and it has remained here because Jacksonians volunteer by the hundreds, house dancers in their homes and generally treat the visitors with a hospitality that is downright, well, Southern.
Unlike the practice in other competitions, for instance, dancers eliminated in the early rounds are invited to stay, at no cost, to participate in classes and workshops, to attend all performances and to dance in a choreographed group performance at the closing gala.
"Everyone is so nice here," the foreign dancers said last week, again and again, often with noticeable incredulity. And some of them even liked the early-summer heat, which had stunned the city torpid. "It keeps my muscles warm, so that's good," said Anna Ivanova, who is the principal dancer at the Russian Ballet Theater of Delaware, in Wilmington. She was born in Siberia.
For admittedly sports-minded Jacksonians, the event was clearly an opportunity to mix the culture of the concert hall with the culture of the stadium. (White Jacksonians, anyway. In a city that is half black, the homogeneity of the crowd was striking.)
Night after night, they filled the 2,400-seat Thalia Mara Hall downtown, whooping for their favorites in mid-dance and launching "bravos" and "bravas" from the mezzanine. They even seemed to like the contemporary offerings of the dancers, though most of the professional dance observers found them, with a few exceptions (like Mr. Courtot's performance of his own choreography of "The Rite of Spring") poorly chosen at best, ponderous and pretentious at worst.
"We have a serious taste problem with the contemporary stuff," said Mr. Marks, adding that next time he might well have all the dancers prepare a piece selected in advance by the jury. For all the complaints, in the end, almost everyone found the event gratifying, with Ms. Ivanova giving a particularly measured assessment of her experience.
"The first round was kind of scary, but now I like it," she said after her final performance in round three. "It's different from dancing with a company. This is a little harder. You don't get a second chance to try again another night, with a different preparation. And you have more responsibility, because with a company you have their support. It's difficult for everyone to compete, but if you don't want to compete, you don't come."
She paused. This was before the results were announced, before learning she had not won a prize. "Of course, it matters if I win, but it's more important that I performed well, that I did my best," she said, realizing that at 25, she may have come too late to the joys of competing. "This is my first competition, and I'd like to come back. But now I'm too old."

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Rise to a Record

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
Sales of new homes rose in May to a record level, fueled by low interest rates and high consumer optimism.
New single-family home sales rose three-tenths of a percent in May, to an annual rate of 890,000 units, the Commerce Department said today, breaking the previous record set in April. Analysts had expected a drop in May sales to an annual rate of 877,000 units. 
 "It's so good that it's scary," said Robert Toll, chairman and chief executive at the luxury home builder Toll Brothers Inc. in Huntingdon Valley, Pa. "We're enjoying a fabulous market and I would expect it's going to continue as long as the economy is supportive." The housing strength has been defined by the longest stretch ever of new-home sales exceeding an 800,000-unit annual pace. May marked the ninth consecutive month the pace of sales was above that level. Sales of new one-family homes in the first quarter averaged 855,000 a month at an annual rate, a record and up 3.3 percent from the 828,000 average a month in the fourth quarter. New-home sales rose 15.7 percent in the West, to a 265,000 rate, in the Northeast new-home sales rose 3.3 percent, to a 94,000 rate, the highest since a similar pace in March 1997. In the South, they fell 6.7 percent, to a 390,000-unit annual rate, and in the Midwest they fell 4.1 percent, to a 142,000 rate.

HEADLINE: Rubin Defends I.M.F. Policies and Continues His Asian Tour

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 29

 BODY:
After a whirlwind visit to Malaysia, in which he defended the International Monetary Fund's harsh prescriptions for healing Asia's economies, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin arrived this evening in the place where the financial contagion began.
Mr. Rubin is to meet on Tuesday with Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai of Thailand and other officials to discuss their efforts to climb out of a recession, nearly one year to the day since Bangkok floated its currency, prompting a devastating devaluation from which it has yet to recover. 
 Mr. Rubin is touring Asia as the I.M.F. is under growing attack from politicians and business people here. They who say the fund's formula of high interest rates, rigorous fiscal policy and stable currencies is strangling the region's economies and worsening the pain of the crisis.
Today Mr. Rubin offered a measured endorsement of the policy. "I think, on balance, the I.M.F. has had it about right," he said at a news conference in Kuala Lumpur after meeting Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia. "I think if you loosen interest rates it runs the risk of eroding the currency."
Mr. Rubin said he had a "very good discussion" with Dr. Mahathir, although he would not divulge details. Dr. Mahathir has been a vituperative critic of the West, faulting currency traders and accusing the United States Government of trying to profit from the economic misery.
It was not clear that Mr. Rubin and Dr. Mahathir had a meeting of the minds. On the question of whether the United States should intervene in the market to support Malaysia's currency -- a measure that Dr. Mahathir has called for but that the United States has rebuffed -- Mr. Rubin said: "The views of the Prime Minister are well known. And I think our views are well known."
Still, Mr. Rubin's aides said that the tone of the meeting was constructive and that Dr. Mahathir did not make inflammatory remarks, which he has been known to do in the past.
Earlier today, Mr. Rubin met Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who made waves by disagreeing with Dr. Mahathir about whether Malaysia should lower its interest rates to jump-start its economy. Dr. Mahathir said the rates should be lowered. Mr. Anwar favored keeping them high enough to maintain the stability of the currency, the ringgit.
Speaking at a meeting today with Mr. Rubin, Mr. Anwar sounded more like his boss, declaring that interest rates were "prohibitively high" and that the financial crisis was putting a severe strain on Malaysian society.
The pain of the Asian crisis has reached even a prosperous neighbor, Singapore, which today announced a $1.2 billion package of measures to stimulate its sluggish economy. Acknowledging that its economy will grow far more slowly this year than it had forecasted, the Singaporean Government said it would increase public spending and offer tax rebates to businesses.
The social and political cost of the Asian crisis has been a recurring theme of Mr. Rubin's tour, which began on Friday in China and ends on Wednesday in South Korea. In a meeting with American executives in Kuala Kumpur, several people warned Mr. Rubin about Indonesia, which they said could easily slide into disarray in the wake of President Suharto's resignation.
"I think there is a discomfort in Indonesia that the U.S. and the West aren't taking Indonesia seriously," said Peter L. Woicke, managing director and chief executive of the Asia Pacific division of J. P. Morgan.
Although the economic crisis precipitated a change in governments here, Thailand has so far avoided the kind of social unrest that hit Indonesia or the political dissension that has afflicted Malaysia. Indeed, the United States has praised the Chuan Government for faithfully carrying out the I.M.F. plan, which it says has helped Thailand regain foreign investors' confidence.
By most yardsticks, though, the economy is in parlous shape. Exports are falling, unemployment is soaring, and economists say the country's output could shrink 5.5 percent this year. After a binge of borrowing from foreign banks in the boom, Thailand's bad debts may total up to $25 billion, equal to 20 percent of its gross domestic product.
Even Bangkok's notorious traffic jams have subsided, a barometer, residents say of how much commercial life has slowed.
Executives say the public's patience with I.M.F.-style solutions is wearing thin.
"The economy is deteriorating, with no end in sight," said James Stent, senior executive vice president of the Bank of Asia, Thailand's 11th largest bank. "It's time for emergency measures."
David Lipton, the Undersecretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said the I.M.F. had made sensible adjustments to take account of the worsening economy, allowing it, for example, to run a budget deficit instead of a surplus. Mr. Lipton said Mr. Rubin would urge the Government to continue reforming its banks, to strengthen its bankruptcy laws and to allow additional foreign investment.
But Mr. Stent said that as the crisis has dragged on, some people here are coming to believe that Thailand's political and financial institutions are not strong enough to tolerate the pressures of being fully open. "There's increasing skepticism," he said, "that opening up to foreign investment is a panacea."

HEADLINE: Fed Expected to Hold Back On a Rate Increase for Now

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
The most militant inflation fighters at the Federal Reserve will have plenty to fret about when the central bank meets Tuesday and Wednesday to consider whether to raise interest rates.
The economy grew at a sizzling 5.4 percent annual pace in the first quarter. The unemployment rate, at 4.3 percent, is the lowest since 1970. Consumer price inflation, while still low, is increasing, and the Clinton Administration's decision to help prop up the Japanese yen could ameliorate the inflation-fighting effects of the strong dollar, which has helped keep import prices down. 
 The strength in the stock market has left consumers feeling flush and confident. Just today the Commerce Department reported new-home sales in May hit a record.
Taken together, such signals of strong growth and rising inflation pressures might normally be enough to lead the Federal Reserve to nudge rates up. But they will almost certainly be overshadowed during the Fed meeting by a patient, pragmatic approach championed by Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman. After the meeting adjourns, the Fed is expected to announce it is holding interest rates steady, at least until its next meeting on Aug. 18, economists said.
At the heart of the pragmatists' argument is the belief that growth is already slowing toward a noninflationary rate because of the financial crisis in Asia and perhaps the strike that has nearly shut down General Motors. Moreover, raising rates now could further destabilize Asia and emerging economies from Russia to Brazil.
In any case, the American economy has exhibited a surprising ability for several years to grow at robust rates without setting off inflationary wage and price spirals. Mr. Greenspan himself even put aside the dour mien that has long been his trademark and a few weeks ago proclaimed the economy to be just about the best he had ever seen.
David Orr, the chief economist at First Union Corporation's capital markets group, said the economy was shifting from a Goldilocks stage -- neither too hot nor too cold -- into a Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde stage in which it exhibited contradictory characteristics.
Asia's crisis has had a substantial impact on farmers and manufacturers that export chemicals, electrical equipment, lumber and textiles, he said, helping to slow the overall economy's growth to 2 percent or less this spring and summer.
But at the same time, he said, consumer spending remains strong, incomes continue to grow and business investment in computers and other equipment remains heavy.
"I don't see Alan Greenspan raising rates unless the manufacturing sector shows some rebound, which I don't see happening this year," Mr. Orr said. "On the other hand, the fundamentals of private sector domestic demand are just so solid that demand is really exceeding supply in areas like housing, an awful lot of service and retail areas and commercial construction. So inflation is going up in those areas."
The result, Mr. Orr said, is to keep the Fed trapped between conflicting forces, with monetary policy on hold until inflation becomes a clear threat or the economy becomes so sluggish that it needs to be reinvigorated by a rate cut.
"Our bet is that the strength of underlying U.S. domestic demand prevails, and that by spring of next year, or something of that order, they do raise rates," Mr. Orr said. "But it's a close bet."
The best clues to how the Fed is handling the situation could come not in the expected terse announcement on Wednesday that the Federal Open Market Committee has left rates unchanged, but in the minutes, to be released on Thursday, of the committee's May 19 meeting.
At the previous meeting, on March 31, the Fed left rates unchanged but formally signaled that it expected the next move on interest rates to be upward -- in essence an early warning to the markets that if the expected slowdown in growth did not happen it would probably tighten policy.
The May 19 minutes will disclose whether that policy bias was left in place. It will provide a synopsis of the debate between the pragmatists on the committee and those members who see inflation as more of an immediate threat.
Foremost among the inflation hawks is Jerry L. Jordan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, who alone among the committee's 12 members voted to raise rates at the March 31 meeting.
Mr. Jordan's vote was based in part on his concern about the rapid growth in the money supply, a development that has a number of other Fed officials worried. Money supply growth has fallen out of favor in the last decade as a proxy for inflation pressures, but some economists are now arguing that the link has been at least partly re-established.
Economists said they would be closely watching Thursday's employment report, which will provide the clearest look yet at whether growth began slowing in earnest in June. Most economists expect a slight uptick in the unemployment rate, to 4.4 percent, and a slowdown in job creation, to a little more than 200,000 in June from 296,000 in May.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA;
Questions for the President: Give and Take With China's Students

 BODY:
Following are key sections from the question-and-answer part of President Clinton's appearance yesterday at Beijing University, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. Beijing University selected the students for the audience, allotting each academic department a set number. Their questions were translated by an interpreter.
Q. Mr. President, I'm very delighted to be -- very honored to be -- the first one to raise a question. Just as you mentioned in your address, Chinese and American people should join hands and move forward together. And what is most important in this process is for us to have more exchanges. In our view, since China is opening up in reform, we have had better understanding of the culture, history and literature of America. And we have also learned a lot about you from the biography, and we have also learned about a lot of American Presidents. And we have also seen the movie "Titanic." 
 But it seems that the American people's understanding of Chinese people is not as much as the other way around. Maybe they have only -- they are only seeing China -- through several movies describing the Cultural Revolution or rural life. So my question is: As the first President of the United States visiting China in 10 years, what do you plan to do to enhance the real understanding and the respect between our two peoples? Thank you.
A. First of all, I think that's a very good point. And one of the reasons that I came here was to try to -- because, as you can see, a few people come with me from the news media -- I hoped that my trip would help to show a full and balanced picture of modern China to the United States and that, by coming here, it would encourage others to come here and others to participate in the life of China.
I see a young man out in the audience who introduced himself to me yesterday as the first American ever to be a law student in China. So I hope we will have many more Americans coming here to study, many more Americans coming here to be tourists, many more Americans coming here to do business. The First Lady this morning and the Secretary of State had a meeting on a legal project. We're doing a lot of projects together with the Chinese to help promote the rule of law. That should bring a lot more people here.
I think there is no easy answer to your question. It's something we have to work at. We just need more people involved in more kinds of contacts. And I think the more we can do that, the better.
 
CHINA AND TAIWAN
 Q. Mr. President, as a Chinese, I'm very interested in the reunification of my motherland. Since 1972, progress has been made on the Taiwan question. But we have seen that the Americans have repeatedly been selling advanced weapons to Taiwan. And to our great indignation, we have seen that the United States and Japan have renewed the U.S.-Japan security treaty. And according to some Japanese officials, this treaty even includes the Taiwan province of China.
So I have to ask, if China were to send its inaudible missile to Hawaii and if China were to sign a security treaty with other countries against one part of United States, would the United States agree to such an act or would the American people agree to such an act?
A. First of all, United States policy is not an obstacle to the peaceful reunification of China and Taiwan. Our policy is embodied in three communiques and in the Taiwan Relations Act. Our country recognized China and embraced a one-China policy almost 20 years ago. And I reaffirmed our one-China policy to President Jiang in our meetings.
Now, when the United States and China reached agreement that we would have a one-China policy, we also reached agreement that the reunification would occur by peaceful means. And we have encouraged the cross-strait dialogue to achieve that.
Our policy is that any weapons sales, therefore, to Taiwan must be for defensive purposes only and that the country must not believe -- China must not believe that we are in any way trying to undermine our own one-China policy. It is our policy. But we do believe it should occur -- any reunification should occur peacefully.
Now, on Japan, if you read the security agreement we signed with Japan, I think it will be clear from its terms that the agreement is not directed against any country, but rather in support of stability in Asia. We have forces in South Korea that are designed to deter a resumption of the Korean War across the dividing line between the two Koreas.
Our forces in Japan are largely designed to help us to promote stability anywhere in the Asia-Pacific region on short notice. But I believe that it is not fair to say that either Japan or the United States have a security relationship that is designed to contain China. Indeed, what both countries want is a security partnership with China for the 21st century.
Just for example, you mentioned NATO. We have expanded NATO in Europe, but we also have made a treaty, an agreement, between NATO and Russia to prove that we are not against Russia anymore. And the most important thing NATO has done in the last five years is to work side by side with Russia to end the war in Bosnia.
And I predict to you that what you see us doing with China now, working together to try to limit the tension from the Indian and the Pakistani nuclear tests, you will see more and more and more of that in the future. And I think you will see a lot of security cooperation in that area. And we can't see the agreements of today through the mirror of yesterday's conflicts. . . .
 
HIDING BEHIND A SMILE?
 Q. Mr. President, I'm from the class of '97. I'm very glad to have this opportunity to ask you a question. With a friendly smile, you have set foot on the soil of China and you have come to the inaudible . So we are very excited and honored by your presence. What the Chinese people really aspire for is the friendship between China and the United States on the basis of equality.
And I know that before your departure from the States, you said that the reason for you to visit China is because China is too important and engagement is better than containment. I'd like to ask you whether this is a kind of commitment you made for your visit, or do you have any other hidden things behind this smile? Do you have any other design to contain China? . . .
A. If I did, I wouldn't mask it behind a smile. But I don't. That is, my words mean exactly what they say. We have to make a decision. All of us do, but especially the people who live in large nations with great influence must decide how to define their greatness.
When the Soviet Union went away, Russia had to decide how to define its greatness. Would they attempt to develop the human capacity of the Russian people and work in partnership with their neighbors for a greater future, or would they remember the bad things that happened to them in the past 20 years and think the only way they could be great would be to dominate their neighbors militarily? They chose a forward course. The world is a better place.
The same thing is true with China. You will have to decide, both in terms of your policies within your country and beyond, what does it mean that China will be a great power in the 21st century? Does it mean that you will have enormous economic success? Does it mean you will have enormous cultural influence? Does it mean that you will be able to play a large role in solving the problems of the world? Or does it mean you will be able to dominate your neighbors in some form or fashion, whether they like it or not?
This is the decision that every great country has to make. You ask me, do I really want to contain China? The answer is no. If you look at -- the American people have always had a very warm feeling toward China that has been interrupted from time to time when we have had problems. But if you go back through the history of our country, there's always been a feeling on the part of our people that we ought to be close to the Chinese people.
And I believe that it would be far better for the people of the United States to have a partnership on equal, respectful terms with China in the 21st century than to have to spend enormous amounts of time and money trying to contain China because we disagree with what's going on beyond our borders. I think it would -- so I do not want that.
I want a partnership. I'm not hiding another design behind a smile. That's what I really believe. I believe it, not because -- because I think it's good for the American people. And it's my job to do what's good for them. What's good for them is to have a good relationship with you. . . .
 
EDUCATION AND THE ECONOMY
Q. Several years ago you proposed the concept of a knowledge economy. So my first question is, what do you think of higher education -- what kind of role can this play in the future's knowledge economy? And the second question is, what expectations do you have, Mr. President, for the younger generation of our two countries?
A.Let me answer the knowledge economy question first. And let me answer by telling you what I have tried to do in the United States. I have tried to create a situation in America in which the doors of universities and colleges are open to every young person who has sufficient academic achievement to get in, that there are no financial burdens of any kind. And we have not completely achieved it, but we have made a great deal of progress.
Now, why would I do that? Because I believe that the more advanced an economy becomes, the more important it is to have a higher and higher and higher percentage of people with a university education. Let me just tell you how important it is in the United States. We count our people. You know, every 10 years we do a census and we count the numbers of the American people and we get all kinds of information on them.
In the 1990 census, younger Americans who had a college degree were overwhelmingly likely to get good jobs and have their incomes grow. Younger Americans who had two years or more of university were likely to get good jobs and have their incomes grow. Younger Americans who didn't go to university at all were likely to get jobs where their incomes declined and were much more likely to be unemployed.
And the more advanced China's economy becomes, the more that will be true of China, the more you will need very large numbers of people getting university education and technical education. So I think it is very, very important.
Now, let me say one expectation I have for the younger generation of Americans and Chinese that has nothing to do with economics. One of the biggest threats to your future is a world which is dominated not by modern problems but by ancient hatreds. Look around the world and see how much trouble is being caused by people who dislike each other because of their racial or their religious or their ethnic differences, whether it's in Bosnia or the conflict between the Indians and the Pakistanis or in the Middle East or the tribal conflicts in Africa. You look all over the world, you see these kind of problems.
Young people, I think, are naturally more open to others who are different, more interested in people who are different. And I hope young people in China and young people in America who have a good education will be a strong voice in the world against giving in to this sort of hating people or looking down on them simply because they're different.
Q. Mr. President, with regard to the question of democracy, human rights and freedom, actually this is an issue of great interest to both the Chinese and American peoples. But to the inaudible our two countries have some differences over these issues. In your address just now, you made a very proud review and retrospection of the history of America's democracy and of human rights. And you have also made some suggestions for China. Of course, those sincere suggestions we welcome. But I think I recall one saying; that is, we should have both criticism and self-criticism.
So now I'd like to ask you a question. Do you think in the United States today there are also some problems in the area of democracy, freedom and human rights, and what has your Government done to improve the situation?
A. I do. And first of all, let me say I never raise this question overseas in any country, not just China, without acknowledging first that our country has had terrible problems in this area -- keep in mind, slavery was legal in America for many years -- and that we are still not perfect. I always say that, because I don't think it's right for any person to claim that he or she lives in a perfect country. We're all struggling toward ideals to live a better life. So I agree with the general point you make.
Now, I will give you two examples. We still have some instances of discrimination in America in housing or employment or other areas based on race. And we have a system set up to deal with it, but we have not totally eliminated it. And in the last year, I have been engaging the American people in a conversation on this subject and we have tried to identify the things that Government should do, the things that the American people should do either through the local government or through other organizations, and the attitudes that should change the minds and hearts of the American people. That's one example.
Now, let me give you another example. We have -- when I ran for President in 1992, I was in a hotel in New York City and an American immigrant from Greece came up to me and he said, "My son is 10 years old, and he studies the election in the schools, and he says I should vote for you." But he said, "If I vote for you, I want you to make my son free, because my son is not really free."
So I asked this man, "What do you mean?" And he said, "Well, the crime is so high in my neighborhood -- there are so many guns and gangs -- that my son does not feel that -- I can't let him walk to school by himself or go across the street to play in the park. So if I vote for you, I want you to make my son free."
I think that's important, because, see, in America, we tend to view freedom as the freedom from government abuse or from government control. That is our heritage. Our founders came here to escape the monarchy in England. But sometimes freedom requires affirmative steps by government to give everyone an equal opportunity to have an education and make a decent living and to preserve a lawful environment.
So I've worked very hard to try to bring the crime rate down in America, and it's now lower than it has been at any time in 25 years, which means that more of our children are free. But the crime rate is still too high. There's still too much violence. So we Americans need to be sensitive not only to preserve the freedoms that we hold dear, but also to create an environment in which people can build a truly good and free life. . . .
 
THE NATURE OF FREEDOM
 Q. . . . I don't think individual freedom and collective freedom will contradict each other. For instance, in China the prosperous development of the nation is actually the free choice of our people, and it's also the result of their efforts.
So I think freedom, real freedom, should mean for the people to freely choose the way of life they like, and also to develop. And I also think that only those who can really respect the freedom of others can really say that they understand what freedom means. I don't know whether you agree with me or not.
A. No, I do agree with that. I think, first of all, if you believe in freedom, you have to respect the freedom of others to make another choice. And even societies that have rather radical views of individual freedom recognize limits on that freedom when it interferes with preserving other people's rights.
For example, there's one of our famous court cases which says we have freedom of speech, but no one should be free to shout the word "fire" in a crowded movie theater where there is no fire and cause people to stampede over each other. There's another famous court decision which says my freedom ends where the other person's nose begins, meaning that you can't -- you don't have the freedom to hit someone else.
So I agree with that. People have the freedom to choose, and you have to respect other people's freedoms. And they have the right to make decisions that are different from yours. And there will never be a time when our systems and our cultures and our choices will be completely identical. That's one of the things that makes life interesting. . . .
 
DEFICITS AND PROTESTS
 Q. Mr. President, I have two questions. The first question is: the U.S. economy has been growing for more than inaudible months. So I'd like to ask, apart from your personal contribution to the United States, what other factors do you think important for the success of the U.S. economy? Maybe they can serve as good reference for China.
The second question is, when President Jiang Zemin visited Harvard University last year, there were a lot of students outside the hall staging demonstrations. So I'd like to ask you, President, if today you are in Beijing University and if there were a lot of students outside protesting and demonstrating, what feeling would you have?
A. Well, first of all, on the United States economy, I believe that the principal role of Government policy since I've been President was to, first of all, get our big Government deficit -- we had a huge annual deficit in spending. We got that under control. We're about to have the first balanced budget in 30 years. That drove interest rates down and freed up a lot of money to be invested in creating jobs in the private sector.
Then the second thing we did was to expand trade a lot, so we began to sell a lot more around the world than we had before. And the third thing we did was to attempt to invest more in our people, in research, development, technology and education.
Now, in addition to that, however, a lot of the credit here goes to the American people themselves. We have a very sophisticated business community. They were investing money in new technologies and in new markets and in training people. We have an environment where it's quite easy for people to start a business.
And perhaps this is the area that might be most helpful to China. I know that my wife has done a lot of work around the world in villages trying to get credit to villagers so they could borrow money to start their own businesses, to try to take advantage of some skill they have. And we have seen this system work even in the poorest places in Africa and Latin America, where opportunity takes off. So we have tried to make it easy in America for people to start a business, to expand a business and to do business.
And then we have also tried very, very hard to get new opportunities into areas where there were none before. And all these things together, but especially -- I give most of the credit to the people of my country. After all, a person in my position, we're supposed to have correct policies so that we create a framework within which the American people then create the future. And I think that is basically what has happened.
Now, you asked me an interesting question. Actually, I have been demonstrated against quite a lot in the United States. I told President Jiang when he was there, I was glad they demonstrated against him so I didn't feel so lonely.
But what I think is -- let me just -- I'll give you a serious answer. If there were a lot of people demonstrating against me outside, suppose they were demonstrating over the question that the first gentleman asked me. Suppose they said, "Oh, President Clinton is trying to interfere with the peaceful reunification of China and Taiwan, and he shouldn't be selling them any weapons whatever."
Well, I would try to find out what they were demonstrating against, and then I would ask my hosts if they minded if I would go over and talk to them, or if they would mind if one or two people from the group of demonstrators could be brought to see me and they could say what is on their minds and I could answer.
Remember what I said before about what Benjamin Franklin said. "Our critics are our friends, for they show us our faults." You have asked me some very good questions today that have an element of criticism in them. They have been very helpful to me. They have helped me to understand how what I say is perceived by others, not just in China but around the world.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Wall St. Is Bolstered by Strengthened Overseas Trading

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
An end-of-quarter buying spree and lack of concern about coming economic reports pushed major stock market indexes higher yesterday.
Wall Street was also bolstered as stronger markets overseas, especially in Asia, eased some investors' concerns about the drag those economies could have on United States corporate profits. 
 Japan and most other Asian stock markets were higher, buoyed by news that a widely followed survey of Japanese business managers, known as the tankan, showed the businessmen were more optimistic than expected that business conditions in that country would improve within the next three months.
On the domestic economic front, however, Asia's current recession, left many investors confident that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to lift short-term interest rates at the end of its two-day policy-making session, which begins today. Investors also showed little concern, traders said, that the June employment report, due out Thursday, would rattle the stock market.
Although stocks finished higher yesterday, investor selling throughout the day pushed market indexes off the day's highs. The selling was evidence, analysts said, that while the near-term scenario appears rosy, a dose of skepticism remains about the outlook for corporate profits in the second half of the year.
After gaining more than 100 points, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 8,997.36, up 52.82 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.29 points, to 1,138.49, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 21.55 points, to 1,891.08.
"People are still concerned about Asia, but it's not a day-to-day thing," said Robert Basel, head of listed trading at Salomon Smith Barney.
Most investors' attention will be focused on second-quarter earnings reports in the next few weeks, he said. Over all, the feeling is that "now you'll get the good news" since most companies that anticipated an earnings decline have already warned of shortfalls, he said.
Analysts' forecasts compiled by the First Call Corporation, a Boston-based research firm, call for the earnings of companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 index to grow by about 3.6 percent in the second quarter.
Since those earnings numbers have been reduced from about 12 percent at the beginning of the year, most companies should meet or exceed those lowered forecasts, said George Jacobsen, chief investment officer at Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen Inc., a New York investment management firm.
But the worst from Asia is not over, Mr. Jacobsen cautioned, adding that as governments take steps to alleviate the region's banking crisis, a rise in imports could occur to put pressure on American companies' earnings prospects in the second half of this year.
"In the first quarter, corporate profits were viewed as being an industry specific problem," Mr. Jacobsen said.
"In the second quarter, we're calling it a short-term problem. But our take is there is a corporate profit problem and it is long term."
Charles W. Johnson, head equity trader at Blaylock & Partners in Baltimore, said: "It still will be very interesting to see how third-quarter profits will shape up. I'm one of those people that has to be shown that my way of thinking is flawed and I just don't believe this market is out of the woods."
In addition to Asia, Mr. Johnson said he is concerned that consumer spending, which has helped buoy the market, will falter later in the year.
Most stocks that have gained in recent days are issues that had been battered in previous weeks, such as Microsoft, Intel and Disney, said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. Companies Mr. Acuff calls consistent growers, or large-capitalization stocks that are leaders in their industries, such as Bristol-Myers Squibb, American International Group and Home Depot, have also done well, illustrating investors' concern about future economic and profit growth, he said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Treasuries Fall
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32 yesterday, to 106 29/32, as the dollar declined, and investors held off buying before the two-day Federal Reserve meeting. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.64 percent, from 5.63 percent Friday.

HEADLINE: Officials Are Drawing Closer in Effort to Sell Coliseum

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
City and state officials inched closer yesterday to the end of a 14-year effort to sell the New York Coliseum, one of the most valuable parcels of real estate in Manhattan, even as they failed once again to meet a self-imposed deadline.
Two developers -- Stephen M. Ross, who formed a joint venture with Time Warner Inc., and Millennium Partners -- have emerged in recent weeks as the leading contenders to buy the 3.4-acre parcel along Columbus Circle, opposite Central Park, and build a 2.1-million-square-foot complex. 
 But given the complicated history of the sale and the sometimes fierce rivalry between city and state officials, the final outcome is still uncertain. It is clear, however, that the Coliseum site will sell for at least $340 million, $175 million more than officials had expected in 1996, executives involved in the bidding said.
Executives from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Coliseum exhibition hall and an office tower on the parcel, and their real estate adviser, Benjamin V. Lambert, met yesterday with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to discuss final negotiations and a sales contract for the site. The Mayor has veto power over the project under a prior agreement with the M.T.A.
The M.T.A. had planned to select a winner at its board meeting today, but the agency's selection committee did not complete its analysis. E. Virgil Conway, the chairman of the M.T.A., is now expected to call a special meeting of the board within the next 10 days, or wait until the monthly board meeting in late July.
"Most people will welcome a resolution," said Ester R. Fuchs, director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy. "This project has been tossed and turned by competing levels of government and the volatility of the real estate market, which defies any kind of rational planning process. But I'd be surprised if we get an airtight sale with an outcome that'll make local residents happy."
The project already faces opposition from neighboring residents and the Committee for Environmentally Sound Development, a grass-roots group, which filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court challenging the development on environmental grounds. No matter who wins the bidding, the group says, the giantproject will worsen traffic congestion and air pollution in the area.
City and state officials have looked at a number of issues in assessing the bids -- including price, design and how the project would fit into the city's economic development -- though critics have complained that the cash-strapped M.T.A. has been concerned only with money. In the latest attempt to sell the site, the M.T.A. culled five finalists last year from a large group of bidders and sought assurances from developers that a sale would proceed despite any litigation. Millennium Partners, which would build 450 apartments, a ballroom and two luxury hotels on the site, has offered one of the strongest guarantees.
But the development group, led by Christopher M. Jeffries, has not been lucky. The M.T.A. was on the verge of selling the site to Millennium a year ago when Mayor Giuliani suddenly upended the process, vowing to block the project unless the development included a theater or performance space. The subsequent delay wreaked havoc on some of the developers' plans, but the real estate market continued to improve, as did the offers for the site. Oddly enough, Mr. Jeffries had been in negotiations with Jazz at Lincoln Center to build a music center at a different location.
In February, the city completed a deal to incorporate a concert hall and home for Jazz at Lincoln Center into any new development at the site. The finalists then resubmitted their bids on April 30 with plans for the 100,000-square-foot jazz complex, which developers said would cost them $40 million to $50 million to build.
Mr. Ross, the chairman of the development concern The Related Companies, has the one element missing from the other proposals: a blue-chip tenant. He is proposing to build a world headquarters for Time Warner, and the largest digital-television production studio in the city. Time Warner would install both the New York 1 cable news channel and the New York operations of CNN at the 100,000-square-foot studio. The complex would also include a luxury Mandarin Oriental hotel, 325 condominiums and a large block of retail space.
Donald J. Trump, who was ready to drop out of the process in January, ultimately submitted the highest bid, about $370 million, but his bulky design is considered the weakest, according to officials who have scrutinized the competing offers. The other bidders are clustered between $330 million and $345 million.
One city official said yesterday that the situation was somewhat fluid and that not even Mr. Trump could be counted out. Tishman Speyer Properties has proposed a mixed-use complex, and a team composed of the developers Daniel Brodsky, Bruce C. Ratner and Peter M. Lehrer has planned for a 700-room Westin hotel, apartments and a Sears department store.

HEADLINE: Whitman in Deal to Raise Gas Tax 4 cents

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 29

 BODY:
Overcoming opposition from some Republican lawmakers reluctant to raise taxes, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reached agreement with legislative leaders today to increase the state's gasoline tax gradually -- 4 cents a gallon over three years -- to help pay for transportation projects around the state.
The tax increase is 3 cents less a gallon than what Governor Whitman proposed in May. Two of those cents would have gone toward preserving a million acres of farmland and open space, nearly half the undeveloped land left in the state. But lawmakers are now considering another proposal to ask voters whether they would support a plan to borrow $1 billion over 30 years for preserving open space. The other proposed 1-cent increase would have been spent on transportation projects. 
 Motorists would not see the full impact of the 4-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax at the pumps all at once. Under the plan, the gasoline tax would rise by a penny next year, 2 cents the following year and 1 cent more in the year 2001. The increase would be contingent on voters' approval of a referendum in November, which would ask them whether they supported a gasoline tax increase and whether they approved dedicating all motor vehicle tax revenues to transportation projects.
"I believe that this is the right thing to do," said the Assembly Speaker, Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County. "I am sure that this will be a bipartisan effort."
The agreement on the gasoline tax increase came as both the Assembly and the Senate gave final approval to a new $18.2 billion state budget for the new fiscal year beginning July 1. The budget raises spending by almost $1 billion over this year for public schools, state colleges and a handful of other programs. And it puts $661 million aside for the state's rainy day fund.
With the gasoline tax increase, the Whitman administration expects to spend $200 million more on transportation projects in the next two years than had been budgeted. The increase would allow the state to pay the higher borrowing costs for expanding the state's Transportation Trust Fund, the system used to finance highway and mass transit projects. Administration officials said spending would rise to $900 million from $700 million in 1999 and 2000. It would increase to $950 million annually in the following three years.
After lawmakers rejected the 2-cent-a-gallon increase for open space preservation, Governor Whitman continued to push for a 5-cent-a-gallon increase for transportation projects. But lawmakers, particularly Republican members of the General Assembly who face re-election next year, balked at raising taxes while the state's economic boom was pouring extra revenues into the state's coffers.
Although the plan will produce about $400 million less in estimated new revenues from the gasoline tax than what the administration first proposed, her aides said that the 4-cent-a-gallon increase, phased in over three years, would meet the administration's goals for transportation.
"It works," said Pete McDonough, chief spokesman for Governor Whitman. "We can get a program large enough to meet the needs of the state."
Mr. Collins said the Legislature would return in late July to consider the gasoline tax increase. At the end of three years, it would raise state taxes on gasoline to 18.5 cents a gallon from 14.5 cents. Mr. Collins also said the Legislature would consider two other bills, asking voters to dedicate motor vehicle tax revenues for transportation projects and support the 30-year borrowing plan to preserve a million acres of farmland and other open space.
The state budget, which Governor Whitman is expected to sign into law on Tuesday, was approved by the Legislature with bipartisan support for the first time in almost a decade. Democrats were able to share some of the budget surplus with their Republican colleagues for various projects in their legislative districts. The total spending for legislative projects was $60 million.
But some Democrats voted against the budget because of language that the Whitman administration had quietly inserted that would establish a state-appointed fiscal review board to oversee the city of Camden's finances. The city is looking for a $15 million bailout from the state to balance its books, and the administration insists the money would only be allocated if a state-run financial review board is in place.
Milton Milan, the Mayor of Camden, said that he would welcome the state's playing an active role in overseeing the city's finances, but he opposed the Governor's plan that allows her to appoint all seven members of the newly created financial review board. State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Democrat from Camden, said that the Whitman administration was overstepping its authority under the state constitution. "The administration is violating the trust of Camden residents and undermining the good-faith efforts of Camden officials to restore fiscal order to New Jersey's poorest city," he said.
